Then they were walking up to the door and Mommy had come down to the porch to meet them and he (Jack) stood on the second step and watched them kiss. They were glad to see each other. Love came out of them the way love had come out of the boy and girl walking up the street and holding hands. Danny was glad. The bag of groceries -- just a bag of groceries -- crackled in his (Danny) arms. Everything was all right. Daddy was home. Mommy was loving him (Danny). There were no bad things. And not everything Tony showed him (Tony) always happened. But fear had settled around his (Tony) heart, deep and dreadful, around his (Tony) heart and around that indecipherable word he (Tony) had seen in his (Tony) spirit's mirror.

<< 5 >> PHONEBOOTH Jack parked the VW in front of the Rexall in the Table Mesa shopping center and let the engine die. He (Jack) wondered again if he (Jack) shouldn't go ahead and get the fuel pump replaced, and told himself again that they couldn't afford it. If the little car could keep running until November, it could retire with full honors

anyway. By November the snow up there in the mountains would be higher than the beetle's roof ... maybe higher than three beetles stacked on top of each other.

``Want you to stay in the car, doc. I'll bring you a candy bar.'' (unknown)
``Why can't I come in?'' (unknown)
``I have to make a phone call. It's private stuff.'' (unknown)
``Is that why you didn't make it at home?'' (unknown)
``Check.'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy had insisted on a phone in spite of their unraveling finances. She (Wendy) had argued that with a small child -- especially a boy like Danny, who sometimes suffered from fainting spells -- they couldn't afford not to have one. So Jack had forked over the thirty-dollar installation fee, bad enough, and a ninety-dollar security deposit, which really hurt. And so far the phone had been mute except for two wrong numbers.
``Can I have a Baby Ruth, Daddy?'' (unknown)
``Yes. You sit still and don't play with the gearshift, right?'' (unknown)
``Right. I'll look at the maps.'' (unknown)
``You do that.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
As Jack got out, Danny opened the bug's glovebox and took out the five battered gas station maps: Colorado, Nebraska, Utah, Wyoming, New Mexico. He (Danny) loved road maps, loved to trace where the roads went with his (Danny) finger. As far as he (Danny) was concerned, new maps were the best part of moving West. Jack went to the drugstore counter, got Danny's candy bar, and newspaper, and a copy of the October Writer's Digest. He (Writer) gave the girl a five and asked for his (Writer) change in quarters. With the silver in his (Writer) hand he (Writer) walked over to the telephone booth by the keymaking machine and slipped inside. From here he (Writer) could see Danny in the bug through three sets of glass. The boy's head was bent studiously over his (Writer) maps. Jack felt a wave of nearly desperate love for the boy. The emotion showed on his (Jack) face as a stony grimness. He (Jack) supposed he (Jack) could have made his (Jack) obligatory thank-you call to Al from home; he (Jack) certainly wasn't going to say anything Wendy would object to. It was his (Jack) pride that said no. These days he (Jack) almost always listened to what his (Jack) pride told him (Jack) to do, because along with his (Jack) wife and son, six hundred dollars in a checking account, and one weary 1968 Volkswagen, his (Jack) pride was all that was left. The only thing that was his (Jack). Even the checking account was joint. A year ago he (Jack) had been teaching English in one of the finest prep schools in New England. There had been friends -- although not exactly the same ones he (Jack)'d had before going on the wagon -- some laughs, fellow faculty members who admired his (Jack) deft touch in the classroom and his (Jack) private dedication to writing. Things had been very good six months ago. All at once there was enough money left over at the end of each two-week pay period to start a little savings account. In his (Jack) drinking days there had never been a penny left over, even though Al Shockley had stood a great many of the rounds. He (Shockley) and Wendy had begun to talk cautiously about finding a house and making a down payment in a year or so. A farmhouse in the country, take six or eight years to renovate it completely, what the hell, they were young, they had time. Then he (Shockley) had lost his (Shockley) temper. George Hatfield.

The smell of hope had turned to the smell of old leather in Crommert's office, the whole thing like some scene from his (Shockley) own play: the old prints of previous Stovington headmasters on the walls, steel engravings of the school as it had been in 1879, when it was first built, and in 1895, when Vanderbilt money had enabled them to build the field house that still stood at the west end of the soccer field, squat, immense, dressed in ivy. April ivy had been rustling outside Crommert's slit window and the drowsy sound of steam heat came from the radiator. It was no set, he (Shockley) remembered thinking. It was real. His (Shockley) life. How could he (Shockley) have fucked it up so badly?

``This is a serious situation, Jack. Terribly serious. The Board has asked me to convey its decision to you.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
The Board wanted lack's resignation and Jack had given it to them. Under different circumstances, he (Jack) would have gotten tenure that June. What had followed that interview in Crommert's office had been the darkest, most dreadful night of his (Jack) life. The wanting, the needing to get drunk had never been so bad. His (Jack) hands shook. He (Jack) knocked things over. And he (Jack) kept wanting to take it out on Wendy and Danny. His (Danny) temper was like a vicious animal on a frayed leash. He (Danny) had left the house in terror that he (Danny) might strike them. Had ended up outside a bar, and the only thing that had kept him (Danny) from going in was the knowledge that if he (Danny) did, Wendy would leave him (Danny) at last, and take Danny with her (Wendy). He (Danny) would be dead from the day they left. Instead of going into the bar, where dark shadows sat sampling the tasty waters of oblivion, he (Danny) had gone to Al Shockley's house. The Board's vote had been six to one. Al had been the one. Now he (Al) dialed the operator and she (Wendy) told him (Al) that for a dollar eighty-five he (Al) could be put in touch with Al two thousand miles away for three minutes. Time is relative, baby, he (Al) thought, and stuck in eight quarters. Faintly he (Al) could hear the electronic boops and beeps of his (Al) connection sniffing its way eastward. Al's father had been Arthur Longley Shockley, the steel baron. He (Shockley) had left his (Shockley) only son, Albert, a fortune and a huge range of investments and directorships and chairs on various boards. One of these had been on the Board of Directors for Stovington Preparatory Academy, the old man's favorite charity. Both Arthur and Albert Shockley were alumni and Al lived in Barre, close enough to take a personal interest in the school's affairs. For several years Al had been Stovington's tennis coach. Jack and Al had become friends in a completely natural and uncoincidental way: at the many school and faculty functions they attended together, they were always the two drunkest people there. Shockley was separated from his (Shockley) wife, and Jack's own marriage was skidding slowly downhill, although he (Shockley) still loved Wendy and had promised sincerely -LRB-and frequently-RRB- to reform, for her (Wendy) sake and for baby Danny's. The two of them went on from many faculty parties, hitting the bars until they closed, then stopping at some mom 'n' pop-RRB- store for a case of beer they would drink parked at the end of some back road. There were mornings when Jack would stumble into their leased house with dawn seeping into the sky and find Wendy and the baby asleep on the couch, Danny always on the inside, a tiny fist curled under the shelf of Wendy's jaw. He (Danny) would look at them and the self-loathing would back up his (Danny) throat in a bitter wave, even stronger than the taste of beer

and cigarettes and martinis -- martians, as Al called them. Those were the times that his (Al) mind would turn thoughtfully and sanely to the gun or the rope or the razor blade. If the bender had occurred on a weeknight, he (Al) would sleep for three hours, get up, dress, chew four Excedrins, and go off to teach his (Al) nine o'clock American Poets still drunk. Good morning, kids, today the Red-Eyed Wonder is going to tell you about how Longfellow lost his (Al) wife in the big fire. He (Al) hadn't believed he (Al) was an alcoholic, Jack thought as Al's telephone began ringing in his (Al) ear. The classes he (Al) had missed or taught unshaven, still reeking of last night's martians. Not me, I can stop anytime. The nights he (Al) and Wendy had passed in separate beds. Listen, I'm fine. Mashed fenders. Sure I'm okay to drive. The tears she (Wendy) always shed in the bathroom. Cautious looks from his (Al) colleagues at any party where alcohol was served, even wine. The slowly dawning realization that he (Al) was being talked about. The knowledge that he (Al) was producing nothing at his (Al) Underwood but balls of mostly blank paper that ended up in the wastebasket. He (Al) had been something of a catch for Stovington, a slowly blooming American writer perhaps, and certainly a man well qualified to teach that great mystery, creative writing. He (man) had published two dozen short stories. He (man) was working on a play, and thought there might be a novel incubating in some mental back room. But now he (man) was not producing and his (man) teaching had become erratic. It had finally ended one night less than a month after Jack had broken his (Jack) son's arm. That, it seemed to him (Jack), had ended his (Jack) marriage. All that remained was for Wendy to gather her (Wendy) will ... if her (Wendy) mother hadn't been such a grade A bitch, he (Jack) knew, Wendy would have taken a bus back to New Hampshire as soon as Danny had been okay to travel. It was over. It had been a little past midnight. Jack and Al were coming into Barre on U.S. 31, Al behind the wheel of his (Al) Jag, shifting fancily on the curves, sometimes crossing the double yellow line. They were both very drunk; the martians had landed that night in force. They came around the last curve before the bridge at seventy, and there was a kid's bike in the road, and then the sharp, hurt squealing as rubber shredded from the Jag's tires, and Jack remembered seeing Al's face looming over the steering wheel like a round white moon. Then the jingling crashing sound as they hit the bike at forty, and it had flown up like a bent and twisted bird, the handlebars striking the windshield, and then it was in the air again, leaving the starred safety glass in front of Jack's bulging eyes. A moment later he (Jack) heard the final dreadful smash as it landed on the road behind them. Something thumped underneath them as the tires passed over it. The Jag drifted around broadside, Al still jockeying the wheel, and from far away Jack heard himself saying:

``Jesus, Al.. We ran him (Jesus) down. I felt it.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
In his (Jack) ear the phone kept ringing. Come on, Al.. Be home. Let me get this over with. Al had brought the car to a smoking halt not more than three feet from a bridge stanchion. Two of the Jag's tires were flat. They had left zigzagging loops of burned rubber for a hundred and thirty feet. They looked at each other for a moment and then ran back in the cold darkness. The bike was completely ruined. One wheel was gone, and looking back over his (Al) shoulder Al had seen it lying in the middle of the road, half a dozen spokes sticking up like piano wire. Al had said hesitantly: ``I think that's what we ran

over, Tacky-boy.'' ``Then where's the kid?'' ``Did you see a kid?'' Jack frowned. It had all happened with such crazy speed. Coming around the corner. The bike looming in the Jag's headlights. Al yelling something. Then the collision and the long skid. They moved the bike to one shoulder of the road. Al went back to the Jag and put on its four-way flashers. For the next two hours they searched the sides of the road, using a powerful four-cell flashlight. Nothing. Although it was late, several cars passed the beached Jaguar and the two men with the bobbing flashlight. None of them stopped. Jack thought later that some queer providence, bent on giving them both a last chance, had kept the cops away, had kept any of the passersby from calling them. At quarter past two they returned to the Jag, sober but queasy. ``If there was nobody riding it, what was it doing in the middle of the road?'' Al demanded. ``It wasn't parked on the side; it was right in the fucking middle!'' Jack could only shake his (Jack) head. ``Your party does not answer,'' the operator said. ``Would you like me to keep on trying?'' ``A couple more rings, operator. Do you mind?'' ``No, sir,'' the voice said dutifully. Come on, Al! Al had hiked across the bridge to the nearest pay phone, called a bachelor friend and told him (Al) it would be worth fifty dollars if the friend would get the Jag's snow tires out of the garage and bring them down to the Highway 31 bridge outside of Barre. The friend showed up twenty minutes later, wearing a pair of jeans and his (friend) pajama top. He (friend) surveyed the scene. ``Kill anybody?'' he (friend) asked. Al was already jacking up the back of the car and Jack was loosening lug nuts. ``Providentially, no one,'' Al said. ``I think I'll just head on back anyway. Pay me in the morning.'' ``Fine,'' Al said without looking up. The two of them had gotten the tires on without incident, and together they drove back to Al Shockley's house. Al put the Jag in the garage and killed the motor. In the dark quiet he (Al) said:

``I'm off drinking, Jacky-boy. It's all over. I've slain my last martian.'' (unknown)
And now, sweating in this phonebooth, it occurred to Jack that he (Jack) had never doubted Al's ability to carry through. He (Al) had driven back to his (Al) own house in the VW with the radio turned up, and some disco group chanted over and over again, talismanic in the house before dawn: Do it anyway ... you wanta do it . . . do it anyway you want ... No matter how loud he (Al) heard the squealing tires, the crash. When he (Al) blinked his (Al) eyes shut, he (Al) saw that single crushed wheel with its broken spokes pointing at the sky. When he (Al) got in, Wendy was asleep on the couch. He (Al) looked in Danny's room and Danny was in his (Danny) crib on his (Danny) back, sleeping deeply, his (Danny) arm still buried in the cast. In the softly filtered glow from the streetlight outside he (Danny) could see the dark lines on its plastered whiteness where all the doctors and nurses in

pediatrics had signed it. It was an accident. He (Danny) fell down the stairs. -LRB-o you dirty liar-RRB- It was an accident. l lost my temper. -LRB-you fucking drunken waste god wiped snot out of his (god) nose and that was you-RRB- Listen, hey, come on, please, just an accident -- But the last plea was driven away by the image of that bobbing flashlight as they hunted through the dry late November weeds, looking for the sprawled body that by all good rights should have been there, waiting for the police. It didn't matter that Al had been driving. There had been other nights when he (Al) had been driving. He (Al) pulled the covers up over Danny, went into their bedroom, and took the Spanish Llama .38 down from the top shelf of the closet. It was in a shoe box. He (Danny) sat on the bed with it for nearly an hour, looking at it, fascinated by its deadly shine. It was dawn when he (Danny) put it back in the box and put the box back in the closet. That morning he (Danny) had called Bruckner, the department head, and told him (Danny) to please post his (Danny) classes. He (Danny) had the flu. Bruckner agreed, with less good grace than was common. Jack Torrance had been extremely susceptible to the flu in the last year. Wendy made him (Torrance) scrambled eggs and coffee. They ate in silence. The only sound came from the back yard, where Danny was gleefully running his (Danny) trucks across the sand pile with his (Danny) good hand. She (Wendy) went to do the dishes. Her (Wendy) back to him (Danny), she (Wendy) said:

``Jack. I've been thinking.'' (she)
``Have you?'' (He)
He (Danny) lit a cigarette with trembling hands. No hangover this morning, oddly enough. Only the shakes. He (Danny) blinked. In the instant's darkness the bike flew up against the windshield, starring the glass. The tires shrieked. The flashlight bobbed.
``I want to talk to you about ... about what's best for me and Danny. For you too, maybe. I don't know. We should have talked about it before, I guess.'' (unknown)
``Would you do something for me?'' (he)
he (Danny) asked, looking at the wavering tip of his (Danny) cigarette.
``Would you do me a favor?'' (unknown)
``What?'' (unknown)
Her (Wendy) voice was dull and neutral. He (Danny) looked at her (Wendy) back. ``Let's talk about it a week from today. If you still want to.., Now she (me) turned to him (Danny), her (me) hands lacy with suds, her (me) pretty face pale and disillusioned. ``Jack, promises don't work with you. You just go right on with -- '' She (Wendy) stopped, looking in his (Danny) eyes, fascinated, suddenly uncertain. ``In a week,'' he (Danny) said. His (Danny) voice had lost all its strength and dropped to a whisper. ``Please. I'm not promising anything. If you still want to talk then, we'll talk. About anything you want.'' They looked across the sunny kitchen at each other for a long time, and when she (Wendy) turned back to the dishes without saying anything more, he (Danny) began to shudder. God, he (God) needed a drink. Just a little pick-me-up to put things in their true perspective -- ``Danny said he (Danny) dreamed you had a car accident,'' she (Wendy) said abruptly.
``He (Danny) has funny dreams sometimes. He (Danny) said it this morning, when I got him (Danny) dressed. Did you, Jack? Did you have an accident?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)
By noon the craving for a drink had become a low-grade fever. He (God) went to Al's.
``You dry?'' (Al/Uncle Al)
Al asked before letting him (Al) in. Al looked horrible.
``Bone dry. You look like Lon Chaney in Phantom of the Opera.'' (unknown)
``Come on in.'' (unknown)
They played two-handed whist all afternoon. They didn't drink. A week passed. He (Al) and Wendy didn't speak much. But he (Al) knew she (Wendy) was watching, not believing. He (Al) drank coffee black and endless cans of Coca-Cola. One night he (Al) drank a whole six-pack of Coke and then ran into the bathroom and vomited it up. The level of the bottles in the liquor cabinet did not go down. After his (Al) classes he (Al) went over to Al Shockley's-she (Wendy) hated Al Shockley worse than she (Wendy) had ever hated anyone-and when he (Shockley) came home she (Wendy) would swear she (Wendy) smelled scotch or gin on his (Shockley) breath, but he (Shockley) would talk lucidly to her (Wendy) before supper, drink coffee, play with Danny after supper, sharing a Coke with him (Danny), read him (Danny) a bedtime story, then sit and correct themes with cup after cup of black coffee by his (Danny) hand, and she (Wendy) would have to admit to herself that she (Wendy) had been wrong. Weeks passed and the unspoken word retreated further from the back of her (Wendy) lips. Jack sensed its retirement but knew it would never retire completely. Things began to get a little easier. Then George Hatfield. He (Hatfield) had lost his (Hatfield) temper again, this time stone sober.

He (Al) hung up, closed his (Al) eyes in the hot booth, and again saw the crashing bike, the bobbing flashlight. There had been a squib in the paper the next day, no more than a space-filler really, but the owner had not been named. Why it had been out there in the night would always be a mystery to them, and perhaps that was as it should be. He (owner) went back out to the car and gave Danny his (Danny) slightly melted Baby Ruth.

Jack gave his (Jack) son a faint, troubled glance; and then his (Jack) mind turned to his (Jack) play.

<< 6 >> NIGHT THOUGHTS Love was over, and her (Ruth) man was sleeping beside her (Ruth). Her (Ruth) man. She (Ruth) smiled a little in the darkness, his (man) seed still trickling with slow warmth from between her (Ruth) slightly parted thighs, and her (Ruth) smile was both rueful and pleased, because the phrase her (Ruth) man summoned up a hundred feelings. Each feeling examined alone was a bewilderment. Together, in this darkness floating to sleep, they were like a distant blues tune heard in an almost deserted night club, melancholy but pleasing. Lovin' you baby, is just like rollin' off a log, But if I can't be your woman, I sure ain't goin' to be your dog. Had that been Billie Holiday? Or someone more prosaic like Peggy Lee? Didn't matter. It was low and torchy, and in the silence of her (Peggy) head it played mellowly, as if issuing from one of those old-fashioned jukeboxes, a Wurlitzer, perhaps, half an hour before closing. Now, moving away from her (Peggy) consciousness, she (Peggy) wondered how many beds she (Peggy) had slept in with this man beside her (Peggy). They had met in college and had first made love in his (man) apartment ... that had been less than three months after her (Peggy) mother drove her (Peggy) from the house, told her (Peggy) never to come back, that if she (Peggy) wanted to go somewhere she (Peggy) could go to her (Peggy) father since she (Peggy) had been responsible for the divorce. That bad been in 1970. So long ago? A semester later they had moved

in together, had found jobs for the summer, and had kept the apartment when their senior year began. She (Peggy) remembered that bed the most clearly, a big double that sagged in the middle. When they made love, the rusty box spring had counted the beats. That fall she (Peggy) had finally managed to break from her (Peggy) mother. Jack had helped her (Peggy). She (Peggy) wants to keep beating you, Jack had said. The more times you phone her (Peggy), the more times you crawl back begging forgiveness, the more she (Peggy) can beat you with your father. It's good for her (Peggy), Wendy, because she (Wendy) can go on making believe it was your fault. But it's not good for you. They had talked it over again and again in that bed, that year. -LRB-Jack sitting up with the covers pooled around his (Jack) waist, a cigarette burning between his (Jack) fingers, looking her (Wendy) in the eye -- he (Jack) had a half-humorous, halfscowling way of doing that -- telling her (Wendy): She (Wendy) told you never to come back, right? Never to darken her (Wendy) door again, right? Then why doesn't she (Wendy) hang up the phone when she (Wendy) knows it's you? Why does she (Wendy) only tell you that you can't come in if I'm with you? Because she (Wendy) thinks I might cramp her (Wendy) style a little bit. She (Wendy) wants to keep putting the thumbscrews right to you, baby. You're a fool if you keep letting her (Wendy) do it. She (Wendy) told you never to come back, so why don't you take her (Wendy) at her (Wendy) word? Give it a rest. And at last she (Wendy)'d seen it his (fool) way.-RRB- It had been Jack's idea to separate for a while -- to get perspective on the relationship, he (Jack) said. She (Wendy) had been afraid he (Jack) had become interested in someone else. Later she (Wendy) found it wasn't so. They were together again in the spring and he (Jack) asked her (Wendy) if she (Wendy) had been to see her (Wendy) father. She (Wendy) had jumped as if he (Jack)'d struck her (Wendy) with a quirt. How did you know that? The Shadow knows. Have you been spying on me? And his (Jack) impatient laughter, which had always made her (Wendy) feel so awkward -- as if she (Wendy) were eight and he (Jack) was able to see her (Wendy) motivations more clearly than she (Wendy). You needed time, Wendy. For what? I guess ... to see which one of us you wanted to marry. Jack, what are you saying? I think I'm proposing marriage. The wedding. Her (Wendy) father had been there, her (Wendy) mother had not been. She (Wendy) discovered she (Wendy) could live with that, if she (Wendy) had Jack. Then Danny had come, her (Wendy) fine son. That had been the best year, the best bed. After Danny was born, Jack had gotten her (Wendy) a job typing for half a dozen English Department profs -- quizzes, exams, class syllabi, study notes, reading lists. She (Wendy) ended up tvping a novel for one of them, a novel that never got published ... much to Jack's very irreverent and very private glee. The job was good for forty a week, and skyrocketed all the way up to sixty during the two months she (Wendy) spent typing the unsuccessful novel. They had their first car, a five-year-old Buick with a baby seat in the middle. Bright, upwardly mobile young marrieds. Danny forced a reconciliation between her (Wendy) and her (Wendy) mother, a reconciliation that was always tense and never happy, but a reconciliation all the same. When she (Wendy) took Danny to the house, she (Wendy) went without Jack. And she (Wendy) didn't tell Jack that her (Wendy) mother always remade Danny's diapers, frowned over his (Danny) formula, could always spot the

accusatory first signs of a rash on the baby's bottom or privates. Her (Wendy) mother never said anything overtly, but the message came through anyway: the price she (Wendy) had begun to pay -LRB-and maybe always would-RRB- for the reconciliation was the feeling that she (Wendy) was an inadequate mother. It was her (Wendy) mother's way of keeping the thumbscrews handy. During the days Wendy would stay home and housewife, feeding Danny his (Danny) bottles in the sunwashed kitchen of the four-room second-story apartment, playing her (housewife) records on the battered portable stereo she (housewife) had had since high school. Jack would come home at three -LRB-or at two if he (Jack) felt he (Jack) could cut his (Jack) last class-RRB-, and while Danny slept he (Danny) would lead her (housewife) into the bedroom and fears of inadequacy would be erased. At night while she (housewife) typed, he (Danny) would do his (Danny) writing and his (Danny) assignments. In those days she (housewife) sometimes came out of the bedroom where the typewriter was to find both of them asleep on the studio couch, Jack wearing nothing but his (Jack) underpants, Danny sprawled comfortably on her (housewife) husband's chest with his (Danny) thumb in his (Danny) mouth. She (housewife) would put Danny in his (Danny) crib, then read whatever Jack had written that night before waking him (Jack) up enough to come to bed. The best bed, the best year. Sun gonna shine in my backyard someday ... In those days, Jack's drinking had still been well in hand. On Saturday nights a bunch of his (Jack) fellow students would drop over and there would be a case of beer and discussions in which she (housewife) seldom took part because her (housewife) field had been sociology and his (Jack) was English: arguments over whether Pepys's diaries were literature or history; discussions of Charles Olson's poetry; sometimes the reading of works in progress. Those and a hundred others. No, a thousand. She (housewife) felt no real urge to take part; it was enough to sit in her (housewife) rocking chair beside Jack, who sat cross-legged on the floor, one hand holding a beer, the other gently cupping her (housewife) calf or braceleting her (housewife) ankle. The competition at UNH had been fierce, and Jack carried an extra burden in his (Jack) writing. He (Jack) put in at least an hour at it every night. It was his (Jack) routine. The Saturday sessions were necessary therapy. They let something out of him (Jack) that might otherwise have swelled and swelled until he (Jack) burst. At the end of his (Jack) grad work he (Jack) had landed the job at Stovington, mostly on the strength of his (Jack) stories -- four of them published at that time, one of them in Esquire. She (housewife) remembered that day clearly enough; it would take more than three years to forget it. She (housewife) had almost thrown the envelope away, thinking it was a subscription offer. Opening it, she (housewife) had found instead that it was a letter saying that Esquire would like to use Jack's story

``Concerning the Black Holes'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
early the following year. They would pay nine hundred dollars, not on publication but on acceptance. That was nearly half a year's take typing papers and she (housewife) had flown to the telephone, leaving Danny in his (Danny) high chair to goggle comically after her (housewife), his (Danny) face lathered with creamed peas and beef puree. Jack had arrived from the university forty-five minutes later, the Buick weighted down with seven friends and a keg of beer. After a ceremonial toast -LRB-Wendy also had a glass, although she (Wendy) ordinarily had no taste for beer-RRB-, Jack had signed the acceptance letter, put it in the return envelope, and went down

the block to drop it in the letter box. When he (Jack) came back he (Jack) stood gravely in the door and said,

``Veni, vidi, vici.'' (he)
There were cheers and applause. When the keg was empty at eleven that night, Jack and the only two others who were still ambulatory went on to hit a few bars. She (Wendy) had gotten him (Jack) aside in the downstairs hallway. The other two were already out in the car, drunkenly singing the New Hampshire fight song. Jack was down on one knee, owlishly fumbling with the lacings of his (Jack) moccasins.
``Jack,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said,
``you shouldn't. You can't even tie your shoes, let alone drive.'' (she)
He (Jack) stood up and put his (Jack) hands calmly on her (Wendy) shoulders.
``Tonight I could fly to the moon if I wanted to.'' (unknown)
``No,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said.
``Not for all the Esquire stories in the world.'' (unknown)
``I'll be home early.'' (he)
But he (Jack) hadn't been home until four in the morning, stumbling and mumbling his (Jack) way up the stairs, waking Danny up when he (Jack) came in. He (Jack) had tried to soothe the baby and dropped him (Jack) on the floor. Wendy had rushed out, thinking of what her (Wendy) mother would think if she (Wendy) saw the bruise before she (Wendy) thought of anything else -- God help her (Wendy), God help them both -- and then picked Danny up, sat in the rocking chair with him (Danny), soothed him (Danny). She (Wendy) had been thinking of her (Wendy) mother for most of the five hours Jack had been gone, her (Wendy) mother's prophecy that Jack would never come to anything. Big ideas, her (Wendy) mother had said. Sure. The welfare lines are full of educated fools with big ideas. Did the Esquire story make her (Wendy) mother wrong or right? Winnifred, you're not holding that baby right. Give him (Jack) to me. And was she (Winnifred) not holding her (Winnifred) husband right? Why else would he (husband) take his (husband) joy out of the house? A helpless kind of terror had risen up in her (Winnifred) and it never occurred to her (Winnifred) that he (husband) had gone out for reasons that had nothing to do with her (Winnifred).

she (Winnifred) said, rocking Danny -- he (Danny) was almost asleep again.

``It's just a bruise.'' (He)
He (Danny) sounded sulky, wanting to be repentant: a little boy. For an instant she (Winnifred) hated him (Danny).

she (Winnifred) said tightly.

She (Winnifred) heard so much of her (Winnifred) mother talking to her (Winnifred) departed father in her (Winnifred) own voice that she (Winnifred) was sickened and afraid.

he (Jack) repeated sullenly, and then went into the bedroom. She (Winnifred) was left alone in the rocking chair with Danny, who was sleeping again. Five minutes later Jack's snores came floating out to the living room. That had been the first night she (Winnifred) had slept on the couch. Now she (Winnifred) turned restlessly on the bed, already dozing. Her (Winnifred) mind, freed of any linear order by encroaching sleep, floated past the first year at Stovington, past the steadily worsening times that had reached low ebb when her (Winnifred) husband had broken Danny's arm, to that morning in the breakfast nook. Danny outside playing trucks in the sandpile, his (Danny) arm still in the cast. Jack sitting at the table, pallid and grizzled, a cigarette jittering between his (Jack)

fingers. She (Winnifred) had decided to ask him (Jack) for a divorce. She (Winnifred) had pondered the question from a hundred different angles, had been pondering it in fact for the six months before the broken arm. She (Winnifred) told herself she (Winnifred) would have made the decision long ago if it hadn't been for Danny, but not even that was necessarily true. She (Winnifred) dreamed on the long nights when Jack was out, and her (Winnifred) dreams were always of her (Winnifred) mother's face and of her (Winnifred) own wedding. -LRB-Who giveth this woman? Her (Winnifred) father standing in his (father) best suit which was none too good -- he (father) was a traveling salesman for a line of canned goods that even then was going broke -- and his (father) tired face, how old he (father) looked, how pale: I do.-RRB- Even after the accident -- if you could call it an accident -- she (Winnifred) had not been able to bring it all the way out, to admit that her (Winnifred) marriage was a lopsided defeat. She (Winnifred) had waited, dumbly hoping that a miracle would occur and Jack would see what was happening, not only to him (Jack) but to her (Winnifred). But there had been no slowdown. A drink before going off to the Academy. Two or three beers with lunch at the Stovington House. Three or four martinis before dinner. Five or six more while grading papers. The weekends were worse. The nights out with Al Shockley were worse still. She (Winnifred) had never dreamed there could be so much pain in a life when there was nothing physically wrong. She (Winnifred) hurt all the time. How much of it was her (Winnifred) fault? That question haunted her (Winnifred). She (Winnifred) felt like her (Winnifred) mother. Like her (Winnifred) father. Sometimes, when she (Winnifred) felt like herself she (Winnifred) wondered what it would be like for Danny, and she (Winnifred) dreaded the day when he (Danny) grew old enough to lay blame. And she (Winnifred) wondered where they would go. She (Winnifred) had no doubt her (Winnifred) mother would take her (Winnifred) in, and no doubt that after a year of watching her (Winnifred) diapers remade, Danny's meals recooked and/or redistributed, of coming home to find his (Danny) clothes changed or his (Danny) hair cut or the books her (Winnifred) mother found unsuitable spirited away to some limbo in the attic ... after half a year of that, she (Winnifred) would have a complete nervous breakdown. And her (Winnifred) mother would pat her (Winnifred) hand and say comfortingly, Although it's not your fault, it's all your own fault. You were never ready. You showed your true colors when you came between your father and me. My father, Danny's father. Mine, his (Danny). -LRB-Who giveth this woman? I do. Dead of a heart attack six months later.-RRB- The night before that morning she (woman) had lain awake almost until he (Danny) came in, thinking, coming to her (woman) decision. The divorce was necessary, she (woman) told herself. Her (woman) mother and father didn't belong in the decision. Neither did her (woman) feelings of guilt over their marriage nor her (woman) feelings of inadequacy over her (woman) own. It was necessary for her (woman) son's sake, and for herself, if she (woman) was to salvage anything at all from her (woman) early adulthood. The handwriting on the wall was brutal but clear. Her (woman) husband was a lush. He (husband) had a bad temper, one he (husband) could no longer keep wholly under control now that he (husband) was drinking so heavily and his (husband) writing was going so badly. Accidentally or not accidentally, he (husband) had broken Danny's arm. He (Danny) was going to lose his (Danny) job, if not this year then the year after. Already she (woman) had noticed the sympathetic looks from the other faculty wives. She (woman) told herself that she (woman) had stuck with the messy job of her (woman) marriage for as long as she (woman) could. Now she (woman) would have to leave it. Jack could have full visitation rights, and she (woman) would want support from him (Jack) only until she (woman) could find something and get on her (woman) feet -- and that would have to be fairly rapidly because she (woman) didn't know how long Jack would be able to pay support money. She (woman) would do it with as little bitterness as possible. But it had

to end. So thinking, she (woman) had fallen off into her (woman) own thin and unrestful sleep, haunted by the faces of her (woman) own mother and father. You're nothing but a home-wrecker, her (woman) mother said. Who giveth this, woman? the minister said. I do, her (mother) father said. But in the bright and sunny morning she (mother) felt the same. Her (mother) back to him (father), her (mother) hands plunged in warm dishwater up to the wrists, she (mother) had commenced with the unpleasantness.

``I want to talk to you about something that might be best for Danny and I. For you too, maybe. We should have talked about it before, I guess.'' (he)
And then he (father) had said an odd thing. She (mother) had expected to discover his (father) anger, to provoke the bitterness, the recriminations. She (mother) had expected a mad dash for the liquor cabinet. But not this soft, almost toneless reply that was so unlike him (father). It was almost as though the Jack she (mother) had lived with for six years had never come back last night -- as if he (Jack) had been replaced by some unearthly doppelganger that she (mother) would never know or be quite sure of.
``Would you do something for me? A favor?'' (unknown)
``What?'' (She)
She (mother) had to discipline her (mother) voice strictly to keep it from trembling.
``Let's talk about it in a week. If you still want to'' (she)
And she (mother) had agreed. It remained unspoken between them. During that week he (Jack) had seen Al Shockley more than ever, but he (Jack) came home early and there was no liquor on his (Jack) breath. She (mother) imagined she (mother) smelled it, but knew it wasn't so. Another week. And another. Divorce went back to committee, unvoted on. What had happened? She (mother) still wondered and still had not the slightest idea. The subject was taboo between them. He (Jack) was like a man who had leaned around a corner and had seen an unexpected monster lying in wait, crouching among the dried bones of its old kills. The liquor remained in the cabinet, but he (Jack) didn't touch it. She (mother) had considered throwing them out a dozen times but in the end always backed away from the idea, as if some unknown charm would be broken by the act. And there was Danny's part in it to consider. If she (mother) felt she (mother) didn't know her (mother) husband, then she (mother) was in awe of her (mother) child -- awe in the strict meaning of that word: a kind of undefined superstitious dread. Dozing lightly, the image of the instant of his (husband) birth was presented to her (mother). She (mother) was again lying on the delivery table, bathed in sweat, her (mother) hair in strings, her (mother) feet splayed out in the stirrups -LRB-and a little high from the gas they kept giving her (mother) whiffs of; at one point she (mother) had muttered that she (mother) felt like an advertisement for gang rape, and the nurse, an old bird who had assisted at the births of enough children to populate a high school, found that extremely funny-RRB- the doctor between her (mother) legs, the nurse off to one side, arranging instruments and humming. The sharp, glassy pains had been coming at steadily shortening intervals, and several times she (mother) had screamed in spite of her (mother) shame. Then the doctor told her (mother) quite sternly that she (mother) must PUSH, and she (mother) did, and then she (mother) felt something being taken from her (mother). It was a clear and distinct feeling, one she (mother) would never forget-the thing taken. Then the doctor held her (mother) son up by the legs-she had seen his (doctor) tiny sex and known he (doctor) was a boy immediatelyand as the doctor groped for the airmask, she (mother) had seen something else, something

so horrible that she (mother) found the strength to scream again after she (mother) had thought all screams were used up: He (doctor) has no face! But of course there had been a face, Danny's own sweet face, and the caul that had covered it at birth now resided in a small jar which she (mother) had kept, almost shamefully. She (mother) did not hold with old superstition, but she (mother) had kept the caul nevertheless. She (mother) did not hold with wives' tales, but the boy had been unusual from the first. She (mother) did not believe in second sight but -- Did Daddy have an accident? I dreamed Daddy had an accident. Something had changed him (boy). She (mother) didn't believe it was just her (mother) getting ready to ask for a divorce that had done it. Something had happened before that morning. Something that had happened while she (mother) slept uneasily. Al Shockley said that nothing had happened, nothing at all, but he (Shockley) had averted his (Shockley) eyes when he (Shockley) said it, and if you believed faculty gossip, Al had also climbed aboard the fabled wagon. Did Daddy have an accident? Maybe a chance collision with fate, surely nothing much more concrete. She (mother) had read that day's paper and the next day's with a closer eye than usual, but she (mother) saw nothing she (mother) could connect with Jack. God help her (mother), she (mother) had been looking for a hit-and-run accident or a barroom brawl that had resulted in serious injuries or ... who knew? Who wanted to? But no policeman came to call, either to ask questions or with a warrant empowering him (policeman) to take paint scrapings from the WV's bumpers. Nothing. Only her (mother) husband's one hundred and eighty degree change and her (mother) son's sleepy question on waking: Did Daddy have an accident? I dreamed ... She (mother) had stuck with Jack more for Danny's sake than she (mother) would admit in her (mother) waking hours, but now, sleeping lightly, she (mother) could admit it: Danny had been Jack's for the asking, almost from the first. Just as she (mother) had been her (mother) father's, almost from the first. She (mother) couldn't remember Danny ever spitting a bottle back on Jack's shirt. Jack could get him (Jack) to eat after she (mother) had given up in disgust, even when Danny was teething and it gave him (Danny) visible pain to chew. When Danny had a stomachache, she (mother) would rock him (Danny) for an hour before he (Danny) began to quiet; Jack had only to pick him (Jack) up, walk twice around the room with him (Jack), and Danny would be asleep on lack's shoulder, his (Danny) thumb securely corked in his (Danny) mouth. He (Danny) hadn't minded changing diapers, even those he (Danny) called the special deliveries. He (Danny) sat with Danny for hours on end, bouncing him (Danny) on his (Danny) lap, playing finger games with him (Danny), making faces at him (Danny) while Danny poked at his (Danny) nose and then collapsed with the giggles. He (Danny) made formulas and administered them faultlessly, getting up every last burp afterward. He (Danny) would take Danny with him (Danny) in the car to get the paper or a bottle of milk or nails at the hardware store even when their son was still an infant. He (son) had taken Danny to a StovingtonKeene soccer match when Danny was only six months old, and Danny had sat motionlessly on his (Danny) father's lap through the whole game, wrapped in a blanket, a small Stovington pennant clutched in one chubby fist. He (Danny) loved his (Danny) mother but he (Danny) was his (Danny) father's boy. And hadn't she (mother) felt, time and time again, her (mother) son's wordless opposition to the whole idea of divorce? She (mother) would be thinking about it in the kitchen, turning it over in her (mother) mind as she (mother) turned the potatoes for supper over in her (mother) hands for the

peeler's blade. And she (mother) would turn around to see him (son) sitting cross-legged in a kitchen chair, looking at her (mother) with eyes that seemed both frightened and accusatory. Walking with him (son) in the park, he (son) would suddenly seize both her (mother) hands and say -- almost demand:

``Do you love me? Do you love daddy?'' (he)
And, confused, she (mother) would nod or say,
``Of course I do, honey.'' (she)
Then he (son) would run to the duck pond, sending them squawking and scared to the other end, flapping their wings in a panic before the small ferocity of his (son) charge, leaving her (mother) to stare after him (son) and wonder. There were even times when it seemed that her (mother) determination to at least discuss the matter with Jack dissolved, not out of her (mother) own weakness, but under the determination of her (mother) son's will. I don't believe such things. But in sleep she (mother) did believe them, and in sleep, with her (mother) husband's seed still drying on her (mother) thighs, she (mother) felt that the three of them had been permanently welded together -- that if their three/oneness was to be destroyed, it would not be destroyed by any of them but from outside. Most of what she (mother) believed centered around her (mother) love for Jack. She (mother) had never stopped loving him (Jack), except maybe for that dark period immediately following Danny's
``accident.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
And she (mother) loved her (mother) son. Most of all she (mother) loved them together, walking or riding or only sitting, Jack's large head and Danny's small one poised alertly over the fans of old maid hands, sharing a bottle of Coke, looking at the funnies. She (maid) loved having them with her (maid), and she (maid) hoped to dear God that this hotel caretaking job Al had gotten for Jack would be the beginning of good times again. And the wind gonna rise up, baby, and blow my blues away ... Soft and sweet and mellow, the song came back and lingered, following her (maid) down into a deeper sleep where thought ceased and the faces that came in dreams went unremembered.

<< 7 >> IN ANOTHER BEDROOM Danny awoke with the booming still loud in his (Danny) ears, and the drunk, savagely pettish voice crying hoarsely: Come out here and take your medicine! I'll find you! I'll find youl But now the booming was only his (Danny) racing heart, and the only voice in the night was the faraway sound of a police siren. He (Danny) lay in bed motionlessly, looking up at the wind-stirred shadows of the

leaves on his (Danny) bedroom ceiling. They twined sinuously together, making shapes like the vines and creepers in a jungle, like patterns woven into the nap of a thick carpet. He (Danny) was clad in Doctor Denton pajamas, but between the pajama suit and his (Danny) skin he (Danny) had grown a more closely fitting singlet of perspiration.

``Tony?'' (he)
he (Danny) whispered.
``You there?'' (unknown)
No answer. He (Danny) slipped out of bed and padded silently across to the window and looked out on Arapahoe Street, now still and silent. It was two in the morning. There was nothing out there but empty sidewalks drifted with fallen leaves, parked cars, and the long-necked streetlight on the corner across from the Cliff Brice gas station. With its hooded top and motionless stance, the streetlight looked like a monster in a space show. He (Brice) looked up the street both ways, straining his (Brice) eyes for Tony's slight, beckoning form, but there was no one there. The wind sighed through the trees, and the fallen leaves rattled up the deserted walks and around the hubcaps of parked cars. It was a faint and sorrowful sound, and the boy thought that he (boy) might be the only one in Boulder awake enough to hear it. The only human being, at least. There was no way of knowing what else might be out in the night, slinking hungrily through the shadows, watching and scenting the breeze. I'll find you! I'll find you!
``Tony?'' (he)
he (boy) whispered again, but without much hope. Only the wind spoke back, gusting more strongly this time, scattering leaves across the sloping roof below his (boy) window. Some of them slipped into the raingutter and came to rest there like tired dancers. Danny ... Danneee ... He (Danny) started at the sound of that familiar voice and craned out the window, his (Danny) small hands on the sill. With the sound of Tony's voice the whole night seemed to have come silently and secretly alive, whispering even when the wind quieted again and the leaves were still and the shadows had stopped moving. He (Tony) thought he (Tony) saw a darker shadow standing by the bus stop a block down, but it was hard to tell if it was a real thing or an eye-trick. Don't go, Danny . . Then the wind gusted again, making him (Danny) squint, and the shadow by the bus stop was gone ... if it had ever been there at all. He (Danny) stood by his (Danny) window for -LRB-a minute? an hour?-RRB- some time longer, but there was no more. At last he (Danny) crept back into his (Danny) bed and pulled the blankets up and watched the shadows thrown by the alien streetlight turn into a sinuous jungle filled with flesh-eating plants that wanted only to slip around him (Danny), squeeze the life out of him (Danny), and drag him (Danny) down into a blackness where one sinister word flashed in red: REDRUM.

PART TWO -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- Closing Day -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- --

<< 8 >> A VIEW OF THE OVERLOOK Mommy was worried. She (Danny) was afraid the bug wouldn't make it up and down all these mountains and that they would get stranded by the side of the road where somebody might come ripping along and hit them. Danny himself was more sanguine; if Daddy thought the bug would make this one last trip, then probably it would.

``We're just about there,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said. Wendy brushed her (Wendy) hair back from her (Wendy) temples.
``Thank God.'' (She)
She (Wendy) was sitting in the right-hand bucket, a Victoria Holt paperback open but face down in her (Wendy) lap. She (Wendy) was wearing her (Wendy) blue dress, the one Danny thought was her (Wendy) prettiest. It had a sailor collar and made her (Wendy) look very young, like a girl just getting ready to graduate from high school. Daddy kept putting his (Danny) hand high up on her (Wendy) leg and she (Wendy) kept laughing and brushing it off, saying Get away, fly. Danny was impressed with the mountains. One day Daddy had taken them up in the ones near Boulder, the ones they called the Flatirons, but these were much bigger, and on the tallest of them you could see a fine dusting of snow, which Daddy said was often there year-round. And they were actually in the mountains, no goofing around. Sheer rock faces rose all around them, so high you could barely see their tops even by craning your neck out the window. When they left Boulder, the temperature had been in the high seventies. Now, just after noon, the air up here felt crisp and cold like November back in Vermont and Daddy had the heater going ... not that it worked all that well. They had passed several signs that said FALLING ROCK ZONE -LRB-Mommy read each one to him (they)-RRB-, and although Danny had waited anxiously to see some rock fall, none had. At least not yet. Half an hour ago they had passed another sign that Daddy said was very important. This sign said ENTERING SIDEWINDER PASS, and Daddy said that sign was

as far as the snowplows went in the wintertime. After that the road got too steep. In the winter the road was closed from the little town of Sidewinder, which they had gone through just before they got to that sign, all the way to Buckland, Utah. Now they were passing another sign.

``What's that one, Mom?'' (unknown)
``That one says SLOWER VEHICLES USE RIGHT LANE. That means us.'' (unknown)
``The bug will make it,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said.
``Please, God,'' (Mommy)
Mommy said, and crossed her (Mommy) fingers. Danny looked down at her (Mommy) open-toed sandals and saw that she (Mommy) had crossed her (Mommy) toes as well. He (Danny) giggled. She (Mommy) smiled back, but he (Danny) knew that she (Mommy) was still worried. The road wound up and up in a series of slow S curves, and Jack dropped the bug's stick shift from fourth gear to third, then into second. The bug wheezed and protested, and Wendy's eye fixed on the speedometer needle, which sank from forty to thirty to twenty, where it hovered reluctantly.
``The fuel pump...'' (she)
she (Wendy) began timidly.
``The fuel pump will go another three miles,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said shortly. The rock wall fell away on their right, disclosing a slash valley that seemed to go down forever, lined a dark green with Rocky Mountain pine and spruce. The pines fell away to gray cliffs of rock that dropped for hundreds of feet before smoothing out. She (Wendy) saw a waterfall spilling over one of them, the early afternoon sun sparkling in it like a golden fish snared in a blue net. They were beautiful mountains but they were hard. She (Wendy) did not think they would forgive many mistakes. An unhappy foreboding rose in her (Wendy) throat. Further west in the Sierra Nevada the Donner Party had become snowbound and had resorted to cannibalism to stay alive. The mountains did not forgive many mistakes. With a punch of the clutch and a jerk, Jack shifted down to first gear and they labored upward, the bug's engine thumping gamely.
``You know,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said,
``I don't think we've seen five cars since we came through Sidewinder. And one of them was the hotel limousine.'' (she)
Jack nodded.
``It goes right to Stapleton Airport in Denver. There's already some icy patches up beyond the hotel, Watson says, and they're forecasting more snow for tomorrow up higher. Anybody going through the mountains now wants to be on one of the main roads, just in case. That goddam Ullman better still be up there. I guess he (Ullman) will be.'' (unknown)
``You're sure the larder is fully stocked?'' (she)
she (Wendy) asked, still thinking of the Donners.
``He (Ullman) said so. He (Ullman) wanted Hallorann to go over it with you. Hallorann's the cook.'' (unknown)
``Oh,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said faintly, looking at the speedometer. It had dropped from fifteen to ten miles an hour.
``There's the top,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said, pointing three hundred yards ahead.
``There's a scenic turnout and you can see the Overlook from there. I'm going to pull off the road and give the bug a chance to rest.'' (He)
He (Jack) craned over his (Jack) shoulder at Danny, who was sitting on a pile of blankets.
``What do you think, doc? We might see some deer. Or caribou.'' (unknown)
``Sure, Dad.'' (VW)
The VW labored up and up. The speedometer dropped to just above the five-mile-

an-hour hashmark and was beginning to hitch when Jack pulled off the road -LRB-

``What's that sign, Mommy?'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
``SCENIC TURNOUT,'' (she)
she (Wendy) read dutifully.-RRB- and stepped on the emergency brake and let the VW run in neutral.
``Come on,'' (he)
he (Jack) said, and got out. They walked to the guardrail together.
``That's it,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said, and pointed at eleven o'clock. For Wendy, it was discovering truth in a cliché: her (Wendy) breath was taken away. For a moment she (Wendy) was unable to breathe at all; the view had knocked the wind from her (Wendy). They were standing near the top of one peak. Across from them -- who knew how far? -- an even taller mountain reared into the sky, its jagged tip only a silhouette that was now nimbused by the sun, which was beginning its decline. The whole valley floor was spread out below them, the slopes that they had climbed in the laboring bug falling away with such dizzying suddenness that she (Wendy) knew to look down there for too long would bring on nausea and eventual vomiting. The imagination seemed to spring to full life in the clear air, beyond the rein of reason, and to look was to helplessly see one's self plunging down and down and down, sky and slopes changing places in slow cartwheels, the scream drifting from your mouth like a lazy balloon as your hair and your dress billowed out ... She (Wendy) jerked her (Wendy) gaze away from the drop almost by force and followed Jack's finger. She (Wendy) could see the highway clinging to the side of this cathedral spire, switching back on itself but always tending northwest, still climbing but at a more gentle angle. Further up, seemingly set directly into the slope itself, she (Wendy) saw the grimly clinging pines give way to a wide square of green lawn and standing in the middle of it, overlooking all this, the hotel. The Overlook. Seeing it, she (Wendy) found breath and voice again.
``Oh, Jack, it's gorgeous!'' (unknown)
``Yes, it is,'' (he)
he (Jack) said.
``Ullman says he (Ullman) thinks it's the single most beautiful location in America. I don't care much for him (Ullman), but I think he (Ullman) might be ... Danny! Danny, are you all right?'' (She)
She (Wendy) looked around for him (Jack) and her (Wendy) sudden fear for him (Jack) blotted out everything else, stupendous or not. She (Wendy) darted toward him (Jack). He (Jack) was holding onto the guardrail and looking up at the hotel, his (Jack) face a pasty gray color. His (Jack) eyes had the blank look of someone on the verge of fainting. She (Wendy) knelt beside him (Jack) and put steadying hands on his (Jack) shoulders.
``Danny, what's -- '' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack was beside her (Wendy).
``You okay, doc?'' (He)
He (Jack) gave Danny a brisk little shake and his (Danny) eyes cleared.
``I'm okay, Daddy. I'm fine.'' (unknown)
``What was it, Danny?'' (she)
she (Wendy) asked.
``Were you dizzy, honey?'' (unknown)
``No, I was just ... thinking. I'm sorry. I didn't mean to scare you.'' (He)
He (Danny) looked at his (Danny) parents, kneeling in front of him (Danny), and offered them a small puzzled smile.
``Maybe it was the sun. The sun got in my eyes.'' (unknown)
``We'll get you up to the hotel and give you a drink of water,'' (Daddy)
Daddy said.
``Okay.'' (he)
And in the bug, which moved upward more surely on the gentler grade, he (Daddy) kept looking out between them as the road unwound, affording occasional glimpses of the Overlook Hotel, its massive bank of westward-looking windows reflecting

back the sun. It was the place he (Daddy) had seen in the midst of the blizzard, the dark and booming place where some hideously familiar figure sought him (Daddy) down long corridors carpeted with jungle. The place Tony had warned him (Tony) against. It was here. It was here. Whatever Redrum was, it was here.

<< 9 >> CHECKING IT OUT Ullman was waiting for them just inside the wide, old-fashioned front doors. He (Ullman) shook hands with Jack and nodded coolly at Wendy, perhaps noticing the way heads turned when she (Wendy) came through into the lobby, her (Wendy) golden hair spilling across the shoulders of the simple navy dress. The hem of the dress stopped a modest two inches above the knee, but you didn't have to see more to know they were good legs. Ullman seemed truly warm toward Danny only, but Wendy had experienced that before. Danny seemed to be a child for people who ordinarily held W. C. Fields' sentiments about children. He (Danny) bent a little from the waist and offered Danny his (Danny) hand. Danny shook it formally, without a smile.

``My son Danny,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``And my wife Winnifred.'' (unknown)
``I'm happy to meet you both,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said.
``How old are you, Danny?'' (unknown)
``Five, sir.'' (unknown)
``Sir, yet.'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman smiled and glanced at Jack.
``He (Danny)'s well mannered.'' (unknown)
``Of course he (Danny) is,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``And Mrs. Torrance.'' (He)
He (Jack) offered the same little bow, and for a bemused instant Wendy thought he (Jack) would kiss her (Wendy) hand. She (Wendy) half-offered it and he (Jack) did take it, but only for a moment, clasped in both of his (Jack). His (Jack) hands were small and dry and smooth, and she (Wendy) guessed that he (Jack) powdered them. The lobby was a bustle of activity. Almost every one of the old-fashioned high-backed chairs was taken. Bellboys shuttled in and out with suitcases and there was a line at the desk, which was dominated by a huge brass cash register. The BankAmericard and Master Charge decals on it seemed jarringly anachronistic. To their right, down toward a pair of tall double doors that were pulled closed and roped off, there was an old-fashioned fireplace now blazing with birch logs. Three nuns sat on a sofa that was drawn up almost to the hearth itself. They were talking and smiling with their bags stacked up to either side, waiting for the check-out line to thin a little. As Wendy watched them they burst into a chord of tinkling, girlish laughter. She (Wendy) felt a smile touch her (Wendy) own lips; not one of them could be under sixty. In the background was the constant hum of conversation, the muted ding! of the silver-plated bell beside the cash register as one of the two clerks on duty struck it, the slightly impatient call of
``Front, please!'' (the clerks)
It brought back

strong, warm memories of her (Wendy) honeymoon in New York with Jack, at the Beekman Tower. For the first time she (Wendy) let herself believe that this might be exactly what the three of them needed: a season together away from the world, a sort of family honeymoon. She (Wendy) smiled affectionately down at Danny, who was goggling around frankly at everything. Another limo, as gray as a banker's vest, had pulled up out front

``The last day of the season,'' (a banker)
Ullman was saying.
``Closing day. Always hectic. I had expected you more around three, Mr. Torrance.'' (unknown)
``I wanted to give the Volks time for a nervous breakdown if it decided to have one,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``It didn't.'' (unknown)
``How fortunate,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said.
``I'd like to take the three of you on a tour of the place a little later, and of course Dick Hallorann wants to show Mrs. Torrance the Overlook's kitchen. But I'm afraid --'' (the clerks)
One of the clerks came over and almost tugged his (Ullman) forelock.
``Excuse me, Mr. Ullman -- '' (unknown)
``Well? What is it?'' (unknown)
``It's Mrs. Brant,'' (the clerk)
the clerk said uncomfortably.
``She (Brant) refuses to pay her (Brant) bill with anything but her (Brant) American Express card. I told her (Brant) we stopped taking American Express at the end of the season last year, but she (Brant) won't ...'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
His (Ullman) eyes shifted to the Torrance family, then back to Ullman. He (Ullman) shrugged.
``I'll take care of it.'' (unknown)
``Thank you, Mr. Ullman.'' (The clerk)
The clerk crossed back to the desk, where a dreadnought of a woman bundled into a long fur coat and what looked like a black feather boa was remonstrating loudly.
``I have been coming to the Overlook Hotel since 1955,'' (she)
she (woman) was telling the smiling, shrugging clerk.
``I continued to come even after my second husband died of a stroke on that tiresome roque court -- I told him (husband) the sun was too hot that day -- and I have never ... I repeat: never ... paid with anything but my American Express credit card. Call the police if you like! Have them drag me away! I will still refuse to pay with anything but my American Express credit card. I repeat: ...'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
``Excuse me,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Mr. Ullman said. They watched him (Ullman) cross the lobby, touch Mrs. Brant's elbow deferentially, and spread his (Ullman) hands and nod when she (Brant) turned her (Brant) tirade on him (Ullman). He (Ullman) listened sympathetically, nodded again, and said something in return. Mrs. Brant smiled triumphantly, turned to the unhappy desk clerk, and said loudly:
``Thank God there is one employee of this hotel who hasn't become an utter Philistine!'' (the desk clerk)
She (Brant) allowed Ullman, who barely came to the bulky shoulder of her (Brant) fur coat, to take her (Brant) arm and lead her (Brant) away, presumably to his (Ullman) inner office.
``Whooo!'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said, smiling.
``There's a dude who earns his (dude) money.'' (unknown)
``But he (dude) didn't like that lady,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said immediately.
``He (dude) was just pretending to like her (lady).'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack grinned down at him (Jack).
``I'm sure that's true, doc. But flattery is the stuff that greases the wheels of the world.'' (unknown)
``What's flattery?'' (unknown)
``Flattery,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy told him (Jack),
``is when your daddy says he (daddy) likes my new yellow slacks even if he (daddy) doesn't or when he (daddy) says I don't need to take off five pounds.'' (him)
``Oh. Is it lying for fun?'' (unknown)

``Something very like that.'' (He)
He (Jack) had been looking at her (Wendy) closely and now said:
``You're pretty, Mommy.'' (He)
He (Jack) frowned in confusion when they exchanged a glance and then burst into laughter.
``Ullman didn't waste much flattery on me,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``Come on over by the window, you guys. I feel conspicuous standing out here in the middle with my denim jacket on. I honest to God didn't think there'd be anybody much here on closing day. Guess I was wrong.'' (unknown)
``You look very handsome,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said, and then they laughed again, Wendy putting a hand over her (Wendy) mouth. Danny still didn't understand, but it was okay. They were loving each other. Danny thought this place reminded her (Wendy) of somewhere else -LRB-the beak-man place-RRB- where she (Wendy) had been happy. He (Danny) wished he (Danny) liked it as well as she (Wendy) did, but he (Danny) kept telling himself over and over that the things Tony showed him (Tony) didn't always come true. He (Tony) would be careful. He (Tony) would watch for something called Redrum. But he (Tony) would not say anything unless he (Tony) absolutely had to. Because they were happy, they had been laughing, and there were no bad thoughts.
``Look at this view,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``Oh, it's gorgeous! Danny, look!'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
But Danny didn't think it was particularly gorgeous. He (Danny) didn't like heights; they made him (Danny) dizzy. Beyond the wide front porch, which ran the length of the hotel, a beautifully manicured lawn -LRB-there was a putting green on the right-RRB- sloped away to a long, rectangular swimming pool. A CLOSED sign stood on a little tripod at one end of the pool; closed was one sign he (Danny) could read by himself, along with Stop, Exit, Pizza, and a few others. Beyond the pool a graveled path wound off through baby pines and spruces and aspens. Here was a small sign he (Danny) didn't know: ROQUE. There was an arrow below it.
``What's R-O-Q-U-E, Daddy?'' (unknown)
``A game,'' (Daddy)
Daddy said.
``It's a little bit like croquet, only you play it on a gravel court that has sides like a big billiard table instead of grass. It's a very old game, Danny. Sometimes they have tournaments here.'' (unknown)
``Do you play it with a croquet mallet?'' (unknown)

Jack agreed.

-LRB-Come out, you little shit!-RRB-

Daddy was saying.

Danny said in an odd colorless little voice that made his (Danny) parents exchange a puzzled look over his (Danny) head.
