``Sure.'' (unknown)
``Do you like the animals?'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy asked.
``That's called a topiary.'' (unknown)
Beyond the path leading to roque there were hedges clipped into the shapes of various animals. Danny, whose eyes were sharp, made out a rabbit, a dog, a horse, a cow, and a trio of bigger ones that looked like frolicking lions.
``Those animals were what made Uncle Al think of me for the job,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack told him (Jack). ``He (Al) knew that when I was in college I used to work for a landscaping company. That's a business that fixes people's lawns and bushes and hedges. I

used to trim a lady's topiary.'' Wendy put a hand over her (Wendy) mouth and snickered. Looking at her (Wendy), Jack said, ``Yes, I used to trim her (lady) topiary at least once a week'' ``Get away, fly,'' Wendy said, and snickered again. ``Did she (lady) have nice hedges, Dad?'' Danny asked, and at this they both stifled great bursts of laughter. Wendy laughed so hard that tears streamed down her (Wendy) cheeks and she (Wendy) had to get a Kleenex out of her (Wendy) handbag. ``They weren't animals, Danny,'' Jack said when he (Jack) had control of himself. ``They were playing cards. Spades and hearts and clubs and diamonds. But the hedges grow, you see -- '' -LRB-They creep, Watson had said ... no, not the hedges, the boiler. You have to watch it all the time or you and your fambly will end up on the fuckin moon.-RRB- They looked at him (Watson), puzzled. The smile had faded off his (Watson) face. ``Dad?'' Danny asked. He (Danny) blinked at them, as if coming back from far away. ``They grow, Danny, and lose their shape. So I'll have to give them a haircut once or twice a week until it gets so cold they stop growing for the year.'' ``And a playground, too,'' Wendy said. ``My lucky boy.'' The playground was beyond the topiary. Two slides, a big swing set with half a dozen swings set at varying heights, a jungle gym, a tunnel made of cement rings, a sandbox, and a playhouse that was an exact replica of the Overlook itself. ``Do you like it, Danny?'' Wendy asked. ``I sure do,'' he (Danny) said, hoping he (Danny) sounded more enthused than he (Danny) felt. ``It's neat.'' Beyond the playground there was an inconspicuous chain link security fence, beyond that the wide, macadamized drive that led up to the hotel, and beyond that the valley itself, dropping away into the bright blue haze of afternoon. Danny didn't know the word isolation, but if someone had explained it to him (Danny) he (Danny) would have seized on it. Far below, lying in the sun like a long black snake that had decided to snooze for a while, was the road that led back through Sidewinder Pass and eventually to Boulder. The road that would be closed all winter long. He (Danny) felt a little suffocated at the thought, and almost jumped when Daddy dropped his (Danny) hand on his (Danny) shoulder. ``I'll get you that drink as soon as I can, doc. They're a little busy right now.''

``Sure, Dad.'' (unknown)
Mrs. Brant came out of the inner office looking vindicated. A few moments later two bellboys, struggling with eight suitcases between them, followed her (Brant) as best they could as she (Brant) strode triumphantly out the door. Danny watched through the window as a man in a gray uniform and a hat like a captain in the Army brought her (Brant) long silver car around to the door and got out. He (Danny) tipped his (Danny) cap to her (Brant) and ran around to open the trunk. And in one of those flashes that sometimes came, he (Danny) got a complete thought from her (Brant), one that floated above the confused, low-pitched babble of emotions and colors that he (Danny) usually got in crowded places. -LRB-i' d like to get into his (Danny) pants-RRB- Danny's brow wrinkled as he (Danny) watched the bellboys put her (Brant) cases into the trunk.

She (Brant) was looking rather sharply at the man in the gray uniform, who was supervising the loading. Why would she (Brant) want to get that man's pants? Was she (Brant) cold, even with that long fur coat on? And if she (Brant) was that cold, why hadn't she (Brant) just put on some pants of her (Brant) own? His (man) mommy wore pants just about all winter. The man in the gray uniform closed the trunk and walked back to help her (Brant) into the car. Danny watched closely to see if she (Brant) would say anything about his (Danny) pants, but she (Brant) only smiled and gave him (Danny) a dollar bill -- a tip. A moment later she (Brant) was guiding the big silver car down the driveway. He (Danny) thought about asking his (Danny) mother why Mrs. Brant might want the car-man's pants, and decided against it. Sometimes questions could get you in a whole lot of trouble. It had happened to him (Danny) before. So instead he (Danny) squeezed in between them on the small sofa they were sharing and watched all the people check out at the desk. He (Danny) was glad his (Danny) mommy and daddy were happy and loving each other, but he (Danny) couldn't help being a little worried. He (Danny) couldn't help it.

<< 10 >> HALLORANN The cook didn't conform to Wendy's image of the typical resort hotel kitchen personage at all. To begin with, such a personage was called a chef, nothing so mundane as a cook -- cooking was what she (Wendy) did in her (Wendy) apartment kitchen when she (Wendy) threw all the leftovers into a greased Pyrex casserole dish and added noodles. Further, the culinary wizard of such a place as the Overlook, which advertised in the resort section of the New York Sunday Times, should be small, rotund, and pasty-faced -LRB-rather like the Pillsbury Dough-Boy-RRB-; he (wizard) should have a thin pencilline mustache like a forties musical comedy star, dark eyes, a French accent, and a detestable personality. Hallorann had the dark eyes and that was all. He (wizard) was a tall black man with a modest afro that was beginning to powder white. He (wizard) had a soft southern accent and he (wizard) laughed a lot, disclosing teeth too white and too even to be anything but 1950-vintage Sears and Roebuck dentures. Her (Hallorann) own father had had a pair, which he (father) called Roebuckers, and from time to time he (father) would push them out at her (Hallorann) comically at the supper table ... always, Wendy remembered now, when her (Wendy) mother was out in the kitchen getting something else or on the telephone. Danny had stared up at this black giant in blue serge, and then had smiled when Hallorann picked him (Danny) up easily, set him (Danny) in the crook of his (Danny) elbow, and said:

``You ain't gonna stay up here all winter.'' (the crook)
``Yes I am,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said with a shy grin.
``No, you're gonna come down to St. Pete's with me and learn to cook and go out on the beach every damn evenin watchin for crabs. Right?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)

Danny giggled delightedly and shook his (Danny) head no. Hallorann set him (Danny) down.

``If you're gonna change your mind,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said, bending over him (Danny) gravely,
``you better do it quick. Thirty minutes from now and I'm in my car. Two and a half hours after that, I'm sitting at Gate 32, Concourse B, Stapleton International Airport, in the mile-high city of Denver, Colorado. Three hours after that, I'm rentin a car at the Miama Airport and on my way to sunny St. Pete's, waiting to get iota my swimtrunks and just laaafin up my sleeve at anybody stuck and caught in the snow. Can you dig it, my boy?'' (him)
``Yes, sir,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said, smiling. Hallorann turned to Jack and Wendy.
``Looks like a fine boy there.'' (unknown)
``We think he (boy)'ll do,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said, and offered his (Jack) hand. Hallorann took it.
``I'm Jack Torrance. My wife Winnifred. Danny you've met.'' (unknown)
``And a pleasure it was. Ma'am, are you a Winnie or a Freddie?'' (unknown)
``I'm a Wendy,'' (she)
she (Hallorann) said, smiling.
``Okay. That's better than the other two, I think. Right this way. Mr. Ullman wants you to have the tour, the tour you'll get.'' (He)
He (Jack) shook his (Jack) bead and said under his (Jack) breath:
``And won't I be glad to see the last of him (Ullman).'' (He)
Hallorann commenced to tour them around the most immense kitchen Wendy had ever seen in her (Hallorann) life. It was sparkling clean. Every surface was coaxed to a high gloss. It was more than just big; it was intimidating. She (Hallorann) walked at Hallorann's side while Jack, wholly out of his (Jack) element, hung back a little with Danny. A long wallboard hung with cutting instruments which went all the way from paring knives to twohanded cleavers hung beside a four-basin sink. There was a breadboard as big as their Boulder apartment's kitchen table. An amazing array of stainless-steel pots and pans hung from floor to ceiling, covering one whole wall.
``I think I'll have to leave a trail of breadcrumbs every time I come in,'' (she)
she (Hallorann) said.
``Don't let it get you down,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said. ``It's big, but it's still only a kitchen. Most of this stuff you'll never even have to touch. Keep it clean, that's all I ask. Here's the stove I'd be using, if I was you. There are three of them in all, but this is the smallest. Smallest, she (It) thought dismally, looking at it There were twelve burners, two regular ovens and a Dutch oven, a heated well on top in which you could simmer sauces or bake beans, a broiler, and a warmer -- plus a million dials and temperature gauges. ``All gas,'' Hallorann said. ``You've cooked with gas before, Wendy?'' ``Yes.. '' ``I love gas,'' he (Danny) said, and turned on one of the burners. Blue flame popped into life and he (Danny) adjusted it down to a faint glow with a delicate touch. ``I like to be able to see the flame you're cookin with. You see where all the surface burner switches are?'' ``Yes.'' ``And the oven dials are all marked. Myself, I favor the middle one because it seems to heat the most even, but you use whichever one you like -- or all three, for that matter.'' ``A TV dinner in each one,'' Wendy said, and laughed weakly. Hallorann roared. ``Go right ahead, if you like. I left a list of everything

edible over by the sink. You see it?'' ``Here it is, Mommy!'' Danny brought over two sheets of paper, written closely on both sides. ``Good boy,'' Hallorann said, taking it from him (Danny) and ruffling his (Danny) hair. ``You sure you don't want to come to Florida with me, my boy? Learn to cook the sweetest shrimp creole this side of paradise?'' Danny put his (Danny) hands over his (Danny) mouth and giggled and retreated to his (Danny) father's side. ``You three folks could eat up here for a year, I guess,'' Hallorann said. ``We got a cold-pantry, a walk-in freezer, all sorts of vegetable bins, and two refrigerators. Come on and let me show you.'' For the next ten minutes Hallorann opened bins and doors, disclosing food in such amounts as Wendy had never seen before. The food supplies amazed her (Wendy) but did not reassure her (Wendy) as much as she (Wendy) might have thought: the Donner Party kept recurring to her (Wendy), not with thoughts of cannibalism -LRB-with all this food it would indeed be a long time before they were reduced to such poor rations as each other-RRB-, but with the reinforced idea that this was indeed a serious business: when snow fell, getting out of here would not be a matter of an hour's drive to Sidewinder but a major operation. They would sit up here in this deserted grand hotel, eating the food that had been left them like creatures in a fairy tale and listening to the bitter wind around their snowbound eaves. In Vermont, when Danny had broken his (Danny) arm -LRB-when Jack broke Danny's arm-RRB- she (fairy) had called the emergency Medix squad, dialing the number from the little card attached to the phone. They had been at the house only ten minutes later. There were other numbers written on that little card. You could have a police car in five minutes and a fire truck in even less time than that, because the fire station was only three blocks away and one block over. There was a man to call if the lights went out, a man to call if the shower stopped up, a man to call if the TV went on the fritz. But what would happen up here if Danny had one of his (Danny) fainting spells and swallowed his (Danny) tongue? -LRB-oh God what a thought!-RRB- What if the place caught on fire? If Jack fell down the elevator shaft and fractured his (Jack) skull? What if -- ? -LRB-what if we have a wonderful time now stop it, Winnifred!-RRB- Hallorann showed them into the walk-in freezer first, where their breath puffed out like comic strip balloons. In the freezer it was as if winter had already come. Hamburger in big plastic bags, ten pounds in each bag, a dozen bags. Forty whole chickens hanging from a row of hooks in the wood-planked walls. Canned hams stacked up like poker chips, a dozen of them. Below the chickens, ten roasts of beef, ten roasts of pork, and a huge leg of lamb. ``You like lamb, doc?'' Hallorann asked, grinning. ``I love it,'' Danny said immediately. He (Danny) had never had it. ``I knew you did. There's nothin like two good slices of lamb on a cold night, with some mint jelly on the side. You got the mint jelly here, too. Lamb eases the belly. It's a noncontentious sort of meat.'' From behind them Jack said curiously:

``How did you know we called him (Lamb) doc?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)

Hallorann turned around.

He (Danny) looked at Hallorann, startled and a little scared. Hallorann winked solemnly and turned back to the food. Wendy looked from the cook's broad, serge-clad back to her (Hallorann) son. She (Hallorann) had the oddest feeling that something had passed between them, something she (Hallorann) could not quite follow.

Hallorann said, leading them back toward the wide swinging doors that gave on the Overlook dining room.

Jack said.

Wendy asked.

Hallorann said.

He (man) had two boys and one of them was killed in a riding accident on the grounds while the hotel was still abuilding. That would have been 1908 or '09. The old man's wife died of the flu, and then it was just the old man and his (man) youngest son. They ended up getting took back on as caretakers in the same hotel the old man had built.'' (unknown)
``It is sort of a pity,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said.

Hallorann said. ``Sometime in the early thirties before the Depression closed this place down for ten years. ``Anyway, Jack, I'd appreciate it if you and your wife would keep an eye out for rats in the kitchen, as well. If you should see them ... traps, not

poison.'' Jack blinked. ``Of course. Who'd want to put rat poison in the kitchen?'' Hallorann laughed derisively. ``Mr. Ullman, that's who. That was his (Ullman) bright idea last fall. I put it to him (Ullman), I said: `What if we all get up here next May, Mr. Ullman, and I serve the traditional opening night dinner' -- which just happens to be salmon in a very nice sauce -- `and everybody gits sick and the doctor comes and says to you,

``Ullman, what have you been doing up here? You've got eighty of the richest folks in America suffering from rat poisoning!'' (the doctor)
''' Jack threw his (Jack) head back and bellowed laughter. ``What did Ullman say?'' Hallorann tucked his (Jack) tongue into his (Jack) cheek as if feeling for a bit of food in there. ``He (Ullman) said: `Get some traps, Hallorann.' '' This time they all laughed, even Danny, although he (Danny) was not completely sure what the joke was, except it had something to do with Mr. Ullman, who didn't know everything after all. The four of them passed through the dining room, empty and silent now, with its fabulous western exposure on the snow-dusted peaks. Each of the white linen tablecloths had been covered with a sheet of tough clear plastic. The rug, now rolled up for the season, stood in one corner like a sentinel on guard duty. Across the wide room was a double set of batwing doors, and over them an oldfashioned sign lettered in gilt script: The Colorado Lounge. Following his (guard) gaze, Hallorann said, ``If you're a drinkin man, I hope you brought your own supplies. That place is picked clean. Employee's party last night, you know. Every maid and bellhop in the place is goin around with a headache today, me included.'' ``I don't drink,'' Jack said shortly. They went back to the lobby. It had cleared greatly during the half hour they'd spent in the kitchen. The long main room was beginning to take on the quiet, deserted look that Jack supposed they would become familiar with soon enough. The high-backed chairs were empty. The nuns who had been sitting by the fire were gone, and the fire itself was down to a bed of comfortably glowing coals. Wendy glanced out into the parking lot and saw that all but a dozen cars had disappeared. She (Wendy) found herself wishing they could get back in the VW and go back to Boulder... or anywhere else. Jack was looking around for Ullman, but he (Ullman) wasn't in the lobby. A young maid with her (maid) ash-blond hair pinned up on her (maid) neck came over. ``Your luggage is out on the porch, Dick.'' ``Thank you, Sally.'' He (Ullman) gave her (maid) a peck on the forehead. ``You have yourself a good winter. Getting married, I hear.'' He (Ullman) turned to the Torrances as she (maid) strolled away, backside twitching pertly. ``I've got to hurry along if I'm going to make that plane. I want to wish you all the best. Know you'll have it.'' ``Thanks,'' Jack said. ``You've been very kind.'' ``I'll take good care of your kitchen,'' Wendy promised again. ``Enjoy Florida.'' ``I always do,'' Hallorann said. He (Jack) put his (Jack) hands on his (Jack) knees and bent down to Danny. ``Last chance, guy. Want to come to Florida?'' ``I guess not,'' Danny said, smiling. ``Okay. Like to give me a hand out to my car with my bags?''
``If my mommy says I can.'' (unknown)

``You can,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said,
``but you'll have to have that jacket buttoned.'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
She (Wendy) leaned forward to do it but Hallorann was ahead of her (Hallorann), his (Danny) large brown fingers moving with smooth dexterity.
``I'll send him (guy) right back in,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said.
``Fine,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said, and followed them to the door. Jack was still looking around for Ullman. The last of the Overlooks guests were checking out at the desk.

<< 11 >> THE SHINING There were four bags in a pile just outside the door. Three of them were giant, battered old suitcases covered with black imitation alligator hide. The last was an oversized zipper bag with a faded tartan skin.

``Guess you can handle that one, can't you?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann asked him (Jack). He (Jack) picked up two of the big cases in one hand and hoisted the other under his (Jack) arm.
``Sure,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said. He (Danny) got a grip on it with both hands and followed the cook down the porch steps, trying manfully not to grunt and give away how heavy it was. A sharp and cutting fall wind had come up since they had arrived; it whistled across the parking lot, making Danny wince his (Danny) eyes down to slits as he (Danny) carried the zipper bag in front of him (Danny), bumping on his (Danny) knees. A few errant aspen leaves rattled and turned across the now mostly deserted asphalt, making Danny think momentarily of that night last week when he (Danny) had wakened out of his (Danny) nightmare and had heard -- or thought he (Danny) heard, at least -- Tony telling him (Tony) not to go. Hallorann set his (Tony) bags down by the trunk of a beige Plymouth Fury.
``This ain't much car,'' (he)
he (Tony) confided to Danny,
``just a rental job. My Bessie's on the other end. She (Bessie)'s a car. 1950 Cadillac, and does she (Bessie) run sweet? I'll tell the world. I keep her (Bessie) in Florida because she (Bessie)'s too old for all this mountain climbing. You need a hand with that?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
``No, sir,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said. He (Danny) managed to carry it the last ten or twelve steps without grunting and set it down with a large sigh of relief.
``Good boy,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said. He (Danny) produced a large key ring from the pocket of his (Danny) blue serge jacket and unlocked the trunk. As he (Danny) lifted the bags in he (Danny) said:
``You shine on, boy. Harder than anyone I ever met in my life. And I'm sixty years old this January.'' (he)
``Huh?'' (unknown)
``You got a knack,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said, turning to him (Danny).
``Me, I've always called it shining. That's what my grandmother called it, too. She (grandmother) had it. We used to sit in the kitchen when I was a boy no older than you and have long talks without even openin our mouths.'' (unknown)

``Really?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann smiled at Danny's openmouthed, almost hungry expression and said,
``Come on up and sit in the car with me for a few minutes. Want to talk to you.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
He (Danny) slammed the trunk. In the lobby of the Overlook, Wendy Torrance saw her (Torrance) son get into the passenger side of Hallorann's car as the big black cook slid in behind the wheel. A sharp pang of fear struck her (Hallorann) and she (Hallorann) opened her (Hallorann) mouth to tell Jack that Hallorann had not been lying about taking their son to Florida -- there was a kidnaping afoot. But they were only sitting there. She (Hallorann) could barely see the small silhouette of her (Hallorann) son's head, turned attentively toward Hallorann's big one. Even at this distance that small head had a set to it that she (Hallorann) recognized -- it was the way her (Hallorann) son looked when there was something on the TV that particularly fascinated him (son), or when he (son) and his (son) father were playing old maid or idiot cribbage. Jack, who was still looking around for Ullman, hadn't noticed. Wendy kept silent, watching Hallorann's car nervously, wondering what they could possibly be talking about that would make Danny cock his (Danny) head that way. In the car Hallorann was saying:
``Get you kinda lonely, thinkin you were the only one?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny, who had been frightened as well as lonely sometimes, nodded.
``Am I the only one you ever met?'' (he)
he (Danny) asked. Hallorann laughed and shook his (Danny) head.
``No, child, no. But you shine the hardest.'' (unknown)
``Are there lots, then?'' (unknown)
``No,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said,
``but you do run across them. A lot of folks, they got a little bit of shine to them. They don't even know it. But they always seem to show up with flowers when their wives are feelin blue with the monthlies, they do good on school tests they don't even study for, they got a good idea how people are feelin as soon as they walk into a room. I come across fifty or sixty like that. But maybe only a dozen, countin my gram, that knew they was shinin.'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
``Wow,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said, and thought about it. Then:
``Do you know Mrs. Brant?'' (unknown)
``Her (Brant)?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann asked scornfully.
``She (Brant) don't shine. Just sends her (Brant) supper back two-three times every night.'' (unknown)
``I know she (Brant) doesn't,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said earnestly.
``But do you know the man in the gray uniform that gets the cars?'' (unknown)
``Mike? Sure, I know Mike. What about him (Mike)?'' (unknown)
``Mr. Hallorann, why would she (Brant) want his (Hallorann) pants?'' (unknown)
``What are you talking about, boy?'' (unknown)
``Well, when she (Brant) was watching him (Hallorann), she (Brant) was thinking she (Brant) would sure like to get into his (Hallorann) pants and I just wondered why -- '' (he)
But he (Danny) got no further. Hallorann had thrown his (Danny) head back, and rich, dark laughter issued from his (Danny) chest, rolling around in the car like cannonfire. The seat shook with the force of it. Danny smiled, puzzled, and at last the storm subsided by fits and starts. Hallorann produced a large silk handkerchief from his (Danny) breast pocket like a white flag of surrender and wiped his (Danny) streaming eyes.
``Boy,'' (he)
he (Danny) said, still snorting a little,
``you are gonna know everything there is to know about the human condition before you make ten. I dunno if to envy you or not.'' (he)
``But Mrs. Brant -- '' (he)

``You never mind her (Brant),'' (he)
he (Danny) said.
``And don't go askin your mom, either. You'd only upset her (mom), dig what I'm sayin?'' (unknown)
``Yes, sir,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said. He (Danny) dug it perfectly well. He (Danny) had upset his (Danny) mother that way in the past.
``That Mrs. Brant is just a dirty old woman with an itch, that's all you have to know.'' (He)
He (Danny) looked at Danny speculatively.
``How hard can you hit, doc?'' (unknown)
``Huh?'' (unknown)
``Give me a blast. Think at me. I want to know if you got as much as I think you do.'' (unknown)
``What do you want me to think?'' (unknown)
``Anything. Just think it hard.'' (unknown)
``Okay,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said. He (Danny) considered it for a moment, then gathered his (Danny) concentration and flung it out at Hallorann. He (Danny) had never done anything precisely like this before, and at the last instant some instinctive part of him (Danny) rose up and blunted some of the thought's raw force-he didn't want to hurt Mr. Hallorann. Still the thought arrowed out of him (Hallorann) with a force he (Hallorann) never would have believed. It went like a Nolan Ryan fastball with a little extra on it. -LRB-Gee I hope I don't hurt him (Ryan)-RRB- And the thought was: -LRB-!!! HI, DICK!!!-RRB- Hallorann winced and jerked backward on the seat. His (Ryan) teeth came together with a hard click, drawing blood from his (Ryan) lower lip in a thin trickle. His (Ryan) hands flew up involuntarily from his (Ryan) lap to the level of his (Ryan) chest and then settled back again. For a moment his (Ryan) eyelids fluttered limply, with no conscious control, and Danny was frightened.
``Mr. Hallorann? Dick? Are you okay?'' (unknown)
``I don't know,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said, and laughed weakly.
``I honest to God don't. My God, boy, you're a pistol.'' (unknown)
``I'm sorry,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said, more alarmed.
``Should I get my daddy? I'll run and get him (daddy).'' (unknown)
``No, here I come. I'm okay, Danny. You just sit right there. I feel a little scrambled, that's all.'' (unknown)
``I didn't go as hard as I could,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny confessed.
``I was scared to, at the last minute.'' (unknown)
``Probably my good luck you did ... my brains would be leakin out my ears.'' (He)
He (Danny) saw the alarm on Danny's face and smiled.
``No harm done. What did it feel like to you?'' (unknown)
``Like I was Nolan Ryan throwing a fastball,'' (he)
he (Danny) replied promptly.
``You like baseball, do you?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann was rubbing his (Danny) temples gingerly.
``Daddy and me like the Angels,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said.
``The Red Sox in the American League East and the Angels in the West. We saw the Red Sox against Cincinnati in the World Series. I was a lot littler then. And Daddy was ...'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny's face went dark and troubled.
``Was what, Dan?'' (unknown)
``I forget,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said. He (Danny) started to put his (Danny) thumb in his (Danny) mouth to suck it, but that was a baby trick. He (Danny) put his (Danny) hand back in his (Danny) lap.
``Can you tell what your mom and dad are thinking, Danny?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann was watching him (Danny) closely.

``Most times, if I want to. But usually I don't try.'' (unknown)
``Why not?'' (unknown)
``Well ...'' (he)
he (Danny) paused a moment, troubled.
``It would be like peeking into the bedroom and watching while they're doing the thing that makes babies. Do you know that thing?'' (unknown)
``I have had acquaintance with it,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said gravely.
``They wouldn't like that. And they wouldn't like me peeking at their thinks. It would be dirty.'' (unknown)
``I see.'' (unknown)
``But I know how they're feeling,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said.
``I can't help that. I know how you're feeling, too. I hurt you. I'm sorry.'' (unknown)
``It's just a headache. I've had hangovers that were worse. Can you read other people, Danny?'' (unknown)
``I can't read yet at all,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said,
``except a few words. But Daddy's going to teach me this winter. My daddy used to teach reading and writing in a big school. Mostly writing, but he (Danny) knows reading, too.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
``I mean, can you tell what anybody is thinking?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny thought about it.
``I can if it's loud,'' (he)
he (Danny) said finally.
``Like Mrs. Brant and the pants. Or like once, when me and Mommy were in this big store to get me some shoes, there was this big kid looking at radios, and he (kid) was thinking about taking one without buying it. Then he (kid)'d think, what if I get caught? Then he (kid)'d think, I really want it. Then he (kid)'d think about getting caught again. He (kid) was making himself sick about it, and he (kid) was making me sick. Mommy was talking to the man who sells the shoes so I went over and said, `Kid, don't take that radio. Go away.' And he (Kid) got really scared. He (Kid) went away fast.'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann was grinning broadly.
``I bet he (Kid) did. Can you do anything else, Danny? Is it only thoughts and feelings, or is there more?'' (unknown)
Cautiously:
``Is there more for you?'' (unknown)
``Sometimes,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said.
``Not often. Sometimes ... sometimes there are dreams. Do you dream, Danny?'' (unknown)
``Sometimes,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said,
``I dream when I'm awake. After Tony comes.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
His (Danny) thumb wanted to go into his (Danny) mouth again. He (Danny) had never told anyone but Mommy and Daddy about Tony. He (Tony) made his (Tony) thumb-sucking hand go back into his (Tony) lap.
``Who's Tony?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
And suddenly Danny had one of those flashes of understanding that frightened him (Danny) most of all; it was like a sudden glimpse of some incomprehensible machine that might be safe or might be deadly dangerous. He (Danny) was too young to know which. He (Danny) was too young to understand.
``What's wrong?'' (he)
he (Danny) cried.
``You're asking me all this because you're worried, aren't you? Why are you worried about me? Why are you worried about us?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann put his (Danny) large dark hands on the small boy's shoulders.
``Stop,'' (he)
he (Danny) said.
``It's probably nothin. But if it is somethin ... well, you've got a large thing in your head, Danny. You'll have to do a lot of growin yet before you catch up to it, I guess. You got to be brave about it.'' (unknown)
``But I don't understand things!'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny burst out.
``I do but I don't! People ... they feel things and I feel them, but I don't know what I'm feeling!'' (He)
He (Danny) looked down at his (Danny) lap wretchedly. ``I wish I could read. Sometimes Tony shows me

signs and I can hardly read any of them.'' ``Who's Tony?'' Hallorann asked again. ``Mommy and Daddy call him (Tony) my `invisible playmate, ''' Danny said, reciting the words carefully. ``But he (Tony)'s really real. At least, I think he (Tony) is. Sometimes, when I try real hard to understand things, he (Tony) comes. He (Tony) says, `Danny, I want to show you something.' And it's like I pass out. Only ... there are dreams, like you said.'' He (Danny) looked at Hallorann and swallowed. ``They used to be nice. But now ... I can't remember the word for dreams that scare you and make you cry.'' ``Nightmares?'' Hallorann asked. ``Yes. That's right. Nightmares.'' ``About this place? About the Overlook?'' Danny looked down at his (Danny) thumb-sucking hand again. ``Yes,'' he (Danny) whispered. Then he (Danny) spoke shrilly, looking up into Hallorann's face: ``But I can't tell my daddy, and you can't, either! He (daddy) has to have this job because it's the only one Uncle Al could get for him (Al) and he (Al) has to finish his (Al) play or he (Al) might start doing the Bad Thing again and I know what that is, it's getting drunk, that's what it is, it's when he (Al) used to always be drunk and that was a Bad Thing to do!'' He (Danny) stopped, on the verge of tears. ``Shh,'' Hallorann said, and pulled Danny's face against the rough serge of his (Danny) jacket. It smelled faintly of mothballs. ``That's all right, son. And if that thumb likes your mouth, let it go where it wants.'' But his (Danny) face was troubled. He (Danny) said: ``What you got, son, I call it shinin on, the Bible calls it having visions, and there's scientists that call it precognition. I've read up on it, son. I've studied on it. They all mean seeing the future. Do you understand that?'' Danny nodded against Hallorann's coat. ``I remember the strongest shine I ever had that way ... I'm not liable to forget. It was 1955. I was still in the Army then, stationed overseas in West Germany. It was an hour before supper, and I was standin by the sink, givin one of the KPs hell for takin too much of the potato along with the peel. I says, `Here, lemme show you how that's done.' He (I) held out the potato and the peeler and then the whole kitchen was gone. Bang, just like that. You say you see this guy Tony before ... before you have dreams?'' Danny nodded. Hallorann put an arm around him (Danny). ``With me it's smellin oranges. All that afternoon I'd been smellin them and thinkin nothin of it, because they were on the menu for that night--we had thirty crates of Valencias. Everybody in the damn kitchen was smellin oranges that night. ``For a minute it was like I had just passed out. And then I heard an explosion and saw flames. There were people screaming. Sirens. And I heard this hissin noise that could only be steam. Then it seemed like I got a little closer to whatever it was and I saw a railroad car off the tracks and laying on its side with Georgia aced South Carolina Railroad written on it, and I knew like a flash that my brother Carl was on that train and it jumped the tracks and Carl was dead. Just like that. Then it was gone and here's this scared, stupid little KP in front of me, still holdin out that potato and the peeler. He (Carl) says, `Are you okay, Sarge?' And I says, `No. My brother's just been killed down in Georgia' And when I finally got my momma on the overseas telephone, she (momma) told me how it

was.

``But see, boy, I already knew how it was.'' (He)
He (Danny) shook his (Danny) head slowly, as if dismissing the memory, and looked down at the wide-eyed boy.
``But the thing you got to remember, my boy, is this: Those things don't always come true. I remember just four years ago I had a job cookin at a boys' camp up in Maine on Long Lake. So I am sittin by the boarding gate at Logan Airport in Boston, just waiting to get on my flight, and I start to smell oranges. For the first time in maybe five years. So I say to myself, `My God, what's comin on this crazy late show now?' and I got down to the bathroom and sat on one of the toilets to be private. I never did black out, but I started to get this feelin, stronger and stronger, that my plane was gonna crash. Then the feeling went away, and the smell of oranges, and I knew it was over. I went back to the Delta Airlines desk and changed my flight to one three hours later. And do you know what happened?'' (unknown)
``What?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny whispered.
``Nothin!'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said, and laughed. He (Danny) was relieved to see the boy smile a little, too.
``Not one single thing! That old plane landed right on time and without a single bump or bruise. So you see ... sometimes those feelins don't come to anything.'' (unknown)
``Oh,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said.
``Or you take the race track. I go a lot, and I usually do pretty well. I stand by the rail when they go by the starting gate, and sometimes I get a little shine about this horse or that one. Usually those feelins help me get real well. I always tell myself that someday I'm gonna get three at once on three long shots and make enough on the trifecta to retire early. It ain't happened yet. But there's plenty of times I've come home from the track on shank's mare instead of in a taxicab with my wallet swollen up. Nobody shines on all the time, except maybe for God up in heaven.'' (unknown)
``Yes, sir,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said, thinking of the time almost a year ago when Tony had showed him (Tony) a new baby lying in a crib at their house in Stovington. He (Tony) had been very excited about that, and had waited, knowing that it took time, but there had been no new baby.
``Now you listen,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said, and took both of Danny's hands in his (Danny) own.
``I've had some bad dreams here, and I've had some bad feelins. I've worked here two seasons now and maybe a dozen times I've had ... well, nightmares. And maybe half a dozen times I've thought I've seen things. No, I won't say what. It ain't for a little boy like you. Just nasty things. Once it had something to do with those damn hedges clipped to look like animals. Another time there was a maid, Delores Vickery her (Vickery) name was, and she (Vickery) had a little shine to her (Vickery), but I don't think she (Vickery) knew it. Mr. Ullman fired her (Vickery) ... do you know what that is, doc?'' (unknown)
``Yes, sir,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said candidly,
``my daddy got fired from his (daddy) teaching job and that's why we're in Colorado, I guess.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
``Well, Ullman fired her (Vickery) on account of her (Vickery) saying she (Vickery)'d seen something in one of the rooms where ... well, where a bad thing happened. That was in Room 217, and I want you to promise me you won't go in there, Danny. Not all winter. Steer right clear.'' (unknown)

``All right,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said.
``Did the lady -- the maiden -- did she (lady) ask you to go look?'' (unknown)
``Yes, she (lady) did. And there was a bad thing there. But ... I don't think it was a bad thing that could hurt anyone, Danny, that's what I'm tryin to say. People who shine can sometimes see things that are gonna happen, and I think sometimes they can see things that did happen. But they're just like pictures in a book. Did you ever see a picture in a book that scared you, Danny?'' (unknown)
``Yes,'' (he)
he (Danny) said, thinking of the story of Bluebeard and the picture where Bluebeard's new wife opens the door and sees all the heads.
``But you knew it couldn't hurt you, didn't you?'' (unknown)
``Ye -- ess...'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said, a little dubious.
``Well, that's how it is in this hotel. I don't know why, but it seems that all the bad things that ever happened here, there's little pieces of those things still layin around like fingernail clippins or the boogers that somebody nasty just wiped under a chair. I don't know why it should just be here, there's bad goings-on in just about every hotel in the world, I guess, and I've worked in a lot of them and had no trouble. Only here. But Danny, I don't think those things can hurt anybody.'' (He)
He (Danny) emphasized each word in the sentence with a mild shake of the boy's shoulders.
``So if you should see something, in a hallway or a room or outside by those hedges ... just look the other way and when you look back, it'll be gone. Are you diggin me?'' (unknown)
``Yes,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said. He (Danny) felt much better, soothed. He (Danny) got up on his (Danny) knees, kissed Hallorann's cheek, and gave him (Danny) a big hard hug. Hallorann hugged him (Danny) back. When he (Danny) released the boy he (Danny) asked:
``Your folks, they don't shine, do they?'' (he)
``No, I don't think so.'' (unknown)
``I tried them like I did you,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said.
``Your momma jumped the tiniest bit. I think all mothers shine a little, you know, at least until their kids grow up enough to watch out for themselves. Your dad ...'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann paused momentarily. He (Danny) had probed at the boy's father and he (Danny) just didn't know. It wasn't like meeting someone who had the shine, or someone who definitely did not. Poking at Danny's father had been ... strange, as if Jack Torrance had something -- something that he (Torrance) was hiding. Or something he (Torrance) was holding in so deeply submerged in himself that it was impossible to get to.
``I don't think he (dad) shines at all,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann finished.
``So you don't worry about them. You just take care of you. I don't think there's anything here that can hurt you. So just be cool, okay?'' (unknown)
``Okay.'' (unknown)
``Danny! Hey, doc!'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny looked around.
``That's Mom. She (Mom) wants me. I have to go.'' (unknown)
``I know you do,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said.
``You have a good time here, Danny. Best you can, anyway.'' (unknown)
``I will. Thanks, Mr. Hallorann. I feel a lot better.'' (unknown)
The smiling thought came in his (Danny) mind: -LRB-Dick, to my friends-RRB- -LRB-Yes, Dick, okay-RRB- Their eyes met, and Dick Hallorann winked. Danny scrambled across the seat of the car and opened the passenger side door. As he (Danny) was getting out, Hallorann said,
``Danny?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)

``What?'' (unknown)
``If there Is trouble ... you give a call. A big loud holler like the one you gave a few minutes ago. I might hear you even way down in Florida. And if I do, I'll come on the run.'' (unknown)
``Okay,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said, and smiled.
``You take care, big boy.'' (unknown)
``I will.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny slammed the door and ran across the parking lot toward the porch, where Wendy stood holding her (Wendy) elbows against the chill wind. Hallorann watched, the big grin slowly fading. I don't think there's anything here that can hurt you. I don't think. But what if he (Danny) was wrong? He (Danny) had known that this was his (Danny) last season at the Overlook ever since he (Danny) had seen that thing in the bathtub of Room 217. It had been worse than any picture in any book, and from here the boy running to his (boy) mother looked so small ... I don't think -- His (boy) eyes drifted down to the topiary animals. Abruptly he (boy) started the car and put it in gear and drove away, trying not to look back. And of course he (boy) did, and of course the porch was empty. They had gone back inside. It was as if the Overlook had swallowed them.

<< 12 >> THE GRAND TOUR

``What were you talking about, hon?'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy asked him (boy) as they went back inside.
``Oh, nothing much.'' (unknown)
``For nothing much it sure was a long talk.'' (He)
He (boy) shrugged and Wendy saw Danny's paternity in the gesture; Jack could hardly have done it better himself. She (Wendy) would get no more out of Danny. She (Wendy) felt strong exasperation mixed with an even stronger love: the love was helpless, the exasperation came from a feeling that she (Wendy) was deliberately being excluded. With the two of them around she (Wendy) sometimes felt like an outsider, a bit player who had accidentally wandered back onstage while the main action was taking place. Well, they wouldn't be able to exclude her (Wendy) this winter, her (Wendy) two exasperating males; quarters were going to be a little too close for that. She (Wendy) suddenly realized she (Wendy) was feeling jealous of the closeness between her (Wendy) husband and her (Wendy) son, and felt ashamed. That was too close to the way her (Wendy) own mother might have felt ... too close for comfort. The lobby was now empty except for Ullman and the head desk clerk -LRB-they were at the register, cashing up-RRB-, a couple of maids who had changed to warm slacks

and sweaters, standing by the front door and looking out with their luggage pooled around them, and Watson, the maintenance man. He (Watson) caught her (clerk) looking at him (Watson) and gave her (clerk) a wink ... a decidedly lecherous one. She (clerk) looked away hurriedly. Jack was over by the window just outside the restaurant, studying the view. He (Jack) looked rapt and dreamy. The cash register apparently checked out, because now Ullman ran it shut with an authoritative snap. He (Ullman) initialed the tape and put it in a small zipper case. Wendy silently applauded the head clerk, who looked greatly relieved. Ullman looked like the type of man who might take any shortage out of the head clerk's hide ... without ever spilling a drop of blood. Wendy didn't much care for Ullman or his (Ullman) officious, ostentatiously bustling manner. He (Ullman) was like every boss she (Wendy)'d ever had, male or female. He (Ullman) would be saccharin sweet with the guests, a petty tyrant when he (Ullman) was backstage with the help. But now school was out and the head clerk's pleasure was written large on his (Ullman) face. It was out for everyone but she (clerk) and Jack and Danny, anyway.

``Mr. Torrance,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman called peremptorily.
``Would you come over here, please?'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack walked over, nodding to Wendy and Danny that they were to come too. The clerk, who had gone into the back, now came out again wearing an overcoat.
``Have a pleasant winter, Mr. Ullman.'' (unknown)
``I doubt it,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said distantly.
``May twelfth, Braddock. Not a day earlier. Not a day later.'' (unknown)
``Yes, sir.'' (Braddock)
Braddock walked around the desk, his (Ullman) face sober and dignified, as befitted his (Ullman) position, but when his (Ullman) back was entirely to Ullman, he (Ullman) grinned like a schoolboy. He (Ullman) spoke briefly to the two girls still waiting by the door for their ride, and he (Ullman) was followed out by a brief burst of stifled laughter. Now Wendy began to notice the silence of the place. It had fallen over the hotel like a heavy blanket muting everything but the faint pulse of the afternoon wind outside. From where she (Wendy) stood she (Wendy) could look through the inner office, now neat to the point of sterility with its two bare desks and two sets of gray filing cabinets. Beyond that she (Wendy) could see Hallorann's spotless kitchen, the big portholed double doors propped open by rubber wedges.
``I thought I would take a few extra minutes and show you through the Hotel,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said, and Wendy reflected that you could always hear that capital H in Ullman's voice. You were supposed to hear it.
``I'm sure your husband will get to know the ins and outs of the Overlook quite well, Mrs. Torrance, but you and your son will doubtless keep more to the lobby level and the first floor, where your quarters are.'' (unknown)
``Doubtless,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy murmured demurely, and Jack shot her (Wendy) a private glance.
``It's a beautiful place,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said expansively.
``I rather enjoy showing it off.'' (I)
I'll bet you do, Wendy thought.
``Let's go up to third and work our way down,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said. He (Ullman) sounded positively enthused.
``If we're keeping you -- '' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack began.
``Not at all,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said: ``The shop is shut. Tout fins, for this season, at least. And I plan to overnight in Boulder -- at the Boulderado, of course. Only decent hotel this side of Denver ... except for the Overlook itself, of

course. This way.'' They stepped into the elevator together. It was ornately scrolled in copper and brass, but it settled appreciably before Ullman pulled the gate across. Danny stirred a little uneasily, and Ullman smiled down at him (Ullman). Danny tried to smile back without notable success. ``Don't you worry, little man,'' Ullman said. ``Safe as houses.'' ``So was the Titanic,'' Jack said, looking up at the cut-glass globe in the center of the elevator ceiling. Wendy bit the inside of her (Wendy) cheek to keep the smile away. Ullman was not amused. He (Ullman) slid the inner gate across with a rattle and a bang. ``The Titanic made only one voyage, Mr. Torrance. This elevator has made thousands of them since it was installed in 1926.'' ``That's reassuring,'' Jack said. He (Jack) ruffed Danny's hair. ``The plane ain't gonna crash, doc.'' Ullman threw the lever over, and for a moment there was nothing but a shuddering beneath their feet and the tortured whine of the motor below them. Wendy had a vision of the four of them being trapped between floors like flies in a bottle and found in the spring ... with little bits and pieces gone ... like the Donner Party ... -LRB-Stop it!-RRB- The elevator began to rise, with some vibration and clashing and banging from below at first. Then the ride smoothed out. At the third floor Ullman brought them to a bumpy stop, retracted the gate, and opened the door. The elevator car was still six inches below floor level. Danny gazed at the difference in height between the third-floor hall and the elevator floor as if he (Danny) had just sensed the universe was not as sane as he (Danny) had been told. Ullman cleared his (Ullman) throat and raised the car a little, brought it to a stop with a jerk -LRB-still two inches low-RRB-, and they all climbed out. With their weight gone the car rebounded almost to floor level, something Wendy did not find reassuring at all. Safe as houses or not, she (Wendy) resolved to take the stairs when she (Wendy) had to go up or down in this place. And under no conditions would she (Wendy) allow the three of them to get into the rickety thing together. ``What are you looking at, doc?'' Jack inquired humorously. ``See any spots there?'' ``Of course not,'' Ullman said, nettled. ``All the rugs were shampooed just two days ago.'' Wendy glanced down at the hall runner herself. Pretty, but definitely not anything she (Wendy) would choose for her (Wendy) own home, if the day ever came when she (Wendy) had one. Deep blue pile, it was entwined with what seemed to be a surrealistic jungle scene full of ropes and vines and trees filled with exotic birds. It was hard to tell just what sort of birds, because all the interweaving was done in unshaded black, giving only silhouettes. ``Do you like the rug?'' Wendy asked Danny.

``Yes, Mom,'' (unknown)
he (Danny) said colorlessly. They walked down the hall, which was comfortably wide. The wallpaper was silk, a lighter blue to go against the rug. Electric flambeaux stood at ten-foot intervals at a height of about seven feet. Fashioned to look like London gas lamps, the bulbs were masked behind cloudy, cream-hued glass that was bound with

crisscrossing iron strips.

``I like those very much,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said. Ullman nodded, pleased.
``Mr. Derwent had those installed throughout the Hotel after the war -- number Two, I mean. In fact most -- although not all -- of the thirdfloor decorating scheme was his (Mr.) idea. This is 300, the Presidential Suite.'' (He)
He (Ullman) twisted his (Ullman) key in the lock of the mahogany double doors and swung them wide. The sitting room's wide western exposure made them all gasp, which had probably been Ullman's intention. He (Ullman) smiled.
``Quite a view, isn't it?'' (unknown)
``It sure is,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said. The window ran nearly the length of the sitting room, and beyond it the sun was poised directly between two sawtoothed peaks, casting golden light across the rock faces and the sugared snow on the high tips. The clouds around and behind this picture-postcard view were also tinted gold, and a sunbeam glinted duskily down into the darkly pooled firs below the timberline. Jack and Wendy were so absorbed in the view that they didn't look down at Danny, who was staring not out the window but at the red-and-white-striped silk wallpaper to the left, where a door opened into an interior bedroom. And his (Danny) gasp, which had been mingled with theirs, had nothing to do with beauty. Great splashes of dried blood, flecked with tiny bits of grayish-white tissue, clotted the wallpaper. It made Danny feel sick. It was like a crazy picture drawn in blood, a surrealistic etching of a man's face drawn back in terror and pain, the mouth yawning and half the head pulverized -- -LRB-So if you should see something ... just look the other way and when you look back, it'll be gone. Are you diggin me?-RRB- He (man) deliberately looked out the window, being careful to show no expression on his (man) face, and when his (man) mommy's hand closed over his (man) own he (man) took it, being careful not to squeeze it or give her (mommy) a signal of any kind. The manager was saying something to his (manager) daddy about making sure to shutter that big window so a strong wind wouldn't blow it in. Jack was nodding. Danny looked cautiously back at the wall. The big dried bloodstain was gone. Those little gray-white flecks that had been scattered all through it, they were gone, too. Then Ullman was leading them out. Mommy asked him (Ullman) if he (Ullman) thought the mountains were pretty. Danny said he (Danny) did, although he (Danny) didn't really care for the mountains, one way or the other. As Ullman was closing the door behind them, Danny looked back over his (Danny) shoulder. The bloodstain had returned, only now it was fresh. It was running. Ullman, looking directly at it, went on with his (Ullman) running commentary about the famous men who had stayed here. Danny discovered that he (Danny) had bitten his (Danny) lip hard enough to make it bleed, and he (Danny) had never even felt it. As they walked on down the corridor, he (Danny) fell a little bit behind the others and wiped the blood away with the back of his (Danny) hand and thought about -LRB-blood-RRB- -LRB-Did Mr. Hallorann see blood or was it something worse?-RRB- -LRB-I don't think those things can hurt you.-RRB- There was an iron scream behind his (Hallorann) lips, but he (Hallorann) would not let it out. His (Hallorann) mommy and daddy could not see such things; they never had. He (Hallorann) would keep quiet. His (Hallorann) mommy and daddy were loving each other, and that was a real thing. The other things were just like pictures in a book. Some pictures were scary, but they

couldn't hurt you. They ... couldn't ... hurt you. Mr. Ullman showed them some other rooms on the third floor, leading them through corridors that twisted and turned like a maze. They were all sweets up here, Mr. Ullman said, although Danny didn't see any candy. He (Danny) showed them some rooms where a lady named Marilyn Monroe once stayed when she (Monroe) was married to a man named Arthur Miller -LRB-Danny got a vague understanding that Marilyn and Arthur had gotten a DIVORCE not long after they were in the Overlook Hotel-RRB-.

``Mommy?'' (unknown)
``What, honey?'' (unknown)
``If they were married, why did they have different names? You and Daddy have the same names.'' (unknown)
``Yes, but we're not famous, Danny,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``Famous women keep their same names even after they get married because their names are their bread and butter.'' (unknown)
``Bread and butter,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said, completely mystified.
``What Daddy means is that people used to like to go to the movies and see Marilyn Monroe,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said,
``but they might not like to go to see Marilyn Miller.'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
``Why not? She (Marilyn)'d still be the same lady. Wouldn't everyone know that?'' (unknown)
``Yes, but -- '' (She)
She (Wendy) looked at Jack helplessly.
``Truman Capote once stayed in this room,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman interrupted impatiently. He (Ullman) opened the door.
``That was in my time. An awfully nice man. Continental manners.'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
There was nothing remarkable in any of these rooms -LRB-except for the absence of sweets, which Mr. Ullman kept calling them-RRB-, nothing that Danny was afraid of. In fact, there was only one other thing on the third floor that bothered Danny, and he (Danny) could not have said why. It was the fire extinguisher on the wall just before they turned the corner and went back to the elevator, which stood open and waiting like a mouthful of gold teeth. It was an old-fashioned extinguisher, a flat hose folded back a dozen times upon itself, one end attached to a large red valve, the other ending in a brass nozzle. The folds of the hose were secured with a red steel slat on a hinge. In case of a fire you could knock the steel slat up and out of the way with one hard push and the hose was yours. Danny could see that much; he (Danny) was good at seeing how things worked. By the time he (Danny) was two and a half he (Danny) had been unlocking the protective gate his (Danny) father had installed at the top of the stairs in the Stovington house. He (Danny) had seen how the lock worked. His (Danny) daddy said it was a NACK. Some people had the NACK and some people didn't. This fire extinguisher was a little older than others he (NACK) had seen -- the one in the nursery school, for instance -- but that was not so unusual. Nonetheless it filled him (NACK) with faint unease, curled up there against the light blue wallpaper like a sleeping snake. And he (NACK) was glad when it was out of sight around the corner.
``Of course all the windows have to be shuttered,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Mr. Ullman said as they stepped back into the elevator. Once again the car sank queasily beneath their feet.
``But I'm particularly concerned about the one in the Presidential Suite. The original bill on that window was four hundred and twenty dollars, and that was over thirty years ago. It would cost eight times that to replace today.'' (unknown)

``I'll shutter it,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said. They went down to the second floor where there were more rooms and even more twists and turns in the corridor. The light from the windows had begun to fade appreciably now as the sun went behind the mountains. Mr. Ullman showed them one or two rooms and that was all. He (Ullman) walked past 217, the one Dick Hallorann had warned him (Hallorann) about, without slowing. Danny looked at the bland number-plate on the door with uneasy fascination. Then down to the first floor. Mr. Ullman didn't show them into any rooms here until they had almost reached the thickly carpeted staircase that led down into the lobby again.
``Here are your quarters,'' (he)
he (Ullman) said.
``I think you'll find them adequate.'' (unknown)
They went in. Danny was braced for whatever might be there. There was nothing. Wendy Torrance felt a strong surge of relief. The Presidential Suite, with its cold elegance, had made her (Torrance) feel awkward and clumsy -- it was all very well to visit some restored historical building with a bedroom plaque that announced Abraham Lincoln or Franklin D. Roosevelt had slept there, but another thing entirely to imagine you and your husband lying beneath acreages of linen and perhaps making love where the greatest men in the world had once lain -LRB-the most powerful, anyway, she (Torrance) amended-RRB-. But this apartment was simpler, homier, almost inviting. She (Torrance) thought she (Torrance) could abide this place for a season with no great difficulty.
``It's very pleasant,'' (she)
she (Torrance) said to Ullman, and heard the gratitude in her (Torrance) voice. Ullman nodded.
``Simple but adequate. During the season, this suite quarters the cook and his (cook) wife, or the cook and his (cook) apprentice.'' (unknown)
``Mr. Hallorann lived here?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny broke in. Mr. Ullman inclined his (Ullman) head to Danny condescendingly.
``Quite so. He (Hallorann) and Mr. Nevers.'' (He)
He (Ullman) turned back to Jack and Wendy.
``This is the sitting room.'' (Detective)
There were several chairs that looked comfortable but not expensive, a coffee table that had once been expensive but now had a long chip gone from the side, two bookcases -LRB-stuffed full of Reader's Digest Condensed Books and Detective Book Club trilogies from the forties, Wendy saw with some amusement-RRB-, and an anonymous hotel TV that looked much less elegant than the buffed wood consoles in the rooms.
``No kitchen, of course,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said,
``but there is a dumb-waiter. This apartment is directly over the kitchen.'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
He (Ullman) slid aside a square of paneling and disclosed a wide, squarer tray. He (Ullman) gave it a push and it disappeared, trailing rope behind it.
``It's a secret passage!'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said excitedly to his (Danny) mother, momentarily forgetting all fears in favor of that intoxicating shaft behind the wall.
``Just like in Abbott and Costello Meet the Monsters!'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Mr. Ullman frowned but Wendy smiled indulgently. Danny ran over to the dumbwaiter and peered down the shaft.,
``This way, please.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
He (Danny) opened the door on the far side of the living room. It gave on the bedroom, which was spacious and airy. There were twin beds. Wendy looked at her (Wendy) husband, smiled, shrugged.
``No problem,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``We'll push them together.'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)

Mr. Ullman looked over his (Ullman) shoulder, honestly puzzled.

``Beg pardon?'' (unknown)
``The beds,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said pleasantly.
``We can push them together.'' (unknown)
``Oh, quite,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said, momentarily confused. Then his (Ullman) face cleared and a red flush began to creep up from the collar of his (Ullman) shirt.
``Whatever you like.'' (He)
He (Ullman) led them back into the sitting room, where a second door opened on a second bedroom, this one equipped with bunk beds. A radiator clanked in one corner, and the rug on the floor was a hideous embroidery of western sage and cactus -- Danny bad already fallen in love with it, Wendy saw. The walls of this smaller room were paneled in real pine.
``Think you can stand it in here, doc?'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack asked.
``Sure I can. I'm going to sleep in the top bunk. Okay?'' (unknown)
``If that's what you want.'' (unknown)
