Mr. Ullman looked for a moment as if he (Ullman) had sunk his (Ullman) teeth into a lemon. Then he (Ullman) smiled and patted Danny's head.
``Those are your quarters,'' (he)
he (Danny) said,
``except for the bath, which opens off the main bedroom. It's not a huge apartment, but of course you'll have the rest of the hotel to spread out in. The lobby fireplace is in good working order, or so Watson tells me, and you must feel free to eat in the dining room if the spirit moves you to do so.'' (he)
He (Danny) spoke in the tone of a man conferring a great favor.
``All right,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``Shall we go down?'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Mr. Ullman asked.
``Fine,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said. They went downstairs in the elevator, and now the lobby was wholly deserted except for Watson, who was leaning against the main doors in a rawhide jacket, a toothpick between his (Watson) lips.
``I would have thought you'd be miles from here by now,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Mr. Ullman said, his (Ullman) voice slightly chill.
``Just stuck around to remind Mr. Torrance here about the boiler,'' (Watson/Mr. Watson)
Watson said, straightening up.
``Keep your good weather eye on her (you), fella, and she (you)'ll be fine. Knock the press down a couple of times a day. She (you) creeps.'' (She)
She (Wendy) creeps, Danny thought, and the words echoed down a long and silent corridor in his (Danny) mind, a corridor lined with mirrors where people seldom looked.
``I will,'' (daddy)
his (Danny) daddy said.
``You'll be fine,'' (Watson/Mr. Watson)
Watson said, and offered Jack his (Watson) hand. Jack shook it. Watson turned to Wendy and inclined his (Watson) head.
``Ma'am,'' (he)
he (Watson) said.
``I'm pleased,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said, and thought it would sound absurd. It didn't. She (Wendy) had come out here from New England, where she (Wendy) had spent her (Wendy) life, and it seemed to her (Wendy) that in a few short sentences this man Watson, with his (Watson) fluffy fringe of hair, had epitomized what the West was supposed to be all about. And never mind the lecherous wink earlier.
``Young master Torrance,'' (Watson/Mr. Watson)
Watson said gravely, and put out his (Watson) hand. Danny, who had known all about handshaking for almost a year now, put his (Danny) own hand out gingerly and felt it swallowed up.
``You take good care of em, Dan.'' (unknown)
``Yes, sir.'' (Watson/Mr. Watson)
Watson let go of Danny's hand and straightened up fully. He (Watson) looked at Ullman.
``Until next year, I guess,'' (he)
he (Ullman) said, and held his (Ullman) hand out. Ullman touched it bloodlessly. His (Ullman) pinky ring caught the lobby's electric

lights in a baleful sort of wink.

``May twelfth, Watson,'' (he)
he (Ullman) said.
``Not a day earlier or later.'' (unknown)
``Yes, sir,'' (Watson/Mr. Watson)
Watson said, and Jack could almost read the codicil in Watson's mind: ... you fucking little faggot.
``Have a good winter, Mr. Ullman.'' (unknown)
``Oh, I doubt it,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said remotely. Watson opened one of the two big main doors; the wind whined louder and began to flutter the collar of his (Watson) jacket.
``You folks take care now,'' (he)
he (Watson) said. It was Danny who answered.
``Yes, sir, we will.'' (Watson/Mr. Watson)
Watson, whose not-so-distant ancestor had owned this place, slipped humbly through the door. It closed behind him (Watson), muffling the wind. Together they watched him (Watson) clop down the porch's broad front steps in his (Watson) battered black cowboy boots. Brittle yellow aspen leaves tumbled around his (Watson) heels as he (Watson) crossed the lot to his (Watson) International Harvester pickup and climbed in. Blue smoke jetted from the rusted exhaust pipe as he (Watson) started it up. The spell of silence held among them as he (Watson) backed, then pulled out of the parking lot. His (Watson) truck disappeared over the brow of the hill and then reappeared, smaller, on the main road, heading west. For a moment Danny felt more lonely than he (Danny) ever had in his (Danny) life.

<< 13 >> THE FRONT PORCH The Torrance family stood together on the long front porch of the Overlook Hotel as if posing for a family portrait, Danny in the middle, zippered into last year's fall jacket which was now too small and starting to come out at the elbow, Wendy behind him (Danny) with one hand on his (Danny) shoulder, and Jack to his (Jack) left, his (Jack) own hand resting lightly on his (Jack) son's head. Mr. Ullman was a step below them, buttoned into an expensive-looking brown mohair overcoat. The sun was entirely behind the mountains now, edging them with gold fire, making the shadows around things look long and purple. The only three vehicles left in the parking lots were the hotel truck, Ullman's Lincoln Continental, and the battered Torrance VW.

``You've got your keys, then,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman said to Jack,
``and you understand fully about the furnace and the boiler?'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack nodded, feeling some real sympathy for Ullman. Everything was done for the season, the ball of string was neatly wrapped up until next May 12 -- not a day earlier or later -- and Ullman, who was responsible for all of it and who referred to the hotel in the unmistakable tones of infatuation, could not help looking for loose ends.
``I think everything is well in hand,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``Good. I'll be in touch.'' (he)
But he (Jack) still lingered for a moment, as if waiting

for the wind to take a hand and perhaps gust him (Jack) down to his (Jack) car. He (Jack) sighed.

``All right. Have a good winter, Mr. Torrance, Mrs. Torrance. You too, Danny.'' (unknown)
``Thank you, sir,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said.
``I hope you do, too.'' (unknown)
``I doubt it,'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman repeated, and he (Ullman) sounded sad.
``The place in Florida is a dump, if the out-and-out truth is to be spoken. Busywork. The Overlook is my real job. Take good care of it for me, Mr. Torrance.'' (unknown)
``I think it will be here when you get back next spring,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said, and a thought flashed through Danny's mind -LRB-but will we?-RRB- and was gone.
``Of course. Of course it will.'' (Ullman/Mr. Ullman)
Ullman looked out toward the playground where the hedge animals were clattering in the wind. Then he (Ullman) nodded once more in a businesslike way.
``Good-by, then.'' (He)
He (Ullman) walked quickly and prissily across to his (Ullman) car--a ridiculously big one for such a little man and tucked himself into it. The Lincoln's motor purred into life and the taillights flashed as he (Ullman) pulled out of his (Ullman) parking stall. As the car moved away, Jack could read the small sign at the head of the stall: RESERVED FOR MR. ULLMAN, MGR.
``Right,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said softly. They watched until the car was out of sight, headed down the eastern slope. When it was gone, the three of them looked at each other for a silent, almost frightened moment. They were alone. Aspen leaves whirled and skittered in aimless packs across the lawn that was now neatly mowed and tended for no guest's eyes. There was no one to see the autumn leaves steal across the grass but the three of them. It gave Jack a curious shrinking feeling, as if his (Jack) life force had dwindled to a mere spark while the hotel and the grounds had suddenly doubled in size and become sinister, dwarfing them with sullen, inanimate power. Then Wendy said:
``Look at you, doc. Your nose is running like a fire hose. Let's get inside.'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
And they did, closing the door firmly behind them against the restless whine of the wind.

PART THREE -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- The Wasps' Nest -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- --

<< 14 >> UP ON THE ROOF

``Oh you goddam fucking son of a bitch!'' (The Wasps)
Jack Torrance cried these words out in both surprise and agony as he (Torrance) slapped his (Torrance) right hand against his (Torrance) blue chambray workshirt, dislodging the big, slowmoving wasp that had stung him (Torrance). Then he (Torrance) was scrambling up the roof as fast as he (Torrance) could, looking back over his (Torrance) shoulder to see if the wasp's brothers and sisters were rising from the nest he (Torrance) had uncovered to do battle. If they were, it could be bad; the nest was between him (Torrance) and his (Torrance) ladder, and the trapdoor leading down into the attic was locked from the inside. The drop was seventy feet from the roof to the cement patio between the hotel and the lawn. The clear air above the nest was still and undisturbed. Jack whistled disgustedly between his (Jack) teeth, sat straddling the peak of the roof, and examined his (Jack) right index finger. It was swelling already, and he (Jack) supposed he (Jack) would have to try and creep past that nest to his (Jack) ladder so he (Jack) could go down and put some ice on it. It was October 20. Wendy and Danny had gone down to Sidewinder in the hotel truck -LRB-an elderly, rattling Dodge that was still more trustworthy than the VW, which was now wheezing gravely and seemed terminal-RRB- to get three gallons of milk and do some Christmas shopping. It was early to shop, but there was no telling when the snow would come to stay. There had already been flurries, and in some places the road down from the Overlook was slick with patch ice. So far the fall had been almost preternaturally beautiful. In the three weeks they had been here, golden day had followed golden day. Crisp, thirty-degree mornings gave way to afternoon temperatures in the low sixties, the perfect temperature for climbing around on the Overlook's gently sloping western roof and doing the shingling. Jack had admitted freely to Wendy that he (Jack) could have finished the job four days ago, but he (Jack) felt no real urge to hurry. The view from up here was spectacular, even putting the vista from the Presidential Suite in the shade. More important, the work itself was soothing. On the roof he (Jack) felt himself healing from the troubled wounds of the last three years. On the roof he (Jack) felt at peace. Those three years began to seem like a turbulent nightmare. The shingles had been badly rotted, some of them blown entirely away by last winter's storms. He (Jack) had ripped them all up, yelling
``Bombs away!'' (He)
as he (Jack) dropped them over the side, not wanting Danny to get hit in case he (Danny) had wandered over. He (Danny) had been pulling out bad flashing when the wasp had gotten him (Danny). The ironic part was that he (Danny) warned himself each time he (Danny) climbed onto the roof to keep an eye out for nests; he (Danny) had gotten that bug bomb just in case. But this morning the stillness and peace had been so complete that his (Danny) watchfulness had

lapsed. He (Danny) had been back in the world of the play he (Danny) was slowly creating, roughing out whatever scene he (Danny) would be working on that evening in his (Danny) head. The play was going very well, and although Wendy had said little, he (Danny) knew she (Wendy) was pleased. He (Danny) had been roadblocked on the crucial scene between Denker, the sadistic headmaster, and Gary Benson, his (Benson) young hero, during the last unhappy six months at Stovington, months when the craving for a drink had been so bad that he (Benson) could barely concentrate on his (Benson) in-class lectures, let alone his (Benson) extracurricular literary ambitions. But in the last twelve evenings, as he (Benson) actually sat down in front of the office-model Underwood he (Underwood) had borrowed from the main office downstairs, the roadblock had disappeared under his (Underwood) fingers as magically as cotton candy dissolves on the lips. He (Underwood) had come up almost effortlessly with the insights into Denker's character that had always been lacking, and he (Denker) had rewritten most of the second act accordingly, making it revolve around the new scene. And the progress of the third act, which he (Denker) had been turning over in his (Denker) mind when the wasp put an end to cogitation, was coming clearer all the time. He (Denker) thought he (Denker) could rough it out in two weeks, and have a clean copy of the whole damned play by New Year's. He (Denker) had an agent in New York, a tough red-headed woman named Phyllis Sandler who smoked Herbert Tareytons, drank Jim Beam from a paper cup, and thought the literary sun rose and set on Sean O'Casey. She (Phyllis) had marketed three of Jack's short stories, including the Esquire piece. He (Jack) had written her (Phyllis) about the play, which was called The Little School, describing the basic conflict between Denker, a gifted student who had failed into becoming the brutal and brutalizing headmaster of a turn-of-the-century New England prep school, and Gary Benson, the student he (Benson) sees as a younger version of himself. Phyllis had written back expressing interest and admonishing him (Benson) to read O'Casey before sitting down to it. She (Phyllis) had written again earlier that year asking where the hell was the play? He (Benson) had written back wryly that The Little School had been indefinitely -- and perhaps infinitely -- delayed between hand and page

``in that interesting intellectual Gobi known as the writer's block.'' (Little School)
Now it looked as if she (Phyllis) might actually get the play. Whether or not it was any good or if it would ever see actual production was another matter. And he (Benson) didn't seem to care a great deal about those things. He (Benson) felt in a way that the play itself, the whole thing, was the roadblock, a colossal symbol of the bad years at Stovington Prep, the marriage he (Benson) had almost totaled like a nutty kid behind the wheel of an old jalopy, the monstrous assault on his (Benson) son, the incident in the parking lot with George Hatfield, an incident he (Hatfield) could no longer view as just another sudden and destructive flare of temper. He (Hatfield) now thought that part of his (Hatfield) drinking problem had stemmed from an unconscious desire to be free of Stovington and the security he (Hatfield) felt was stifling whatever creative urge he (Hatfield) had. He (Hatfield) had stopped drinking, but the need to be free had been just as great. Hence George Hatfield. Now all that remained of those days was the play on the desk in his (Hatfield) and Wendy's bedroom, and when it was done and sent off to Phyllis's hole-in-the-wall New York agency, he (Hatfield) could turn to other things. Not a novel, he (Hatfield) was not ready to stumble into the swamp of another three-year undertaking, but surely more short stories. Perhaps a book of them. Moving warily, he (Hatfield) scrambled back down the slope of the roof on his (Hatfield) hands and

knees past the line of demarcation where the fresh green Bird shingles gave way to the section of roof he (Hatfield) had just finished clearing. He (Hatfield) came to the edge on the left of the wasps' nest he (Hatfield) had uncovered and moved gingerly toward it, ready to backtrack and bolt down his (Hatfield) ladder to the ground if things looked too hot. He (Hatfield) leaned over the section of pulled-out flashing and looked in. The nest was in there, tucked into the space between the old flashing and the final roof undercoating of three-by-fives. It was a damn big one. The grayish paper ball looked to Jack as if it might be nearly two feet through the center. Its shape was not perfect because the space between the flashing and the boards was too narrow, but he (Jack) thought the little buggers had still done a pretty respectable job. The surface of the nest was acrawl with the lumbering, slowmoving insects. They were the big mean ones, not yellow jackets, which are smaller and calmer, but wall wasps. They had been rendered sludgy and stupid by the fall temperatures, but Jack, who knew about wasps from his (Jack) childhood, counted himself lucky that he (Jack) had been stung only once. And, he (Jack) thought, if Ullman had hired the job done in the height of summer, the workman who tore up that particular section of the flashing would have gotten one hell of a surprise. Yes indeedy. When a dozen wall wasps land on you all at once and start stinging your face and hands and arms, stinging your legs right through your pants, it would be entirely possible to forget you were seventy feet up. You might just charge right off the edge of the roof while you were trying to get away from them. All from those little things, the biggest of them only half the length of a pencil stub. He (your) had read someplace -- in a Sunday supplement piece or a back-of-the-book newsmagazine article -- that 7 per cent of all automobile fatalities go unexplained. No mechanical failure, no excessive speed, no booze, no bad weather. Simply one-car crashes on deserted sections of road, one dead occupant, the driver, unable to explain what had happened to him (driver). The article had included an interview with a state trooper who theorized that many of these so-called

``foo crashes'' (a state trooper)
resulted from insects in the car. Wasps, a bee, possibly even a spider or moth. The driver gets panicky, tries to swat it or unroll a window to let it out. Possibly the insect stings him (driver). Maybe the driver just loses control. Either way it's bang! ... all over. And the insect, usually completely unharmed, would buzz merrily out of the smoking wreck, looking for greener pastures. The trooper had been in favor of having pathologists look for insect venom while autopsying such victims, Jack recalled. Now, looking down into the nest, it seemed to him (Jack) that it could serve as both a workable symbol for what he (Jack) had been through -LRB-and what he (Jack) had dragged his (Jack) hostages to fortune through-RRB- and an omen for a better future. How else could you explain the things that had happened to him (Jack)? For he (Jack) still felt that the whole range of unhappy Stovington experiences had to be looked at with Jack Torrance in the passive mode. He (Torrance) had not done things; things had been done to him (Torrance). He (Torrance) had known plenty of people on the Stovington faculty, two of them right in the English Department, who were hard drinkers. Zack Tunney was in the habit of picking up a full keg of beer on Saturday afternoon, plonking it in a backyard snowbank overnight, and then killing damn near all of it on Sunday watching football games and old movies. Yet through the week Zack was as sober as a judge -- a weak cocktail with lunch was an occasion.

He (Zack) and Al Shockley had been alcoholics. They had sought each other out like two castoffs who were still social enough to prefer drowning together to doing it alone. The sea had been whole-grain instead of salt, that was all. Looking down at the wasps, as they slowly went about their instinctual business before winter closed down to kill all but their hibernating queen, he (Zack) would go further. He (Zack) was still an alcoholic, always would be, perhaps had been since Sophomore Class Night in high school when he (Sophomore) had taken his (Sophomore) first drink. It had nothing to do with willpower, or the morality of drinking, or the weakness or strength of his (Sophomore) own character. There was a broken switch somewhere inside, or a circuit breaker that didn't work, and he (Sophomore) had been propelled down the chute willynilly, slowly at first, then accelerating as Stovington applied its pressures on him (Sophomore). A big grease& slide and at the bottom had been a shattered, ownerless bicycle and a son with a broken arm. Jack Torrance in the passive mode. And his (Torrance) temper, same thing. All his (Torrance) life he (Torrance) had been trying unsuccessfully to control it. He (Torrance) could remember himself at seven, spanked by a neighbor lady for playing with matches. He (Torrance) had gone out and hurled a rock at a passing car. His (Torrance) father had seen that, and he (Torrance) had descended on little Jacky, roaring. He (Torrance) had reddened Jack's behind ... and then blacked his (Jack) eye. And when his (Jack) father had gone into the house, muttering, to see what was on television, Jack had come upon a stray dog and had kicked it into the gutter. There had been two dozen fights in grammar school, even more of them in high school, warranting two suspensions and uncounted detentions in spite of his (Jack) good grades. Football had provided a partial safety valve, although he (Jack) remembered perfectly well that he (Jack) had spent almost every minute of every game in a state of high piss-off, taking every opposing block and tackle personally. He (Jack) had been a fine player, making All-Conference in his (Jack) junior and senior years, and he (Jack) knew perfectly well that he (Jack) had his (Jack) own bad temper to thank ... or to blame. He (Jack) had not enjoyed football. Every game was a grudge match. And yet, through it all, he (Jack) hadn't felt like a son of a bitch. He (Jack) hadn't felt mean. He (Jack) had always regarded himself as Jack Torrance, a really nice guy who was just going to have to learn how to cope with his (Torrance) temper someday before it got him (Torrance) in trouble. The same way he (Torrance) was going to have to learn how to cope with his (Torrance) drinking. But he (Torrance) had been an emotional alcoholic just as surely as he (Torrance) had been a physical one the two of them were no doubt tied together somewhere deep inside him (Torrance), where you'd just as soon not look. But it didn't much matter to him (Torrance) if the root causes were interrelated or separate, sociological or psychological or physiological. He (Torrance) had had to deal with the results: the spankings, the beatings from his (Torrance) old man, the suspensions, with trying to explain the school clothes torn in playground brawls, and later the hangovers, the slowly dissolving glue of his (Torrance) marriage, the single bicycle wheel with its bent spokes pointing into the sky, Danny's broken arm. And George Hatfield, of course. He (Hatfield) felt that he (Hatfield) had unwittingly stuck his (Hatfield) hand into The Great Wasps' Nest of Life. As an image it stank. As a cameo of reality, he (Hatfield) felt it was serviceable. He (Hatfield) had stuck his (Hatfield) hand through some rotted flashing in high summer and that hand and his (Hatfield) whole arm had been consumed in holy, righteous fire, destroying conscious thought, making the concept of civilized behavior obsolete. Could you be expected to behave as a thinking human being when your hand was being impaled on red-hot darning needles? Could you be expected to live in the love of your

nearest and dearest when the brown, furious cloud rose out of the hole in the fabric of things -LRB-the fabric you thought was so innocent-RRB- and arrowed straight at you? Could you be held responsible for your own actions as you ran crazily about on the sloping roof seventy feet above the ground, not knowing where you were going, not remembering that your panicky, stumbling feet could lead you crashing and blundering right over the rain gutter and down to your death on the concrete seventy feet below? Jack didn't think you could. When you unwittingly stuck your hand into the wasps' nest, you hadn't made a covenant with the devil to give up your civilized self with its trappings of love and respect and honor. It just happened to you. Passively, with no say, you ceased to be a creature of the mind and became a creature of the nerve endings; from college-educated man to wailing ape in five easy seconds. He (man) thought about George Hatfield. Tall and shaggily blond, George had been an almost insolently beautiful boy. In his (George) tight faded jeans and Stovington sweatshirt with the sleeves carelessly pushed up to the elbows to disclose his (George) tanned forearms, he (George) had reminded Jack of a young Robert Redford, and he (Redford) doubted that George had much trouble scoring -- no more than that young footballplaying devil Jack Torrance had ten years earlier. He (Torrance) could say that he (Torrance) honestly didn't feel jealous of George, or envy him (George) his (George) good looks; in fact, he (George) had almost unconsciously begun to visualize George as the physical incarnation of his (George) play hero, Gary Benson -- the perfect foil for the dark, slumped, and aging Denker, who grew to hate Gary so much. But he (Gary), Jack Torrance, had never felt that way about George. If he (George) had, he (George) would have known it. He (George) was quite sure of that. George had floated through his (George) classes at Stovington. A soccer and baseball star, his (George) academic program had been fairly undemanding and he (George) had been content with C's and an occasional B in history or botany. He (George) was a fierce field contender but a lackadaisical, amused sort of student in the classrooms. Jack was familiar with the type, more from his (Jack) own days as a high school and college student than from his (Jack) teaching experience, which was at second hand. George Hatfield was a jock. He (Hatfield) could be a calm, undemanding figure in the classroom, but when the right set of competitive stimuli was applied -LRB-like electrodes to the temples of Frankenstein's monster, Jack thought wryly-RRB-, he (Jack) could become a juggernaut. In January, George had tried out with two dozen others for the debate team. He (George) had been quite frank with Jack. His (Jack) father was a corporation lawyer, and he (Jack) wanted his (Jack) son to follow in his (Jack) footsteps. George, who felt no burning call to do anything else, was willing. His (George) grades were not top end, but this was, after all, only prep school and it was still early times. If should be came to must be, his (George) father could pull some strings. George's own athletic ability would open still other doors. But Brian Hatfield thought his (Hatfield) son should get on the debate team. It was good practice, and it was something that law-school admissions boards always looked for. So George went out for debate, and in late March Jack cut him (George) from the team. The late winter inter-squad debates had fired George Hatfield's competitive soul. He (Hatfield) became a grimly determined debater, prepping his (Hatfield) pro or con position fiercely. It didn't matter if the subject was legalization of marijuana, reinstating the death penalty, or the oil-depletion allowance. George became

conversant, and he (George) was just jingoist enough to honestly not care which side he (George) was on--a rare and valuable trait, even in high-level debaters, Jack knew. The souls of a true carpetbagger and a true debater were not far removed from each other; they were both passionately interested in the main chance. So far, so good. But George Hatfield stuttered. This was not a handicap that had even shown up in the classroom, where George was always cool and collected -LRB-whether he (George) had done his (George) homework or not-RRB-, and certainly not on the Stovington playing fields, where talk was not a virtue and they sometimes even threw you out of the game for too much discussion. When George got tightly wound up in a debate, the stutter would come out. The more eager he (George) became, the worse it was. And when he (George) felt he (George) had an opponent dead in his (George) sights, an intellectual sort of buck fever seemed to take place between his (George) speech centers and his (George) mouth and he (George) would freeze solid while the clock ran out. It was painful to watch.

``S-S-So I th-th-think we have to say that the fuh-fuh-facts in the c-case Mr. D-D-D-Dorsky cites are ren-ren-rendered obsolete by the ruh-recent duh-duhdecision handed down inin-in ... '' (George/George Hatfield/Hatfield)
The buzzer would go off and George would whirl around to stare furiously at Jack, who sat beside it. George's face at those moments would be flushed, his (George) notes crumpled spasmodically in one hand. Jack had held on to George long after he (George) had cut most of the obvious flat tires, hoping George would work out. He (George) remembered one late afternoon about a week before he (George) had reluctantly dropped the ax. George had stayed after the others had filed out, and then had confronted Jack angrily.
``You s-set the timer ahead.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack looked up from the papers he (Jack) was putting back into his (Jack) briefcase.
``George, what are you talking about?'' (unknown)
``I d-didn't get my whole five mih-minutes. You set it ahead. I was wuhwatching the clock.'' (unknown)
``The clock and the timer may keep slightly different times, George, but I never touched the dial on the damned thing. Scout's honor.'' (unknown)
``Yuh-yuh-you did!'' (I)
The belligerent, I'm-sticking-up-for-my-rights way George was looking at him (George) had sparked Jack's own temper. He (George) had been off the sauce for two months, two months too long, and he (George) was ragged. He (George) made one last effort to hold himself in.
``I assure you I did not, George. It's your stutter. Do you have any idea what causes it? You don't stutter in class.'' (unknown)
``I duh-duh-don't s-s-st-st-stutterl'' (unknown)
``Lower your voice.'' (unknown)
``You w-want to g-get me! You duh-don't w-want me on your g-g-goddam team!'' (unknown)
``Lower your voice, I said. Let's discuss this rationally.'' (unknown)
``F-fuh-fuck th-that!'' (unknown)
``George, if you control your stutter, I'd be glad to have you. You're well prepped for every practice and you're good at the background stuff, which means you're rarely surprised. But all that doesn't mean much if you can't control that--'' (he)
``I've neh-neh-never stuttered!'' (he)
he (George) cried out.
``It's yuh-you! I-i-if suhsomeone else had the d-d-deb-debate t-team, I could -- '' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)

Jack's temper slipped another notch.

``George, you're never going to make much of a lawyer, corporation or otherwise, if you can't control that. Law isn't like soccer. Two hours of practice every night won't cut it. What are you going to do, stand up in front of a board meeting and say, `Nuh-nuh-now, g-gentlemen, about this t-ttort'?'' (He)
He (Jack) suddenly flushed, not with anger but with shame at his (Jack) own cruelty. This was not a man in front of him (Jack) but a seventeen-year-old boy who was facing the first major defeat of his (Jack) life, and maybe asking in the only way he (Jack) could for Jack to help him (Jack) find a way to cope with it. George gave him (George) a final, furious glance, his (George) lips twisting and bucking as the words bottled up behind them struggled to find their way out.
``Yuh-yuh-you s-s-set it ahead! You huh-hate me b-because you nuh-nuh-nuh-know ... you know ... nuh-nuh -- '' (he)
With an articulate cry he (George) had rushed out of the classroom, slamming the door hard enough to make the wire-reinforced glass rattle in its frame. Jack had stood there, feeling, rather than hearing, the echo of George's Adidas in the empty hall. Still in the grip of his (George) temper and his (George) shame at mocking George's stutter, his (George) first thought had been a sick sort of exultation: For the first time in his (George) life George Hatfield had wanted something he (George) could not have. For the first time there was something wrong that all of Daddy's money could not fix. You couldn't bribe a speech center. You couldn't offer a tongue an extra fifty a week and a bonus at Christmas if it would agree to stop flapping like a record needle in a defective groove. Then the exultation was simply buried in shame, and he (George) felt the way he (George) had after he (George) had broken Danny's arm. Dear God, I am not a son of a bitch. Please. That sick happiness at George's retreat was more typical of Denker in the play than of Jack Torrance the playwright. You hate me because you know ... Because he (Torrance) knew what? What could he (Torrance) possibly know about George Hatfield that would make him (Hatfield) hate him (Hatfield)? That his (Hatfield) whole future lay ahead of him (Hatfield)? That he (Hatfield) looked a little bit like Robert Redford and all conversation among the girls stopped when he (Redford) did a double gainer from the pool diving board? That he (Redford) played soccer and baseball with a natural, unlearned grace? Ridiculous. Absolutely absurd. He (Redford) envied George Hatfield nothing. If the truth was known, he (Redford) felt worse about George's unfortunate stutter than George himself, because George really would have made an excellent debater. And if Jack had set the timer ahead -- and of course he (Jack) hadn't -- it would have been because both he (Jack) and the other members of the squad were embarrassed for George's struggle, they had agonized over it the way you agonize when the Class Night speaker forgets some of his (speaker) lines. If he (speaker) had set the timer ahead, it would have been just to ... to put George out of his (George) misery. But he (George) hadn't set the timer ahead. He (George) was quite sure of it. A week later he (George) had cut him (George), and that time he (George) had kept his (George) temper. The shouts and the threats had all been on George's side. A week after that he (George) had gone out to the parking lot halfway through practice to get a pile of sourcebooks that he (George) had left in the trunk of the VW and there had been George, down on one knee with his (George) long blond hair swinging in his (George) face, a hunting knife in one hand. He (George) was

sawing through the VW's right front tire. The back tires were already shredded, and the bug sat on the flats like a small, tired dog. Jack had seen red, and remembered very little of the encounter that followed. He (Jack) remembered a thick growl that seemed to issue from his (Jack) own throat:

``All right, George. If that's how you want it, just come here and take your medicine.'' (He)
He (Jack) remembered George looking up, startled and fearful. He (George) had said:
``Mr. Torrance -- '' (He)
as if to explain how all this was just a mistake, the tires had been flat when he (George) got there and he (George) was just cleaning dirt out of the front treads with the tip of this gutting knife he (George) just happened to have with him (George) and -- Jack had waded in, his (Jack) fists held up in front of him (Jack), and it seemed that he (Jack) had been grinning. But he (Jack) wasn't sure of that. The last thing be remembered was George holding up the knife and saying:
``You better not come any closer -- '' (George/George Hatfield/Hatfield)
And the next thing was Miss Strong, the French teacher, holding Jack's arms, crying, screaming:
``Stop it, Jack! Stop it! You're going to kill him (Jack)!'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
He (Jack) had blinked around stupidly. There was the hunting knife, glittering harmlessly on the parking lot asphalt four yards away. There was his (Jack) Volkswagen, his (Jack) poor old battered bug, veteran of many wild midnight drunken rides, sitting on three flat shoes. There was a new dent in the right front fender, he (dent) saw, and there was something in the middle of the dent that was either red paint or blood. For a moment he (dent) had been confused, his (dent) thoughts -LRB-jesus christ al we hit him (dent) after all-RRB- of that other night. Then his (dent) eyes had shifted to George, George lying dazed and blinking on the asphalt. His (George) debate group had come out and they were huddled together by the door, staring at George. There was blood on his (George) face from a scalp laceration that looked minor, but there was also blood running out of one of George's ears and that probably meant a concussion. When George tried to get up, Jack shook free of Miss Strong and went to him (George). George cringed. Jack put his (George) hands on George's chest and pushed him (George) back down.
``Lie still,'' (he)
he (George) said.
``Don't try to move.'' (He)
He (George) turned to Miss Strong, who was staring at them both with horror.
``Please go call the school doctor, Miss Strong,'' (her)
be told her (Jack). She (Jack) turned and fled toward the office. He (George) looked at his (George) debate class then, looked them right in the eye because he (George) was in charge again, fully himself, and when he (George) was himself there wasn't a nicer guy in the whole state of Vermont. Surely they knew that.
``You can go home now,'' (he)
he (guy) told them quietly.
``We'll meet again tomorrow.'' (debaters)
But by the end of that week six of his (guy) debaters had dropped out, two of them the class of the act, but of course it didn't matter much because he (guy) had been informed by then that he (guy) would be dropping out himself. Yet somehow he (guy) had stayed off the bottle, and he (guy) supposed that was something. And he (guy) had not hated George Hatfield. He (guy) was sure of that. He (guy) had not acted but had been acted upon. You hate me because you know ... But he (guy) had known nothing. Nothing. He (guy) would swear that before the Throne of Almighty God, just as he (God) would swear that he (God) had set the timer ahead no more than a minute. And not out of hate but out of pity. Two wasps were crawling sluggishly about on the roof beside the hole in the

flashing. He (God) watched them until they spread their aerodynamically unsound but strangely efficient wings and lumbered off into the October sunshine, perchance to sting someone else. God had seen fit to give them stingers and Jack supposed they had to use them on somebody. How long had he (Jack) been sitting there, looking at that hole with its unpleasant surprise down inside, raking over old coals? He (Jack) looked at his (Jack) watch. Almost half an hour. He (Jack) let himself down to the edge of the roof, dropped one leg over, and felt around until his (Jack) foot found the top rung of the ladder just below the overhang. He (Jack) would go down to the equipment shed where he (Jack) had stored the bug bomb on a high shelf out of Danny's reach. He (Danny) would get it, come back up, and then they would be the ones surprised. You could be stung, but you could also sting back. He (Danny) believed that sincerely. Two hours from now the nest would be just so much chewed paper and Danny could have it in his (Danny) room if he (Danny) wanted to -- Jack had had one in his (Jack) room when he (Jack) was just a kid, it had always smelled faintly of woodsmoke and gasoline. He (Jack) could have it right by the head of his (Jack) bed. It wouldn't hurt him (Jack).

``I'm getting better.'' (him)
The sound of his (Jack) own voice, confident in the silent afternoon, reassured him (Jack) even though he (Jack) hadn't meant to speak aloud. He (Jack) was getting better. It was possible to graduate from passive to active, to take the thing that had once driven you nearly to madness as a neutral prize of no more than occasional academic interest. And if there was a place where the thing could be done, this was surely it. He (Jack) went down the ladder to get the bug bomb. They would pay. They would pay for stinging him (Jack).

<< 15 >> DOWN IN THE FRONT YARD Jack had found a huge white-painted wicker chair in the back of the equipment shed two weeks ago, and had dragged it around to the porch over Wendy's objections that it was really the ugliest thing she (Wendy) had ever seen in her (Wendy) whole life. He (Jack) was sitting in it now, amusing himself with a copy of E. L. Doctorow's Welcome to Hard Times, when his (L.) wife and son rattled up the driveway in the hotel truck. Wendy parked it in the turn-around, raced the engine sportily, and then turned it off. The truck's single taillight died. The engine rumbled grumpily with post-ignition and finally stopped. Jack got out of his (Jack) chair and ambled down to meet them.

``Hi, Dad!'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny called, and raced up the hill. He (Danny) had a box in one hand.
``Look what Mommy bought me!'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack picked his (Jack) son up, swung him (Jack) around twice, and kissed him (Jack) heartily on the mouth.
``Jack Torrance, the Eugene O'Neill of his (O'Neill) generation, the American Shakespeare!'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said, smiling.
``Fancy meeting you here, so far up in the mountains.'' (unknown)
``The common ruck became too much for me, dear lady,'' (he)
he (Jack) said, and slipped his (Jack) arms around her (Wendy). They kissed.
``How was your trip?'' (unknown)
``Very good. Danny complains that I keep jerking him (Danny) but I didn't stall the truck once and ... oh, Jack, you finished it!'' (She)
She (Wendy) was looking at the roof, and Danny followed her (Wendy) gaze. A faint frown touched his (Danny) face as he (Danny) looked at the wide swatch of fresh shingles atop the Overlook's west wing, a lighter green than the rest of the roof. Then he (Danny) looked down at the box in his (Danny) hand and his (Danny) face cleared again. At night the pictures Tony had showed him (Tony) came back to haunt in all their original clarity, but in sunny daylight they were easier to disregard.
``Look, Daddy, look!'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack took the box from his (Jack) son. It was a model car, one of the Big Daddy Roth caricatures that Danny bad expressed an admiration for in the past. This one was the Violent Violet Volkswagen, and the picture on the box showed a huge purple VW with long '59 Cadillac Coupe de Ville taillights burning up a dirt track. The VW had a sunroof, and poking up through it, clawed hands on the wheel down below, was a gigantic warty monster with popping bloodshot eyes, a maniacal grin, and a gigantic English racing cap turned around backward. Wendy was smiling at him (Danny), and Jack winked at her (Wendy).
``That's what I like about you, doc,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said, handing the box back.
``Your taste runs to the quiet, the sober, the introspective. You are definitely the child of my loins.'' (unknown)
``Mommy said you'd help me put it together as soon as I could read all of the first Dick and Jane.'' (unknown)
``That ought to be by the end of the week,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``What else have you got in that fine-looking truck, ma'am?'' (unknown)
``Uh-uh.'' (She)
She (Wendy) grabbed his (Jack) arm and pulled him (Jack) back.
``No peeking. Some of that stuff is for you. Danny and I will take it in. You can get the milk. It's on the floor of the cab.'' (unknown)
``That's all I am to you,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack cried, clapping a hand to his (Jack) forehead.
``Just a dray horse, a common beast of the field. Dray here, dray there, dray everywhere.'' (unknown)
``Just dray that milk right into the kitchen, mister.'' (unknown)
``It's too much!'' (he)
he (Jack) cried, and threw himself on the ground while Danny stood over him (Danny) and giggled.
``Get up, you ox,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said, and prodded him (Danny) with the toe of her (Wendy) sneaker.
``See?'' (he)
he (Danny) said to Danny.
``She (You) called me an ox. You're a witness.'' (unknown)

Danny concurred gleefully, and broadjumped his (Danny) prone father. Jack sat up.
``That reminds me, chumly. I've got something for you. too. On the porch by my ashtray.'' (unknown)

``What is it?'' (unknown)
``Forgot. Go and see.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack got up and the two of them stood together, watching Danny charge up the lawn and then take the steps to the porch two by two. He (Danny) put an arm around Wendy's waist.
``You happy, babe?'' (She)
She (Wendy) looked up at him (Danny) solemnly.
``This is the happiest I've been since we were married.'' (unknown)
``Is that the truth?'' (unknown)
``God's honest.'' (He)
He (Danny) squeezed her (Wendy) tightly.
``I love you.'' (She)
She (Wendy) squeezed him (Danny) back, touched. Those had never been cheap words with John Torrance; she (Wendy) could count the number of times he (Torrance) had said them to her (Wendy), both before and after marriage, on both her (Wendy) hands.
``I love you too.'' (unknown)

Danny was on the porch now, shrill and excited.

Jack said.

she (Wendy) said, and elbowed him (Jack).
``See if you don't.'' (unknown)
``I was hoping I'd get it tonight,'' (he)
he (Jack) remarked, and she (Wendy) laughed. A moment later he (Jack) asked,
``Is Danny happy, do you think?'' (he)
``You ought to know. You're the one who has a long talk with him (Danny) every night before bed.'' (unknown)
``That's usually about what he (Danny) wants to be when he (Danny) grows up or if Santa Claus is really real. That's getting to be a big thing with him (Claus). she (Wendy) said. They were climbing the porch steps now.

``He (Jack)'s just getting tall.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny's back was to them. He (Danny) was examining something on the table by Jack's chair, but Wendy couldn't see what it was.
``He (Jack)'s not eating as well, either. He (Jack) used to be the original steam shovel. Remember last year?'' (unknown)
``They taper off,'' (he)
he (Jack) said vaguely.
``I think I read that in Spock. He (Spock)'ll be using two forks again by the time he (Spock)'s seven.'' (unknown)
They had stopped on the top step.
``He (Spock)'s pushing awfully hard on those readers, too,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said.
``I know he (Spock) wants to learn how, to please us ... to please you,'' (she)
she (Wendy) added reluctantly.
``To please himself most of all,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``I haven't been pushing him (Spock) on that at all. In fact, I do wish he (Spock) wouldn't go quite so hard.'' (unknown)

She (Wendy) shrugged.
``I suppose. If you think it's foolish -- '' (unknown)

``I don't. In fact, you can make appointments for all three of us. We'll get our clean bills of health and then we can sleep easy at night.'' (unknown)
``I'll make the appointments this afternoon,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said.
``Mom! Look, Mommy!'' (He)
He (Jack) came running to her (Wendy) with a large gray thing in his (Jack) hands, and for one comic-horrible moment Wendy thought it was a brain. She (Wendy) saw what it really was and recoiled instinctively. Jack put an arm around her (Wendy).
``It's all right. The tenants who didn't fly away have been shaken out. I used the bug bomb.'' (She)
She (Wendy) looked at the large wasps' nest her (Wendy) son was holding but would not touch it.
``Are you sure it's safe?'' (unknown)
``Positive. I had one in my room when I was a kid. My dad gave it to me. Want to put it in your room, Danny?'' (unknown)
``Yeah! Right now!'' (He)
He (son) turned around and raced through the double doors. They could hear his (son) muffled, running feet on the main stairs.
``There were wasps up there,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said.
``Did you get stung?'' (unknown)
``Where's my purple heart?'' (he)
he (son) asked, and displayed his (son) finger. The swelling had already begun to go down, but she (Wendy) ooohed over it satisfyingly and gave it a small, gentle kiss.
``Did you pull the stinger out?'' (unknown)
``Wasps don't leave them in. That's bees. They have barbed stingers. Wasp stingers are smooth. That's what makes them so dangerous. They can sting again and again.'' (unknown)
``Jack, are you sure that's safe for him (Jack) to have?'' (unknown)
``I followed the directions on the bomb. The stuff is guaranteed to kill every single bug in two hours' time and then dissipate with no residue.'' (unknown)
``I hate them,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said.
``What... wasps?'' (unknown)
``Anything that stings,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said. Her (Wendy) hands went to her (Wendy) elbows and cupped them, her (Wendy) arms crossed over her (Wendy) breasts.
``I do too,'' (he)
he (son) said, and hugged her (Wendy).

<< 16 >> DANNY Down the hall, in the bedroom, Wendy could hear the typewriter Jack had carried up from downstairs burst into life for thirty seconds, fall silent for a minute or two, and then rattle briefly again. It was like listening to machinegun fire from an isolated pillbox. The sound was music to her (Wendy) ears; Jack had not been writing so steadily since the second year of their marriage, when he (Jack) wrote

the story that Esquire had purchased. He (Jack) said he (Jack) thought the play would be done by the end of the year, for better or worse, and he (Jack) would be moving on to something new. He (Jack) said he (Jack) didn't care if The Little School stirred any excitement when Phyllis showed it around, didn't care if it sank without a trace, and Wendy believed that, too. The actual act of his (Jack) writing made her (Wendy) immensely hopeful, not because she (Wendy) expected great things from the play but because her (Wendy) husband seemed to be slowly closing a huge door on a roomful of monsters. He (husband) had had his (husband) shoulder to that door for a long time now, but at last it was swinging shut. Every key typed closed it a little more.

``Look, Dick, look.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny was hunched over the first of the five battered primers Jack had dug up by culling mercilessly through Boulder's myriad secondhand bookshops. They would take Danny right up to the second-grade reading level, a program she (Wendy) had told Jack she (Wendy) thought was much too ambitious. Their son was intelligent, they knew that, but it would be a mistake to push him (son) too far too fast. Jack had agreed. There would be no pushing involved. But if the kid caught on fast, they would be prepared. And now she (Wendy) wondered if Jack hadn't been right about that, too. Danny, prepared by four years of
``Sesame Street'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
and three years of
``Electric Company,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
seemed to be catching on with almost scary speed. It bothered her (Wendy). He (Danny) hunched over the innocuous little books, his (Danny) crystal radio and balsa glider on the shelf above him (Danny), as though his (Danny) life depended on learning to read. His (Danny) small face was more tense and paler than she (Wendy) liked in the close and cozy glow of the goosenecked lamp they had put in his (Danny) room. He (Danny) was taking it very seriously, both the reading and the workbook pages his (Danny) father made up for him (Danny) every afternoon. Picture of an apple and a peach. The word apple written beneath in Jack's large, neatly made printing. Circle the right picture, the one that went with the word. And their son would stare from the word to the pictures, his (son) lips moving, sounding out, actually sweating it out, And with his (son) double-sized red pencil curled into his (son) pudgy right fist, he (son) could now write about three dozen words on his (son) own. His (son) finger traced slowly under the words in the reader. Above them was a picture Wendy half-remembered from her (Wendy) own grammar school days, nineteen years before. A laughing boy with brown curly hair. A girl in a short dress, her (girl) hair in blond ringlets one hand holding a jump rope. A prancing dog running after a large red rubber ball. The first-grade trinity. Dick, Jane, and Jip.
``See Jip run,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny read slowly.
``Run, Jip, run. Run, run, run.'' (He)
He (Danny) paused, dropping his (Danny) finger down a line.
``See the ...'' (He)
He (Danny) bent closer, his (Danny) nose almost touching the page now.
``See the ...'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
``Not so close, doc,'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy said quietly.
``You'll hurt your eyes. It's-'' (he)
``Don't tell me!'' (he)
he (Danny) said, sitting up with a jerk. His (Danny) voice was alarmed.
``Don't tell me, Mommy, I can get it!'' (unknown)
``All right, honey,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said.
``But it's not a big thing. Really it's not.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Unheeding, Danny bent forward again. On his (Danny) face was an expression that might be more commonly seen hovering over a graduate record exam in a college gym somewhere. She (Wendy) liked it less and less.
``See the ... buh. Aw. El. El. See the buhaw-el-el? See the buhawl. Ball!'' (unknown)
Suddenly triumphant. Fierce. The fierceness in his (Danny) voice scared her (Wendy). ``See the

ball!'' ``That's right,'' she (Wendy) said. ``Honey, I think that's enough for tonight.'' ``A couple more pages, Mommy? Please?'' ``No, doc.'' She (Wendy) closed the red-bound book firmly. ``It's bedtime.'' ``Please?'' ``Don't tease me about it, Danny. Mommy's tired.'' ``Okay.'' But he (Danny) looked longingly at the primer. ``Go kiss your father and then wash up. Don't forget to brush.'' ``Yeah.'' He (Danny) slouched out, a small boy in pajama bottoms with feet and a large flannel top with a football on the front and NEW ENGLAND PATRIOTS written on the back. Jack's typewriter stopped, and she (Wendy) heard Danny's hearty smack. ``Night, Daddy.'' ``Goodnight, doc. How'd you do?'' ``Okay, I guess. Mommy made me stop.'' ``Mommy was right. It's past eight-thirty. Going to the bathroom?'' ``Yeah.''

``Good. There's potatoes growing out of your ears. And onions and carrots and chives and -- '' (unknown)
Danny's giggle, fading, then cut off by the firm click of the bathroom door. He (Danny) was private about his (Danny) bathroom functions, while both she (Wendy) and Jack were pretty much catch-as-catch-can. Another sign -- and they were multiplying all the time -- that there was another human being in the place, not just a carbon copy of one of them or a combination of both. It made her (Wendy) a little sad. Someday her (Wendy) child would be a stranger to her (Wendy), and she (Wendy) would be strange to him (stranger) ... but not as strange as her (Wendy) own mother had become to her (Wendy). Please don't let it be that way, God. Let him (God) grow up and still love his (God) mother. Jack's typewriter began its irregular bursts again. Still sitting in the chair beside Danny's reading table, she (mother) let her (mother) eyes wander around her (mother) son's room. The glider's wing had been neatly mended. His (Danny) desk was piled high with picture books, coloring books, old Spiderman comic books with the covers half torn off, Crayolas, and an untidy pile of Lincoln Logs. The VW model was neatly placed above these lesser things, its shrink-wrap still undisturbed. He (Spiderman) and his (Spiderman) father would be putting it together tomorrow night or the night after if Danny went on at this rate, and never mind the end of the week. His (Danny) pictures of Pooh and Eyore and Christopher Robin were tacked neatly to the wall, soon enough to be replaced with pin-ups and photographs of dopesmoking rock singers, she (Spiderman) supposed. Innocence to experience. Human nature, baby. Grab it and growl. Still it made her (Spiderman) sad. Next year he (Robin) would be in school and she (Spiderman) would lose at least half of him (Robin), maybe more, to his (Robin) friends. She (Spiderman) and Jack had tried to have another one for a while when things had seemed to be going well at Stovington, but she (Spiderman) was on the pill again now. Things were too uncertain. God knew where they would be in nine months. Her (Spiderman) eyes fell on the wasps' nest. It held the ultimate high place in Danny's room, resting on a large plastic plate on the table by his (Danny) bed. She (Spiderman) didn't like it, even if it was empty. She (Spiderman) wondered vaguely if it might have germs, thought to ask Jack, then decided he (Jack) would laugh at her (Spiderman). But she (Spiderman) would ask the doctor tomorrow, if she (Spiderman) could catch him (Jack) with Jack out of the room. She (Spiderman) didn't like the idea of that thing,

constructed from the chewings and saliva of so many alien creatures, lying within a foot of her (Spiderman) sleeping son's head. The water in the bathroom was still running, and she (Spiderman) got up and went into the big bedroom to make sure everything was okay. Jack didn't look up; he (Jack) was lost in the world he (Jack) was making, staring at the typewriter, a filter cigarette clamped in his (Jack) teeth. She (Spiderman) knocked lightly on the closed bathroom room.

``You okay, doc? You awake?'' (unknown)
No answer.
``Danny?'' (unknown)
No answer. She (Spiderman) tried the door. It was locked.
``Danny?'' (She)
She (Spiderman) was worried now. The lack of any sound beneath the steadily running water made her (Spiderman) uneasy.
``Danny? Open the door, honey.'' (unknown)
No answer.
``Danny!'' (unknown)
``Jesus Christ, Wendy, I can't think if you're going to pound on the door all night.'' (unknown)
``Danny's locked himself in the bathroom and he (Danny) doesn't answer me!'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack came around the desk, looking put out. He (Jack) knocked on the door once, hard.
``Open up, Danny. No games.'' (unknown)
No answer. Jack knocked harder.
``Stop fooling, doc. Bedtime's bedtime. Spanking if you don't open up.'' (He)
He (Jack)'s losing his (Jack) temper, she (Spiderman) thought, and was more afraid. He (Jack) had not touched Danny in anger since that evening two years ago, but at this moment he (Danny) sounded angry enough to do it.
``Danny, honey -- '' (she)
she (Spiderman) began. No answer. Only running water.
``Danny, if you make me break this lock I can guarantee you you'll spend the night sleeping on your belly,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack warned. Nothing.
``Break it,'' (she)
she (Spiderman) said, and suddenly it was hard to talk.
``Quick.'' (He)
He (Jack) raised one foot and brought it down hard against the door to the right of the knob. The lock was a poor thing; it gave immediately and the door shuddered open, banging the tiled bathroom wall and rebounding halfway.
``Danny!'' (she)
she (Spiderman) screamed. The water was running full force in the basin. Beside it, a tube of Crest with the cap off. Danny was sitting on the rim of the bathtub across the room, his (Danny) toothbrush clasped limply in his (Danny) left hand, a thin foam of toothpaste around his (Danny) mouth. He (Danny) was staring, trancelike, into the mirror on the front of the medicine cabinet above the washbasin. The expression on his (Danny) face was one of drugged horror, and her (Spiderman) first thought was that he (Danny) was having some sort of epileptic seizure, that he (Danny) might have swallowed his (Danny) tongue.
``Danny!'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny didn't answer. Guttural sounds came from his (Danny) throat. Then she (Spiderman) was pushed aside so hard that she (Spiderman) crashed into the towel rack, and Jack was kneeling in front of the boy.
``Danny,'' (he)
he (Jack) said.
``Danny, Danny!'' (He)

Danny said.

``Oh, honey, I'm sorry. I'm sorry, doc. Please. Don't cry. I'm sorry. Everything's okay.'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)

At last Danny began to relax again.

``Sure.'' (She)
She (Wendy) plugged in the night light, which showed Snoopy lying fast asleep on top of his (Snoopy) doghouse. He (Snoopy) had never wanted a night light until they moved into the Overlook, and then he (Snoopy) had specifically requested one. ``You sleepy?'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack asked, brushing Danny's hair off his (Danny) forehead.
``Yeah.'' (unknown)

``Roque.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Jack turned back, all zero at the bone.
``Danny -- ?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)
Silence again, spinning out.
``Daddy?'' (unknown)
``What?'' (unknown)
``Tony came and told me about roque.'' (unknown)
``Did he (Tony), doc? What did he (Tony) say?'' (unknown)
``I don't remember much. Except he (Tony) said it was in innings. Like baseball. Isn't that funny?'' (unknown)
``Yes.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack's heart was thudding dully in his (Jack) chest. How could the boy possibly know a thing like that? Roque was played by innings, not like baseball but like cricket.
``Daddy ... ?'' (He)

He (Jack) took it over to the bedtable and carefully slid the bowl and the nest onto it. The wasps buzzed angrily inside their prison. Then, putting his (Jack) hand firmly on top of the bowl so it wouldn't slip, he (Jack) went out into the hall.
``Coming to bed, Jack?'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy asked.
``Coming to bed, Daddy?'' (unknown)
``Have to go downstairs for a minute,'' (he)
he (Jack) said, making his (Jack) voice light. How had it happened? How in God's name? The bomb sure hadn't been a dud. He (God) had seen the thick white smoke start to puff out of it when he (God) had pulled the ring. And when he (God) had gone up two hours later, he (God) had shaken a drift of small dead bodies out of the hole in the top. Then how? Spontaneous regeneration? That was crazy. Seventeenth-century bullshit. Insects didn't regenerate. And

even if wasp eggs could mature full-grown insects in twelve hours, this wasn't the season in which the queen laid. That happened in April or May. Fall was their dying time. A living contradiction, the wasps buzzed furiously under the bowl. He (God) took them downstairs and through the kitchen. In back there was a door which gave on the outside. A cold night wind blew against his (God) nearly naked body, and his (God) feet went numb almost instantly against the cold concrete of the platform he (God) was standing on, the platform where milk deliveries were made during the hotel's operating season. He (God) put the puzzle and the bowl down carefully, and when he (God) stood up he (God) looked at the thermometer nailed outside the door. FRESH UP WITH 7-up, the thermometer said, and the mercury stood at an even twenty-five degrees. The cold would kill them by morning. He (God) went in and shut the door firmly. After a moment's thought he (God) locked it, too. He (God) crossed the kitchen again and shut off the lights. He (God) stood in the darkness for a moment, thinking, wanting a drink. Suddenly the hotel seemed full of a thousand stealthy sounds: creakings and groans and the sly sniff of the wind under the eaves where more wasps' nests might be hanging like deadly fruit. They had come back. And suddenly he (God) found that he (God) didn't like the Overlook so well anymore, as if it wasn't wasps that had stung his (God) son, wasps that had miraculously lived through the bug bomb assault, but the hotel itself. His (God) last thought before going upstairs to his (God) wife and son -LRB-from now on you will hold your temper. No Mattes What.-RRB- was firm and hard and sure. As he (God) went down the hall to them he (God) wiped his (God) lips with the back of his (God) hand.

<< 17 >> THE DOCTOR'S OFFICE Stripped to his (God) underpants, lying on the examination table, Danny Torrance looked very small. He (Torrance) was looking up at Dr. -LRB-

Bill Edmonds said.

Danny thought about it. He (Danny) looked at Edmonds and then, with a small effort of concentration, he (Danny) tried to catch Edmonds's thoughts or at least the color of his (Edmonds) mood. And suddenly he (Edmonds) got an oddly comforting image in his (Edmonds) head: file cabinets, their doors sliding shut one after another, locking with a click. Written on the small tabs in the center of each door was: A-C, SECRET; D-G, SECRET; and so on. This made Danny feel a little easier. Cautiously he (Danny) said:
``I don't know who Tony is.'' (he)
``Is he (Tony) your age?'' (unknown)
``No. He (Tony)'s at least eleven. I think he (Tony) might be even older. I've never seen him (Tony) right up close. He (Tony) might be old enough to drive a car.'' (unknown)
``You just see him (Tony) at a distance, huh?'' (unknown)
``Yes, Sir.'' (unknown)
``And he (Tony) always comes just before you pass out?'' (unknown)
``Well, I don't pass out. It's like I go with him (Tony). And he (Tony) shows me things.'' (unknown)
``What kind of things?'' (unknown)
``Well ...'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny debated for a moment and then told Edmonds about Daddy's trunk with all his (Danny) writing in it, and about how the movers hadn't lost it between Vermont and Colorado after all. It had been right under the stairs all along.
``And your daddy found it where Tony said he (Tony) would?'' (unknown)
``Oh yes, sir. Only Tony didn't tell me. He (Tony) showed me.'' (unknown)
``I understand. Danny, what did Tony show you last night? When you locked yourself in the bathroom?'' (unknown)
``I don't remember,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said quickly.
``Are you sure?'' (unknown)
``Yes, sir.'' (unknown)
``A moment ago I said you locked the bathroom door. But that wasn't right, was

it? Tony locked the door.'' ``No, sir. Tony couldn't lock the door because he (Tony) isn't real. He (Tony) wanted me to do it, so I did. I locked it.'' ``Does Tony always show you where lost things are?'' ``No, sir. Sometimes he (Tony) shows me things that are going to happen.'' ``Really?'' ``Sure. Like one time Tony showed me the amusements and wild animal park in Great Barrington. Tony said Daddy was going to take me there for my birthday. He (Tony) did, too.'' ``What else does he (Tony) show you?'' Danny frowned. ``Signs. He (Tony)'s always showing me stupid old signs. And I can't read them, hardly ever.'' ``Why do you suppose Tony would do that, Danny?'' ``I don't know.'' Danny brightened. ``But my daddy and mommy are teaching me to read, and I'm trying real hard.'' ``So you can read Tony's signs.'' ``Well, I really want to learn. But that too, yeah.'' ``Do you like Tony, Danny?'' Danny looked at the tile floor and said nothing. ``Danny?'' ``It's hard to tell,'' Danny said. ``I used to. I used to hope he (Danny)'d come every day, because he (Danny) always showed me good things, especially since Mommy and Daddy don't think about DIVORCE anymore.'' Dr. Edmonds's gaze sharpened, but Danny didn't notice. He (Danny) was looking hard at the floor, concentrating on expressing himself. ``But now whenever he (Danny) comes he (Danny) shows me bad things. Awful things. Like in the bathroom last night. The things he (Danny) shows me, they sting me like those wasps stung me. Only Tony's things sting me up here.'' He (Danny) cocked a finger gravely at his (Danny) temple, a small boy unconsciously burlesquing suicide. ``What things, Danny?'' ``I can't remember!'' Danny cried out, agonized. ``I'd tell you if I could! It's like I can't remember because it's so bad I don't want to remember. All I can remember when I wake up is REDRUM.'' ``Red drum or red rum?'' ``Rum. '' ``What's that, Danny?'' ``I don't know.'' ``Danny?'' ``Yes, sir?'' ``Can you make Tony come now?'' ``I don't know. He (Tony) doesn't always come. I don't even know if I want him (Tony) to come anymore.'' ``Try, Danny. I'll be right here.'' Danny looked at Edmonds doubtfully. Edmonds nodded encouragement. Danny let out a long, sighing breath and nodded. ``But I don't know if it will work. I never did it with anyone looking at me before. And Tony doesn't always come, anyway.'' ``If he (Tony) doesn't, he (Tony) doesn't,'' Edmonds said. ``I just want you to try.''

``Okay.'' (mommy daddy)
He (Danny) dropped his (Danny) gaze to Edmonds's slowly swinging loafers and cast his (Danny) mind

outward toward his (Danny) mommy and daddy. They were here someplace ... right beyond that wall with the picture on it, as a matter of fact. In the waiting room where they had come in. Sitting side by side but not talking. Leafing through magazines. Worried. About him (Danny). He (Danny) concentrated harder, his (Danny) brow furrowing, trying to get Into the feeling of his (Danny) mommy's thoughts. It was always harder when they weren't right there in the room with him (Danny). Then he (Danny) began to get it. Mommy was thinking about a sister. Her (Mommy) sister. The sister was dead. His (Danny) mommy was thinking that was the main thing that turned her (mommy) mommy into such a -LRB-bitch?-RRB- into such an old biddy. Because her (mommy) sister had died. As a little girl she (mommy) was -LRB-hit by a car oh god i could never stand anything like that again like aileen but what if he (god)'s sick really sick cancer spinal meningitis leukemia brain tumor like john gunther's son or muscular dystrophy oh jeez kids his (son) age get leukemia all the time radium treatments chemotherapy we couldn't afford anything like that but of course they just can't turn you out to die on the street can they and anyway he (son)'s all right all right all right you really shouldn't let yourself think-RRB- -LRB-Danny -- -RRB- -LRB-about aileen and-RRB- -LRB-Dannee -- -RRB- -LRB-that car-RRB- -LRB-Dannee -- -RRB- But Tony wasn't there. Only his (Tony) voice. And as it faded, Danny followed it down into darkness, falling and tumbling down some magic hole between Dr. Bill's swinging loafers, past a loud knocking sound, further, a bathtub cruised silently by in the darkness with some horrible thing lolling in it, past a sound like sweetly chiming church bells, past a clock under a dome of glass. Then the dark was pierced feebly by a single light, festooned with cobwebs. The weak glow disclosed a stone floor that looked damp and unpleasant. Somewhere not far distant was a steady mechanical roaring sound, but muted, not frightening. Soporific. It was the thing that would be forgotten, Danny thought with dreamy surprise. As his (Danny) eyes adjusted to the gloom he (Danny) could see Tony just ahead of him (Danny), a silhouette. Tony was looking at something and Danny strained his (Tony) eyes to see what it was. -LRB-Your daddy. See your daddy?-RRB- Of course he (daddy) did. How could he (daddy) have missed him (daddy), even in the basement light's feeble glow? Daddy was kneeling on the floor, casting the beam of a flashlight over old cardboard boxes and wooden crates. The cardboard boxes were mushy and old; some of them had split open and spilled drifts of paper onto the floor. Newspapers, books, printed pieces of paper that looked like bills. His (daddy) daddy was examining them with great interest. And then Daddy looked up and shone his (daddy) flashlight in another direction. Its beam of light impaled another book, a large white one bound with gold string. The cover looked like white leather. It was a scrapbook. Danny suddenly needed to cry out to his (Danny) daddy, to tell him (Danny) to leave that book alone, that some books should not be opened. But his (Danny) daddy was climbing toward it.

The mechanical roaring sound, which he (daddy) now recognized as the boiler at the Overlook which Daddy checked three or four times every day, had developed an ominous, rhythmic hitching. It began to sound like ... like pounding. And the smell of mildew and wet, rotting paper was changing to something else -- the high, junipery smell of the Bad Stuff. It hung around his (daddy) daddy like a vapor as he (daddy) reached for the book ... and grasped it. Tony was somewhere in the darkness -LRB-This inhuman place makes human monsters. This inhuman place-RRB- repeating the same incomprehensible thing over and over. -LRB-makes human monsters.-RRB- Falling through darkness again, now accompanied by the heavy, pounding thunder that was no longer the boiler but the sound of a whistling mallet striking silkpapered walls, knocking out whiffs of plaster dust. Crouching helplessly on the blue-black woven jungle rug. -LRB-Come out-RRB- -LRB-This inhuman place-RRB- -LRB-and take your medicine!-RRB- -LRB-makes human monsters.-RRB- With a gasp that echoed in his (monsters) own head he (monsters) jerked himself out of the darkness. Hands were on him (monsters) and at first he (monsters) shrank back, thinking that the dark thing in the Overlook of Tony's world had somehow followed him (Tony) back into the world of real things -- and then Dr. Edmonds was saying:

``You're all right, Danny. You're all right. Everything is fine.'' (Dr. Edmonds)
Danny recognized the doctor, then his (Danny) surroundings in the office. He (Danny) began to shudder helplessly. Edmonds held him (Danny). When the reaction began to subside, Edmonds asked,
