Out in the waiting room?'' ``Yes, sir.'' ``Danny, how would you know that?'' ``I don't know,'' Danny said wanly. ``The shining, I guess.'' ``The what?'' Danny shook his (Danny) head very slowly. ``I'm awful tired. Can't I go see my mommy and daddy? I don't want to answer any more questions. I'm tired. And my stomach hurts.'' ``Are you going to throw up?'' ``No, sir. I just want to go see my mommy and daddy.'' ``Okay, Dan.'' Edmonds stood up. ``You go on out and see them for a minute, then send them in so I can talk to them. Okay?.'' ``Yes, sir.'' ``There are books out there to look at. You like books, don't you?'' ``Yes, sir,'' Danny said dutifully. ``You're a good boy, Danny.'' Danny gave him (Danny) a faint smile. * * * ``I can't find a thing wrong with him (Danny),'' Dr. Edmonds said to the Torrances. ``Not physically. Mentally, he (Danny)'s bright and rather too imaginative. It happens. Children have to grow into their imaginations like a pair of oversized shoes. Danny's is still way too big for him (Danny). Ever had his (Danny) IQ tested?'' ``I don't believe in them,'' Jack said. ``They straight-jacket the expectations of both parents and teachers.'' Dr. Edmonds nodded. ``That may be. But if you did test him (Danny), I think you'd find he (Danny)'s right off the scale for his (Danny) age group. His (Danny) verbal ability, for a boy who is five going on six, is amazing.'' ``We don't talk down to him (Danny),'' Jack said with a trace of pride. ``I doubt if you've ever had to in order to make yourself understood.'' Edmonds paused, fiddling with a pen. ``He (Danny) went into a trance while I was with him (Danny). At my request. Exactly as you described him (Danny) in the bathroom last night. All his (Danny) muscles went lax, his (Danny) body slumped, his (Danny) eyeballs rotated outward. Textbook autohypnosis. I was amazed. I still am.'' The Torrances sat forward. ``What happened?'' Wendy asked tensely, and Edmonds carefully related Danny's trance, the muttered phrase from which Edmonds had only been able to pluck the word ``monsters,'' the ``dark,'' the ``pounding.'' The aftermath of tears, near-hysteria, and nervous stomach. ``Tony again,'' Jack said. ``What does it mean?'' Wendy asked. ``Have you any idea?'' ``A few. You might not like them.'' ``Go ahead anyway,'' Jack told him (Jack). ``From what Danny told me, his (Danny) `invisible friend' was truly a friend until you folks moved out here from New England. Tony has only become a threatening figure

since that move. The pleasant interludes have become nightmarish, even more frightening to your son because he (son) can't remember exactly what the nightmares are about. That's common enough. We all remember our pleasant dreams more clearly than the scary ones. There seems to be a buffer somewhere between the conscious and the subconscious, and one hell of a bluenose lives in there. This censor only lets through a small amount, and often what does come through is only symbolic. That's oversimplified Freud, but it does pretty much describe what we know of the mind's interaction with itself.'' ``You think moving has upset Danny that badly?'' Wendy asked. ``It may have, if the move took place under traumatic circumstances,'' Edmonds said. ``Did it?'' Wendy and Jack exchanged a glance. ``I was teaching at a prep school,'' Jack said slowly. ``I lost my job.'' ``I see,'' Edmonds said. He (Jack) put the pen he (Jack) bad been playing with firmly back in its holder. ``There's more here, I'm afraid. It may be painful to you. Your son seems to believe you two have seriously contemplated divorce. He (son) spoke of it in an offhand way, but only because he (son) believes you are no longer considering it.'' Jack's mouth dropped open, and Wendy recoiled as if slapped. The blood drained from her (Wendy) face. ``We never even discussed it!'' she (Wendy) said. ``Not in front of him (son), not even in front of each other! We -- '' ``I think it's best if you understand everything, Doctor,'' Jack said. ``Shortly after Danny was born, I became an alcoholic. I'd had a drinking problem all the way through college, it subsided a little after Wendy and I met, cropped up worse than ever after Danny was born and the writing I consider to be my real work was going badly. When Danny was three and a half, he (Danny) spilled some beer on a bunch of papers I was working on ... papers I was shuffling around, anyway ... and I ... well ... oh shit.'' His (Jack) voice broke, but his (Jack) eyes remained dry and unflinching. ``It sounds so goddam beastly said out loud. I broke his (Danny) arm turning him (Danny) around to spank him (Danny). Three months later I gave up drinking. I haven't touched it since.'' ``I see,'' Edmonds said neutrally. ``I knew the arm had been broken, of course. It was set well.'' He (Edmonds) pushed back from his (Edmonds) desk a little and crossed his (Edmonds) legs. ``If I may be frank, it's obvious that he (Danny)'s been in no way abused since then. Other than the stings, there's nothing on him (Danny) but the normal bruises and scabs that any kid has in abundance.'' ``Of course not,'' Wendy said hotly. ``Jack didn't mean-- '' ``No, Wendy,'' Jack said. ``I meant to do it. I guess someplace inside I really did mean to do that to him (Jack). Or something even worse.'' He (Jack) looked back at Edmonds again. ``You know something, Doctor? This is the first time the word divorce has been mentioned between us. And alcoholism. And child-beating. Three firsts in five minutes.'' ``That may be at the root of the problem,'' Edmonds said. ``I am not a psychiatrist. If you want Danny to see a child psychiatrist, I can recommend a good one who works out of the Mission Ridge Medical Center in Boulder. But I am fairly confident of my diagnosis. Danny is an intelligent, imaginative, perceptive boy. I don't believe he (Danny) would have been as upset by your marital problems as you believed. Small children are great accepters. They don't

understand shame, or the need to hide things.'' Jack was studying his (Jack) hands. Wendy took one of them and squeezed it. ``But he (Danny) sensed the things that were wrong. Chief among them from his (Chief) point of view was not the broken arm but the broken -- or breaking -- link between you two. He (Chief) mentioned divorce to me, but not the broken arm. When my nurse mentioned the set to him (Chief), he (Chief) simply shrugged if off. It was no pressure thing. `It happened a long time ago' is what I think he (Chief) said.'' ``That kid,'' Jack muttered. His (Jack) jaws were clamped together, the muscles in the cheeks standing out. ``We don't deserve him (Chief).'' ``You have him (Chief), all the same,'' Edmonds said dryly. ``At any rate, he (Chief) retires into a fantasy world from time to time. Nothing unusual about that; lots of kids do. As I recall, I had my own invisible friend when I was Danny's age, a talking rooster named Chug-Chug. Of course no one could see Chug-Chug but me. I had two older brothers who often left me behind, and in such a situation Chug-Chug came in mighty handy. And of course you two must understand why Danny's invisible friend is named Tony instead of Mike or Hal or Dutch.'' ``Yes,'' Wendy said. ``Have you ever pointed it out to him (Hal)?'' ``No,'' Jack said. ``Should we?'' ``Why bother? Let him (Hal) realize it in his (Hal) own time, by his (Hal) own logic. You see, Danny's fantasies were considerably deeper than those that grow around the ordinary invisible friend syndrome, but he (friend) felt he (friend) needed Tony that much more. Tony would come and show him (Tony) pleasant things. Sometimes amazing things. Always good things. Once Tony showed him (Tony) where Daddy's lost trunk was ... under the stairs. Another time Tony showed him (Tony) that Mommy and Daddy were going to take him (Tony) to an amusement park for his (Tony) birthday -- '' ``At Great Barrington!'' Wendy cried. ``But how could he (Great) know those things? It's eerie, the things he (Great) comes out with sometimes. Almost as if -- '' ``He (Great) had second sight?'' Edmonds asked, smiling. ``He (Great) was born with a caul,'' Wendy said weakly. Edmonds's smile became a good, hearty laugh. Jack and Wendy exchanged a glance and then also smiled, both of them amazed at how easy it was. Danny's occasional ``lucky guesses'' about things was something else they had not discussed much. ``Next you'll be telling me he (Great) can levitate,'' Edmonds said, still smiling. ``No, no, no, I'm afraid not. It's not extrasensory but good old human perception, which in Danny's case is unusually keen. Mr. Torrance, he (Torrance) knew your trunk was under the stairs because you had looked everywhere else. Process of elimination, what? It's so simple Ellery Queen would laugh at it. Sooner or later you would have thought of it yourself.

``As for the amusement park at Great Barrington, whose idea was that originally? Yours or his (Great)?'' (unknown)

``Then a men's magazine I'd sold a story to back in 1971 sent a check for fifty dollars,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``They were reprinting the story in an annual, or something. So we decided to spend it on Danny.'' (Edmonds/Bill '' -RRB- Edmonds/Bill Edmonds)

``Wish fulfillment plus a lucky coincidence.'' (unknown)

``Goddammit, I bet that's just right,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said. Edmonds smiled a little.
``And Danny himself told me that Tony often showed him (Tony) things that never occurred. Visions based on faulty perception, that's all. Danny is doing subconsciously what these so-called mystics and mind readers do quite consciously and cynically. I admire him (Danny) for it. If life doesn't cause him (Danny) to retract his (Danny) antennae, I think he (Danny)'ll be quite a man.'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy nodded -- of course she (Wendy) thought Danny would be quite a man -- but the doctor's explanation struck her (Wendy) as glib. It tasted more like margarine than butter. Edmonds had not lived with them. He (Edmonds) had not been there when Danny found lost buttons, told her (Wendy) that maybe the TV Guide was under the bed, that he (Danny) thought he (Danny) better wear his (Danny) rubbers to nursery school even though the sun was out ... and later that day they had walked home under her (Wendy) umbrella through the pouring rain. Edmonds couldn't know of the curious way Danny had of preguessing them both. She (Wendy) would decide to have an unusual evening cup of tea, go out in the kitchen and find her (Wendy) cup out with a tea bag in it. She (Wendy) would remember that the books were due at the library and find them all neatly piled up on the hall table, her (Wendy) library card on top. Or Jack would take it into his (Jack) head to wax the Volkswagen and find Danny already out there, listening to tinny top-forty music on his (Danny) crystal radio as he (Danny) sat on the curb to watch. Aloud she (Wendy) said,
``Then why the nightmares now? Why did Tony tell him (Tony) to lock the bathroom door?'' (she)
``I believe it's because Tony has outlived his (Tony) usefulness,'' (Edmonds/Bill '' -RRB- Edmonds/Bill Edmonds)
Edmonds said.
``He (Tony) was born -- Tony, not Danny -- at a time when you and your husband were straining to keep your marriage together. Your husband was drinking too much. There was the incident of the broken arm. The ominous quiet between you.'' (unknown)
Ominous quiet, yes, that phrase was the real thing, anyway. The stiff, tense meals where the only conversation had been please pass the butter or Danny, eat the rest of your carrots or may I be excused, please. The nights when Jack was gone and she (Wendy) had lain down, dry-eyed, on the couch while Danny watched TV. The mornings when she (Wendy) and Jack had stalked around each other like two angry cats with a quivering, frightened mouse between them. It all rang true; -LRB-dear God, do old scars ever stop hurting?-RRB- horribly, horribly true. Edmonds resumed,
``But things have changed. You know, schizoid behavior is a pretty common thing in children. It's accepted, because all we adults have this unspoken agreement that children are lunatics. They have invisible friends. They may go and sit in the closet when they're depressed, withdrawing from the world. They attach talismanic importance to a special blanket, or a teddy bear, or a stuffed tiger. They suck their thumbs. When an adult sees things that aren't there, we consider him (They) ready for the rubber room. When a child says he (They)'s seen a troll in his (They) bedroom or a vampire outside the window, we simply smile indulgently. We have a one-sentence explanation that explains the whole range of such phenomena in children -- '' (Edmonds/Bill '' -RRB- Edmonds/Bill Edmonds)
``He (They)'ll grow out of it,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said. Edmonds blinked.
``My very words,'' (he)
he (Edmonds) said. ``Yes. Now I would guess that Danny was in a pretty good position to develop a full-fledged psychosis. Unhappy home life, a big imagination, the invisible friend who was so real to him (friend) that he (friend) nearly became real to you. Instead of `growing out of' his (friend) childhood

schizophrenia, he (friend) might well have grown into it.'' ``And become autistic?'' Wendy asked. She (Wendy) had read about autism. The word itself frightened her (Wendy); it sounded like dread and white silence. ``Possible but not necessarily. He (friend) might simply have entered Tony's world someday and never come back to what he (Tony) calls `real things.' '' ``God,'' Jack said. ``But now the basic situation has changed drastically. Mr. Torrance no longer drinks. You are in a new place where conditions have forced the three of you into a tighter family unit than ever before -- certainly tighter than my own, where my wife and kids may see me for only two or three hours a day. To my mind, he (Torrance) is in the perfect healing situation. And I think the very fact that he (Torrance) is able to differentiate so sharply between Tony's world and `real things' says a lot about the fundamentally healthy state of his (Tony) mind. He (Tony) says that you two are no longer considering divorce. Is he (Tony) as right as I think he (Tony) is?'' ``Yes,'' Wendy said, and Jack squeezed her (Wendy) hand tightly, almost painfully. She (Wendy) squeezed back. Edmonds nodded. ``He (Tony) really doesn't need Tony anymore. Danny is flushing him (Danny) out of his (Danny) system. Tony no longer brings pleasant visions but hostile nightmares that are too frightening for him (Tony) to remember except fragmentarily. He (Tony) internalized Tony during a difficult -- desperate -- life situation, and Tony is not leaving easily. But he (Tony) is leaving. Your son is a little like a junkie kicking the habit.'' He (Edmonds) stood up, and the Torrances stood also. ``As I said, I'm not a psychiatrist. If the nightmares are still continuing when your job at the Overlook ends next spring, Mr. Torrance, I would strongly urge you to take him (Torrance) to this man in Boulder.'' ``I will.'' ``Well, let's go out and tell him (Torrance) he (Torrance) can go home,'' Edmonds said. ``I want to thank you,'' Jack told him (Jack) painfully. ``I feel better about all this than I have in a very long time.'' ``So do I,'' Wendy said. At the door, Edmonds paused and looked at Wendy. ``Do you or did you have a sister, Mrs. Torrance? Named Aileen?'' Wendy looked at him (Edmonds), surprised. ``Yes, I did. She (Torrance) was killed outside our home in Somersworth, New Hampshire, when she (Torrance) was six and I was ten. She (Torrance) chased a ball into the street and was struck by a delivery van.'' ``Does Danny know that?'' ``I don't know. I don't think so.'' ``He (Danny) says you were thinking about her (Torrance) in the waiting room.'' ``I was,'' Wendy said slowly. ``For the first time in ... oh, I don't know how long.'' ``Does the word `redrum' mean anything to either of you?'' Wendy shook her (Wendy) head but Jack said, ``He (Danny) mentioned that word last night, just before he (Danny) went to sleep. Red drum.'' ``No, rum,'' Edmonds corrected. ``He (Danny) was quite emphatic about that. Rum. As in the drink. The alcoholic drink.'' ``Oh,'' Jack said.

``It fits in, doesn't it?'' (unknown)
He (Jack) took his (Jack) handkerchief out of his (Jack) back pocket and wiped his (Jack) lips with it.

``Does the phrase `the shining' mean anything to you?'' (unknown)
This time they both shook their heads.
``Doesn't matter, I guess,'' (Edmonds/Bill '' -RRB- Edmonds/Bill Edmonds)
Edmonds said. He (Edmonds) opened the door into the waiting room.
``Anybody here named Danny Torrance that would like to go home?'' (unknown)
``Hi, Daddy! Hi, Mommy!'' (He)
He (Edmonds) stood up from the small table where he (Edmonds) had been leafing slowly through a copy of Where the Wild Things Are and muttering the words he (Edmonds) knew aloud. He (Edmonds) ran to Jack, who scooped him (Jack) up. Wendy ruffled his (Jack) hair. Edmonds peered at him (Edmonds).
``If you don't love your mommy and daddy, you can stay with good old Bill.'' (unknown)

<< 18 >> THE SCRAPBOOK Jack found the scrapbook on the first of November, while his (Jack) wife and son were hiking up the rutted old road that ran from behind the roque court to a deserted sawmill two miles further up. The fine weather still held, and all three of them had acquired improbable autumn suntans. He (Jack) had gone down in the basement to knock the press down on the boiler and then, on impulse, he (Jack) had taken the flashlight from the shelf where the plumbing schematics were and decided to look at some of the old papers. He (Jack) was also looking for good places to set his (Jack) traps, although he (Jack) didn't plan to do that for another month -- I want them all to be home from vacation, he (Jack) had told Wendy. Shining the flashlight ahead of him (Jack), he (Jack) stepped past the elevator shaft -LRB-at Wendy's insistence they hadn't used the elevator since they moved in-RRB- and through the small stone arch. His (Jack) nose wrinkled at the smell of rotting paper. Behind him (Jack) the boiler kicked on with a thundering whoosh, making him (Jack) jump. He (Jack) flickered the light around, whistling tunelessly between his (Jack) teeth. There was a scale-model Andes range down here: dozens of boxes and crates stuffed with papers, most of them white and shapeless with age and damp. Others had broken open and spilled yellowed sheaves of paper onto the stone floor. There were bales of newspaper tied up with hayrope. Some boxes contained what looked like ledgers, and others contained invoices bound with rubber bands. Jack pulled one out and put the flashlight beam on it.

ROCKY MOUNTAIN EXPRESS, INC.. To: OVERLOOK HOTEL From: SIDEY'S WAREHOUSE, 1210 16th Street, Denver, CO.. Via: CANDIAN PACIFIC RR Contents: 400 CASES DELSEY TOILET TISSUE, 1 GROSS/CASE Signed D E F Date August 24, 1954 Smiling, Jack let the paper drop back into the box. He (Jack) flashed the light above it and it speared a hanging lightbulb, almost buried in cobwebs. There was no chain pull. He (Jack) stood on tiptoe and tried screwing the bulb in. It lit weakly. He (Jack) picked up the toilet-paper invoice again and used it to wipe off some of the cobwebs. The glow didn't brighten much. Still using the flashlight, he (Jack) wandered through the boxes and bales of paper, looking for rat spoor. They had been here, but not for quite a long time ... maybe years. He (Jack) found some droppings that were powdery with age, and several nests of neatly shredded paper that were old and unused. Jack pulled a newspaper from one of the bundles and glanced down at the headline. JOHNSON PROMISES ORDERLY TRANSITION Says Work Begun by JFK Will Go Forward in Coming Year The paper was the Rocky Mountain News, dated December 19, 1963. He (Rocky) dropped it back onto its pile. He (Rocky) supposed he (Rocky) was fascinated by that commonplace sense of history that anyone can feel glancing through the fresh news of ten or twenty years ago. He (Rocky) found gaps in the piled newspapers and records; nothing from 1937 to 1945, from 1957 to 1960, from 1962 to 1963. Periods when the hotel had been closed, he (Rocky) guessed. When it had been between suckers grabbing for the brass ring. Ullman's explanations of the Overlook's checkered career still didn't ring quite true to him (Ullman). It seemed that the Overlooks spectacular location alone should have guaranteed its continuing success. There had always been an American jetset, even before jets were invented, and it seemed to Jack that the Overlook should have been one of the bases they touched in their migrations. It even sounded right. The Waldorf in May, the Bar Harbor House in June and July, the Overlook in August and early September, before moving on to Bermuda, Havana, Rio, wherever. He (Jack) found a pile of old desk registers and they bore him (Jack) out. Nelson Rockefeller in 1950. Henry Ford & Fam. in 1927. Jean Harlow in 1930. Clark Gable and Carole Lombard. In 1956 the whole top floor had been taken for a week by

``Darryl F. Zanuck & Party.'' (Comstock)
The money must have rolled down the corridors and into the cash registers like a twentieth-century Comstock Lode. The management must have been spectacularly bad. There was history here, all right, and not just in newspaper headlines. It was buried between the entries in these ledgers and account books and room-service chits where you couldn't quite see it. In 1922 Warren G. Harding had ordered a

whole salmon at ten o'clock in the evening, and a case of Coors beer. But whom had he (Harding) been eating and drinking with? Had it been a poker game? A strategy session? What? Jack glanced at his (Jack) watch and was surprised to see that forty-five minutes had somehow slipped by since he (Jack) had come down here. His (Jack) hands and arms were grimy, and he (Jack) probably smelled bad. He (Jack) decided to go up and take a shower before Wendy and Danny got back. He (Danny) walked slowly between the mountains of paper, his (Danny) mind alive and ticking over possibilities in a speedy way that was exhilarating. He (Danny) hadn't felt this way in years. It suddenly seemed that the book he (Danny) had semijokingly promised himself might really happen. It might even be right here, buried in these untidy heaps of paper. It could be a work of fiction, or history, or both -- a long book exploding out of this central place in a hundred directions. He (Danny) stood beneath the cobwebby light, took his (Danny) handkerchief from his (Danny) back pocket without thinking, and scrubbed at his (Danny) lips with it. And that was when he (Danny) saw the scrapbook. A pile of five boxes stood on his (Danny) left like some tottering Pisa. The one on top was stuffed with more invoices and ledgers. Balanced on top of those, keeping its angle of repose for who knew how many years, was a thick scrapbook with white leather covers, its pages bound with two hanks of gold string that bad been tied along the binding in gaudy bows. Curious, he (Danny) went over and took it down. The top cover was thick with dust. He (Danny) held it on a plane at lip level, blew the dust off in a cloud, and opened it. As he (Danny) did so a card fluttered out and he (Danny) grabbed it in mid-air before it could fall to the stone floor. It was rich and creamy, dominated by a raised engraving of the Overlook with every window alight. The lawn and playground were decorated with glowing Japanese lanterns. It looked almost as though you could step right into it, an Overlook Hotel that had existed thirty years ago. Horace M. Derwent Requests The Pleasure of Your Company At a Masked Ball to Celebrate The Grand Opening of THE OVERLOOK HOTEL Dinner Will Be Served At 8 P.M. Unmasking And Dancing At Midnight August 29, 1945 RSVP Dinner at eight! Unmasking at midnight! He (Horace) could almost see them in the dining room, the richest men in America and their women. Tuxedos and glimmering starched shirts; evening gowns; the band playing; gleaming high-heeled pumps. The clink of glasses, the jocund pop of champagne corks. The war was over, or almost over. The future lay ahead, clean and shining. America was the colossus of the world and at last she (colossus) knew it and accepted it. And later, at midnight, Derwent himself crying:

``Unmask! Unmask!'' (Derwent/Horace Derwent)
The masks

coming off and... -LRB-The Red Death held sway over all!-RRB- He (Derwent) frowned. What left field had that come out of? That was Poe, the Great American Hack. And surely the Overlook -- this shining, glowing Overlook on the invitation he (Poe) held in his (Poe) hands-was the farthest cry from E. A. Poe imaginable. He (Poe) put the invitation back and turned to the next page. A paste-up from one of the Denver papers, and scratched beneath it the date: May 15, 1947. POSH MOUNTAIN RESORT REOPENS WITH STELLAR GUEST REGISTER Derwent Says Overlook Will Be

``Showplace of the World'' (David)
By David Felton, Features Editor The Overlook Hotel has been opened and reopened in its thirty-eight-year history, but rarely with such style and dash as that promised by Horace Derwent, the mysterious California millionaire who is the latest owner of the hostelry. Derwent, who makes no secret of having sunk more than one million dollars into his (Derwent) newest venture -- and some say the figure is closer to three million -- says that
``The new Overlook will be one of the world's showplaces, the kind of hotel you will remember overnighting in thirty years later.'' (Derwent/Horace Derwent)
When Derwent, who is rumored to have substantial Las Vegas holdings, was asked if his (Derwent) purchase and refurbishing of the Overlook signaled the opening gun in a battle to legalize casino-style gambling in Colorado, the aircraft, movie, munitions, and shipping magnate denied it ... with a smile.
``The Overlook would be cheapened by gambling,'' (he)
he (magnate) said,
``and don't think I'm knocking Vegas! They've got too many of my markers out there for me to do that! I have no interest in lobbying for legalized gambling in Colorado. It would be spitting into the wind.'' (he)
When the Overlook opens officially -LRB-there was a gigantic and hugely successful party there some time ago when the actual work was finished-RRB-, the newly painted, papered, and decorated rooms will be occupied by a stellar guest list, ranging from Chic designer Corbat Stani to...

Smiling bemusedly, Jack turned the page. Now he (Jack) was looking at a full-page ad from the New York Sunday Times travel section. On the page after that a story on Derwent himself, a balding man with eyes that pierced you even from an old newsprint photo. He (man) was wearing rimless spectacles and a forties-style pencilline mustache that did nothing at all to make him (man) look like Errol Flynn. His (man) face was that of an accountant. It was the eyes that made him (man) look like someone or something else. Jack skimmed the article rapidly. He (Jack) knew most of the information from a Newsweek story on Derwent the year before. Born poor in St. Paul, never finished high school, joined the Navy instead. Rose rapidly, then left in a bitter wrangle over the patent on a new type of propeller that he (Rose) had designed. In the tug of war between the Navy and an unknown young man named Horace Derwent, Uncle Sam came off the predictable winner. But Uncle Sam had never gotten another patent, and there had been a lot of them. In the late twenties and early thirties, Derwent turned to aviation. He (Derwent) bought out a bankrupt cropdusting company, turned it into an airmail service, and prospered. More patents followed: a new monoplane wing design, a bomb carriage

used on the Flying Fortresses that had rained fire on Hamburg and Dresden and Berlin, a machine gun that was cooled by alcohol, a prototype of the ejection seat later used in United States jets. And along the line, the accountant who lived in the same skin as the inventor kept piling up the investments. A piddling string of munition factories in New York and New Jersey. Five textile mills in New England. Chemical factories in the bankrupt and groaning South. At the end of the Depression his (inventor) wealth had been nothing but a handful of controlling interests, bought at abysmally low prices, salable only at lower prices still. At one point Derwent boasted that he (Derwent) could liquidate completely and realize the price of a three-year-old Chevrolet. There had been rumors, Jack recalled, that some of the means employed by Derwent to keep his (Jack) head above water were less than savory. Involvement with bootlegging. Prostitution in the Midwest. Smuggling in the coastal areas of the South where his (Jack) fertilizer factories were. Finally an association with the nascent western gambling interests. Probably Derwent's most famous investment was the purchase of the foundering Top Mark Studios, which had not had a hit since their child star, Little Margery Morris, had died of a heroin overdose in 1934. She (Margery) was fourteen. Little Margery, who had specialized in sweet seven-year-olds who saved marriages and the lives of dogs unjustly accused of killing chickens, had been given the biggest Hollywood funeral in history by Top Mark -- the official story was that Little Margery had contracted a

``wasting disease'' (Margery)
while entertaining at a New York orphanage -- and some cynics suggested the studio had laid out all that long green because it knew it was burying itself. Derwent hired a keen businessman and raging sex maniac named Henry Finkel to run Top Mark, and in the two years before Pearl Harbor the studio ground out sixty movies, fifty-five of which glided right into the face of the Hayes Office and spit on its large blue nose. The other five were government training films. The feature films were huge successes. During one of them an unnamed costume designer had juryrigged a strapless bra for the heroine to appear in during the Grand Ball scene, where she (heroine) revealed everything except possibly the birthmark just below the cleft of her (heroine) buttocks. Derwent received credit for this invention as well, and his (designer) reputation -- or notoriety -- grew. The war had made him (designer) rich and he (designer) was still rich. Living in Chicago, seldom seen except for Derwent Enterprises board meetings -LRB-which he (designer) ran with an iron hand-RRB-, it was rumored that he (designer) owned United Air Lines, Las Vegas -LRB-where he (designer) was known to have controlling interests in four hotel-casinos and some involvement in at least six others-RRB-, Los Angeles, and the U.S.A. itself. Reputed to be a friend of royalty, presidents, and underworld kingpins, it was supposed by many that he (friend) was the richest man in the world. But he (friend) had not been able to make a go of the Overlook, Jack thought. He (Jack) put the scrapbook down for a moment and took the small notebook and mechanical pencil he (Jack) always kept with him (Jack) out of his (Jack) breast pocket. He (Jack) jotted
``Look into H. Derwent, Sidwndr lbry?'' (He)
He (Jack) put the notebook back and picked up the scrapbook again. His (Jack) face was preoccupied, his (Jack) eyes distant. He (Jack) wiped his (Jack) mouth constantly with his (Jack) hand as he (Jack) turned the pages. He (Jack) skimmed the material that followed, making a mental note to read it more closely later. Press releases were pasted into many of the pages. So-and-so was

expected at the Overlook next week, thus-and-such would be entertaining in the lounge -LRB-in Derwent's time it had been the Red-Eye Lounge-RRB-. Many of the entertainers were Vegas names, and many of the guests were Top Mark executives and stars. Then, in a clipping marked February 1, 1952: MILLIONAIRE EXEC TO SELL COLORADO INVESTMENTS Deal Made with California Investors on Overlook, Other Investments, Derwent Reveals By Rodney Conklin, Financial Editor In a terse communique yesterday from the Chicago offices of the monolithic Derwent Enterprises, it was revealed that millionaire -LRB-perhaps billionaire-RRB- Horace Derwent has sold out of Colorado in a stunning financial power play that will be completed by October 1, 1954. Derwent's investments include natural gas, coal, hydroelectric power, and a land development company called Colorado Sunshine, Inc., which owns or holds options on better than 500,000 acres of Colorado land. The most famous Derwent holding in Colorado, the Overlook Hotel, has already been sold, Derwent revealed in a rare interview yesterday. The buyer was a California group of investors headed by Charles Grondin, a former director of the California Land Development Corporation. While Derwent refused to discuss price, informed sources ...

He (Derwent) had sold out everything, lock, stock, and barrel. It wasn't just the Overlook. But somehow.. . somehow... He (Derwent) wiped his (Derwent) lips with his (Derwent) hand and wished he (Derwent) had a drink. This would go better with a drink. He (Derwent) turned more pages. The California group had opened the hotel for two seasons, and then sold it to a Colorado group called Mountainview Resorts. Mountainview went bankrupt in 1957 amid charges of corruption, nest-feathering, and cheating the stockholders. The president of the company shot himself two days after being subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury. The hotel had been closed for the rest of the decade. There was a single story about it, a Sunday feature headlined FORMER GRAND HOTEL SINKING INTO DECAY. The accompanying photos wrenched at Jack's heart: the paint on the front porch peeling, the lawn a bald and scabrous mess, windows broken by storms and stones. This would be a part of the book, if he (Jack) actually wrote it, too -- the phoenix going down into the ashes to be reborn. He (Jack) promised himself he (Jack) would take care of the place, very good care. It seemed that before today he (Jack) had never really understood the breadth of his (Jack) responsibility to the Overlook. It was almost like having a responsibility to history. In 1961 four writers, two of them Pulitzer Prize winners, had leased the Overlook and reopened it as a writers' school. That had lasted one year. One of the students had gotten drunk in his (Jack) third-floor room, crashed out of the window somehow, and fell to his (Jack) death on the cement terrace below. The paper hinted that it might have been suicide. Any big hotel have got scandals, Watson had said, just like every big hotel has got a ghost. Why? Hell, people come and go...

Suddenly it seemed that he (Watson) could almost feel the weight of the Overlook bearing down on him (Watson) from above, one hundred and ten guest rooms, the storage rooms, kitchen, pantry, freezer, lounge, ballroom, dining room ... -LRB-In the room the women come and go-RRB- -LRB-... and the Red Death held sway over all.-RRB- He (guest) rubbed his (guest) lips and turned to the next page in the scrapbook. He (guest) was in the last third of it now, and for the first time he (guest) wondered consciously whose book this was, left atop the highest pile of records in the cellar. A new headline, this one dated April 10, 1963. LAS VEGAS GROUP BUYS FAMED COLORADO HOTEL Scenic Overlook to Become Key Club Robert T. Leffing, spokesman for a group of investors going under the name of High Country Investments, announced today in Las Vegas that High Country has negotiated a deal for the famous Overlook Hotel, a resort located high in the Rockies. Leffing declined to mention the names of specific investors, but said the hotel would be turned into an exclusive

``key club.'' (investors)
He (T.) said that the group he (T.) represents hopes to sell memberships to high echelon executives in American and foreign companies. High Country also owns hotels in Montana, Wyoming, and Utah. The Overlook became world-known in the years 1946 to 1952 when it was owned by elusive mega-millionaire Horace Derwent, who ...

The item on the next page was a mere squib, dated four months later. The Overlook had opened under its new management. Apparently the paper hadn't been able to find out or wasn't interested in who the key holders were, because no name was mentioned but High Country Investments -- the most anonymous-sounding company name Jack had ever heard except for a chain of bike and appliance shops in western New England that went under the name of Business, Inc.. He (Jack) turned the page and blinked down at the clipping pasted there. MILLIONAIRE DERWENT BACK IN COLORADO VIA BACK DOOR? High Country Exec Revealed to be Charles Grondin By Rodney Conklin, Financial Editor The Overlook Hotel, a scenic pleasure palace in the Colorado high country and once the private plaything of millionaire Horace Derwent, is at the center of a financial tangle which is only now beginning to come to light. On April 10 of last year the hotel was purchased by a Las Vegas firm, High Country Investments, as a key club for wealthy executives of both foreign and domestic breeds. Now informed sources say that High Country is headed by Charles Grondin, 53, who was the head of California Land Development Corp. until 1959, when he (Grondin) resigned to take the position of executive veep in the Chicago home office of Derwent Enterprises. This has led to speculation that High Country Investments may be controlled by Derwent, who may have acquired the Overlook for the second time, and under decidedly peculiar circumstances. Grondin, who was indicted and acquitted on charges of tax evasion in 1960, could not be reached for comment, and Horace Derwent, who guards his (Derwent) own privacy jealously, had no comment when reached by telephone. State

Representative Dick Bows of Golden has called for a complete investigation into ...

That clipping was dated July 27, 1964. The next was a column from a Sunday paper that September. The byline belonged to Josh Brannigar, a muck-raking investigator of the Jack Anderson breed. Jack vaguely recalled that Brannigar had died in 1968 or '69. MAFIA FREE-ZONE IN COLORADO? By Josh Brannigar It now seems possible that the newest r&r spot of Organization overlords in the U.S. is located at an out-of-the-way hotel nestled in the center of the Rockies. The Overlook Hotel, a white elephant that has been run lucklessly by almost a dozen different groups and individuals since it first opened its doors in 1910, is now being operated as a security-jacketed

``key club,'' (individuals)
ostensibly for unwinding businessmen. The question is, what business are the Overlook's key holders really in? The members present during the week of August 16-23 may give us an idea. The list below was obtained by a former employee of High Country Investments, a company first believed to be a dummy company owned by Derwent Enterprises. It now seems more likely that Derwent's interest in High Country -LRB-if any-RRB- is outweighed by those of several Las Vegas gambling barons. And these same gaming honchos have been linked in the past to both suspected and convicted underworld kingpins. Present at the Overlook during that sunny week in August were: Charles Grondin, President of High Country Investments. When it became known in July of this year that he (Grondin) was running the High Country ship it was announced -- considerably after the fact -- that he (Grondin) had resigned his (Grondin) position in Derwent Enterprises previously. The silver-maned Grondin, who refused to talk to me for this column, has been tried once and acquitted on tax evasion charges -LRB-1960-RRB- . Charles
``Baby Charlie'' (Charles)
Battaglia, a 60-year-old Vegas empressario -LRB-controlling interests in The Greenback and The Lucky Bones on the Strip-RRB-. Battaglia is a close personal friend of Grondin. His (Grondin) arrest record stretches back to 1932, when he (Grondin) was tried and acquitted in the gangland-style murder of Jack
``Dutchy'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Morgan. Federal authorities suspect his (Jack) involvement in the drug traffic, prostitution, and murder for hire, but
``Baby Charlie'' (Federal authorities)
has only been behind bars once, for income tax evasion in 1955-56. Richard Scarne, the principal stockholder of Fun Time Automatic Machines. Fun Time makes slot machines for the Nevada crowd, pinball machines, and jukeboxes -LRB-Melody-Coin-RRB- for the rest of the country. He (Richard) has done time for assault with a deadly weapon -LRB-1940-RRB-, carrying a concealed weapon -LRB-1948-RRB-, and conspiracy to commit tax fraud -LRB-1961-RRB- . Peter Zeiss, a Miami-based importer, now nearing 70. For the last five years Zeiss has been fighting deportation as an undesirable person. He (Peter) has been convicted on charges of receiving and concealing stolen property -LRB-1958-RRB-, and conspiracy to commit tax fraud -LRB-1954-RRB-. Charming, distinguished, and courtly, Pete Zeiss is called
``Poppa'' (Pete)
by his (Pete) intimates and has been tried on charges of murder and accessory to murder. A large stockholder in Scarne's Fun Time company, he (Pete) also has known interests in four Las Vegas casinos. Vittorio Gienelli, also known as
``Vito the Chopper,'' (Gienelli/Vittorio Gienelli)
tried twice for gangland-style murders, one of them the ax-murder of Boston vice overlord

Frank Scoffy. Gienelli has been indicted twenty-three times, tried fourteen times, and convicted only once, for shoplifting in 1940. It has been said that in recent years Gienelli has become a power in the organization's western operation, which is centered in Las Vegas. Carl

``Jimmy-Ricks'' (Carl)
Prashkin, a San Francisco investor, reputed to be the heir apparent of the power Gienelli now wields. Prashkin owns large blocks of stock in Derwent Enterprises, High Country Investments, Fun Time Automatic Machines, and three Vegas casinos. Prashkin is clean in America, but was indicted in Mexico on fraud charges that were dropped quickly three weeks after they were brought. It has been suggested that Prashkin may be in charge of laundering money skimmed from Vegas casino operations and funneling the big bucks back into the organization's legitimate western operations. And such operations may now include the Overlook Hotel in Colorado. Other visitors during the current season include...

There was more but Jack only skimmed it, constantly wiping his (Jack) lips with his (Jack) hand. A banker with Las Vegas connections. Men from New York who were apparently doing more in the Garment District than making clothes. Men reputed to be involved with drugs, vice, robbery, murder. God, what a story! And they had all been here, right above him (God), in those empty rooms. Screwing expensive whores on the third floor, maybe. Drinking magnums of champagne. Making deals that would turn over millions of dollars, maybe in the very suite of rooms where Presidents had stayed. There was a story, all right. One hell of a story. A little frantically, he (God) took out his (God) notebook and jotted down another memo to check all of these people out at the library in Denver when the caretaking job was over. Every hotel has its ghost? The Overlook had a whole coven of them. First suicide, then the Mafia, what next? The next clipping was an angry denial of Brannigar's charges by Charles Grondin. Jack smirked at it. The clipping on the next page was so large that it had been folded. Jack unfolded it and gasped harshly. The picture there seemed to leap out at him (Jack): the wallpaper had been changed since June of 1966, but he (Jack) knew that window and the view perfectly well. It was the western exposure of the Presidential Suite. Murder came next. The sitting room wall by the door leading into the bedroom was splashed with blood and what could only be white flecks of brain matter. A blank-faced cop was standing over a corpse hidden by a blanket. Jack stared, fascinated, and then his (Jack) eyes moved up to the headline. GANGLAND-STYLE SHOOTING AT COLORADO HOTEL Reputed Crime Overlord Shot at Mountain Key Club Two Others Dead SIDEWINDER, COLO -LRB-UPI-RRB--Forty miles from this sleepy Colorado town, a gangland-style execution has occurred in the heart of the Rocky Mountains. The Overlook Hotel, purchased three years ago as an exclusive key club by a Las Vegas firm, was the site of a triple shotgun slaying. Two of the men were either the companions or bodyguards of Vittorio Gienelli, also known as

``The Chopper'' (Gienelli/Vittorio Gienelli)
for his (Gienelli) reputed involvement in a Boston slaying twenty years ago. Police were summoned by Robert Norman, manager of the Overlook, who said

he (Norman) heard shots and that some of the guests reported two men wearing stockings on their faces and carrying guns had fled down the fire escape and driven off in a late-model tan convertible. State Trooper Benjamin Moorer discovered two dead men, later identified as Victor T. Boorman and Roger Macassi, both of Las Vegas, outside the door of the Presidential Suite where two American Presidents have stayed. Inside, Moorer found the body of Gienelli sprawled on the floor. Gienelli was apparently fleeing his (Gienelli) attackers when he (Gienelli) was cut down. Moorer said Gienelli had been shot with heavy-gauge shotguns at close range. Charles Grondin, the representative of the company which now owns the Overlook, could not be reached for...

Below the clipping, in heavy strokes of a ball-point pen, someone had written: They took his (Grondin) balls along with them. Jack stared at that for a long time, feeling cold. Whose book was this? He (Jack) turned the page at last, swallowing a click in his (Jack) throat. Another column from Josh Brannigar, this one dated early 1967. He (Brannigar) only read the headline: NOTORIOUS HOTEL SOLD FOLLOWING MURDER OF UNDERWORLD FIGURE. The sheets following that clipping were blank. -LRB-They took his (Brannigar) balls along with them.-RRB- He (Brannigar) flipped back to the beginning, looking for a name or address. Even a room number. Because he (Brannigar) felt quite sure that whoever had kept this little book of memories had stayed at the hotel. But there was nothing. He (Brannigar) was getting ready to go through all the clippings, more closely this time, when a voice called down the stairs:

``Jack? Hon?'' (He)
Wendy. He (Brannigar) started, almost guiltily, as if he (Brannigar) had been drinking secretly and she (Wendy) would smell the fumes on him (Brannigar). Ridiculous. He (Brannigar) scrubbed his (Brannigar) lips with his (Brannigar) hand and called back,
``Yeah, babe. Lookin for rats.'' (He)
She (Wendy) was coming down. He (Brannigar) heard her (Wendy) on the stairs, then crossing the boiler room. Quickly, without thinking why he (Brannigar) might be doing it, be stuffed the scrapbook under a pile of bills and invoices. He (Brannigar) stood up as she (Wendy) came through the arch.
``What in the world have you been doing down here? It's almost three o'clock!'' (He)
He (Brannigar) smiled.
``Is it that late? I got rooting around through all this stuff. Trying to find out where the bodies are buried, I guess.'' (unknown)
The words clanged back viciously in his (Brannigar) mind. She (Wendy) came closer, looking at him (Brannigar), and he (Brannigar) unconsciously retreated a step, unable to help himself. He (Brannigar) knew what she (Wendy) was doing. She (Wendy) was trying to smell liquor on him (Brannigar). Probably she (Wendy) wasn't even aware of it herself, but he (Brannigar) was, and it made him (Brannigar) feel both guilty and angry.
``Your mouth is bleeding,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said in a curiously flat tone.
``Huh?'' (He)
He (Brannigar) put his (Brannigar) hand to his (Brannigar) lips and winced at the thin stinging. His (Brannigar) index finger came away bloody. His (Brannigar) guilt increased.
``You've been rubbing your mouth again,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said. He (Brannigar) looked down and shrugged.
``Yeah, I guess I have.'' (unknown)
``It's been hell for you, hasn't it?'' (unknown)
``No, not so bad.'' (unknown)
``Has it gotten any easier?'' (He)

He (Brannigar) looked up at her (Wendy) and made his (Brannigar) feet start moving. Once they were actually in motion it was easier. He (Brannigar) crossed to his (Brannigar) wife and slipped an arm around her (wife) waist. He (Brannigar) brushed aside a sheaf of her (wife) blond hair and kissed her (wife) neck.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Brannigar) said.
``Where's Danny?'' (unknown)
``Oh, he (Danny)'s around somewhere. It's started to cloud up outside. Hungry?'' (He)
He (Brannigar) slipped a hand over her (wife) taut, jeans-clad bottom with counterfeit lechery.
``Like ze bear, madame.'' (unknown)
``Watch out, slugger. Don't start something you can't finish.'' (unknown)
``Fig-fig, madame?'' (he)
he (Brannigar) asked, still rubbing.
``Dirty peeotures? Unnatural positions?'' (he)
As they went through the arch, he (Brannigar) threw one glance back at the box where the scrapbook -LRB-whose?-RRB- was hidden. With the light out it was only a shadow. He (Brannigar) was relieved that he (Brannigar) had gotten Wendy away. His (Brannigar) lust became less acted, more natural, as they approached the stairs.
``Maybe,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said.
``After we get you a sandwich-yeek!'' (She)
She (Wendy) twisted away from him (Brannigar), giggling.
``That tickles!'' (unknown)
``It teekles nozzing like Jock Torrance would like to teekle you, madame.'' (unknown)
``Lay off, Jock. How about a ham and cheese ... for the first course?'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
They went up the stairs together, and Jack didn't look over his (Jack) shoulder again. But he (Jack) thought of Watson's words: Every big hotel has got a ghost. Why? Hell, people come and go... Then Wendy shut the basement door behind them, closing it into darkness.

<< 19 >> OUTSIDE 217 Danny was remembering the words of someone else who had worked at the Overlook during the season: Her (Wendy) saying she (Wendy)'d seen something in one of the rooms where ... a bad thing happened. That was in Room 217 and I want you to promise me you won't go in there, Danny ... steer right clear ... It was a perfectly ordinary door, no different from any other door on the first two floors of the hotel. It was dark gray, halfway down a corridor that ran at right angles to the main second-floor hallway. The numbers on the door looked no different from the house numbers on the Boulder apartment building they had lived in. A 2, a 1, and a 7. Big deal. Just below them was a tiny glass circle, a peephole. Danny had tried several of them. From the inside you got a wide, fish-eye view of the corridor. From outside you could screw up your eye seven ways to Sunday and still not see a thing. A dirty gyp: -LRB-Why are you here?-RRB-

After the walk behind the Overlook, he (Danny) and Mommy had come back and she (Mommy) had fixed him (Danny) his (Danny) favorite lunch, a cheese and bologna sandwich plus Campbell's Bean Soup. They ate in Dick's kitchen and talked. The radio was on, getting thin and crackly music from the Estes Park station. The kitchen was his (Estes) favorite place in the hotel, and he (Estes) guessed that Mommy and Daddy must feel the same way, because after trying their meals in the dining room for three days or so, they had begun eating in the kitchen by mutual consent, setting up chairs around Dick Hallorann's butcher block, which was almost as big as their dining room table back in Stovington, anyway. The dining room had been too depressing, even with the lights on and the music playing from the tape cassette system in the office. You were still just one of three people sitting at a table surrounded by dozens of other tables, all empty, all covered with those transparent plastic dustcloths. Mommy said it was like having dinner in the middle of a Horace Walpole novel, and Daddy had laughed and agreed. Danny had no idea who Horace Walpole was, but he (Danny) did know that Mommy's cooking had begun to taste better as soon as they began to eat it in the kitchen. He (Danny) kept discovering little flashes of Dick Hallorann's personality lying around, and they reassured him (Hallorann) like a warm touch. Mommy had eaten half a sandwich, no soup. She (they) said Daddy must have gone out for a walk of his (Daddy) own since both the VW and the hotel truck were in the parking lot. She (they) said she (they) was tired and might lie down for an hour or so, if he (Daddy) thought he (Daddy) could amuse himself and not get into trouble. Danny told her (they) around a mouthful of cheese and bologna that he (Danny) thought he (Danny) could.

``Why don't you go out into the playground?'' (she)
she (they) asked him (Danny).
``I thought you'd love that place, with a sandbox for your trucks and all.'' (He)
He (Danny) swallowed and the food went down his (Danny) throat in a lump that was dry and hard.
``Maybe I will,'' (he)
he (Danny) said, turning to the radio and fiddling with it.
``And all those neat hedge animals,'' (she)
she (they) said, taking his (Danny) empty plate.
``Your father's got to get out and trim them pretty soon.'' (unknown)
``Yeah,'' (he)
he (Danny) said. -LRB-Just nasty things ... once it had to do with those damn hedges clipped to look like animals ...-RRB-
``If you see your father before I do, tell him (father) I'm lying down.'' (unknown)
``Sure, Mom.'' (She)
She (they) put the dirty dishes in the sink and came back over to him (Danny).
``Are you happy here, Danny?'' (He)
He (Danny) looked at her (they) guilelessly, a milk mustache on his (Danny) lip.
``Uh-huh.'' (unknown)
``No more bad dreams?'' (unknown)
``No.'' (Tony)
Tony had come to him (Tony) once, one night while he (Tony) was lying in bed, calling his (Tony) name faintly and from far away. Danny had squeezed his (Danny) eyes tightly shut until Tony had gone.
``You sure?'' (unknown)
``Yes, Mom.'' (She)
She (they) seemed satisfied.
``How's your hand?'' (He)
He (Tony) flexed it for her (they).
``All better.'' (She)
She (they) nodded. Jack had taken the nest under the Pyrex bowl, full of frozen wasps, out to the incinerator in back of the equipment shed and burned it. They had seen no more wasps since. He (Jack) had written to a lawyer in Boulder, enclosing

the snaps of Danny's hand, and the lawyer had called back two days ago -- that had put Jack in a foul temper all afternoon. The lawyer doubted if the company that had manufactured the bug bomb could be sued successfully because there was only Jack to testify that he (Jack) had followed directions printed on the package. Jack had asked the lawyer if they couldn't purchase some others and test them for the same defect. Yes, the lawyer said, but the results were highly doubtful even if all the test bombs malfunctioned. He (lawyer) told Jack of a case that involved an extension ladder company and a man who had broken his (man) back. Wendy had commiserated with Jack, but privately she (Wendy) had just been glad that Danny had gotten off as cheaply as he (Danny) had. It was best to leave lawsuits to people who understood them, and that did not include the Torrances. And they had seen no more wasps since.

``Go and play, doc. Have fun.'' (he)
But he (Danny) hadn't had fun. He (Danny) had wandered aimlessly around the hotel, poking into the maids' closets and the janitor's rooms, looking for something interesting, not finding it, a small boy padding along a dark blue carpet woven with twisting black lines. He (boy) had tried a room door from time to time, but of course they were all locked. The passkey was hanging down in the office, he (boy) knew where, but Daddy had told him (Daddy) he (Daddy) shouldn't touch that. And he (Daddy) didn't want to. Did be? -LRB-Why are you here?-RRB- There was nothing aimless about it after all. He (Daddy) had been drawn to Room 217 by a morbid kind of curiosity. He (Daddy) remembered a story Daddy had read to him (Daddy) once when he (Daddy) was drunk. That had been a long time ago, but the story was just as vivid now as when Daddy had read it to him (Daddy). Mommy had scolded Daddy and asked what he (Daddy) was doing, reading a three-year-old baby something so horrible. The name of the story was Bluebeard. That was clear in his (Daddy) mind too, because he (Daddy) had thought at first Daddy was saying Bluebird, and there were no bluebirds in the story, or birds of any kind for that matter. Actually the story was about Bluebeard's wife, a pretty lady that had corn-colored hair like Mommy. After Bluebeard married her (lady), they lived in a big and ominous castle that was not unlike the Overlook. And every day Bluebeard went off to work and every day he (Daddy) would tell his (Daddy) pretty little wife not to look in a certain room, although the key to that room was hanging right on a hook, just like the passkey was hanging on the office wall downstairs. Bluebeard's wife had gotten more and more curious about the locked room. She (wife) tried to peep through the keyhole the way Danny had tried to look through Room 217's peephole with similar unsatisfying results. There was even a picture of her (wife) getting down on her (wife) knees and trying to look under the door, but the crack wasn't wide enough. The door swung wide and ... The old fairy tale book had depicted her (fairy) discovery in ghastly, loving detail. The image was burned on Danny's mind. The severed heads of Bluebeard's seven previous wives were in the room, each one on its own pedestal, the eyes turned up to whites, the mouths unhinged and gaping in silent screams. They were somehow balanced on necks ragged from the broadsword's decapitating swing, and there was blood running down the pedestals. Terrified, she (fairy) had turned to flee from the room and the castle, only to discover Bluebeard standing in the doorway, his (Danny) terrible eyes blazing.
``I told you not to enter this room,'' (Bluebeard)
Bluebeard said, unsheathing his (Danny) sword.
``Alas, in your curiosity you are like the other seven, and though I loved you best of all

your ending shall be as was theirs. Prepare to die, wretched woman!'' (unknown)

It seemed vaguely to Danny that the story had bad a happy ending, but that had paled to insignificance beside the two dominant images: the taunting, maddening locked door with some great secret behind it, and the grisly secret itself, repeated more than half a dozen times. The locked door and behind it the heads, the severed beads. His (Danny) hand reached out and stroked the room's doorknob, almost furtively. He (Danny) had no idea how long be had been here, standing hypnotized before the bland gray locked door. -LRB-And maybe three times I've thought I've seen things ... nasty things ...-RRB- But Mr. Hallorann -- Dick -- had also said he (Hallorann) didn't think those things could hurt you. They were like scary pictures in a book, that was all. And maybe he (Hallorann) wouldn't see anything. On the other hand ... He (Hallorann) plunged his (Hallorann) left hand into his (Hallorann) pocket and it came out holding the passkey. It had been there all along, of course. He (Hallorann) held it by the square metal tab on the end which had OFFICE printed on it in Magic Marker. He (Hallorann) twirled the key on its chain, watching it go around and around. After several minutes of this he (Hallorann) stopped and slipped the passkey into the lock. It slid in smoothly, with no hitch, as if it had wanted to be there all along. -LRB-I've thought I've seen things ... nasty things ... promise me you won't go in there.-RRB- -LRB-I promise.-RRB- And a promise was, of course, very important. Still, his (Hallorann) curiosity itched at him (Hallorann) as maddeningly as poison ivy in a place you aren't supposed to scratch. But it was a dreadful kind of curiosity, the kind that makes you peek through your fingers during the scariest parts of a scary movie. What was beyond that door would be no movie. -LRB-I don't think those things can hurt you ... like scary pictures in a book ...-RRB- Suddenly he (Hallorann) reached out with his (Hallorann) left hand, not sure of what it was going to do until it had removed the passkey and stuffed it back into his (Hallorann) pocket. He (Hallorann) stared at the door a moment longer, blue-gray eyes wide, then turned quickly and walked back down the corridor toward the main hallway that ran at right angles to the corridor he (Hallorann) was in. Something made him (Hallorann) pause there and he (Hallorann) wasn't sure what for a moment. Then he (Hallorann) remembered that directly around this corner, on the way back to the stairs, there was one of those old-fashioned fire extinguishers curled up against the wall. Curled there like a dozing snake. They weren't chemical-type extinguishers at all, Daddy said, although there were several of those in the kitchen. These were the forerunner of the modern sprinkler systems. The long canvas hoses hooked directly into the Overlook's plumbing system, and by turning a single valve you could become a one-man fire department. Daddy said that the chemical extinguishers, which sprayed foam or CO, were much better. The chemicals smothered fires, took away the oxygen they needed to burn, while a high-pressure spray might just spread the flames around. Daddy said that Mr. Ullman should replace the old-fashioned hoses right along with the old-fashioned boiler, but Mr. Ullman would probably do neither because he (Ullman) was a CHEAP PRICK. Danny knew that this was one of the worst epithets his (Danny)

father could summon. It was applied to certain doctors, dentists, and appliance repairmen, and also to the head of his (Danny) English Department at Stovington, who had disallowed some of Daddy's book orders because he (Danny) said the books would put them over budget.

``Over budget, hell,'' (he)
he (Danny) had fumed to Wendy -- Danny had been listening from his (Danny) bedroom where he (Danny) was supposed to be asleep.
``He (You)'s just saving the last five hundred bucks for himself, the CHEAP PRICK.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny looked around the corner. The extinguisher was there, a fiat hose folded back a dozen times on itself, the red tank attached to the wall. Above it was an ax in a glass case like a museum exhibit, with white words printed on a red background: IN CASE OF EMERGENCY, BREAK GLASS. Danny could read the word EMERGENCY, which was also the name of one of his (Danny) favorite TV shows, but was unsure of the rest. But he (Danny) didn't like the way the word was used in connection with that long fiat hose. EMERGENCY was', fire, explosions, car crashes, hospitals, sometimes death. And he (Danny) didn't like the way that hose hung so blandly on the wall. When he (Danny) was alone, he (Danny) always skittered past these extinguishers as fast as he (Danny) could. No particular reason. It just felt better to go fast. It felt safer. Now, heart thumping loudly in his (Danny) chest, he (Danny) came around the corner and looked down the hall past the extinguisher to the stairs. Mommy was down there, sleeping. And if Daddy was back from his (Daddy) walk, he (Daddy) would probably be sitting in the kitchen, eating a sandwich and reading a book. He (Daddy) would just walk right past that old extinguisher and go downstairs. He (Daddy) started toward it, moving closer to the far wall until his (Daddy) right arm was brushing the expensive silk paper. Twenty steps away. Fifteen. A dozen. When he (Daddy) was ten steps away, the brass nozzle suddenly rolled off the fat loop it had been lying -LRB-sleeping?-RRB- on and fell to the hall carpet with a dull thump. It lay there, the dark bore of its muzzle pointing at Danny. He (Danny) stopped immediately, his (Danny) shoulders twitching forward with the suddenness of his (Danny) scare. His (Danny) blood thumped thickly in his (Danny) ears and temples. His (Danny) mouth had gone dry and sour, his (Danny) hands curled into fists. Yet the nozzle of the hose only lay there, its brass casing glowing mellowly, a loop of flat canvas leading back up to the red-painted frame bolted to the wall. So it had fallen off, so what? It was only a fire extinguisher, nothing else. It was stupid to think that it looked like some poison snake from
``Wide World of Animals'' (him)
that had heard him (Danny) and woken up. Even if the stitched canvas did look a little bit like scales. He (Danny) would just step over it and go down the hall to the stairs, walking a little bit fast, maybe, to make sure it didn't snap out after him (Danny) and curl around his (Danny) foot... He (Danny) wiped his (Danny) lips with his (Danny) left hand, in unconscious imitation of his (Danny) father, and took a step forward. No movement from the hose. Another step. Nothing. There, see how stupid you are? You got all worked up thinking about that dumb room and that dumb Bluebeard story and that hose was probably ready to fall off for the last five years. That's all. Danny stared at the hose on the floor and thought of wasps. Eight steps away, the nozzle of the hose gleamed peacefully at him (Danny) from the rug as if to say: Don't worry. I'm just a hose, that's all. And even if that isn't all, what I do to you won't be much worse than a bee sting. Or a wasp

sting. What would I want to do to a nice little boy like you ... except bite... and bite ... and bite? Danny took another step, and another. His (Danny) breath was dry and harsh in his (Danny) throat. Panic was close now. He (Danny) began to wish the hose would move, then at last he (Danny) would know, he (Danny) would be sure. He (Danny) took another step and now he (Danny) was within striking distance. But it's not going to strike at you, he (Danny) thought hysterically. How can it strike at you, bite at you, when it's just a hose? Maybe it's full of wasps. His (Danny) internal temperature plummeted to ten below zero. He (Danny) stared at the black bore in the center of the nozzle, nearly hypnotized. Maybe it was full of wasps, secret wasps, their brown bodies bloated with poison, so full of autumn poison that it dripped from their stingers in clear drops of fluid. Suddenly he (Danny) knew that he (Danny) was nearly frozen with terror; if he (Danny) did not make his (Danny) feet go now, they would become locked to the carpet and he (Danny) would stay here, staring at the black hole in the center of the brass nozzle like a bird staring at a snake, he (Danny) would stay here until his (Danny) daddy found him (Danny) and then what would happen? With a high moan, he (Danny) made himself run. As he (Danny) reached the hose, some trick of the light made the nozzle seem to move, to revolve as if to strike, and he (Danny) leaped high in the air above it; in his (Danny) panicky state it seemed that his (Danny) legs pushed him (Danny) nearly all the way to the ceiling, that he (Danny) could feel the stiff back hairs that formed his (Danny) cowlick brushing the hallway's plaster ceiling, although later he (Danny) knew that couldn't have been so. He (Danny) came down on the other side of the hose and ran, and suddenly he (Danny) heard it behind him (Danny), coming for him (Danny), the soft dry whicker of that brass snake's head as it slithered rapidly along the carpet after him (Danny) like a rattlesnake moving swiftly through a dry field of grass. It was coming for him (Danny), and suddenly the stairs seemed very far away; they seemed to retreat a running step into the distance for each running step he (Danny) took toward them. Daddy! he (Danny) tried to scream, but his (Danny) closed throat would not allow a word to pass. He (Danny) was on his (Danny) own. Behind him (Danny) the sound grew louder, the dry sliding sound of the snake, slipping swiftly over the carpet's dry hackles. At his (Danny) heels now, perhaps rising up with the clear poison dribbling from its brass snout. Danny reached the stairs and had to pinwheel his (Danny) arms crazily for balance. For one moment it seemed sure that he (Danny) would cartwheel over and go head-for-heels to the bottom. He (Danny) threw a glance back over his (Danny) shoulder. The hose had not moved. It lay as it had lain, one loop off the frame, the brass nozzle on the hall floor, the nozzle pointing disinterestedly away from him (Danny). You see, stupid? he (Danny) berated himself. You made it all up, scaredy-cat. It was all your imagination, scaredy-cat, scaredy-cat. He (Danny) clung to the stairway railing, his (Danny) legs trembling in reaction. -LRB-It never chased you-RRB- his (Danny) mind told him (Danny), and seized on that thought, and played it back. -LRB-never chased you, never chased you, never did, never did-RRB- It was nothing to be afraid of. Why, he (Danny) could go back and put that hose right into its frame, if he (Danny) wanted to. He (Danny) could, but he (Danny) didn't think he (Danny) would. Because what if it had chased him (Danny) and had gone back when it saw that it couldn't ...

quite ... catch him (Danny)? The hose lay on the carpet, almost seeming to ask him (Danny) if he (Danny) would like to come back and try again. Panting, Danny ran downstairs.

<< 20 >> TALKING TO MR. ULLMAN The Sidewinder Public Library was a small, retiring building one block down from the town's business area. It was a modest, vine-covered building, and the wide concrete walk up to the door was lined with the corpses of last summer's flowers. On the lawn was a large bronze statue of a Civil War general Jack had never heard of, although he (Jack) had been something of a Civil War buff in his (Jack) teenage years. The newspaper files were kept downstairs. They consisted of the Sidewinder Gazette that had gone bust in 1963, the Estes Park daily, and the Boulder Camera. No Denver papers at all. Sighing, Jack settled for the Camera. When the files reached 1965, the actual newspapers were replaced by spools of microfilm -LRB-

``A federal grant,'' (the librarian)
the librarian told him (Jack) brightly.
``We hope to do 1958 to '64 when the next check comes through, but they're so slow, aren't they? You will be careful, won't you? I just know you will. Call if you need me.'' (unknown)
-RRB-. The only reading machine had a lens that had somehow gotten warped, and by the time Wendy put her (Wendy) hand on his (Jack) shoulder some forty-five minutes after he (Jack) had switched from the actual papers, he (Jack) had a juicy thumper of a headache.
``Danny's in the park,'' (she)
she (Wendy) said,
``but I don't want him (Danny) outside too long. How much longer do you think you'll be?'' (she)
``Ten minutes,'' (he)
he (Jack) said. Actually he (Jack) had traced down the last of the Overlook's fascinating history ¯ the years between the gangland shooting and the takeover by Stuart Ullman & Co.. But he (Ullman) felt the same reticence about telling Wendy.
``What are you up to, anyway?'' (she)
she (Wendy) asked. She (Wendy) ruffed his (Ullman) hair as she (Wendy) said it, but her (Wendy) voice was only half-teasing.

he (Ullman) said.

he (Ullman) said, having to strive to keep his (Ullman) voice pleasant now. She (Wendy) was prying, just the way she (Wendy) had always pried and poked at him (Ullman) when they had been at Stovington and Danny was still a crib-infant. Where are you going, Jack? When

will you be back? How much money do you have with you? Are you going to take the car? Is Al going to be with you? Will one of you stay sober? On and on. She (Wendy) had, pardon the expression, driven him (Al) to drink. Maybe that hadn't been the only reason, but by Christ let's tell the truth here and admit it was one of them. He (reader) had claimed that Excedrin was the only nonprescription drug ever invented that could stop a hangover dead in its tracks. Absolutely the only one. He (reader) had begun to think of his (reader) morning-after thumpers as Excedrin Headache Number Vat 69.

``Well then, I guess the drugstore would be your best bet. They have a booth.'' (unknown)
