He (reader) went out and down the walk, past the anonymous Civil War general. He (reader) began to walk toward the business block, hands stuffed in his (reader) pockets, head thudding like a leaden bell. The sky was also leaden; it was November 7, and with the new month the weather had become threatening. There had been a number of snow flurries. There had been snow in October too, but that had melted. The new flurries had stayed, a light frosting over everything it sparkled in the sunlight like fine crystal. But there had been no sunlight today, and even as he (reader) reached the drugstore it began to spit snow again. The phone booth was at the back of the building, and he (reader) was halfway down an aisle of patent medicines, jingling his (reader) change in his (reader) pocket, when his (reader) eyes fell on the white boxes with their green print. He (reader) took one of them to the cashier, paid, and went back to the telephone booth. He (reader) pulled the door closed, put his (reader) change and matchbook cover on the counter, and dialed O.
``Your call, please?'' (He)
``Fort Lauderdale, Florida, operator.'' (He)
He (reader) gave her (cashier) the number there and the number in the booth. When she (cashier) told him (reader) it would be a dollar ninety for the first three minutes, he (reader) dropped eight quarters into the slot, wincing each time the bell bonged in his (reader) ear. Then, left in limbo with only the faraway clickings and gabblings of connection-making, he (reader) took the green-bottle of Excedrin out of its box, pried up the white cap, and dropped the wad of cotton batting to the floor of the booth. Cradling the phone receiver between his (reader) ear and shoulder, he (reader) shook out three of the white tablets and lined them up on the counter beside his (reader) remaining change. He (reader) recapped the bottle and put it in his (reader) pocket. At the other end, the phone was picked up on the first ring.
``Surf-Sand Resort, how may we help you?'' (unknown)
the perky female voice asked.
``I'd like to speak with the manager, please.'' (unknown)
``Do you mean Mr. Trent or -- '' (unknown)
``I mean Mr. Ullman.'' (unknown)
``I believe Mr. Ullman is busy, but if you would like me to check -- '' (unknown)
``I would. Tell him (Ullman) it's Jack Torrance calling from Colorado.'' (unknown)
``One moment, please.'' (She)
She (reader) put him (reader) on hold. Jack's dislike for that cheap, self-important little prick Ullman came flooding back. He (Ullman) took one of the Excedrins from the counter, regarded it for a moment, then put it into his (Ullman) mouth and began to chew it, slowly and with relish. The taste flooded back like memory, making his (Ullman) saliva squirt in mingled pleasure and unhappiness. A dry, bitter taste, but a compelling one. He (Ullman) swallowed with a grimace. Chewing aspirin had been a habit with him (Ullman) in his (Ullman) drinking days; he (Ullman) hadn't done it at all since then. But when your headache was bad enough, a hangover headache or one like this one, chewing them seemed to make them get to work quicker. He (Ullman) had read somewhere that chewing aspirin could become addictive. Where had he (Ullman) read that, anyway? Frowning, he (Ullman) tried to think. And then Ullman came on the line.
``Torrance? What's the trouble?'' (unknown)
``No trouble,'' (he)
he (Ullman) said. ``The boiler's okay and I haven't even gotten around to

murdering my wife yet. I'm saving that until after the holidays, when things get dull.'' ``Very funny. Why are you calling? I'm a busy -- '' ``Busy man, yes, I understand that. I'm calling about some things that you didn't tell me during your history of the Overlooks great and honorable past. Like how Horace Derwent sold it to a bunch of Las Vegas sharpies who dealt it through so many dummy corporations that not even the IRS knew who really owned it. About how they waited until the time was right and then turned it into a playground for Mafia bigwigs, and about how it had to be shut down in 1966 when one of them got a little bit dead. Along with his (Derwent) bodyguards, who were standing outside the door to the Presidential Suite. Great place, the Overlook's Presidential Suite. Wilson, Harding, Roosevelt, Nixon, and Vito the Chopper, right?'' There was a moment of surprised silence on the other end of the line, and then Ullman said quietly: ``I don't see how that can have any bearing on your job, Mr. Torrance. It '' ``The best part happened after Gienelli was shot, though, don't you think? Two more quick shuffles, now you see it and now you don't, and then the Overlook is suddenly owned by a private citizen, a woman named Sylvia Hunter ... who just happened to be Sylvia Hunter Derwent from 1942 to 1948.'' ``Your three minutes are up,'' the operator said. ``Signal when through.'' ``My dear Mr. Torrance, all of this is public knowledge ... and ancient history.'' ``It formed no part of my knowledge,'' Jack said. ``I doubt if many other people know it, either. Not all of it. They remember the Gienelli shooting, maybe, but I doubt if anybody has put together all the wondrous and strange shuffles the Overlook has been through since 1945. And it always seems like Derwent or a Derwent associate comes up with the door prize. What was Sylvia Hunter running up there in '67 and '68, Mr. Ullman? It was a whorehouse, wasn't it?'' ``Torrance!'' His (Jack) shock crackled across two thousand miles of telephone cable without losing a thing. Smiling, Jack popped another Excedrin into his (Jack) mouth and chewed it. ``She (it) sold out after a rather well known U.S. senator died of a heart attack up there. There were rumors that he (senator) was found naked except for black nylon stockings and a garter belt and a pair of high-heeled pumps. Patent-leather pumps, as a matter of fact.'' ``That's a vicious, damnable lie!'' Ullman cried. ``Is it?'' Jack asked. He (Jack) was beginning to feel better. The headache was draining away. He (Jack) took the last Excedrin and chewed it up, enjoying the bitter, powdery taste as the tablet shredded in his (Jack) mouth. ``It was a very unfortunate occurrence,'' Ullman said. ``Now what is the point, Torrance? If you're planning to write some ugly smear article ... if this is some illconceived, stupid blackmail idea...'' ``Nothing of the sort,'' Jack said. ``I called because I didn't think you played square with me. And because -- '' ``Didn't play square?'' Ullman cried. ``My God, did you think I was going to share a large pile of dirty laundry with the hotel's caretaker? Who in heaven's name do you think you are? And how could those old stories possibly affect you

anyway? Or do you think there are ghosts parading up and down the halls of the west wing wearing bedsheets and crying `Woe!'?'' ``No, I don't think there are any ghosts. But you raked up a lot of my personal history before you gave me the job. You had me on the carpet, quizzing me about my ability to take care of your hotel like a little boy in front of the teacher's desk for peeing in the coatroom. You embarrassed me.'' ``I just do not believe your cheek, your bloody damned impertinence,'' Ullman said. He (Ullman) sounded as if he (Ullman) might be choking. ``I'd like to sack you. And perhaps I will.'' ``I think Al Shockley might object. Strenuously.'' ``And I think you may have finally overestimated Mr. Shockley's commitment to you, Mr. Torrance.'' For a moment Jack's headache came back in all its thudding glory, and he (Jack) closed his (Jack) eyes against the pain. As if from a distance away he (Jack) heard himself ask: ``Who owns the Overlook now? Is it still Derwent Enterprises? Or are you too smallfry to know?'' ``I think that will do, Mr. Torrance. You are an employee of the hotel, no different from a busboy or a kitchen pot scrubber. I have no intention of -- '' ``Okay, I'll write Al,'' Jack said. ``He (Al)'ll know; after all, he (Al)'s on the Board of Directors. And I might just add a little P.S. to the effect that -- '' ``Derwent doesn't own it.'' ``What? I couldn't quite make that out.'' ``I said Derwent doesn't own it. The stockholders are all Easterners. Your friend Mr. Shockley owns the largest block of stock himself, better than thirtyfive per cent. You would know better than I if he (Shockley) has any ties to Derwent.'' ``Who else?'' ``I have no intention of divulging the names of the other stockholders to you, Mr. Torrance. I intend to bring this whole matter to the attention of -- '' ``One other question.'' ``I am under no obligation to you.'' ``Most of the Overlook's history -- savory and unsavory alike -- I found in a scrapbook that was in the cellar. Big thing with white leather covers. Gold thread for binding. Do you have any idea whose scrapbook that might be?'' ``None at all.'' ``Is it possible it could have belonged to Grady? The caretaker who killed himself?'' ``Mr. Torrance,'' Ullman said in tones of deepest frost, ``I am by no means sure that Mr. Grady could read, let alone dig out the rotten apples you have been wasting my time with.'' ``I'm thinking of writing a book about the Overlook Hotel. I thought if I actually got through it, the owner of the scrapbook would like to have an acknowledgment at the front.'' ``I think writing a book about the Overlook would be very unwise,'' Ullman said. ``Especially a book done from your ... uh, point of view.''

``Your opinion doesn't surprise me.'' (unknown)
His (Ullman) headache was all gone now. There had been that one flash of pain, and that was all. His (Ullman) mind felt sharp and accurate, all the way down to millimeters. It was the way he (Ullman) usually felt only when the writing was going extremely well or when he (Ullman) had a threedrink buzz on. That was

another thing he (Ullman) had forgotten about Excedrin; he (Ullman) didn't know if it worked for others, but for him (Ullman) crunching three tablets was like an instant high. Now he (Ullman) said:

``What you'd like is some sort of commissioned guidebook that you could hand out free to the guests when they checked in. Something with a lot of glossy photos of the mountains at sunrise and sunset and a lemon-meringue text to go with it. Also a section on the colorful people who have stayed there, of course excluding the really colorful ones like Gienelli and his (Gienelli) friends.'' (he)
``If I felt I could fire you and be a hundred per cent certain of my own job instead of just ninety-five per cent,'' (unknown)
UIIman said in clipped, strangled tones,
``I would fire you right this minute, over the telephone. But since I feel that five per cent of uncertainty, I intend to call Mr. Shockley the moment you're off the line ... which will be soon, or so I devoutly hope.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said,
``There isn't going to be anything in the book that isn't true, you know. There's no need to dress it up.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)

Jack screamed, and slammed the receiver into its cradle. He (Jack) sat on the stool breathing hard, a little scared now, -LRB-a little? hell, a lot-RRB- wondering why in the name of God he (God) had called Ullman in the first place. -LRB-You lost your temper again, Jack.-RRB- Yes. Yes, he (Jack) had. No sense trying to deny it. And the hell of it was, he (Jack) had no idea how much influence that cheap little prick had over Al, no more than he (Al) knew how much bullshit Al would take from him (Al) in the name of auld lang syne. If Ullman was as good as he (Ullman) claimed to be, and if he (Ullman) gave Al a he-goes-or-I-go ultimatum, might not Al be forced to take it? He (Al) closed his (Al) eyes and tried to imagine telling Wendy. Guess what, babe? I lost another job. This time I had to go through two thousand miles of Bell Telephone cable to find someone to punch out, but I managed it. He (Bell) opened his (Bell) eyes and wiped his (Bell) mouth with his (Bell) handkerchief. He (Bell) wanted a drink. Hell, he (Bell) needed one. There was a cafe just down the street, surely he (Bell) had time for a quick beer on his (Bell) way up to the park, just one to lay the dust ... He (Bell) clenched his (Bell) hands together helplessly. The question recurred: Why had he (Bell) called Ullman in the first place? The number of the Surf-Sand in Lauderdale had been written in a small notebook by the phone and the CB radio in the office-plumbers' numbers, carpenters, glaziers, electricians, others. Jack had copied it onto the matchbook cover shortly after getting out of bed, the idea of calling Ullman fullblown and gleeful in his (Ullman) mind. But to what purpose? Once, during the drinking phase, Wendy had accused him (Ullman) of desiring his (Ullman) own destruction but not possessing the necessary moral fiber to support a full-blown deathwish. So he (Ullman) manufactured ways in which other people could do it, lopping a piece at a time off himself and their family. Could it be true? Was be afraid somewhere inside that the Overlook might be just what he (Ullman) needed to finish his (Ullman) play and generally collect tip his (Ullman) shit and get it together? Was he (Ullman) blowing the whistle on himself? Please God no, don't let it be that way. Please.

He (God) closed his (God) eyes and an image immediately arose on the darkened screen of his (God) inner lids: sticking his (God) hand through that hole in the shingles to pull out the rotted flashing, the sudden needling sting, his (God) own agonized, startled cry in the still and unheeding air: Oh you goddamn fucking son of a bitch ... Replaced with an image two years earlier, himself stumbling into the house at three in the morning, drunk, falling over a table and sprawling full-length on the floor, cursing, waking Wendy up on the couch. Wendy turning on the light, seeing his (son) clothes ripped and smeared from some cloudy parking-lot scuffle that had occurred at a vaguely remembered honky-tonk just over the New Hampshire border hours before, crusted blood under his (son) nose, now looking up at his (son) wife, blinking stupidly in the light like a mole in the sunshine, and Wendy saying dully, You son of a bitch, you woke Danny up. If you don't care about yourself, can't you care a little bit about us? Oh, why do I even bother talking to you? The telephone rang, making him (Danny) jump. He (Danny) snatched it off the cradle, illogically sure it must be either Ullman or Al Shockley.

he (Shockley) barked.
``Your overtime, sir. Three dollars and fifty cents.'' (unknown)

he (Shockley) said.
``Wait a minute.'' (He)
He (Shockley) put the phone on the shelf, deposited his (Shockley) last six quarters, then went out to the cashier to get more. He (Shockley) performed the transaction automatically, his (Shockley) mind running in a single closed circle like a squirrel on an exercise wheel. Why had he (Shockley) called Ullman? Because Ullman had embarrassed him (Ullman)? He (Ullman) had been embarrassed before, and by real masters the Grand Master, of course, being himself. Simply to crow at the man, expose his (man) hypocrisy? Jack didn't think he (Jack) was that petty. His (Jack) mind tried to seize on the scrapbook as a valid reason, but that wouldn't hold water either. The chances of Ullman knowing who the owner was were no more than two in a thousand. At the interview, he (Ullman) had treated the cellar as another country a nasty underdeveloped one at that. If he (Ullman) had really wanted to know, he (Ullman) would have called Watson, whose winter number was also in the office notebook. Even Watson would not have been a sure thing but surer than Ullman. And telling him (Ullman) about the book idea, that had been another stupid thing. Incredibly stupid. Besides jeopardizing his (Ullman) job, he (Ullman) could be closing off wide channels of information once Ullman called around and told people to beware of New Englanders bearing questions about the Overlook Hotel. He (Ullman) could have done his (Ullman) researches quietly, mailing off polite letters, perhaps even arranging some interviews in the spring ... and then laughed up his (Ullman) sleeve at Ullman's rage when the book came out and he (Ullman) was safely away The Masked Author Strikes Again. Instead he (Ullman) had made that damned senseless call, lost his (Ullman) temper, antagonized Ullman, and brought out all of the hotel manager's Little Caesar tendencies. Why? If it wasn't an effort to get himself thrown out of the good job Al had snagged for him (Al), then what was it? He (Al) deposited the rest of the money in the slots and hung up the phone. It really was the senseless kind of thing he (Al) might have done if he (Al) had been drunk. But he (Al) had been sober; dead cold sober. Walking out of the drugstore be crunched another Excedrin into his (Al) mouth, grimacing yet relishing the bitter taste. On the walk outside he (Al) met Wendy and Danny.

They walked back to where the hotel truck was slantparked against the curb, Jack in the middle, his (Jack) left arm around Wendy's shoulders, his (Jack) right hand holding Danny's hand. He (Jack) had called it home for the first time, for better or worse. As he (Jack) got behind the truck's wheel it occurred to him (Jack) that while he (Jack) was fascinated by the Overlook, he (Jack) didn't much like it. He (Jack) wasn't sure it was good for either his (Jack) wife or his (Jack) son or himself. Maybe that was why he (Jack) had called Ullman. To be fired while there was still time. He (Jack) backed the truck out of its parking space and headed them out of town and up into the mountains.

<< 21 >> NIGHT THOUGHTS It was ten o'clock. Their quarters were filled with counterfeit sleep. Jack lay on his (Jack) side facing the wall, eyes open, listening to Wendy's slow and regular breathing. The taste of dissolved aspirin was still on his (Jack) tongue, making it feel rough and slightly numb. Al Shockley had called at quarter of six, quarter of eight back East. Wendy had been downstairs with Danny, sitting in front of the lobby fireplace and reading.

``Person to person,'' (unknown)
the operator said,
``for Mr. Jack Torrance.'' (unknown)
``Speaking.'' (He)
He (Danny) had switched the phone to his (Danny) right hand, had dug his (Danny) handkerchief out of his (Danny) back pocket with his (Danny) left, and had wiped his (Danny) tender lips with it. Then he (Danny) lit a cigarette.

Al's voice then, strong in his (Danny) ear:

``Jacky-boy, what in the name of God are you up to?'' (Al)
``Hi, Al.'' (He)
He (Danny) snuffed the cigarette and groped for the Excedrin bottle.
``What's going on, Jack? I got this weird phone call from Stuart Ullman this afternoon. And when Stu Ullman calls long-distance out of his (Ullman) own pocket, you know the shit has hit the fan.'' (unknown)
``Ullman has nothing to worry about, Al.. Neither do you.'' (unknown)
``What exactly is the nothing we don't have to worry about? Stu made it sound like a cross between blackmail and a National Enquirer feature on the Overlook. Talk to me, boy.'' (unknown)

Jack said.
``When I came up here to be interviewed, he (boy) had to drag out all my dirty laundry. Drinking problem. Lost your last job for racking over a student. Wonder if you're the right man for this. Et cetera. The thing that bugged me was that he (man) was bringing all this up because he (man) loved the goddamn hotel so much. The beautiful Overlook. The traditional Overlook. The bloody sacred Overlook. Well, I found a scrapbook in the basement. Somebody had put together all the less savory aspects of Ullman's cathedral, and it looked to me like a little black mass had been going on after hours.'' (unknown)

Al's voice sounded frighteningly cold.

he (Jack) barked into the phone.

That sounds like an inflated claim, stated so baldly ... I know it does ... but it's all here, Al! My God, it could be a great book. But it's far in the future, I can promise you that, I've got more on my plate right now than I can eat, and -- '' (He)

Jack was speechless.

he (Jack) muttered, but the coals of resentment had begun to glow around his (Jack) heart. First Ullman, then Wendy, now Al.. What was this? National Let's Pick Jack Torrance Apart Week? He (Torrance) clamped his (Torrance) lips more tightly together, reached for his (Torrance) cigarettes, and knocked them off onto the floor. ``Before you hit that Hatfield kid,'' (Al)
Al was saying,
``I had talked the Board out of letting you go and even had them swung around to considering tenure. You blew that one for yourself. I got you this hotel thing, a nice quiet place for you to get yourself together, finish your play, and wait it out until Harry Effinger and I could convince the rest of those guys that they made a big mistake. Now it looks like you want to chew my arm off on your way to a bigger killing. Is that the way you say thanks to your friends, Jack?'' (Al)

he (Al) whispered. He (Al) didn't dare say more. His (Al) head was throbbing with the hot, acid-etched words that wanted to get out. He (Al) tried desperately to think of Danny and Wendy, depending on him (Danny), Danny and Wendy sitting peacefully downstairs in front of the fire and working on the first of the second-grade reading primers, thinking everything was A-OK. blood beat loudly in his (Al) ears. I subsidize no pictures but pretty pictures. When you paint the daughter of my good friend and business partner, please omit birthmark or back to the rabble you'll go. Of course we're friends... we are both civilized men aren't we? We've shared bed and board and bottle. We'll always be friends, and the dog collar I have on you will always be ignored by mutual consent, and I'll take good and benevolent care of you. All I ask in return is your soul. Small item. We can even ignore the fact that you've handed it over, the way we ignore the dog collar. Remember, my talented friend, there are Michelangelos begging everywhere in the streets of Rome ...

Someday there would be a book, not the soft and thoughtful thing he (Al) had first considered, but a gemhard work of research, photo section and all, and he (Al) would pull apart the entire

Overlook history, nasty, incestuous ownership deals and all. He (Al) would spread it all out for the reader like a dissected crayfish. And if Al Shockley had connections with the Derwent empire, then God help him (God). Strung up like piano wire, he (God) lay staring into the dark, knowing it might be hours yet before he (God) could sleep. *** Wendy Torrance lay on her (Torrance) back, eyes closed, listening to the sound of her (Torrance) husband's slumber -- the long inhale, the brief hold, the slightly guttural exhale. Where did he (husband) go when he (husband) slept, she (Torrance) wondered. To some amusement park, a Great Barrington of dreams where all the rides were free and there was no wifemother along to tell them they'd had enough hotdogs or that they'd better be going if they wanted to get home by dark? Or was it some fathoms-deep bar where the drinking never stopped and the batwings were always propped open and all the old companions were gathered around the electronic hockey game, glasses in hand, Al Shockley prominent among them with his (Shockley) tie loosened and the top button of his (Shockley) shirt undone? A place where both she (them) and Danny were excluded and the boogie went on endlessly? Wendy was worried about him (Danny), the old, helpless worry that she (Wendy) had hoped was behind her (Wendy) forever in Vermont, as if worry could somehow not cross state lines. She (Wendy) didn't like what the Overlook seemed to be doing to Jack and Danny. The most frightening thing, vaporous and unmentioned, perhaps unmentionable, was that all of Jack's drinking symptoms had come back, one by one ... all but the drink itself. The constant wiping of the lips with hand or handkerchief, as if to rid them of excess moisture. Long pauses at the typewriter, more balls of paper in the wastebasket. There had been a bottle of Excedrin on the telephone table tonight after Al had called him (Al), but no water glass. He (Al) had been chewing them again. He (Al) got irritated over little things. He (Al) would unconsciously start snapping his (Al) fingers in a nervous rhythm when things got too quiet. Increased profanity. She (them) had begun to worry about his (Al) temper, too. It would almost come as a relief if he (Al) would lose it, blow off steam, in much the same way that he (Al) went down to the basement first thing in the morning and last thing at night to dump the press on the boiler. It would almost be good to see him (Al) curse and kick a chair across the room or slam a door. But those things, always an integral part of his (Al) temperament, had almost wholly ceased. Yet she (them) had the feeling that Jack was more and more often angry with her (them) or Danny, but was refusing to let it out. The boiler had a pressure gauge: old, cracked, clotted with grease, but still workable. Jack had none. She (them) had never been able to read him (Jack) very well. Danny could, but Danny wasn't talking. And the call from Al.. At about the same time it had come, Danny had lost all interest in the story they had been reading. He (Danny) left her (them) to sit by the fire and crossed to the main desk where Jack had constructed a roadway for his (Jack) matchbox cars and trucks. The Violent Violet Volkswagen was there and Danny had begun to push it rapidly back and forth. Pretending to read her (Violet) own book but actually looking at Danny over the top of it, she (Violet) had seen an odd amalgam of the ways she (Violet) and Jack expressed anxiety. The wiping of the lips. Running both hands nervously through his (Jack) hair, as she (Violet) had done while waiting for Jack to come home from his (Jack)

round of the bars. She (Violet) couldn't believe Al had called just to

``ask how things were going.'' (Al/Uncle Al)
If you wanted to shoot the bull, you called Al.. When Al called you, that was business. Later, when she (Violet) had come back downstairs, she (Violet) had found Danny curled up by the fire again, reading the second-grade-primer adventures of Joe and Rachel at the circus with their daddy in complete, absorbed attention. The fidgety distraction had completely disappeared. Watching him (Danny), she (Rachel) had been struck again by the eerie certainty that Danny knew more and understood more than there was room for in Dr. -LRB-
``Just call me Bill'' (Dr.)
-RRB- Edmonds's philosophy.
``Hey, time for bed, doc,'' (she)
she (Rachel)'d said.
``Yeah, okay.'' (He)
He (Danny) marked his (Danny) place in the book and stood up.
``Wash up and brush your teeth.'' (unknown)
``Okay.'' (unknown)
``Don't forget to use the floss.'' (unknown)
``I won't.'' (unknown)
They stood side by side for a moment, watching the wax and wane of the coals of the fire. Most of the lobby was chilly and drafty, but this circle around the fireplace was magically warm, and hard to leave.
``It was Uncle Al on the phone,'' (she)
she (Rachel) said casually.
``Oh yeah?'' (unknown)
Totally unsurprised.
``I wonder if Uncle Al was mad at Daddy,'' (she)
she (Rachel) said, still casually.
``Yeah, he (Al) sure was,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)

``He (Al) didn't want Daddy to write the book.'' (unknown)
``What book, Danny?'' (unknown)
``About the hotel.'' (she)
The question framed on her (Rachel) lips was one she (Rachel) and Jack had asked Danny a thousand times: How do you know that? She (Rachel) hadn't asked him (Danny). She (Rachel) didn't want to upset him (Danny) before bed, or make him (Danny) aware that they were casually discussing his (Danny) knowledge of things he (Danny) had no way of knowing at all. And he (Danny) did know, she (Rachel) was convinced of that. Dr. Edmonds's patter about inductive reasoning and subconscious logic was just that: patter. Her (Rachel) sister ... how had Danny known she (Rachel) was thinking about Aileen in the waiting room that day? And -LRB-I dreamed Daddy had an accident.-RRB- She (Rachel) shook her (Rachel) head, as if to clear it.
``Go wash up, doc.'' (unknown)
``Okay.'' (He)
He (Danny) ran up the stairs toward their quarters. Frowning, she (Rachel) had gone into the kitchen to warm Jack's milk in a saucepan. And now, lying wakeful in her (Rachel) bed and listening to her (Rachel) husband's breathing and the wind outside -LRB-miraculously, they'd had only another flurry that afternoon; still no heavy snow-RRB-, she (Rachel) let her (Rachel) mind turn fully to her (Rachel) lovely, troubling son, born with a caul over his (son) face, a simple tissue of membrane that doctors saw perhaps once in every seven hundred births, a tissue that the old wives' tales said betokened the second sight. She (Rachel) decided that it was time to talk to Danny about the Overlook ... and high time she (Rachel) tried to get Danny to talk to her (Rachel). Tomorrow. For sure. The two of them would be going down to the Sidewinder Public Library to see if they could get him (Danny) some second-grade-level books on an extended loan through the winter, and she (Rachel) would talk to him (Danny). And frankly. With that thought she (Rachel) felt a little easier, and at last began to drift toward sleep.

*** Danny lay awake in his (Danny) bedroom, eyes open, left arm encircling his (Danny) aged and slightly worse-for-wear Pooh -LRB-Pooh had lost one shoe-button eye and was oozing stuffing from half a dozen sprung seams-RRB-, listening to his (Pooh) parents sleep in their bedroom. He (Pooh) felt as if he (Pooh) were standing unwilling guard over them. The nights were the worst of all. He (Pooh) hated the nights and the constant howl of the wind around the west side of the hotel. His (Pooh) glider floated overhead from a string. On his (Pooh) bureau the VW model, brought up from the roadway setup downstairs, glowed a dimly fluorescent purple. His (Pooh) books were in the bookcase, his (Pooh) coloring books on the desk. A place for everything and everything in its place. Mommy said. Then you know where it is when you want it. But now things had been misplaced. Things were missing. Worse still, things had been added, things you couldn't quite see, like in one of those pictures that said CAN YOU SEE THE INDIANS? And if you strained and squinted, you could see some of them the thing you had taken for a cactus at first glance was really a brave with a knife clamped in his (its) teeth, and there were others hiding in the rocks, and you could even see one of their evil, merciless faces peering through the spokes of a covered wagon wheel. But you could never see all of them, and that was what made you uneasy. Because it was the ones you couldn't see that would sneak up behind you, a tomahawk in one hand and a scalping knife in the other ... He (its) shifted uneasily in his (its) bed, his (its) eyes searching out the comforting glow of the night light. Things were worse here. He (its) knew that much for sure. At first they hadn't been so bad, but little by little ... his (its) daddy thought about drinking a lot more. Sometimes he (its) was angry at Mommy and didn't know why. He (its) went around wiping his (its) lips with his (its) handkerchief and his (its) eyes were far away and cloudy. Mommy was worried about him (its) and Danny, too. He (Danny) didn't have to shine into her (Danny) to know that; it had been in the anxious way she (Danny) had questioned him (Danny) on the day the fire hose had seemed to turn into a snake. Mr. Hallorann said he (Hallorann) thought all mothers could shine a little bit, and she (Danny) had known on that day that something had happened. But not what. He (Hallorann) had almost told her (Danny), but a couple of things had held him (Hallorann) back. He (Hallorann) knew that the doctor in Sidewinder had dismissed Tony and the things that Tony showed him (Tony) as perfectly -LRB-well almost-RRB- normal. His (Tony) mother might not believe him (Tony) if he (Tony) told her (mother) about the hose. Worse, she (mother) might believe him (Tony) in the wrong way, might think he (Tony) was LOSING HIS (Tony) MARBLES. He (Tony) understood a little about LOSING YOUR MARBLES, not as much as he (Tony) did about GETTING A BABY, which his (Tony) mommy had explained to him (Tony) the year before at some length, but enough. Once, at nursery school, his (Tony) friend Scott had pointed out a boy named Robin Stenger, who was moping around the swings with a face almost long enough to step on. Robin's father taught arithmetic at Daddy's school, and Scott's daddy taught history there. Most of the kids at the nursery school were associated either with Stovington Prep or with the small IBM plant just outside of town. The prep kids chummed in one group, the IBM kids in another. There were cross-

friendships, of course, but it was natural enough for the kids whose fathers knew each other to more or less stick together. When there was an adult scandal in one group, it almost always filtered down to the children in some wildly mutated form or other, but it rarely jumped to the other group. He (IBM) and Scotty were sitting in the play rocketship when Scotty jerked his (Scotty) thumb at Robin and said:

``You know that kid?'' (Robin)
``Yeah,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said. Scott leaned forward.
``His (kid) dad LOST HIS (kid) MARBLES last night. They took him (kid) away.'' (unknown)
``Yeah? Just for losing some marbles?'' (Scotty)
Scotty looked disgusted.
``He (kid) went crazy. You know.'' (Scott/miss Scott)
Scott crossed his (Scotty) eyes, flopped out his (Scotty) tongue, and twirled his (Scotty) index fingers in large elliptical orbits around his (Scotty) ears.
``They took him (kid) to THE BUGHOUSE.'' (unknown)
``Wow,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said.
``When will they let him (kid) come back?'' (unknown)
``Never-never-never,'' (Scotty)
Scotty said darkly. In the course of that day and the next, Danny heard that a.-RRB- Mr. Stenger had tried to kill everybody in his (Stenger) family, including Robin, with his (Robin) World War II souvenir pistol; b.-RRB- Mr. Stenger ripped the house to pieces while he (Stenger) was STINKO; c.-RRB- Mr. Stenger had been discovered eating a bowl of dead bugs and grass like they were cereal and milk and crying while he (Stenger) did it; d.-RRB- Mr. Stenger had tried to strangle his (Stenger) wife with a stocking when the Red Sox lost a big ball game. Finally, too troubled to keep it to himself, he (Stenger) had asked Daddy about Mr. Stenger. His (Stenger) daddy had taken him (Stenger) on his (daddy) lap and had explained that Mr. Stenger had been under a great deal of strain, some of it about his (Stenger) family and some about his (Stenger) job and some of it about things that nobody but doctors could understand. He (Stenger) had been having crying fits, and three nights ago he (Stenger) had gotten crying and couldn't stop it and had broken a lot of things in the Stenger home. It wasn't LOSING YOUR MARBLES, Daddy said, it was HAVING A BREAKDOWN, and Mr. Stenger wasn't in a BUGHOUSE but in a SANNY-TARIUM. But despite Daddy's careful explanations, Danny was scared. There didn't seem to be any difference at all between LOSING YOUR MARBLES and HAVING A BREAKDOWN, and whether you called it a BUGHOUSE or a SANNYTARIUM, there were still bars on the windows and they wouldn't let you out if you wanted to go. And his (Danny) father, quite innocently, had confirmed another of Scotty's phrases unchanged, one that filled Danny with a vague and unformed dread. In the place where Mr. Stenger now lived, there were THE MEN IN THE WHITE COATS. They came to get you in a truck with no windows, a truck that was gravestone gray. It rolled up to the curb in front of your house and THE MEN IN THE WHITE COATS got out and took you away from your family and made you live in a room with soft walls. And if you wanted to write home, you had to do it with Crayolas.
``When will they let him (kid) come back?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny asked his (Danny) father.
``Just as soon as he (kid)'s better, doc.'' (unknown)
``But when will that be?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny had persisted.
``Dan,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said,
``NO ONE KNOWS.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
And that was the worst of all. It was another way of saying never-never-never. A month later, Robin's mother took him (Robin) out of nursery school and they moved away

from Stovington without Mr. Stenger. That had been over a year ago, after Daddy stopped taking the Bad Stuff but before he (Stenger) had lost his (Stenger) job. Danny still thought about it often. Sometimes when he (Danny) fell down or bumped his (Danny) head or had a bellyache, he (Danny) would begin to cry and the memory would flash over him (Danny), accompanied by the fear that he (Danny) would not be able to stop crying, that he (Danny) would just go on and on, weeping and wailing, until his (Danny) daddy went to the phone, dialed it, and said:

``Hello? This is Jack Torrance at 149 Mapleline Way. My son here can't stop crying. Please send THE MEN IN THE WHITE COATS to take him (son) to the SANNY-TARIUM. That's right, he (son)'s LOST HIS (son) MARBLES. Thank you.'' (daddy)
And the gray truck with no windows would come rolling up to his (Danny) door, they would load him (Danny) in, still weeping hysterically, and take him (Danny) away. When would he (Danny) see his (Danny) mommy and daddy again? NO ONE KNOWS. It was this fear that had kept him (Danny) silent. A year older, he (Danny) was quite sure that his (Danny) daddy and mommy wouldn't let him (Danny) be taken away for thinking a fire hose was a snake, his (Danny) rational mind was sure of that, but still, when he (Danny) thought of telling them, that old memory rose up like a stone filling his (Danny) mouth and blocking words. It wasn't like Tony; Tony had always seemed perfectly natural -LRB-until the bad dreams, of course-RRB-, and his (Tony) parents had also seemed to accept Tony as a more or less natural phenomenon. Things like Tony came from being BRIGHT, which they both assumed he (Tony) was -LRB-the same way they assumed they were BRIGHT-RRB-, but a fire hose that turned into a snake, or seeing blood and brains on the wall of the Presidential Sweet when no one else could, those things would not be natural. They had already taken him (Sweet) to see a regular doctor. Was it not reasonable to assume that THE MEN IN THE WHITE COATS might come next? Still he (Sweet) might have told them except he (Sweet) was sure, sooner or later, that they would want to take him (Sweet) away from the hotel. And he (Sweet) wanted desperately to get away from the Overlook. But he (Sweet) also knew that this was his (Sweet) daddy's last chance, that he (Sweet) was here at the Overlook to do more than take care of the place. He (Sweet) was here to work on his (Sweet) papers. To get over losing his (Sweet) job. To love Mommy/Wendy. And until very recently, it had seemed that all those things were happening. It was only lately that Daddy had begun to have trouble. Since he (Sweet) found those papers. -LRB-This inhuman place makes human monsters.-RRB- What did that mean? He (Sweet) had prayed to God, but God hadn't told him (God). And what would Daddy do if he (God) stopped working here? He (God) had tried to find out from Daddy's mind, and had become more and more convinced that Daddy didn't know. The strongest proof had come earlier this evening when Uncle Al had called his (Al) daddy up on the phone and said mean things and Daddy didn't dare say anything back because Uncle Al could fire him (Al) from this job just the way that Mr. Crommert, the Stovington headmaster, and the Board of Directors had fired him (Mr.) from his (Mr.) schoolteaching job. And Daddy was scared to death of that, for him (Mr.) and Mommy as well as himself. So he (Mr.) didn't dare say anything. He (Mr.) could only watch helplessly and hope that there really weren't any Indians at all, or if there were that they would be content to wait for bigger game and let their little three-wagon train pass unmolested. But he (Mr.) couldn't believe it, no matter how hard he (Mr.) tried. Things were worse at the Overlook now. The snow was coming, and when it did, any prior options he (Mr.) had would be

abrogated. And after the snow, what? What then, when they were shut in and at the mercy of whatever might have only been toying with them before? -LRB-Come out here and take your medicine!-RRB- What then? REDRUM. He (Mr.) shivered in his (Mr.) bed and turned over again. He (Mr.) could read more now. Tomorrow maybe he (Mr.) would try to call Tony, he (Mr.) would try to make Tony show him (Tony) exactly what REDRUM was and if there was any way he (Tony) could prevent it. He (Tony) would risk the nightmares. He (Tony) had to know. Danny was still awake long after his (Danny) parents' false sleep had become the real thing. He (Danny) rolled in his (Danny) bed, twisting the sheets, grappling with a problem years too big for him (Danny), awake in the night like a single sentinel on picket. And sometime after midnight, he (Danny) slept too and then only the wind was awake, prying at the hotel and hooting in its gables under the bright gimlet gaze of the stars.

<< 22 >> IN THE TRUCK I see a bad moon a-rising. I see trouble on the way. I see earthquakes and lightnin' I see bad times today. Don't go `round tonight, It's bound to take your life, There's a bad moon on the rise.* Someone had added a very old Buick car radio under the hotel truck's dashboard, and now, tinny and choked with static, the distinctive sound of John Fogerty's Creedence Clearwater Revival band came out of the speaker. Wendy and Danny were on their way down to Sidewinder. The day was clear and bright. Danny was turning Jack's orange library card over and over in his (Danny) hands and seemed cheerful enough, but Wendy thought he (Danny) looked drawn and tired, as if be hadn't been sleeping enough and was going on nervous energy alone. The song ended and the disc jockey came on. ``Yeah, that's Creedence. And speakin of bad moon, it looks like it may be risin over the KMTX listening area before long, hard as it is to believe with the beautiful, springlike weather we've enjoyed for the last couple-three days. The KMTX Fearless Forecaster says high pressure will give way by one o'clock this afternoon to a widespread lowpressure area which is just gonna grind to a stop in our KMTX area, up where the air is rare. Temperatures will fall rapidly, and precipitation should start

around dusk. Elevations under seven thousand feet, including the metro-Denver area, can expect a mixture of sleet and snow, perhaps freezing on some roads, and nothin but snow up here, cuz. We're lookin at one to three inches below seven thousand and possible accumulations of six to ten inches in Central Colorado and on the Slope. The Highway Advisory Board says that if you're plannin to tour the mountains in your car this afternoon or tonight, you should remember that the chain law will be in effect. And don't go nowhere unless you have to. Remember,'' the announcer added jocularly, ``that's how the Donners got into trouble. They just weren't as close to the nearest Seven-Eleven as they thought.'' A Clairol commercial came on, and Wendy reached down and snapped the radio off. ``You mind?'' ``Huh-uh, that's okay.'' He (announcer) glanced out at the sky, which was bright blue. ``Guess Daddy picked just the right day to trim those hedge animals, didn't he (you)?'' ``I guess he (you) did,'' Wendy said. ``Sure doesn't look much like snow, though,'' Danny added hopefully. ``Getting cold feet?'' Wendy asked. She (Wendy) was still thinking about that crack the disc jockey had made about the Donner Party. ``Nah, I guess not.'' Well, she (Wendy) thought, this is the time. If you're going to bring it up, do it now or forever hold your peace. ``Danny,'' she (Wendy) said, making her (Wendy) voice as casual as possible, ``would you be happier if we went away from the Overlook? If we didn't stay the winter?'' Danny looked down at his (Danny) hands. ``I guess so,'' he (Danny) said. ``Yeah. But it's Daddy's job.'' ``Sometimes,'' she (Wendy) said carefully, ``I get the idea that Daddy might be happier away from the Overlook, too.'' They passed a sign which read SIDEWINDER 18 mi. and then she (Wendy) took the truck cautiously around a hairpin and shifted up into second. She (Wendy) took no chances on these downgrades; they scared her (Wendy) silly. ``Do you really think so?'' Danny asked. He (Danny) looked at her (Wendy) with interest for a moment and then shook his (Danny) head. ``No, I don't think so.'' ``Why not?'' ``Because he (Danny)'s worried about us,'' Danny said, choosing his (Danny) words carefully. It was hard to explain, he (Danny) understood so little of it himself. He (Danny) found himself harking back to an incident he (Danny) had told Mr. Hallorann about, the big kid looking at department store TV sets and wanting to steal one. That had been distressing, but at least it had been clear what was going on, even to Danny, then little more than an infant. But grownups were always in a turmoil, every possible action muddied over by thoughts of the consequences, by self-doubt, by selfimage, by feelings of love and responsibility. Every possible choice seemed to have drawbacks, and sometimes he (Danny) didn't understand why the drawbacks were drawbacks. It was very hard. ``He (Danny) thinks ...'' Danny began again, and then looked at his (Danny) mother quickly. She (mother) was watching the road, not looking at him (Danny), and he (Danny) felt he (Danny) could go on.

``He (Danny) thinks maybe we'll be lonely. And then he (Danny) thinks that he (Danny) likes it here and it's a good place for us. He (Danny) loves us and doesn't want us to be lonely ... or sad ... but he (Danny) thinks even if we are, it might be okay in the LONGRUN. Do you know LONGRUN?'' (She)

She (mother) nodded.

``Yes, dear. I do.'' (unknown)
``He (Danny)'s worried that if we left he (Danny) couldn't get another job. That we'd have to beg, or something.'' (unknown)
``Is that all?'' (unknown)
``No, but the rest is all mixed up. Because he (Danny)'s different now.'' (unknown)

she (mother) said, almost sighing. The grade eased a little and she (mother) shifted cautiously back to third gear.

<< 23 >> IN THE PLAYGROUND Jack came out onto the porch, tugging the tab of his (Jack) zipper up under his (Jack) chin, blinking into the bright air. In his (Jack) left hand he (Jack) was holding a battery-powered hedge-clipper. He (Jack) tugged a fresh handkerchief out of his (Jack) back pocket with his (Jack) right hand, wiped his (Jack) lips with it, and tucked it away. Snow, they had said on the radio. It was hard to believe, even though he (Snow) could see the clouds building up on the far horizon. He (Snow) started down the path to the topiary, switching the hedge-clipper over to the other hand. It wouldn't be a long job, he (Snow) thought; a little touch-up would do it. The cold nights had surely stunted their growth. The rabbit's ears looked a little fuzzy, and two of the dog's legs had grown fuzzy green bonespurs, but

the lions and the buffalo looked fine. Just a little haircut would do the trick, and then let the snow come. The concrete path ended as abruptly as a diving board. He (Snow) stepped off it and walked past the drained pool to the gravel path which wound through the hedge sculptures and into the playground itself. He (Snow) walked over to the rabbit and pushed the button on the handle of the clippers. It hummed into quiet life.

``Hi, Br`er Rabbit,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``How are you today? A little off the top and get some of the extra off your ears? Fine. Say, did you hear the one about the traveling salesman and the old lady with a pet poodle?'' (he)
His (Jack) voice sounded unnatural and stupid in his (Jack) ears, and he (Jack) stopped. It occurred to him (Jack) that he (Jack) didn't care much for these hedge animals. It had always seemed slightly perverted to him (Jack) to clip and torture a plain old hedge into something that it wasn't. Along one of the highways in Vermont there had been a hedge billboard on a high slope overlooking the road, advertising some kind of ice cream. Making nature peddle ice cream, that was just wrong. It was grotesque. -LRB-You weren't hired to philosophize, Torrance.-RRB- Ah, that was true. So true. He (Torrance) clipped along the rabbit's ears, brushing a small litter of sticks and twigs off onto the grass. The hedge-clipper hummed in that low and rather disgustingly metallic way that all battery-powered appliances seem to have. The sun was brilliant but it held no warmth, and now it wasn't so hard to believe that snow was coming. Working quickly, knowing that to stop and think when you were at this kind of a task usually meant making a mistake, Jack touched up the rabbit's
``face'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
-LRB-up this close it didn't look like a face at all, but he (Jack) knew that at a distance of twenty paces or so light and shadow would seem to suggest one; that, and the viewer's imagination-RRB- and then zipped the clippers along its belly. That done, he (Jack) shut the clippers off, walked down toward the playground, and then turned back abruptly to get it all at once, the entire rabbit. Yes, it looked all right. Well, he (Jack) would do the dog next.
``But if it was my hotel,'' (he)
he (Jack) said,
``I'd cut the whole damn bunch of you down.'' (he)
He (Jack) would, too. Just cut them down and resod the lawn where they'd been and put in half a dozen small metal tables with gaily colored umbrellas. People could have cocktails on the Overlook's lawn in the summer sun. Sloe gin fizzes and margaritas and pink ladies and all those sweet tourist drinks. A rum and tonic, maybe. Jack took his (Jack) handkerchief out of his (Jack) back pocket and slowly rubbed his (Jack) lips with it.
``Come on, come on,'' (he)
he (Jack) said softly. That was nothing to be thinking about. He (Jack) was going to start back, and then some impulse made him (Jack) change his (Jack) mind and he (Jack) went down to the playground instead. It was funny how you never knew kids, he (Jack) thought. He (Jack) and Wendy had expected Danny would love the playground; it had everything a kid could want. But Jack didn't think the boy had been down half a dozen times, if that. He (Jack) supposed if there had been another kid to play with, it would have been different. The gate squeaked slightly as he (Jack) let himself in, and then there was crushed gravel crunching under his (Jack) feet. He (Jack) went first to the playhouse, the perfect scale model of the Overlook itself. It came up to his (Jack) lower thigh, just about Danny's height when he (Jack) was standing up. Jack hunkered down and looked in the

third-floor windows.

``The giant has come to eat you all up in your beds,'' (he)
he (Jack) said hollowly.
``Kiss your Triple A rating goodbye.'' (unknown)
But that wasn't funny, either. You could open the house simply by pulling it apart -- it opened on a hidden hinge. The inside was a disappointment. The walls were painted, but the place was mostly hollow. But of course it would have to be, he (Jack) told himself, or how else could the kids get inside? What play furniture might go with the place in the summer was gone, probably packed away in the equipment shed. He (Jack) closed it up and heard the small click as the latch closed. He (Jack) walked over to the slide, set the hedge-clipper down, and after a glance back at the driveway to make sure Wendy and Danny hadn't returned, he (Danny) climbed to the top and sat down. This was the big kids' slide, but the fit was still uncomfortably tight for his (Danny) grownup ass. How long had it been since he (Danny) had been on a slide? Twenty years? It didn't seem possible it could be that long, it didn't feel that long, but it had to be that, or more. He (Danny) could remember his (Danny) old man taking him (Danny) to the park in Berlin when he (Danny) had been Danny's age, and he (Danny) had done the whole bit slide, swings, teeter-totters, everything. He (Danny) and the old man would have a hotdog lunch and buy peanuts from the man with the cart afterward. They would sit on a bench to eat them and dusky clouds of pigeons would flock around their feet.
``Goddam scavenger birds,'' (dad)
his (man) dad would say,
``don't you feed them, Jacky.'' (dad)
But they would both end up feeding them, and giggling at the way they ran after the nuts, the greedy way they ran after the nuts. Jack didn't think the old man had ever taken his (man) brothers to the park. Jack had been his (Jack) favorite, and even so Jack had taken his (Jack) lumps when the old man was drunk, which was a lot of the time. But Jack had loved him (Jack) for as long as he (Jack) was able, long after the rest of the family could only hate and fear him (Jack). He (Jack) pushed off with his (Jack) hands and went to the bottom, but the trip was unsatisfying. The slide, unused, had too much friction and no really pleasant speed could be built up. And his (Jack) ass was just too big. His (Jack) adult feet thumped into the slight dip where thousands of children's feet had landed before him (Jack). He (Jack) stood up, brushed at the seat of his (Jack) pants, and looked at the hedge-clipper. But instead of going back to it he (Jack) went to the swings, which were also a disappointment. The chains had built up rust since the close of the season, and they squealed like things in pain. Jack promised himself he (Jack) would oil them in the spring. You better stop it, he (Jack) advised himself. You're not a kid anymore. You don't need this place to prove it. But he (Jack) went on to the cement rings they were too small for him (Jack) and he (Jack) passed them up and then to the security fence which marked the edge of the grounds. He (Jack) curled his (Jack) fingers through the links and looked through, the sun crosshatching shadow-lines on his (Jack) face like a man behind bars. He (Jack) recognized the similarity himself and he (Jack) shook the chain link, put a harried expression on his (Jack) face, and whispered:
``Lemme outta here! Lemme outta here!'' (he)
But for the third time, not funny. It was time to get back to work. That was when he (Jack) heard the sound behind him (Jack). He (Jack) turned around quickly, frowning, embarrassed, wondering if someone had seen him (Jack) fooling around down here in kiddie country. His (Jack) eyes ticked off the slides,

the opposing angles of the seesaws, the swings in which only the wind sat. Beyond all that to the gate and the low fence that divided the playground from the lawn and the topiary the lions gathered protectively around the path, the rabbit bent over as if to crop grass, the buffalo ready to charge, the crouching dog. Beyond them, the putting green and the hotel itself. From here he (Jack) could even see the raised lip of the roque court on the Overlook's western side. Everything was just as it had been. So why had the flesh of his (Jack) face and hands begun to creep, and why had the hair along the back of his (Jack) neck begun to stand up, as if the flesh back there had suddenly tightened? He (Jack) squinted up at the hotel again, but that was no answer. It simply stood there, its windows dark, a tiny thread of smoke curling from the chimney, coming from the banked fire in the lobby. -LRB-Buster, you better get going or they're going to come back and wonder if you were doing anything all the while.-RRB- Sure, get going. Because the snow was coming and he (Buster) had to get the damn hedges trimmed. It was part of the agreement. Besides, they wouldn't dare -LRB-Who wouldn't? What wouldn't? Dare do what?-RRB- He (Buster) began to walk back toward the hedge-clipper at the foot of the big kids' slide, and the sound of his (Buster) feet crunching on the crushed stone seemed abnormally loud. Now the flesh on his (Buster) testicles had begun to creep too, and his (Buster) buttocks felt hard and heavy, like stone. -LRB-Jesus, what is this?-RRB- He (Jesus) stopped by the hedge-clipper, but made no move to pick it up. Yes, there was something different. In the topiary. And it was so simple, so easy to see, that he (Jesus) just wasn't picking it up. Come on, he (Jesus) scolded himself, you just trimmed the fucking rabbit, so what's the -LRB-that's it-RRB- His (Jesus) breath stopped in his (Jesus) throat. The rabbit was down on all fours, cropping grass. Its belly was against the ground. But not ten minutes ago it had been up on its hind legs, of course it had been, he (Jesus) had trimmed its ears ... and its belly. His (Jesus) eyes darted to the dog. When he (Jesus) had come down the path it had been sitting up, as if begging for a sweet. Now it was crouched, head tilted, the clipped wedge of mouth seeming to snarl silently. And the lions -- -LRB-oh no, baby, oh no, uh-uh, no way-RRB- the lions were closer to the path. The two on his (Jesus) right had subtly changed positions, had drawn closer together. The tail of the one on the left now almost jutted out over the path. When he (Jesus) had come past them and through the gate, that lion had been on the right and he (Jesus) was quite sure its tail had been curled around it. They were no longer protecting the path; they were blocking it. Jack put his (Jack) hand suddenly over his (Jack) eyes and then took it away. The picture didn't change. A soft sigh, too quiet to be a groan, escaped him (Jack). In his (Jack) drinking days he (Jack) had always been afraid of something like this happening. But when you were a heavy drinker you called it the DTs -- good old Ray Milland in Lost Weekend, seeing the bugs coming out of the walls. What did you call it when you were cold sober? The question was meant to be rhetorical, but his (Ray) mind answered it

-LRB-you call it insanity-RRB- nevertheless. Staring at the hedge animals, he (Ray) realized something had changed while he (Ray) had his (Ray) hand over his (Ray) eyes. The dog had moved closer. No longer crouching, it seemed to be in a running posture, haunches flexed, one front leg forward, the other back. The hedge mouth yawned wider, the pruned sticks looked sharp and vicious. And now he (Ray) fancied he (Ray) could see faint eye indentations in the greenery as well. Looking at him (Ray). Why do they have to be trimmed? he (Ray) thought hysterically. They're perfect. Another soft sound. He (Ray) involuntarily backed up a step when he (Ray) looked at the lions. One of the two on the right seemed to have drawn slightly ahead of the other. Its head was lowered. One paw had stolen almost all the way to the low fence. Dear God, what next? -LRB-next it leaps over and gobbles you up like something in an evil nursery fable-RRB- It was like that game they had played when they were kids, red light. One person was

``it,'' (person)
and while he (God) turned his (God) back and counted to ten, the other players crept forward. When
``it'' (he)
got to ten, he (God) whirled around and if he (God) caught anyone moving, they were out of the game. The others remained frozen in statue postures until
``it'' (The others)
turned his (God) back and counted again. They got closer and closer, and at last, somewhere between five and ten, you would feel a hand on your back... Gravel rattled on the path. He (God) jerked his (God) head around to look at the dog and it was halfway down the pathway, just behind the lions now, its mouth wide and yawning. Before, it had only been a hedge clipped in the general shape of a dog, something that lost all definition when you got up close to it. But now Jack could see that it had been clipped to look like a German shepherd, and shepherds could be mean. You could train shepherds to kill. A low rustling sound. The lion on the left had advanced all the way to the fence now; its muzzle was touching the boards. It seemed to be grinning at him (Jack). Jack backed up another two steps. His (Jack) head was thudding crazily and he (Jack) could feel the dry rasp of his (Jack) breath in his (Jack) throat. Now the buffalo had moved, circling to the right, behind and around the rabbit. The head was lowered, the green hedge horns pointing at him (Jack). The thing was, you couldn't watch all of them. Not all at once. He (Jack) began to make a whining sound, unaware in his (Jack) locked concentration that he (Jack) was making any sound at all. His (Jack) eyes darted from one hedge creature to the next, trying to see them move. The wind gusted, making a hungry rattling sound in the close-matted branches. What kind of sound would there be if they got him (Jack)? But of course he (Jack) knew. A snapping, rending, breaking sound. It would be -LRB-no no NO NO I WILL NOT BELIEVE THIS NOT AT ALL!-RRB- He (Jack) clapped his (Jack) hands over his (Jack) eyes, clutching at his (Jack) hair, his (Jack) forehead, his (Jack) throbbing temples. And he (Jack) stood like that for a long time, dread building until he (Jack) could stand it no longer and he (Jack) pulled his (Jack) hands away with a cry. By the putting green the dog was sitting up, as if begging for a scrap. The buffalo was gazing with disinterest back toward the roque court, as it had been when Jack had come down with the clippers. The rabbit stood on its hind legs,

ears up to catch the faintest sound, freshly clipped belly exposed. The lions, rooted into place, stood beside the path. He (Jack) stood frozen for a long time, the harsh breath in his (Jack) throat finally slowing. He (Jack) reached for his (Jack) cigarettes and shook four of them out onto the gravel. He (Jack) stooped down and picked them up, groped for them, never taking his (Jack) eyes from the topiary for fear the animals would begin to move again. He (Jack) picked them up, stuffed three carelessly back into the pack, and lit the fourth. After two deep drags he (Jack) dropped it and crushed it out. He (Jack) went to the hedge-clipper and picked it up.

``I'm very tired,'' (unknown)
be said, and now it seemed okay to talk out loud. It didn't seem crazy at all.
``I've been under a strain. The wasps ... the play ... Al calling me like that. But it's all right.'' (He)
He (Jack) began to trudge back up to the hotel. Part of his (Jack) mind tugged fretfully at him (Jack), tried to make him (Jack) detour around the hedge animals, but he (Jack) went directly up the gravel path, through them. A faint breeze rattled through them, that was all. He (Jack) had imagined the whole thing. He (Jack) had had a bad scare but it was over now. In the Overlook's kitchen he (Jack) paused to take two Excedrin and then went downstairs and looked at papers until he (Jack) heard the dim sound of the hotel truck rattling into the driveway. He (Jack) went up to meet them. He (Jack) felt all right. He (Jack) saw no need to mention his (Jack) hallucination. He (Jack)'d had a bad scare but it was over now.

<< 24 >> SNOW It was dusk. They stood on the porch in the fading light, Jack in the middle, his (Jack) left arm around Danny's shoulders and his (Jack) right arm around Wendy's waist. Together they watched as the decision was taken out of their hands. The sky had been completely clouded over by two-thirty and it had begun to snow an hour later, and this time you didn't need a weatherman to tell you it was serious snow, no flurry that was going to melt or blow away when the evening wind started to whoop. At first it had fallen in perfectly straight lines, building up a snowcover that coated everything evenly, but now, an hour after it had started, the wind had begun to blow from the northwest and the snow had begun to drift against the porch and the sides of the Overlook's driveway. Beyond the grounds the highway had disappeared under an even blanket of white. The hedge animals were also gone, but when Wendy and Danny had gotten home, she (Wendy) had commended him (Danny) on the good job he (Danny) had done. Do you think so? he (Danny) had asked, and said no more. Now the hedges were buried under amorphous white cloaks. Curiously, all of them were thinking different thoughts but feeling the same

emotion: relief. The bridge had been crossed.

``Will it ever be spring?'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy murmured. Jack squeezed her (Wendy) tighter.
``Before you know it. What do you say we go in and have some supper? It's cold out here.'' (She)
She (Wendy) smiled. All afternoon Jack had seemed distant and ... well, odd. Now he (Jack) sounded more like his (Jack) normal self.
``Fine by me. How about you, Danny?'' (unknown)
``Sure.'' (the scream)
So they went in together, leaving the wind to build to the low-pitched scream that would go on all night a sound they would get to know well. Flakes of snow swirled and danced across the porch. The Overlook faced it as it had for nearly three quarters of a century, its darkened windows now bearded with snow, indifferent to the fact that it was now cut off from the world. Or possibly it was pleased with the prospect. Inside its shell the three of them went about their early evening routine, like microbes trapped in the intestine of a monster.

<< 25 >> INSIDE 217 A week and a half later two feet of snow lay white and crisp and even on the grounds of the Overlook Hotel. The hedge menagerie was buried up to its haunches; the rabbit, frozen on its hind legs, seemed to be rising from a white pool. Some of the drifts were over five feet deep. The wind was constantly changing them, sculpting them into sinuous, dunelike shapes. Twice Jack had snowshoed clumsily around to the equipment shed for his (Jack) shovel to clear the porch, the third time he (Jack) shrugged, simply cleared a path through the towering drift lying against the door, and let Danny amuse himself by sledding to the right and left of the path. The truly heroic drifts lay against the Overlook's west side; some of them towered to a height of twenty feet, and beyond them the ground was scoured bare to the grass by the constant windflow. The first-floor windows were covered, and the view from the dining room which Jack had so admired on closing day was now no more exciting than a view of a blank movie screen. Their phone had been out for the last eight days, and the CB radio in Ullman's office was now their only communications link with the outside world. It snowed every day now, sometimes only brief flurries that powdered the glittering snow crust, sometimes for real, the low whistle of the wind cranking up to a womanish shriek that made the old hotel rock and groan alarmingly even in its deep cradle of snow. Night temperatures had not gotten above 10°, and although the thermometer by the kitchen service entrance sometimes got as high as 25° in the early afternoons, the steady knife edge of the wind made it uncomfortable to go out without a ski mask. But they all did go out on the days

when the sun shone, usually wearing two sets of clothing and mittens on over their gloves. Getting out was almost a compulsive thing; the hotel was circled with the double track of Danny's Flexible Flyer. The permutations were nearly endless: Danny riding while his (Danny) parents pulled; Daddy riding and laughing while Wendy and Danny tried to pull -LRB-it was just possible for them to pull him (Danny) on the icy crust, and flatly impossible when powder covered it-RRB-; Danny and Mommy riding; Wendy riding by herself while her (Wendy) menfolk pulled and puffed white vapor like drayhorses, pretending she (Wendy) was heavier than she (Wendy) was. They laughed a great deal on these sled excursions around the house, but the whooping and impersonal voice of the wind, so huge and hollowly sincere, made their laughter seem tinny and forced. They had seen caribou tracks in the snow and once the caribou themselves, a group of five standing motionlessly below the security fence. They had all taken turns with Jack's Zeiss-Ikon binoculars to see them better, and looking at them had given Wendy a weird, unreal feeling: they were standing leg-deep in the snow that covered the highway, and it came to her (Wendy) that between now and the spring thaw, the road belonged more to the caribou than it did to them. Now the things that men had made up here were neutralized. The caribou understood that, she (Wendy) believed. She (Wendy) had put the binoculars down and had said something about starting lunch and in the kitchen she (Wendy) had cried a little, trying to rid herself of the awful pent-up feeling that sometimes fell on her (Wendy) like a large, pressing hand over her (Wendy) heart. She (Wendy) thought of the caribou. She (Wendy) thought of the wasps Jack had put out on the service entrance platform, under the Pyrex bowl, to freeze. There were plenty of snowshoes hung from nails in the equipment shed, and Jack found a pair to fit each of them, although Danny's pair was quite a bit outsized. Jack did well with them. Although he (Jack) had not snowshoed since his (Jack) boyhood in Berlin, New Hampshire, he (Jack) retaught himself quickly. Wendy didn't care much for it -- even fifteen minutes of tramping around on the outsized laced paddles made her (Wendy) legs and ankles ache outrageously but Danny was intrigued and working hard to pick up the knack. He (Danny) still fell often, but Jack was pleased with his (Jack) progress. He (Jack) said that by February Danny would be skipping circles around both of them. *** This day was overcast, and by noon the sky had already begun to spit snow. The radio was promising another eight to twelve inches and chanting hosannas to Precipitation, that great god of Colorado skiers. Wendy, sitting in the bedroom and knitting a scarf, thought to herself that she (Wendy) knew exactly what the skiers could do with all that snow. She (Wendy) knew exactly where they could put it. Jack was in the cellar. He (Jack) had gone down to check the furnace and boiler -- such checks had become a ritual with him (Jack) since the snow had closed them in -- and after satisfying himself that everything was going well he (Jack) had wandered through the arch, screwed the lightbulb on, and had seated himself in an old and cobwebby camp chair he (Jack) had found. He (Jack) was leafing through the old records and papers, constantly wiping his (Jack) mouth with his (Jack) handkerchief as he (Jack) did so. Confinement had leached his (Jack) skin of its autumn tan, and as he (Jack) sat hunched over the yellowed, crackling sheets, his (Jack) reddish-blond hair tumbling untidily over his (Jack) forehead, he (Jack)

looked slightly lunatic. He (Jack) had found some odd things tucked in among the invoices, bills of lading, receipts. Disquieting things. A bloody strip of sheeting. A dismembered teddy bear that seemed to have been slashed to pieces. A crumpled sheet of violet ladies' stationery, a ghost of perfume still clinging to it beneath the musk of age, a note begun and left unfinished in faded blue ink:

``Dearest Tommy, I can't think so well up here as I'd hoped, about us I mean, of course, who else? Ha. Ha. Things keep getting in the way. I've had strange dreams about things going bump in the night, can you believe that and'' (a ghost)
That was all. The note was dated June 27, 1934. He (Jack) found a hand puppet that seemed to be either a witch or a warlock ... something with long teeth and a pointy hat, at any rate. It had been improbably tucked between a bundle of natural-gas receipts and a bundle of receipts for Vichy water. And something that seemed to be a poem, scribbled on the back of a menu in dark pencil:
``Medoc/are you here?/I've been sleepwalking again, my dear./The plants are moving under the rug.'' (unknown)
No date on the menu, and no name on the poem, if it was a poem. Elusive, but fascinating. It seemed to him (Jack) that these things were like pieces in a jigsaw, things that would eventually fit together if he (Jack) could find the right linking pieces. And so he (Jack) kept looking, jumping and wiping his (Jack) lips every time the furnace roared into life behind him (Jack). *** Danny was standing outside Room 217 again. The passkey was in his (Danny) pocket. He (Danny) was staring at the door with a kind of drugged avidity, and his (Danny) upper body seemed to twitch and jiggle beneath his (Danny) flannel shirt. He (Danny) was humming softly and tunelessly. He (Danny) hadn't wanted to come here, not after the fire hose. He (Danny) was scared to come here. He (Danny) was scared that he (Danny) had taken the passkey again, disobeying his (Danny) father. He (Danny) had wanted to come here. Curiosity -LRB-killed the cat; satisfaction brought him (Danny) back-RRB- was like a constant fishhook in his (Danny) brain, a kind of nagging siren song that would not be appeased. And hadn't Mr. Hallorann said,
``I don't think there's anything here that can hurt you'' (Mr. Hallorann)
? -LRB-You promised.-RRB- -LRB-Promises were made to be broken.-RRB- He (Hallorann) jumped at that. It was as if that thought had come from outside, insectile, buzzing, softly cajoling. -LRB-Promises were made to be broken my dear redrum, to be broken. splintered. shattered. hammered apart. FORE!-RRB- His (Hallorann) nervous humming broke into low, atonal song:
``Lou, Lou, skip to m' Lou, skip to m' Lou my daaarlin...'' (Mr. Hallorann)
Hadn't Mr. Hallorann been right? Hadn't that been, in the end, the reason why he (Hallorann) had kept silent and allowed the snow to close them in? Just close your eyes and it will be gone. What he (Hallorann) had seen in the Presidential Sweet had gone away. And the snake had only been a fire hose that had fallen onto the rug. Yes, even the blood in the Presidential Sweet had been harmless, something old, something that had happened long before he (Sweet) was born or even thought of, something that was done with. Like a

movie that only he (Sweet) could see. There was nothing, really nothing, in this hotel that could hurt him (Sweet), and if he (Sweet) had to prove that to himself by going into this room, shouldn't he (Sweet) do so?

``Lou, Lou, skip to m`Lou ...'' (the cat)
-LRB-Curiosity killed the cat my dear redrum, redrum my dear, satisfaction brought him (Sweet) back safe and sound, from toes to crown; from head to ground he (Sweet) was safe and sound.
