He (wolf) had stopped by the fire extinguisher, had put the brass nozzle back in the frame, and then had poked it repeatedly with his (wolf) finger, heart thumping, whispering:
``Come on and hurt me. Come on and hurt me, you cheap prick. Can't do it, can you? Huh? You're nothing but a cheap fire hose. Can't do nothin but lie there. Come on, come on!'' (He)
He (wolf) had felt insane with bravado. And nothing had happened. It was only a hose after all, only canvas and brass, you could hack it to pieces and it would never complain, never twist and jerk and bleed green slime all over the blue carpet, because it was only a hose, not a nose and not a rose, not glass buttons or satin bows, not a snake in a sleepy doze ... and he (jerk) had hurried on, had hurried on because he (jerk) was -LRB-
``late, I'm late,'' (he)
said the white rabbit.-RRB- the white rabbit. Yes. Now there was a white rabbit out by the playground, once it had been green but now it was white, as if something had shocked it repeatedly on the snowy, windy nights and turned it old ... Danny took the passkey from his (Danny) pocket and slid it into the lock.
``Lou, Lou ...'' (a croquet party)
-LRB-the white rabbit had been on its way to a croquet party to the Red Queen's croquet party storks for mallets hedgehogs for balls-RRB- He (Danny) touched the key, let his (Danny) fingers wander over it. His (Danny) head felt dry and sick. He (Danny) turned the key and the tumblers thumped back smoothly. -LRB-OFF WITH HIS (Danny) HEAD! OFF WITH HIS (Danny) HEAD! OFF WITH HIS (Danny) HEAD!-RRB- -LRB-this game isn't croquet though the mallets are too short this game is-RRB- -LRB-WHACK-BOOM! Straight through the wicket.-RRB- -LRB-OFF WITH HIS (Danny) HEEEEEAAAAAAAD ---RRB- Danny pushed the door open. It swung smoothly, without a creak. He (Danny) was standing just outside a large combination bedsitting room, and although the snow had not reached up this far the highest drifts were still a foot below the second-floor windows the room was dark because Daddy had closed all the shutters on the western exposure two weeks ago. He (Danny) stood in the doorway, fumbled to his (Danny) right, and found the switch plate. Two bulbs in an overhead cut-glass fixture came on. Danny stepped further in and looked around. The rug was deep and soft, a quiet rose color. Soothing. A double bed with a white coverlet. A writing desk -LRB-Pray tell me: Why is a raven like a writing desk?-RRB- by the large shuttered window. During the season the Constant Writer

-LRB-having a wonderful time, wish you were fear-RRB- would have a pretty view of the mountains to describe to the folks back home. He (Writer) stepped further in. Nothing here, nothing at all. Only an empty room, cold because Daddy was heating the east wing today. A bureau. A closet, its door open to reveal a clutch of hotel hangers, the kind you can't steal. A Gideon Bible on an endtable. To his (Gideon) left was the bathroom door, a full-length mirror on it reflecting his (Gideon) own white-faced image. That door was ajar and -- He (Gideon) watched his (Gideon) double nod slowly. Yes, that's where it was, whatever it was. In there. In the bathroom. His (Gideon) double walked forward, as if to escape the glass. It put its hand out, pressed it against his (Gideon) own. Then it fell away at an angle as the bathroom door swung open. He (Gideon) looked in. A long room, old-fashioned, like a Pullman car. Tiny white hexagonal tiles on the floor. At the far end, a toilet with the lid up. At the right, a washbasin and another mirror above it, the kind that hides a medicine cabinet. To the left, a huge white tub on claw feet, the shower curtain pulled closed. Danny stepped into the bathroom and walked toward the tub dreamily, as if propelled from outside himself, as if this whole thing were one of the dreams Tony had brought him (Tony), that he (Tony) would perhaps see something nice when he (Tony) pulled the shower curtain back, something Daddy had forgotten or Mommy had lost, something that would make them both happy -- So he (Tony) pulled the shower curtain back. The woman in the tub had been dead for a long time. She (woman) was bloated and purple, her (woman) gas-filled belly rising out of the cold, ice-rimmed water like some fleshy island. Her (woman) eyes were fixed on Danny's, glassy and huge, like marbles. She (woman) was grinning, her (woman) purple lips pulled back in a grimace. Her (woman) breasts lolled. Her (woman) pubic hair floated. Her (woman) hands were frozen on the knurled porcelain sides of the tub like crab claws. Danny shrieked. But the sound never escaped his (Danny) lips; turning inward and inward, it fell down in his (Danny) darkness like a stone in a well. He (Danny) took a single blundering step backward, hearing his (Danny) heels clack on the white hexagonal tiles, and at the same moment his (Danny) urine broke, spilling effortlessly out of him (Danny). The woman was sitting up. Still grinning, her (woman) huge marble eyes fixed on him (Danny), she (woman) was sitting up. Her (woman) dead palms made squittering noises on the porcelain. Her (woman) breasts swayed like ancient cracked punching bags. There was the minute sound of breaking ice shards. She (woman) was not breathing. She (woman) was a corpse, and dead long years. Danny turned and ran. Bolting through the bathroom door, his (Danny) eyes starting from their sockets, his (Danny) hair on end like the hair of a hedgehog about to be turned into a sacrificial -LRB-croquet? or roque?-RRB- ball, his (Danny) mouth open and soundless. He (Danny) ran full-tilt into the outside door of 217, which was now closed. He (Danny) began hammering on it, far beyond realizing that it was unlocked, and he (Danny) had only to turn the knob to let himself out. His (Danny) mouth pealed forth deafening screams that were beyond human auditory range. He (Danny) could only hammer on the door and hear the dead woman coming for him (Danny), bloated belly, dry hair, outstretched hands something that had lain slain in that tub for perhaps years, embalmed there in magic.

The door would not open, would not, would not, would not. And then the voice of Dick Hallorann came to him (Hallorann), so sudden and unexpected, so calm, that his (Hallorann) locked vocal cords opened and he (Hallorann) began to cry weakly not with fear but with blessed relief. -LRB-I don't think they can hurt you ... they're like pictures in a book ... close your eyes and they'll be gone.-RRB- His (Hallorann) eyelids snapped down. His (Hallorann) hands curled into balls. His (Hallorann) shoulders hunched with the effort of his (Hallorann) concentration: -LRB-Nothing there nothing there not there at all NOTHING THERE THERE IS NOTHING!-RRB- Time passed. And he (Hallorann) was just beginning to relax, just beginning to realize that the door must be unlocked and he (Hallorann) could go, when the years-damp, bloated, fish-smelling hands closed softly around his (Hallorann) throat and he (Hallorann) was turned implacably around to stare into that dead and purple face.

PART FOUR -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- Snowbound -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- --

<< 26 >> DREAMLAND Knitting made her (Hallorann) sleepy. Today even Bartok would have made her (Hallorann) sleepy, and it wasn't Bartok on the little phonograph, it was Bach. Her (Hallorann) hands grew slower and slower, and at the time her (Hallorann) son was making the acquaintance of Room 217's longterm resident, Wendy was asleep with her (Wendy) knitting on her (Wendy) lap. The yarn and needles rose in the slow time of her (Wendy) breathing. Her (Wendy) sleep was deep and she (Wendy) did not dream.

*** Jack Torrance had fallen asleep too, but his (Torrance) sleep was light and uneasy, populated by dreams that seemed too vivid to be mere dreams -- they were certainly more vivid than any dreams he (Torrance) had ever had before. His (Torrance) eyes had begun to get heavy as he (Torrance) leafed through packets of milk bills, a hundred to a packet, seemingly tens of thousands all together. Yet he (Torrance) gave each one a cursory glance, afraid that by not being thorough he (Torrance) might miss exactly the piece of Overlookiana he (Torrance) needed to make the mystic connection that he (Torrance) was sure must be here somewhere. He (Torrance) felt like a man with a power cord in one hand, groping around a dark and unfamiliar room for a socket. If he (Torrance) could find it he (Torrance) would be rewarded with a view of wonders. He (Torrance) had come to grips with Al Shockley's phone call and his (Shockley) request; his (Shockley) strange experience in the playground had helped him (Shockley) to do that. That had been too damned close to some kind of breakdown, and he (Shockley) was convinced that it was his (Shockley) mind in revolt against Al's high-goddam-handed request that he (Shockley) chuck his (Shockley) book project. It had maybe been a signal that his (Shockley) own sense of self-respect could only be pushed so far before disintegrating entirely. He (Shockley) would write the book. If it meant the end of his (Shockley) association with Al Shockley, that would have to be. He (Shockley) would write the hotel's biography, write it straight from the shoulder, and the introduction would be his (Shockley) hallucination that the topiary animals had moved. The title would be uninspired but workable: Strange Resort, The Story of the Overlook Hotel. Straight from the shoulder, yes, but it would not be written vindictively, in any effort to get back at Al or Stuart Ullman or George Hatfield or his (Hatfield) father -LRB-miserable, bullying drunk that he (Hatfield) had been-RRB- or anyone else, for that matter. He (Hatfield) would write it because the Overlook had enchanted him (Hatfield) -- could any other explanation be so simple or so true? He (Hatfield) would write it for the reason he (Hatfield) felt that all great literature, fiction and nonfiction, was written: truth comes out, in the end it always comes out. He (Hatfield) would write it because he (Hatfield) felt he (Hatfield) had to. Five hundred gals whole milk. One hundred gals skim milk. Pd. Billed to acc`t. Three hundred pts orange juice. Pd. He (Hatfield) slipped down further in his (Hatfield) chair, still holding a clutch of the receipts, but his (Hatfield) eyes no longer looking at what was printed there. They had come unfocused. His (Hatfield) lids were slow and heavy. His (Hatfield) mind had slipped from the Overlook to his (Hatfield) father, who had been a male nurse at the Berlin Community Hospital. Big man. A fat man who had towered to six feet two inches, he (man) had been taller than Jack even when Jack got his (Jack) full growth of six feet even -- not that the old man had still been around then.

``Runt of the litter,'' (he)
he (man) would say, and then cuff Jack lovingly and laugh. There had been two other brothers, both taller than their father, and Becky, who at five-ten had only been two inches shorter than Jack and taller than he (Jack) for most of their childhood. His (Jack) relationship with his (Jack) father had been like the unfurling of some flower of beautiful potential, which, when wholly opened, turned out to be blighted inside. Until he (Jack) had been seven he (Jack) had loved the tall, big-bellied man uncritically and strongly in spite of the spankings, the black-and-blues, the occasional black eye. He (Jack) could remember velvet summer nights, the house quiet, oldest brother Brett

out with his (Brett) girl, middle brother Mike studying something, Becky and their mother in the living room, watching something on the balky old TV; and he (Brett) would sit in the hall dressed in a pajama singlet and nothing else, ostensibly playing with his (Brett) trucks, actually waiting for the moment when the silence would be broken by the door swinging open with a large bang, the bellow of his (Brett) father's welcome when he (Brett) saw Jacky was waiting, his (Brett) own happy squeal in answer as this big man came down the hall, his (Brett) pink scalp glowing beneath his (Brett) crewcut in the glow of the hall light. In that light he (Brett) always looked like some soft and flapping oversized ghost in his (Brett) hospital whites, the shirt always untucked -LRB-and sometimes bloody-RRB-, the pants cuffs drooping down over the black shoes. His (Brett) father would sweep him (father) into his (father) arms and Jacky would be propelled deliriously upward, so fast it seemed he (father) could feel air pressure settling against his (father) skull like a cap made out of lead, up and up, both of them crying

``Elevator! Elevator!'' (he)
; and there had been nights when his (father) father in his (father) drunkenness had not stopped the upward lift of his (father) slabmuscled arms soon enough and Jacky had gone right over his (father) father's flattopped head like a human projectile to crash-land on the hall floor behind his (father) dad. But on other nights his (father) father would only sweep him (father) into a giggling ecstasy, through the zone of air where beer hung around his (father) father's face like a mist of raindrops, to be twisted and turned and shaken like a laughing rag, and finally to be set down on his (father) feet, hiccupping with reaction. The receipts slipped from his (father) relaxing hand and seesawed down through the air to land lazily on the floor; his (father) eyelids, which had settled shut with his (father) father's image tattooed on their backs like stereopticon images, opened a little bit and then slipped back down again. He (father) twitched a little. Consciousness, like the receipts, like autumn aspen leaves, seesawed lazily downward. That had been the first phase of his (father) relationship with his (father) father, and as it was drawing to its end he (father) had become aware that Becky and his (father) brothers, all of them older, hated the father and that their mother, a nondescript woman who rarely spoke above a mutter, only suffered him (father) because her (mother) Catholic upbringing said that she (mother) must. In those days it had not seemed strange to Jack that the father won all his (father) arguments with his (father) children by use of his (father) fists, and it had not seemed strange that his (father) own love should go hand-in-hand with his (father) fear: fear of the elevator game which might end in a splintering crash on any given night; fear that his (father) father's bearish good humor on his (father) day off might suddenly change to boarish bellowing and the smack of his (father)
``good right hand'' (father)
; and sometimes, he (father) remembered, he (father) had even been afraid that his (father) father's shadow might fall over him (father) while he (father) was at play. It was near the end of this phase that he (father) began to notice that Brett never brought his (Brett) dates home, or Mike and Becky their chums. Love began to curdle at nine, when his (Brett) father put his (father) mother into the hospital with his (father) cane. He (father) had begun to carry the cane a year earlier, when a car accident had left him (father) lame. After that he (father) was never without it, long and black and thick and gold-headed. Now, dozing, Jack's body twitched in a remembered cringe at the sound it made in the air, a murderous swish, and its heavy crack against the wall ... or against flesh. He (Jack) had beaten their mother for no good reason at all, suddenly and without warning. They had been at the supper table. The cane had been standing by his (Jack) chair. It was a Sunday night, the end of a three-day weekend for Daddy, a weekend which he (Jack) had boozed away in his (Jack) usual

inimitable style. Roast chicken. Peas. Mashed potatoes. Daddy at the head of the table, his (Jack) plate heaped high, snoozing or nearly snoozing. His (Jack) mother passing plates. And suddenly Daddy had been wide awake, his (Jack) eyes set deeply into their fat eyesockets, glittering with a kind of stupid, evil petulance. They flickered from one member of the family to the next, and the vein in the center of his (member) forehead was standing out prominently, always a bad sign. One of his (member) large freckled hands had dropped to the gold knob of his (member) cane, caressing it. He (member) said something about coffee ¯ to this day Jack was sure it had been

``coffee'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
that his (Jack) father said. Momma had opened her (member) mouth to answer and then the cane was whickering through the air, smashing against her (member) face. Blood spurted from her (member) nose. Becky screamed. Momma's spectacles dropped into her (Becky) gravy. The cane had been drawn back, had come down again, this time on top of her (Becky) head, splitting the scalp. Momma had dropped to the floor. He (father) had been out of his (father) chair and around to where she (Becky) lay dazed on the carpet, brandishing the cane, moving with a fat man's grotesque speed and agility, little eyes flashing, jowls quivering as he (man) spoke to her (Becky) just as he (man) had always spoken to his (man) children during such outbursts.
``Now. Now by Christ. I guess you'll take your medicine now. Goddam puppy. Whelp. Come on and take your medicine.'' (Brett)
The cane had gone up and down on her (Becky) seven more times before Brett and Mike got hold of him (Brett), dragged him (Brett) away, wrestled the cane out of his (Brett) hand. Jack -LRB-little Jacky now he (Jack) was little Jacky now dozing and mumbling on a cobwebby camp chair while the furnace roared into hollow life behind him (Jack)-RRB- knew exactly how many blows it had been because each soft whump against his (Jack) mother's body had been engraved on his (Jack) memory like the irrational swipe of a chisel on stone. Seven whumps. No more, no less. He (Jack) and Becky crying, unbelieving, looking at their mother's spectacles lying in her (Becky) mashed potatoes, one cracked lens smeared with gravy. Brett shouting at Daddy from the back hall, telling him (Brett) he (Brett)'d kill him (Brett) if he (Brett) moved. And Daddy saying over and over:
``Damn little puppy. Damn little whelp. Give me my cane, you damn little pup. Give it to me.'' (Brett)
Brett brandishing it hysterically, saying yes, yes, I'll give it to you, just you move a little bit and I'll give you all you want and two extra. I'll give you plenty. Momma getting slowly to her (Becky) feet, dazed, her (Becky) face already puffed and swelling like an old tire with too much air in it, bleeding in four or five different places, and she (Becky) had said a terrible thing, perhaps the only thing Momma had ever said which Jacky could recall word for word:
``Who's got the newspaper? Your daddy wants the funnies. Is it raining yet?'' (Jacky)
And then she (Becky) sank to her (Becky) knees again, her (Becky) hair hanging in her (Becky) puffed and bleeding face. Mike calling the doctor, babbling into the phone. Could he (Mike) come right away? It was their mother. No, he (Mike) couldn't say what the trouble was, not over the phone, not over a party line he (Mike) couldn't. Just come. The doctor came and took Momma away to the hospital where Daddy had worked all of his (Daddy) adult life. Daddy, sobered up some -LRB-or perhaps only with the stupid cunning of any hardpressed animal-RRB-, told the doctor she (mother) had fallen downstairs. There was blood on the tablecloth because he (doctor) had tried to wipe her (mother) dear face with it. Had her (mother) glasses flown all the way through the living room and into the dining room to land in her (mother) mashed potatoes and gravy? the doctor asked with a kind of horrid, grinning sarcasm. Is that what happened, Mark? I have heard of folks who can get a radio station on their gold fillings and I have seen a man get shot between the eyes and live to tell

about it, but that is a new one on me. Daddy had merely shook his (man) head and said he (man) didn't know; they must have fallen off her (mother) face when he (man) brought her (mother) through the dining room. The four children had been stunned to silence by the calm stupendousness of the lie. Four days later Brett quit his (Brett) job in the mill and joined the Army. Jack had always felt it was not just the sudden and irrational beating his (Jack) father had administered at the dinner table but the fact that, in the hospital, their mother had corroborated their father's story while holding the hand of the parish priest. Revolted, Brett had left them to whatever might come. He (Brett) had been killed in Dong Ho province in 1965, the year when Jack Torrance, undergraduate, had joined the active college agitation to end the war. He (Torrance) had waved his (Torrance) brother's bloody shirt at rallies that were increasingly well attended, but it was not Brett's face that hung before his (Brett) eyes when he (Brett) spoke it was the face of his (Brett) mother, a dazed, uncomprehending face, his (Brett) mother saying:

``Who's got the newspaper?'' (mother)
Mike escaped three years later when Jack was twelve he (Jack) went to UNH on a hefty Merit Scholarship. A year after that their father died of a sudden, massive stroke which occurred while he (father) was prepping a patient for surgery. He (father) had collapsed in his (father) flapping and untucked hospital whites, dead possibly even before he (father) hit the industrial black-and-red hospital tiles, and three days later the man who had dominated Jacky's life, the irrational white ghost-god, was under ground. The stone read Mark Anthony Torrance, Loving Father. To that Jack would have added one line: He (Jack) Knew How to Play Elevator. There had been a great lot of insurance money. There are people who collect insurance as compulsively as others collect coins and stamps, and Mark Torrance had been that type. The insurance money came in at the same time the monthly policy payments and liquor bills stopped. For five years they had been rich. Nearly rich ... In his (Torrance) shallow, uneasy sleep his (Torrance) face rose before him (Torrance) as if in a glass, his (Torrance) face but not his (Torrance) face, the wide eyes and innocent bowed mouth of a boy sitting in the ball with his (Torrance) trucks, waiting for his (Torrance) daddy, waiting for the white ghostgod, waiting for the elevator to rise up with dizzying, exhilarating speed through the salt-and-sawdust mist of exhaled taverns, waiting perhaps for it to go crashing down, spilling old clocksprings out of his (Torrance) ears while his (Torrance) daddy roared with laughter, and it -LRB-transformed into Danny's face, so much like his (Danny) own had been, his (Danny) eyes had been light blue while Danny's were cloudy gray, but the lips still made a bow and the complexion was fair; Danny in his (Danny) study, wearing training pants, all his (Danny) papers soggy and the fine misty smell of beer rising ... a dreadful batter all in ferment, rising on the wings of yeast, the breath of taverns ... snap of bone ... his (Danny) own voice, mewling drunkenly Danny, you okay doc? ... '' -- from your father. I repeat, an enormously important announcement from your father. Please stay tuned or tune immediately to the Happy Jack frequency. Repeat, tune immediately to the Happy Hour frequency. I repeat -- '' (momma)

cloudy hallway. -LRB-Things keep getting in the way, dear Tommy ...-RRB- -LRB-Medoc, are you here? I've been sleepwalking again, my dear. It's the inhuman monsters that I fear ...-RRB- -LRB-

``Excuse me, Mr. Ullman, but isn't this the...'' (I)
-RRB- ... office, with its file cabinets, Ullman's big desk, a blank reservations book for next year already in place never misses a trick, that Ullman -- all the keys hanging neatly on their hooks -LRB-except for one, which one, which key, passkey-passkey, passkey, who's got the passkey? if we went upstairs perhaps we'd see-RRB- and the big two-way radio on its shelf. He (Ullman) snapped it on. CB transmissions coming in short, crackly bursts. He (Ullman) switched the band and dialed across bursts of music, news, a preacher haranguing a softly moaning congregation, a weather report. And another voice which he (Ullman) dialed back to. It was his (Ullman) father's voice.
'' -- kill him (Ullman). You have to kill him (Ullman), Jacky, and her (we), too. Because a real artist must suffer. Because each man kills the thing he (man) loves. Because they'll always be conspiring against you, trying to hold you back and drag you down. Right this minute that boy of yours is in where he (boy) shouldn't be. Trespassing. That's what he (boy)'s doing. He (boy)'s a goddam little pup. Cane him (boy) for it, Jacky, cane him (boy) within an inch of his (boy) life. Have a drink Jacky my boy, and we'll play the elevator game. Then I'll go with you while you give him (boy) his (boy) medicine. I know you can do it, of course you can. You must kill him (boy). ``No!'' (him)
he (man) screamed back.
``You're dead, you're in your grave, you're not in me at all!'' (he)
Because he (man) had cut all the father out of him (man) and it was not right that he (man) should come back creeping through this hotel two thousand miles from the New England town where his (man) father had lived and died. He (man) raised the radio up and brought it down, and it smashed on the floor spilling old clocksprings and tubes like the result of some crazy elevator game gone awry, making his (man) father's voice gone, leaving only his (man) voice, Jack's voice, Jacky's voice, chanting in the cold reality of the office:
'' -- dead, you're dead, you're dead!'' (Jacky)
And the startled sound of Wendy's feet hitting the floor over his (man) head, and Wendy's startled, frightened voice:
``Jack? Jack!'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
He (man) stood, blinking down at the shattered radio. Now there was only the snowmobile in the equipment shed to link them to the outside world. He (man) put his (man) hands over his (man) eyes and clutched at his (man) temples. He (man) was getting a headache.

<< 27 >>

CATATONIC Wendy ran down the hall in her (Wendy) stocking feet and ran down the main stairs to the lobby two at a time. She (Wendy) didn't look up at the carpeted flight that led to the second floor, but if she (Wendy) had, she (Wendy) would have seen Danny standing at the top of them, still and silent, his (Danny) unfocused eyes directed out into indifferent space, his (Danny) thumb in his (Danny) mouth, the collar and shoulders of his (Danny) shirt damp. There were puffy bruises on his (Danny) neck and just below his (Danny) chin. Jack's cries had ceased, but that did nothing to ease her (Wendy) fear. Ripped out of her (Wendy) sleep by his (Danny) voice, raised in that old hectoring pitch she (Wendy) remembered so well, she (Wendy) still felt that she (Wendy) was dreaming -- but another part knew she (Wendy) was awake, and that terrified her (Wendy) more. She (Wendy) half-expected to burst into the office and find him (Danny) standing over Danny's sprawled-out body, drunk and confused. She (Wendy) pushed through the door and Jack was standing there, rubbing at his (Jack) temples with his (Jack) fingers. His (Jack) face was ghostwhite. The two-way CB radio lay at his (Jack) feet in a sprinkling of broken glass.

``Wendy?'' (he)
he (Jack) asked uncertainly.
``Wendy -- ?'' (she)
The bewilderment seemed to grow and for a moment she (Wendy) saw his (Jack) true face, the one he (Jack) ordinarily kept so well hidden, and it was a face of desperate unhappiness, the face of an animal caught in a snare beyond its ability to decipher and render harmless. Then the muscles began to work, began to writhe under the skin, the mouth began to tremble infirmly, the Adam's apple began to rise and fall. Her (Wendy) own bewilderment and surprise were overlaid by shock: he (Adam) was going to cry. She (Wendy) had seen him (Adam) cry before, but never since he (Adam) stopped drinking ... and never in those days unless he (Adam) was very drunk and pathetically remorseful. He (Adam) was a tight man, drum-tight, and his (Adam) loss of control frightened her (Wendy) all over again. He (Adam) came toward her (Wendy), the tears brimming over his (Adam) lower lids now, his (Adam) head shaking involuntarily as if in a fruitless effort to ward off this emotional storm, and his (Adam) chest drew in a convulsive gasp that was expelled in a huge, racking sob. His (Adam) feet, clad in Hush Puppies, stumbled over the wreck of the radio and he (Adam) almost fell into her (Wendy) arms, making her (Wendy) stagger back with his (Adam) weight. His (Adam) breath blew into her (Wendy) face and there was no smell of liquor on it. Of course not; there was no liquor up here.
``What's wrong?'' (She)
She (Wendy) held him (Adam) as best she (Wendy) could.
``Jack, what is it?'' (he)
But he (Adam) could do nothing at first but sob, clinging to her (Wendy), almost crushing the wind from her (Wendy), his (Adam) head turning on her (Wendy) shoulder in that helpless, shaking, warding-off gesture. His (Adam) sobs were heavy and fierce. He (Adam) was shuddering all over, his (Adam) muscles jerking beneath his (Adam) plaid shirt and jeans.
``Jack? What? Tell me what's wrong!'' (unknown)
At last the sobs began to change themselves into words, most of them incoherent at first, but coming clearer as his (Adam) tears began to spend themselves. ''... dream, I guess it was a dream, but it was so real, I... it was my mother saying that Daddy was going to be on the radio and I ...

he (Daddy) was ... he (Daddy) was telling me to ... I don't know, he (Daddy) was yelling at me ... and so I broke the radio ... to shut him (Daddy) up. To shut him (Daddy) up. He (Daddy)'s dead. I don't even want to dream about him (Daddy). He (Daddy)'s dead. My God, Wendy, my God. I never had a nightmare like that. I never want to have another one. Christ! It was awful.'' ``You just fell asleep in the office?'' ``No ... not here. Downstairs.'' He (Christ) was straightening a little now, his (Christ) weight coming off her (Wendy), and the steady back-and-forth motion of his (Christ) head first slowed and then stopped. ``I was looking through those old papers. Sitting on a chair I set up down there. Milk receipts. Dull stuff. And I guess I just drowsed off. That's when I started to dream. I must have sleepwalked up here.'' He (Christ) essayed a shaky little laugh against her (Wendy) neck. ``Another first.'' ``Where is Danny, Jack?'' ``I don't know. Isn't he (Danny) with you?'' ``He (Danny) wasn't ... downstairs with you?'' He (Christ) looked over his (Christ) shoulder and his (Christ) face tightened at what he (Christ) saw on her (Wendy) face. ``Never going to let me forget that, are you, Wendy?'' ``Jack -- '' ``When I'm on my deathbed you'll lean over and say, `It serves you right, remember the time you broke Danny's arm?' '' ``Jack!'' ``Jack what?'' he (Christ) asked hotly, and jumped to his (Christ) feet. ``Are you denying that's what you're thinking? That I hurt him (Jack)? That I hurt him (Jack) once before and I could hurt him (Jack) again?'' ``I want to know where he (Jack) is, that's all!'' ``Go ahead, yell your fucking head off, that'll make everything okay, won't it? '' She (Wendy) turned and walked out the door. He (Christ) watched her (Wendy) go, frozen for a moment, a blotter covered with fragments of broken glass in one hand. Then he (Christ) dropped it into the wastebasket, went after her (Wendy), and caught her (Wendy) by the lobby desk. He (Christ) put his (Christ) hands on her (Wendy) shoulders and turned her (Wendy) around. Her (Wendy) face was carefully set. ``Wendy, I'm sorry. It was the dream. I'm upset. Forgive?'' ``Of course,'' she (Wendy) said, her (Wendy) face not changing expression. Her (Wendy) wooden shoulders slipped out of his (Christ) hands. She (Wendy) walked to the middle of the lobby and called: ``Hey, doc! Where are you?'' Silence came back. She (Wendy) walked toward the double lobby doors, opened one of them, and stepped out onto the path Jack had shoveled. It was more like a trench; the packed and drifted snow through which the path was cut came to her (Wendy) shoulders. She (Wendy) called him (Jack) again, her (Wendy) breath coming out in a white plume. When she (Wendy) came back in she (Wendy) had begun to look scared. Controlling his (Jack) irritation with her (Wendy), he (Jack) said reasonably: ``Are you sure he (Jack)'s not sleeping in his (Jack) room?'' ``I told you, he (Jack) was playing somewhere when I was knitting. I could hear him (Jack) downstairs.'' ``Did you fall asleep?'' ``What's that got to do with it? Yes. Danny?''

``Did you look in his (Danny) room when you came downstairs just now?'' (She)

``I -- ``She (Jack) stopped. He (Danny) nodded.

``I didn't really think so.'' (He)
He (Jack) started up the stairs without waiting for her (Wendy). She (Wendy) followed him (Jack), halfrunning, but he (Jack) was taking the risers two at a time. She (Wendy) almost crashed into his (Jack) back when he (Jack) came to a dead stop on the first-floor landing. He (Jack) was rooted there, looking up, his (Jack) eyes wide.
``What -- ?'' (she)
she (Wendy) began, and followed his (Jack) gaze. Danny still stood there, his (Danny) eyes blank, sucking his (Danny) thumb. The marks on his (Danny) throat were cruelly visible in the light of the hall's electric flambeaux.
``Danny!'' (she)
she (Wendy) shrieked. It broke Jack's paralysis and they rushed up the stairs together to where he (Jack) stood. Wendy fell on her (Wendy) knees beside him (Jack) and swept the boy into her (Wendy) arms. Danny came pliantly enough, but he (Danny) did not hug her (Wendy) back. It was like hugging a padded stick, and the sweet taste of horror flooded her (Wendy) mouth. He (Danny) only sucked his (Danny) thumb and stared with indifferent blankness out into the stairwell beyond both of them.
``Danny, what happened?'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack asked. He (Jack) put out his (Jack) hand to touch the puffy side of Danny's neck.
``Who did this to -- '' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
``Don't you touch him (Danny)!'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy hissed. She (Wendy) clutched Danny in her (Wendy) arms, lifted him (Danny), and had retreated halfway down the stairs before Jack could do more than stand up, confused.
``What? Wendy, what the hell are you t -- '' (unknown)
``Don't you touch him (Danny)! I'll kill you if you lay your hands on him (Danny) again!'' (unknown)
``Wendy -- '' (She)
``You bastard!'' (She)
She (Wendy) turned and ran down the rest of the stairs to the first floor. Danny's head jounced mildly up and down as she (Wendy) ran. His (Danny) thumb was lodged securely in his (Danny) mouth. His (Danny) eyes were soaped windows. She (Wendy) turned right at the foot of the stairs, and Jack heard her (Wendy) feet retreat to the end of it. Their bedroom door slammed. The bolt was run home. The lock turned. Brief silence. Then the soft, muttered sounds of comforting. He (Jack) stood for an unknown length of time, literally paralyzed by all that had happened in such a short space of time. His (Jack) dream was still with him (Jack), painting everything a slightly unreal shade. It was as if he (Jack) had taken a very mild mescaline hit. Had he (Jack) maybe hurt Danny as Wendy thought? Tried to strangle his (Danny) son at his (Danny) dead father's request? No. He (Danny) would never hurt Danny. -LRB-He (Danny) fell down the stairs, Doctor.-RRB- He (Danny) would never hurt Danny now. -LRB-How could I know the bug bomb was defective?-RRB- Never in his (Danny) life had he (Danny) been willfully vicious when he (Danny) was sober. -LRB-Except when you almost killed George Hatfield.-RRB-
``No!'' (he)
he (Hatfield) cried into the darkness. He (Hatfield) brought both fists crashing down on his (Hatfield) legs, again and again and again. *** Wendy sat in the overstuffed chair by the window with Danny on her (Wendy) lap, holding him (Danny), crooning the old meaningless words, the ones you never remember

afterward no matter how a thing turns out. He (Danny) had folded onto her (Wendy) lap with neither protest nor gladness, like a paper cutout of himself, and his (Danny) eyes didn't even shift toward the door when Jack cried out

``No!'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
somewhere in the hallway. The confusion had receded a little bit in her (Wendy) mind, but she (Wendy) now discovered something even worse behind it. Panic. Jack had done this, she (Wendy) had no doubt of it. His (Jack) denials meant nothing to her (Wendy). She (Wendy) thought it was perfectly possible that Jack had tried to throttle Danny in his (Danny) sleep just as he (Danny) had smashed the CB radio in his (Danny) sleep. He (Danny) was having a breakdown of some kind. But what was she (Wendy) going to do about it? She (Wendy) couldn't stay locked in here forever. They would have to eat. There was really only one question, and it was asked in a mental voice of utter coldness and pragmatism, the voice of her (Wendy) maternity, a cold and passionless voice once it was directed away from the closed circle of mother and child and out toward Jack. It was a voice that spoke of self-preservation only after son-preservation and its question was: -LRB-Exactly how dangerous is he (Jack)?-RRB- He (Jack) had denied doing it. He (Jack) had been horrified at the bruises, at Danny's soft and implacable disconnection. If he (Danny) had done it, a separate section of himself had been responsible. The fact that he (Danny) had done it when he (Danny) was asleep was in a terrible, twisted way encouraging. Wasn't it possible that he (Danny) could be trusted to get them out of here? To get them down and away. And after that ... But she (Danny) could see no further than she (Danny) and Danny arriving safe at Dr. Edmonds's office in Sidewinder. She (Danny) had no particular need to see further. The present crisis was more than enough to keep her (Danny) occupied. She (Danny) crooned to Danny, rocking him (Danny) on her (Danny) breasts. Her (Danny) fingers, on his (Danny) shoulder, had noticed that his (Danny) T-shirt was damp, but they had not bothered reporting the information to her (Danny) brain in more than a cursory way. If it had been reported, she (Danny) might have remembered that Jack's hands, as he (Jack) had hugged her (Danny) in the office and sobbed against her (Danny) neck, bad been dry. It might have given her (Danny) pause. But her (Danny) mind was still on other things. The decision had to be made -- to approach Jack or not? Actually it was not much of a decision. There was nothing she (Danny) could do alone, not even carry Danny down to the office and call for help on the CB radio. He (Danny) had suffered a great shock. He (Danny) ought to be taken out quickly before any permanent damage could be done. She (Danny) refused to let herself believe that permanent damage might already have been done. And still she (Danny) agonized over it, looking for another alternative. She (Danny) did not want to put Danny back within Jack's reach. She (Danny) was aware now that she (Danny) had made one bad decision when she (Danny) had gone against her (Danny) feelings -LRB-and Danny's-RRB- and allowed the snow to close them in ... for Jack's sake. Another bad decision when she (Danny) had shelved the idea of divorce. Now she (Danny) was nearly paralyzed by the idea that she (Danny) might be making another mistake, one she (Danny) would regret every minute of every day of the rest of her (Danny) life. There was not a gun in the place. There were knives hanging from the magnetized runners in the kitchen, but Jack was between her (Danny) and them. In her (Danny) striving to make the right decision, to find the alternative, the bitter irony of her (Danny) thoughts did not occur: an hour ago she (Danny) had been asleep,

firmly convinced that things were all right and soon would be even better. Now she (Danny) was considering the possibility of using a butcher knife on her (Danny) husband if he (husband) tried to interfere with her (Danny) and her (Danny) son. At last she (Danny) stood up with Danny in her (Danny) arms, her (Danny) legs trembling. There was no other way. She (Danny) would have to assume that Jack awake was Jack sane, and that he (Jack) would help her (Danny) get Danny down to Sidewinder and Dr. Edmonds. And if Jack tried to do anything but help, God help him (Jack). She (Danny) went to the door and unlocked it. Shifting Danny up to her (Danny) shoulder, she (Danny) opened it and went out into the hall.

``Jack?'' (she)
she (Danny) called nervously, and got no answer. With growing trepidation she (Danny) walked down to the stairwell, but Jack was not there. And as she (Danny) stood there on the landing, wondering what to do next, the singing came up from below, rich, angry, bitterly satiric:
``Roll me over In the clo-ho-ver, Roll me over, lay me down and do it again.'' (she)
She (Danny) was frightened even more by the sound of him (Jack) than she (Danny) had been by his (Jack) silence, but there was still no alternative. She (Danny) started down the stairs.

<< 28 >>

``IT WAS HER!'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack had stood on the stairs, listening to the crooning, comforting sounds coming muffled through the locked door, and slowly his (Jack) confusion had given way to anger. Things had never really changed. Not to Wendy. He (Jack) could be off the juice for twenty years and still when he (Jack) came home at night and she (Wendy) embraced him (Jack) at the door, he (Jack) would see/ sense that little flare of her (Wendy) nostrils as she (Wendy) tried to divine scotch or gin fumes riding the outbound train of his (Jack) exhalation. She (Wendy) was always going to assume the worst; if he (Jack) and Danny got in a car accident with a drunken blindman who had had a stroke just before the collision, she (Wendy) would silently blame Danny's injuries on him (Danny) and turn away. Her (Wendy) face as she (Wendy) had snatched Danny away it rose up before him (Danny) and he (Danny) suddenly wanted to wipe the anger that had been on it out with his (Danny) fist. She (Wendy) had no goddam right! Yes, maybe at first. He (Danny) had been a lush, he (Danny) had done terrible things. Breaking Danny's arm had been a terrible thing. But if a man reforms, doesn't he (Danny) deserve to have his (Danny) reformation credited sooner or later? And if he (Danny) doesn't get it, doesn't he (Danny) deserve the game to go with the name? If a father constantly accuses his (father) virginal daughter of screwing every boy in junior high, must she (daughter) not at last

grow weary -LRB-enough-RRB- of it to earn her (daughter) scoldings? And if a wife secretly-and not so secretly-continues to believe that her (daughter) teetotaling husband is a drunk ... He (husband) got up, walked slowly down to the first-floor landing, and stood there for a moment. He (husband) took his (husband) handkerchief from his (husband) back pocket, wiped his (husband) lips with it, and considered going down and pounding on the bedroom door, demanding to be let in so he (husband) could see his (husband) son. She (daughter) had no right to be so goddam highhanded. Well, sooner or later she (daughter)'d have to come out, unless she (daughter) planned a radical sort of diet for the two of them. A rather ugly grin touched his (husband) lips at the thought. Let her (daughter) come to him (husband). She (daughter) would in time. He (husband) went downstairs to the ground floor, stood aimlessly by the lobby desk for a moment, then turned right. He (husband) went into the dining room and stood just inside the door. The empty tables, their white linen cloths neatly cleaned and pressed beneath their clear plastic covers, glimmered up at him (husband). All was deserted now but -LRB-Dinner Will Be Served at 8 P.M. Un-Masking and Dancing At Midnight-RRB- Jack walked among the tables, momentarily forgetting his (Jack) wife and son upstairs, forgetting the dream, the smashed radio, the bruises. He (Jack) trailed his (Jack) fingers over the slick plastic dustcovers, trying to imagine how it must have been on that hot August night in 1945, the war won, the future stretching ahead so various and new, like a land of dreams. The bright and particolored Japanese lanterns hung the whole length of the circular drive, the golden-yellow light spilling from these high windows that were now drifted over with snow. Men and women in costume, here a glittering princess, there a high-booted cavalier, flashing jewelry and flashing wit every where, dancing, liquor flowing freely, first wine and then cocktails and then perhaps boilermakers the level of conversation going up and up and up until the jolly cry rang out from the bandmaster's podium, the cry of

``Unmask! Unmask!'' (the bandmaster)
-LRB-And the Red Death held sway ...-RRB- He (princess) found himself standing on the other side of the dining room, just outside the stylized batwing doors of the Colorado Lounge where, on that night in 1945, all the booze would have been free. -LRB-Belly up to the bar, pardner, the drinks're on the house.-RRB- He (princess) stepped through the batwings and into the deep, folded shadows of the bar. And a strange thing occurred. He (princess) had been in here before, once to check the inventory sheet Ullman had left, and he (Ullman) knew the place had been stripped clean. The shelves were totally bare. But now, lit only murkily by the light which filtered through from the dining room -LRB-which was itself only dimly lit because of the snow blocking the windows-RRB-, he (Ullman) thought he (Ullman) saw ranks and ranks of bottles twinkling mutedly behind the bar, and syphons, and even beer dripping from the spigots of all three highly polished taps. Yes, he (Ullman) could even smell beer, that damp and fermented and yeasty odor, no different from the smell that had hung finely misted around his (Ullman) father's face every night when he (Ullman) came home from work. Eyes widening, he (Ullman) fumbled for the wall switch, and the low, intimate barlighting came on, circles of twenty-watt bulbs emplanted on the tops of the three wagon-wheel chandeliers overhead.

The shelves were all empty. They had not even as yet gathered a good coat of dust. The beer taps were dry, as were the chrome drains beneath them. To his (Ullman) left and right, the velvet-upholstered booths stood like men with high backs, each one designed to give a maximum of privacy to the couple inside. Straight ahead, across the red-carpeted floor, forty barstools stood around the horseshoe-shaped bar. Each stool was upholstered in leather and embossed with cattle brands -- Circle H, Bar D Bar -LRB-that was fitting-RRB-, Rocking W, Lazy B. He (Ullman) approached it, giving his (Ullman) head a little shake of bewilderment as he (Ullman) did so. It was like that day on the playground when ... but there was no sense in thinking about that. Still he (Ullman) could have sworn he (Ullman) had seen those bottles, vaguely, it was true, the way you see the darkened shapes of furniture in a room where the curtains have been drawn. Mild glints on glass. The only thing that remained was that smell of beer, and Jack knew that was a smell that faded into the woodwork of every bar in the world after a certain period of time, not to be eradicated by any cleaner invented. Yet the smell here seemed sharp ... almost fresh. He (Jack) sat down on one of the stools and propped his (Jack) elbows on the bar's leathercushioned edge. At his (Jack) left hand was a bowl for peanuts now empty, of course. The first bar he (Jack)'d been in for nineteen months and the damned thing was dry just his (Jack) luck. All the same, a bitterly powerful wave of nostalgia swept over him (Jack), and the physical craving for a drink seemed to work itself up from his (Jack) belly to his (Jack) throat to his (Jack) mouth and nose, shriveling and wrinkling the tissues as it went, making them cry out for something wet and long and cold. He (Jack) glanced at the shelves again in wild, irrational hope but the shelves were just as empty as before. He (Jack) grinned in pain and frustration. His (Jack) fists, clenching slowly, made minute scratchings on the bar's leather-padded edge.

he (Jack) said.

Lloyd said it was. Lloyd asked him (Lloyd) what it would be.

``really glad. Because I happen to have two twenties and two tens in my wallet and I was afraid they'd be sitting there until sometime next April. There isn't a Seven-Eleven around here, would you believe it? And I thought they had Seven-Elevens on the fucking moon.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)

matter.'' Lloyd thanked him (Lloyd) for saying so. Jack thumped the cap from his (Jack) Excedrin bottle, shook two tablets out, and flipped them into his (Jack) mouth. The familiar acid-compelling taste flooded in. He (Jack) had a sudden sensation that people were watching him (Jack), curiously and with some contempt. The booths behind him (Jack) were full there were graying, distinguished men and beautiful young girls, all of them in costume, watching this sad exercise in the dramatic arts with cold amusement. Jack whirled on his (Jack) stool. The booths were all empty, stretching away from the lounge door to the left and right, the line on his (Jack) left cornering to flank the bar's horseshoe curve down the short length of the room. Padded leather seats and backs. Gleaming dark Formica tables, an ashtray on each one, a book of matches in each ashtray, the words Colorado Lounge stamped on each in gold leaf above the batwing-door logo. He (Jack) turned back, swallowing the rest of the dissolving Excedrin with a grimace. ``Lloyd, you're a wonder,'' he (Jack) said. ``Set up already. Your speed is only exceeded by the soulful beauty of your Neapolitan eyes. Salud.'' Jack contemplated the twenty imaginary drinks, the martini glasses blushing droplets of condensation, each with a swizzle poked through a plump green olive. He (Jack) could almost smell gin on the air. ``The wagon,'' he (Jack) said. ``Have you ever been acquainted with a gentleman who has hopped up on the wagon?'' Lloyd allowed as how he (Lloyd) had met such men from time to time. ``Have you ever renewed acquaintances with such a man after he (man) hopped back off?'' Lloyd could not, in all honesty, recall. ``You never did, then,'' Jack said. He (Jack) curled his (Jack) hand around the first drink, carried his (Jack) fist to his (Jack) mouth, which was open, and turned his (Jack) fist up. He (Jack) swallowed and then tossed the imaginary glass over his (Jack) shoulder. The people were back again, fresh from their costume ball, studying him (Jack), laughing behind their hands. He (Jack) could feel them. If the backbar had featured a mirror instead of those damn stupid empty shelves, he (Jack) could have seen them. Let them stare. Fuck them. Let anybody stare who wanted to stare. ``No, you never did,'' he (Jack) told Lloyd.

``Few men ever return from the fabled Wagon, but those who do come with a fearful tale to tell. When you jump on, it seems like the brightest, cleanest Wagon you ever saw, with ten-foot wheels to keep the bed of it high out of the gutter where all the drunks are laying around with their brown bags and their Thunderbird and their Granddad Flash's Popskull Bourbon. You're away from all the people who throw you nasty looks and tell you to clean up your act or go put it on in another town. From the gutter, that's the finest-lookin Wagon you ever saw, Lloyd my boy. All hung with bunting and a brass band in front and three majorettes to each side, twirling their batons and flashing their panties at you. Man, you got to get on that Wagon and away from the juicers that are straining canned heat and smelling their own puke to get high again and poking along the gutter for butts with half an inch left below the filter.'' (unknown)
He (Lloyd) drained two more imaginary drinks and tossed the glasses back over his (Lloyd) shoulder. He (Lloyd) could almost hear them smashing on the floor. And goddam if he (Lloyd) wasn't starting to feel high. It was the Excedrin.

``So you climb up,'' (he)
he (Lloyd) told Lloyd.
``and ain't you glad to be there. My God yes, that's affirmative. That Wagon is the biggest and best float in the whole parade, and everybody is lining the streets and clapping and cheering and waving, all for you. Except for the winos passed out in the gutter. Those guys used to be your friends, but that's all behind you now.'' (He)
He (Lloyd) carried his (Lloyd) empty fist to his (Lloyd) mouth and sluiced down another -- four down, sixteen to go. Making excellent progress. He (Lloyd) swayed a little on the stool. Let em stare, if that was how they got off. Take a picture, folks, it'll last longer.
``Then you start to see things, Lloydy-my-boy. Things you missed from the gutter. Like how the floor of the Wagon is nothing but straight pine boards, so fresh they're still bleeding sap, and if you took your shoes off you'd be sure to get a splinter. Like how the only furniture in the Wagon is these long benches with high backs and no cushions to sit on, and in fact they are nothing but pews with a songbook every five feet or so. Like how all the people sitting in the pews on the Wagon are these flatchested el birdos in long dresses with a little lace around the collar and their hair pulled back into buns until it's so tight you can almost hear it screaming. And every face is flat and pale and shiny, and they're all singing `Shall we gather at the riiiiver, the beautiful, the beautiful, the riiiiiver,' and up front there's this reekin bitch with blond hair playing the organ and tellin em to sing louder, sing louder. And somebody slams a songbook into your hands and says, `Sing it out, brother. If you expect to stay on this Wagon, you got to sing morning, noon, and night. Especially at night.' And that's when you realize what the Wagon really is, Lloyd. It's a church with bars on the windows, a church for women and a prison for you.'' (He)
He (Lloyd) stopped. Lloyd was gone. Worse still, he (Lloyd) had never been there. The drinks had never been there. Only the people in the booths, the people from the costume party, and he (Lloyd) could almost hear their muffled laughter as they held their hands to their mouths and pointed, their eyes sparkling with cruel pinpoints of light. He (Lloyd) whirled around again.

he (Danny) screamed, running to Jack, his (Jack) eyes huge and affrighted.

<< 29 >> KITCHEN TALK Jack carried Danny into the kitchen. The boy was still sobbing wildly, refusing to look up from Jack's chest. In the kitchen he (Jack) gave Danny back to Wendy, who still seemed stunned and disbelieving.

``Jack, I don't know what he (Jack)'s talking about. Please, you must believe that.'' (unknown)
``I do believe it,'' (he)
he (Danny) said, although he (Danny) had to admit to himself that it gave him (Danny) a certain amount of pleasure to see the shoe switched to the other foot with such dazzling, unexpected speed. But his (Danny) anger at Wendy had been only a passing gut twitch. In his (Danny) heart he (Danny) knew Wendy would pour a can of gasoline over herself and strike a match before harming Danny. The large tea kettle was on the back burner, poking along on low heat. Jack dropped a teabag into his (Jack) own large ceramic cup and poured hot water halfway.
``Got cooking sherry, don't you?'' (he)
he (Jack) asked Wendy.
``What? ... oh, sure. Two or three bottles of it.'' (unknown)
``Which cupboard?'' (She)
She (Wendy) pointed, and Jack took one of the bottles down. He (Jack) poured a hefty dollop into the teacup, put the sherry back, and filled the last quarter of the cup with milk. Then he (Jack) added three tablespoons of sugar and stirred. He (Jack) brought it to Danny, whose sobs had tapered off to snifflings and hitchings. But he (Danny) was trembling all over, and his (Danny) eyes were wide and starey.
``Want you to drink this, doc,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``It's going to taste frigging awful, but it'll make you feel better. Can you drink it for your daddy?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny nodded that he (Jack) could and took the cup. He (Jack) drank a little, grimaced, and looked questioningly at Jack. Jack nodded and Danny drank again. Wendy felt the familiar twist of jealousy somewhere in her (Wendy) middle, knowing the boy would not have drunk it for her (Wendy). On the heels of that came an uncomfortable, even startling thought: Had she (Wendy) wanted to think Jack was to blame? Was she (Wendy) that jealous? It was the way her (Wendy) mother would have thought, that was the really horrible thing. She (Wendy) could remember a Sunday when her (Wendy) Dad had taken her (Wendy) to the park and she (Wendy) had toppled from the second tier of the jungle gym, cutting both knees. When her (Wendy) father brought her (Wendy) home, her (Wendy) mother had shrieked at him (father): What did you do? Why weren't you watching her (Wendy)? What kind of a father are you? -LRB-She (Wendy) had hounded him (father) to his (father) grave; by the time he (father) divorced her (Wendy) it was too late.-RRB- She (Wendy) had never even given Jack the benefit of the doubt. Not the smallest. Wendy felt her (Wendy) face burn yet knew with a kind of helpless finality that if the whole thing were to be played over again, she (Wendy) would do and think the same way. She (Wendy) carried part of her (Wendy) mother with her (Wendy) always, for good or bad.

``Jack -- '' (she)
she (Wendy) began, not sure if she (Wendy) meant to apologize or justify. Either, she (Wendy) knew, would be useless.
``Not now,'' (he)
he (Jack) said. It took Danny fifteen minutes to drink half of the big cup's contents, and by that time he (Danny) had calmed visibly. The shakes were almost gone. Jack put his (Jack) hands solemnly on his (Jack) son's shoulders.
``Danny, do you think you can tell us exactly what happened to you? It's very important.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny looked from Jack to Wendy, then back again. In the silent pause, their setting and situation made themselves known: the whoop of the wind outside, driving fresh snow down from the northwest; the creaking and groaning of the old hotel as it settled into another storm. The fact of their disconnect came to Wendy with unexpected force as it sometimes did, like a blow under the heart.
``I want ... to tell you everything,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said.
``I wish I had before.'' (He)
He (Danny) picked up the cup and held it, as if comforted by the warmth.
``Why didn't you, son?'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack brushed Danny's sweaty, tumbled hair back gently from his (Jack) brow.
``Because Uncle Al got you the job. And I couldn't figure out how it was good for you here and bad for you here at the same time. It was ...'' (He)
He (Jack) looked at them for help. He (Jack) did not have the necessary word.
``A dilemma?'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy asked gently.
``When neither choice seems any good?'' (unknown)
``Yes, that.'' (He)
He (Jack) nodded, relieved. Wendy said:
``The day that you trimmed the hedges, Danny and I had a talk in the truck. The day the first real snow came. Remember?'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Jack nodded. The day he (Jack) had trimmed the hedges was very clear in his (Jack) mind. Wendy sighed.
``I guess we didn't talk enough. Did we, doc?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)

Jack asked.
``I'm not sure how much I like my wife and son -- '' (unknown)
'' -- discussing how much they love you?'' (unknown)

Wendy said quietly.

``Danny said it just right. The place seemed good for you. You were away from all the pressures that made you so unhappy at Stovington. You were your own boss, working with your hands so you could save your brain -- all of your brain -- for your evenings writing. Then ... I don't know just when ... the place began to seem bad for you. Spending all that time down in the cellar, sifting through those old papers, all that old history. he (Danny) said.

He (Danny) swallowed and there was silence for a moment, all quiet while the image of

the wasps sank into them.

Danny said.

I wet my pants. I wet my pants like a baby.'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
