``No,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny whispered huskily. The word fell dry and bare from his (Danny) mouth, which was stripped of moisture. He (Danny) could feel his (Danny) mind wavering now, trying to go away the way it had when the woman in the room had ... no, better not think of that. He (Danny) grasped at the strings of reality and held them tightly. He (Danny) had to get out of here. Concentrate on that. Be cool. Be like the Secret Agent Man. Would Patrick McGoohan be crying and peeing in his (McGoohan) pants like a little baby? Would his (McGoohan) daddy? That calmed him (McGoohan) somewhat. From behind him (McGoohan), that soft Hump sound of falling snow came again. He (McGoohan) turned around and the head of one of the hedge lions was sticking out of the snow now, snarling at him (McGoohan). It was closer than it should have been, almost up to the gate of the playground. Terror tried to rise up and he (McGoohan) quelled it. He (McGoohan) was the Secret Agent Man, and he (Man) would escape. He (Man) began to walk out of the playground, taking the same roundabout course his (Man) father had taken on the day that the snow flew. He (Man) concentrated on operating the snowshoes. Slow, flat strides. Don't lift your foot too high or you'll lose your balance. Twist your ankle and spill the snow off the crisscrossed lacings. It seemed so slow. He (Man) reached the corner of the playground. The snow was drifted high here and he (Man) was able to step over the fence. He (Man) got halfway over and then almost fell flat when the snowshoe on his (Man) behind foot caught on one of the fence posts. He (Man) leaned on the outside edge of gravity, pinwheeling his (Man) arms, remembering how hard it was to get up once you fell down. From his (Man) right, that soft sound again, falling clumps of snow. He (Man) looked over and saw the other two lions, clear of snow now down to their forepaws, side by side, about sixty paces away. The green indentations that were their eyes were fixed on him (Man). The dog had turned its head. -LRB-It only happens when you're not looking.-RRB-
``Oh! Hey -- '' (he)

His (Man) snowshoes had crossed and he (Man) plunged forward into the snow, arms waving uselessly. More snow got inside his (Man) hood and down his (Man) neck and into the tops of his (Man) boots. He (Man) struggled out of the snow and tried to get the snowshoes under him (Man), heart hammering crazily now -LRB-Secret Agent Man remember you're the Secret Agent-RRB- and overbalanced backward. For a moment he (Agent) lay there looking at the sky, thinking it would be simpler to just give up. Then he (Agent) thought of the thing in the concrete tunnel and knew he (Agent) could not. He (Agent) gained his (Agent) feet and stared over at the topiary. All three lions were bunched together now, not forty feet away. The dog had ranged off to their left, as if to block Danny's retreat. They were bare of snow except for powdery ruffs around their necks and muzzles. They were all staring at him (Danny). His (Danny) breath was racing now, and the panic was like a rat behind his (Danny) forehead, twisting and gnawing. He (Danny) fought the panic and he (Danny) fought the snowshoes. -LRB-Daddy's voice: No, don't fight them, doc. Walk on them like they were your own feet. Walk with them.-RRB- -LRB-Yes, Daddy.-RRB- He (Danny) began to walk again, trying to regain the easy rhythm he (Danny) had practiced with his (Danny) daddy. Little by little it began to come, but with the rhythm came an awareness of just how tired he (Danny) was, how much his (Danny) fear had exhausted him (Danny). The tendons of his (Danny) thighs and calves and ankles were hot and trembly. Ahead he (Danny) could see the Overlook, mockingly distant, seeming to stare at him (Danny) with its many windows, as if this were some sort of contest in which it was mildly interested. Danny looked back over his (Danny) shoulder and his (Danny) hurried breathing caught for a moment and then hurried on even faster. The nearest lion was now only twenty feet behind, breasting through the snow like a dog paddling in a pond. The two others were to its right and left, pacing it. They were like an army platoon on patrol, the dog, still off to their left, the scout. The closest lion had its head down. The shoulders bunched powerfully above its neck. The tail was up, as if in the instant before he (scout) had turned to look it had been swishing back and forth, back and forth. He (scout) thought it looked like a great big housecat that was having a good time playing with a mouse before killing it. -LRB- -- falling -- -RRB- No, if he (scout) fell he (scout) was dead. They would never let him (scout) get up. They would pounce. He (scout) pinwheeled his (scout) arms madly and lunged ahead, his (scout) center of gravity dancing just beyond his (scout) nose. He (scout) caught it and hurried on, snapping glances back over his (scout) shoulder. The air whistled in and out of his (scout) dry throat like hot glass. The world closed down to the dazzling snow, the green hedges, and the whispery sound of his (scout) snowshoes. And something else. A soft, muffled padding sound. He (scout) tried to hurry faster and couldn't. He (scout) was walking over the buried driveway now, a small boy with his (scout) face almost buried in the shadow of his (scout) parka hood. The afternoon was still and bright. When he (scout) looked back again, the point lion was only five feet behind. It was grinning. Its mouth was open, its haunches tensed down like a clockspring. Behind it and the others he (scout) could see the rabbit, its head now sticking out of the snow, bright green, as if it had turned its horrid blank face to watch the end of the stalk. Now, on the Overlook's front lawn between the circular drive and the porch, he (scout)

let the panic loose and began to run clumsily in the snowshoes, not daring to look back now, tilting further and further forward, his (scout) arms out ahead of him (scout) like a blind man feeling for obstacles. His (scout) hood fell back, revealing his (scout) complexion, paste white giving way to hectic red blotches on his (scout) cheeks, his (scout) eyes bulging with terror. The porch was very close now. Behind him (scout) he (scout) heard the sudden hard crunch of snow as something leaped. He (scout) fell on the porch steps, screaming without sound, and scrambled up them on his (scout) hands and knees, snowshoes clattering and askew behind him (scout). There was a slashing sound in the air and sudden pain in his (scout) leg. The ripping sound of cloth. Something else that might have -- must have -- been in his (scout) mind. Bellowing, angry roar. Smell of blood and evergreen. He (scout) fell full-length on the porch, sobbing hoarsely, the rich, metallic taste of copper in his (scout) mouth. His (scout) heart was thundering in his (scout) chest. There was a small trickle of blood coming from his (scout) nose. He (scout) had no idea how long he (scout) lay there before the lobby doors flew open and Jack ran out, wearing just his (Jack) jeans and a pair of slippers. Wendy was behind him (Jack).

``Danny!'' (she)
she (Wendy) screamed.
``Doc! Danny, for Christ's sake! What's wrong? What happened?'' (him)
Daddy was helping him (Jack) up. Below the knee his (Jack) snowpants were ripped open. Inside, his (Jack) woollen ski sock had been ripped open and his (Jack) calf had been shallowly scratched ... as if he (Jack) had tried to push his (Jack) way through a closely grown evergreen hedge and the branches had clawed him (Jack). Between them and the road. His (Jack) legs gave way. Jack caught him (Jack). He (Jack) began to cry.

<< 35 >> THE LOBBY He (Jack) had told them everything except what had happened to him (Jack) when the snow had blocked the end of the concrete ring. He (Jack) couldn't bring himself to repeat that. And he (Jack) didn't know the right words to express the creeping, lassitudinous sense of terror he (Jack) had felt when he (Jack) heard the dead aspen leaves begin to crackle furtively down there in the cold darkness. But he (Jack) told them about the soft sound of snow falling in clumps. About the lion with its head and its bunched shoulders working its way up and out of the snow to chase him (Jack). He (Jack) even told them about how the rabbit had turned its head to watch near the end. The three of them were in the lobby. Jack had built a roaring blaze in the fireplace. Danny was bundled up in a blanket on the small sofa where once, a

million years ago, three nuns had sat laughing like girls while they waited for the line at the desk to thin out. He (Danny) was sipping hot noodle soup from a mug. Wendy sat beside him (Danny), stroking his (Danny) hair. Jack had sat on the floor, his (Jack) face seeming to grow more and more still, more and more set as Danny told his (Danny) story. Twice he (Danny) pulled his (Danny) handkerchief out of his (Danny) back pocket and rubbed his (Danny) sorelooking lips with it.

``Then they chased me,'' (he)
he (Danny) finished. Jack got up and went over to the window, his (Jack) back to them. He (Jack) looked at his (Jack) mommy.
``They chased me all the way up to the porch.'' (He)
He (Jack) was struggling to keep his (Jack) voice calm, because if he (Jack) stayed calm maybe they would believe him (Jack). Mr. Stenger hadn't stayed calm. He (Stenger) had started to cry and hadn't been able to stop SO THE MEN IN THE WHITE COATS had come to take him (Stenger) away because if you couldn't stop crying it meant you had LOST YOUR MARBLES and when would you be back? NO ONE KNOWS. His (Stenger) parka and snowpants and the clotted snowshoes lay on the rug just inside the big double doors. -LRB-I won't cry I won't let myself cry-RRB- And he (Stenger) thought he (Stenger) could do that, but he (Stenger) couldn't stop shaking. He (Stenger) looked into the fire and waited for Daddy to say something. High yellow flames danced on the dark stone hearth. A pine-knot exploded with a bang and sparks rushed up the flue.
``Danny, come over here.'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack turned around. His (Jack) face still had that pinched, deathly look. Danny didn't like to look at it.
``Jack -- '' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
``I just want the boy over here for a minute.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny slipped off the sofa and came over beside his (Danny) daddy.
``Good boy. Now what do you see?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny had known what he (Danny) would see even before he (Danny) got to the window. Below the clutter of boot tracks, sled tracks, and snowshoe tracks that marked their usual exercise area, the snowfield that covered the Overlook's lawns sloped down to the topiary and the playground beyond. << 36 >> THE ELEVATOR Jack awoke from a thin and uneasy sleep where huge and ill-defined shapes chased him (Jack) through endless snowfields to what he (Jack) first thought was another dream: darkness, and in it, a sudden mechanical jumble of noises -- clicks and clanks, hummings, rattlings, snaps and whooshes. Then Wendy sat up beside him (Jack) and he (Jack) knew it was no dream.

``What's that?'' (unknown)
Her (Wendy) hand, cold marble, gripped his (Jack) wrist. He (Jack) restrained an urge to shake it off -- how in the hell was he (Jack) supposed to know what it was? The illuminated clock on his (Jack) nightstand said it was five minutes to twelve. The humming sound again. Loud and steady, varying the slightest bit. Followed by a clank as the humming ceased. A rattling bang. A thump. Then the humming resumed. It was the elevator. Danny was sitting up.
``Daddy? Daddy?'' (unknown)
His (Danny) voice was sleepy and scared.
``Right here, doc,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said.
``Come on over and jump in. Your mom's awake, too.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
The bedclothes rustled as Danny got on the bed between them. ``It's the

elevator,'' he (Danny) whispered. ``That's right,'' Jack said. ``Just the elevator.'' ``What do you mean, just?'' Wendy demanded. There was an ice-skim of hysteria on her (Wendy) voice. ``It's the middle of the night. Who's running it?'' Hummmmmmm. Click/clank. Above them now. The rattle of the gate accordioning back, the bump of the doors opening and closing. Then the hum of the motor and the cables again. Danny began to whimper. Jack swung his (Jack) feet out of bed and onto the floor. ``It's probably a short. I'll check.'' ``Don't you dare go out of this room!'' ``Don't be stupid,'' he (Jack) said, pulling on his (Jack) robe. ``It's my job.'' She (Wendy) was out of bed herself a moment later, pulling Danny with her (Wendy). ``We'll go, too.'' ``Wendy -- '' ``What's wrong?'' Danny asked somberly. ``What's wrong, Daddy?'' Instead of answering he (Danny) turned away, his (Danny) face angry and set. He (Danny) belted his (Danny) robe around him (Danny) at the door, opened it, and stepped out into the dark hall. Wendy hesitated for a moment, and it was actually Danny who began to move first. She (Wendy) caught up quickly, and they went out together. Jack hadn't bothered with the lights. She (Wendy) fumbled for the switch that lit the four spaced overheads in the hallway that led to the main corridor. Up ahead, Jack was already turning the corner. This time Danny found the switchplate and flicked all three switches up. The hallway leading down to the stairs and the elevator shaft came alight. Jack was standing at the elevator station, which was flanked by benches and cigarette urns. He (Jack) was standing motionless in front of the closed elevator door. In his (Jack) faded tartan bathrobe and brown leather slippers with the rundown heels, his (Jack) hair all in sleep corkscrews and Alfalfa cowlicks, he (Jack) looked to her (Jack) like an absurd twentieth-century Hamlet, an indecisive figure so mesmerized by onrushing tragedy that he (Jack) was helpless to divert its course or alter it in any way. -LRB-jesus stop thinking so crazy -- -RRB- Danny's hand bad tightened painfully on her (Jack) own. He (Danny) was looking up at her (Jack) intently, his (Danny) face strained and anxious. He (Danny) had been catching the drift of her (Jack) thoughts, she (Jack) realized. Just how much or how little of them he (Danny) was getting was impossible to say, but she (Jack) flushed, feeling much the same as if he (Danny) had caught her (Jack) in a masturbatory act.

``Come on,'' (unknown)
she (Jack) said, and they went down the hall to Jack. The hummings and clankings and thumpings were louder here, terrifying in a disconnected, benumbed way. Jack was staring at the closed door with feverish intensity. Through the diamond-shaped window in the center of the elevator door she (Jack) thought she (Jack) could make out the cables, thrumming slightly. A second later Jack turned the key hard. There was a grating, screeching sound as the elevator car came to an instant standstill. For a moment the declutched motor in the basement whined even louder, and then its circuit breaker cut in and the Overlook went unearthly still. The night wind outside seemed very loud by comparison. Jack looked stupidly at the gray metal elevator door. There were three splotches of blood below the keyhole from his (Jack) lacerated knuckles. He (Jack) turned back to Wendy and Danny for a moment. << 37 >> THE BALLROOM It was the first of December. Danny was in the east-wing ballroom, standing on an over-stuffed, high-backed wing chair, looking at the clock under glass. It stood in the center of the ballroom's high, ornamental mantelpiece, flanked by two large ivory elephants. He (Danny) almost expected the elephants would begin to move and try to gore him (Danny) with their tusks as he (Danny) stood there, but they were moveless. They were

``safe.'' (he)
Since the night of the elevator he (Danny) had come to divide all things at the Overlook into two categories. The elevator, the basement, the playground, Room 217, and the Presidential Suite -LRB-it was Suite, not Sweet; he (Sweet) had seen the correct spelling in an account book Daddy had been reading at supper last night and had memorized it carefully-RRB- -- those places were
``unsafe.'' (he)
Their quarters, the lobby, and the porch were
``safe.'' (unknown)
Apparently the ballroom was, too. -LRB-The elephants are, anyway.-RRB- He (Sweet) was not sure about other places and so avoided them on general principle. He (Sweet) looked at the clock inside the glass dome. It was under glass because all its wheels and cogs and springs were showing. A chrome or steel track ran around the outside of these works, and directly below the clockface there was a small axis bar with a pair of meshing cogs at either end. The hands of the clock stood at quarter past XI, and although he (Sweet) didn't know Roman numerals he (Sweet) could guess by the configuration of the hands at what time the clock had stopped. The clock stood on a velvet base. In front of it, slightly distorted by the curve of the dome, was a carefully carved silver key. He (Sweet) supposed that the clock was one of the things he (Sweet) wasn't supposed to touch, like the decorative fire-tools in their brass-bound cabinet by the lobby fireplace or the tall china highboy at the back of the dining room. A sense of injustice and a feeling of angry rebellion suddenly rose in him (Sweet) and -LRB-never mind what i'm not supposed to touch, just never mind. touched me, hasn't it? played with me, hasn't it?-RRB- It had. And it hadn't been particularly careful not to break him (Sweet), either. Danny put his (Danny) hands out, grasped the glass dome, and lifted it aside. He (Danny) let one finger play over the works for a moment, the pad of his (Danny) index finger denting against the cogs, running smoothly over the wheels. He (Danny) picked up the silver key. For an adult it would have been uncomfortably small, but it fitted his (Danny) own fingers perfectly. He (Danny) placed it in the keyhole at the center of the clockface. It went firmly home with a tiny click, more felt than heard. It wound to the right, of course; clockwise. Danny turned the key until it would turn no more and then removed it. The

clock began to tick. Cogs turned. A large balance wheel rocked back and forth in semicircles. The hands were moving. If you kept your head perfectly motionless and your eyes wide open, you could see the minute hand inching along toward its meeting some forty-five minutes from now with the hour hand. At XII. -LRB-And the Red Death held sway over all.-RRB- He (Danny) frowned, and then shook the thought away. It was a thought with no meaning or reference for him (Danny). He (Danny) reached his (Danny) index finger out again and pushed the minute band up to the hour, curious about what might happen. It obviously wasn't a cuckoo clock, but that steel rail had to have some purpose. There was a small, ratcheting series of clicks, and then the clock began to tinkle Strauss's

``Blue Danube Waltz.'' (Strauss)
A punched roll of cloth no more than two inches in width began to unwind. A small series of brass strikers rose and fell. From behind the clockface two figures glided into view along the steel track, ballet dancers, on the left a girl in a fluffy skirt and white stockings, on the right a boy in a black leotard and ballet slippers. Their hands were held in arches over their beads. They came together in the middle, in front of VI. Danny espied tiny grooves in their sides, just below their armpits. The axis bar slipped into these grooves and he (Danny) heard another small click. The cogs at either end of the bar began to turn.
``The Blue Danube'' (unknown)
tinkled. The dancers' arms came down around each other. The boy flipped the girl up over his (boy) head and then whirled over the bar. They were now lying prone, the boy's head buried beneath the girl's short ballet skirt, the girl's face pressed against the center of the boy's leotard. They writhed in a mechanical frenzy. Danny's nose wrinkled. They were kissing peepees. That made him (Danny) feel sick. A moment later and things began to run backward. The boy whirled back over the axis bar. He (boy) flipped the girl into an upright position. They seemed to nod knowingly at each other as their hands arched back over their heads. They retreated the way they had come, disappearing just as
``The Blue Danube'' (unknown)
finished. The clock began to strike a count of silver chimes. -LRB-Midnight! Stroke of midnight!-RRB- -LRB-Hooray for masks!-RRB- Danny whirled on the chair, almost falling down. The ballroom was empty. Beyond the double cathedral window he (Danny) could see fresh snow beginning to sift down. The huge ballroom rug -LRB-rolled up for dancing, of course-RRB-, a rich tangle of red and gold embroidery, lay undisturbed on the floor. Spaced around it were small, intimate tables for two, the spidery chairs that went with each upended with legs pointing at the ceiling. The whole place was empty. But it wasn't really empty. Because here in the Overlook things just went on and on. Here in the Overlook all times were one. There was an endless night in August of 1945, with laughter and drinks and a chosen shining few going up and coming down in the elevator, drinking champagne and popping party favors in each other's faces. It was a not-yet-light morning in June some twenty years later and the organization hitters endlessly pumped shotgun shells into the torn and bleeding bodies of three men who went through their agony endlessly. In a room on the second floor a woman lolled in her (woman) tub and waited for visitors. In the Overlook all things had a sort of life. It was as if the whole place

had been wound up with a silver key. The clock was running. The clock was running. He (their) was that key, Danny thought sadly. Tony had warned him (Tony) and he (Tony) had just let things go on. -LRB-I'm just five!-RRB- he (Tony) cried to some half-felt presence in the room. -LRB-Doesn't it make any deference that I'm just five?-RRB- There was no answer. He (Tony) turned reluctantly back to the clock. He (Tony) had been putting it off, hoping that something would happen to help him (Tony) avoid trying to call Tony again, that a ranger would come, or a helicopter, or the rescue team; they always came in time on his (ranger) TV programs, the people were saved. On TV the rangers and the SWAT squad and the paramedics were a friendly white force counterbalancing the confused evil that he (ranger) perceived in the world; when people got in trouble they were helped out of it, they were fixed up. They did not have to help themselves out of trouble. -LRB-Please?-RRB- There was no answer. No answer, and if Tony came would it be the same nightmare? Cogs turned and meshed with other cogs. The balance wheel rocked hypnotically back and forth. And if you held your head perfectly still, you could see the minute hand creeping inexorably down from XII to V. If you held your bead perfectly still you could see that -- The clockface was gone. In its place was a round black hole. It led down into forever. It began to swell. The clock was gone. The room behind it. Danny tottered and then fell into the darkness that had been hiding behind the clockface all along. The small boy in the chair suddenly collapsed and lay in it at a crooked unnatural angle, his (boy) head thrown back, his (boy) eyes staring sightlessly at the high ballroom ceiling. he (Dick) screamed. But Tony was gone and suddenly he (Tony) was in a dark room. But not entirely dark. Muted light spilling from somewhere. It was Mommy and Daddy's bedroom. He (Tony) could see Daddy's desk. But the room was a dreadful shambles. He (Tony) had been in this room before. Mommy's record player overturned on the floor. Her (Tony) records scattered on the rug. The mattress half off the bed. Pictures ripped from the walls. His (player) cot lying on its side like a dead dog, the Violent Violet Volkswagen crushed to purple shards of plastic. The light was coming from the bathroom door, half-open. Just beyond it a hand dangled limply, blood dripping from the tips of the fingers. And in the medicine cabinet mirror, the word REDRUM flashing off and on. Suddenly a huge clock in a glass bowl materialized in front of it. There were no hands or numbers on the clockface, only a date written in red: DECEMBER 2. And then, eyes widening in horror, he (it) saw the word REDRUM reflecting dimly from the glass dome, now reflected twice. And he (it) saw that it spelled MURDER. Danny Torrance screamed in wretched terror. The date was gone from the clockface. The clockface itself was gone, replaced by a circular black hole that swelled and swelled like a dilating iris. It blotted out everything and he (Torrance) fell forward, beginning to fall, falling, he (Torrance) was -- ***

-- falling off the chair. For a moment he (Torrance) lay on the ballroom floor, breathing bard. REDRUM. MURDER. REDRUM. MURDER. -LRB-The Red Death held sway over all!-RRB- -LRB-Unmask! Unmask!-RRB- And behind each glittering lovely mask, the as-yet unseen face of the shape that chased him (Torrance) down these dark hallways, its red eyes widening, blank and homicidal. Oh, he (Torrance) was afraid of what face might come to light when the time for unmasking came around at last. -LRB-DICK!-RRB- he (Torrance) screamed with all his (Torrance) might. His (Torrance) head seemed to shiver with the force of it. -LRB-!!! OH DICK OH PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE COME !!!-RRB- Above him (Torrance) the clock he (Torrance) had wound with the silver key continued to mark off the seconds and minutes and hours.

PART FIVE -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- Matters of Life and Death -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- --

<< 38 >> FLORIDA

Mrs. Hallorann's third son, Dick, dressed in his (Dick) cook's whites, a Lucky Strike parked in the corner of his (Dick) mouth, backed his (Dick) reclaimed Cadillac limo out of its space behind the One-A Wholesale Vegetable Mart and drove slowly around the building. Masterton, part owner now but still walking with the patented shuffle he (Masterton) had adopted back before World War II, was pushing a bin of lettuces into the high, dark building. Hallorann pushed the button that lowered the passenger side window and hollered:

``Those avocadoes is too damn high, you cheapskate!'' (passenger)
Masterton looked back over his (Masterton) shoulder, grinned widely enough to expose all three gold teeth, and yelled back,
``And I know exactly where you can put em, my good buddy.'' (Masterton)
``Remarks like that I keep track of, bro.'' (Masterton)
Masterton gave him (Masterton) the finger. Hallorann returned the compliment.
``Get your cukes, did you?'' (Masterton)
Masterton asked.
``I did.'' (unknown)
``You come back early tomorrow, I gonna give you some of the nicest new potatoes you ever seen.'' (unknown)
``I send the boy,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said.
``You comin up tonight?'' (unknown)
``You supplyin the juice, bro?'' (unknown)
``That's a big ten-four.'' (unknown)
``I be there. You keep that thing off the top end goin home, you hear me? Every cop between here an St. Pete knows your name.'' (unknown)
``You know all about it, huh?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann asked, grinning.
``I know more than you'll ever learn, my man.'' (unknown)
``Listen to this sassy nigger. Would you listen?'' (unknown)
``Go on, get outta here fore I start throwin these lettuces.'' (unknown)
``Go on an throw em. I'll take anything for free.'' (Masterton)
Masterton made as if to throw one. Hallorann ducked, rolled up the window, and drove on. He (Masterton) was feeling fine. For the last half hour or so he (Masterton) had been smelling oranges, but he (Masterton) didn't find that queer. For the last half hour he (Masterton) had been in a fruit and vegetable market. It was 4:30 p.m., EST, the first day of December, Old Man Winter settling his (Man) frostbitten rump firmly onto most of the country, but down here the men wore open-throated shortsleeve shirts and the women were in light summer dresses and shorts. On top of the First Bank of Florida building, a digital thermometer bordered with huge grapefruits was flashing 79° over and over. Thank God for Florida, Hallorann thought, mosquitoes and all. In the back of the limo were two dozen avocados, a crate of cucumbers, ditto oranges, ditto grapefruit. Three shopping sacks filled with Bermuda onions, the sweetest vegetable a loving God ever created, some pretty good sweet peas, which would be served with the entree and come back uneaten nine times out of ten, and a single blue Hubbard squash that was strictly for personal consumption. Hallorann stopped in the turn lane at the Vermont Street light, and when the green arrow showed he (Hubbard) pulled out onto state highway 219, pushing up to forty and holding it there until the town began to trickle away into an exurban sprawl of gas stations, Burger Kings, and McDonalds. It was a small order today, he (Hubbard) could

have sent Baedecker after it, but Baedecker had been chafing for his (Hubbard) chance to buy the meat, and besides, Hallorann never missed a chance to bang it back and forth with Frank Masterton if he (Frank) could help it. Masterton might show up tonight to watch some TV and drink Hallorann's Bushmill's, or he (Masterton) might not. Either way was all right. But seeing him (Masterton) mattered. Every time it mattered now, because they weren't young anymore. In the last few days it seemed he (Masterton) was thinking of that very fact a great deal. Not so young anymore, when you got up near sixty years old -LRB-or tell the truth and save a lie -- past it-RRB- you had to start thinking about stepping out. You could go anytime. And that had been on his (Masterton) mind this week, not in a heavy way but as a fact. Dying was a part of living. You had to keep tuning in to that if you expected to be a whole person. And if the fact of your own death was hard to understand, at least it wasn't impossible to accept. Why this should have been on his (Masterton) mind he (Masterton) could not have said, but his (Masterton) other reason for getting this small order himself was so he (Masterton) could step upstairs to the small office over Frank's Bar and Grill. There was a lawyer up there now -LRB-the dentist who had been there last year had apparently gone broke-RRB-, a young black fellow named McIver. Hallorann had stepped in and told this McIver that he (McIver) wanted to make a will, and could McIver help him (McIver) out? Well, McIver asked, how soon do you want the document? Yesterday, said Hallorann, and threw his (McIver) head back and laughed. Have you got anything complicated in mind? was McIver's next question. Hallorann did not. He (McIver) had his (McIver) Cadillac, his (McIver) bank account -- some nine thousand dollars -- a piddling checking account, and a closet of clothes. He (McIver) wanted it all to go to his (McIver) sister. And if your sister predeceases you? McIver asked. Never mind, Hallorann said. If that happens, I'll make a new will. The document had been completed and signed in less than three hours -- fast work for a shyster -- and now resided in Hallorann's breast pocket, folded into a stiff blue envelope with the word WILL on the outside in Old English letters. He (McIver) could not have said why he (McIver) had chosen this warm sunny day when he (McIver) felt so well to do something he (McIver) had been putting off for years, but the impulse had come on him (McIver) and he (McIver) hadn't said no. He (McIver) was used to following his (McIver) hunches. He (McIver) was pretty well out of town now. He (McIver) cranked the limo up to an illegal sixty and let it ride there in the left-hand lane, sucking up most of the Petersburgbound traffic. He (McIver) knew from experience that the limo would still ride as solid as iron at ninety, and even at a hundred and twenty it didn't seem to lighten up much. But his (McIver) screamin days were long gone. The thought of putting the limo up to a hundred and twenty on a straight stretch only scared him (McIver). He (McIver) was getting old. -LRB-Jesus, those oranges smell strong. Wonder if they gone over?-RRB- Bugs splattered against the window. He (Jesus) dialed the radio to a Miami soul station and got the soft, wailing voice of Al Green.

``What a beautiful time we had together, Now it's getting late and we must leave each other...'' (He)
He (Green) unrolled the window, pitched his (Green) cigarette butt out, then rolled it further down to clear out the smell of the oranges. He (Green) tapped his (Green) fingers against the wheel and hummed along under his (Green) breath. Hooked over the rearview mirror, his (Green) St. Christopher's medal swung gently back and forth.

And suddenly the smell of oranges intensified and he (Green) knew it was coming, something was coming at him (Green). He (Green) saw his (Green) own eyes in the rearview, widening, surprised. And then it came all at once, came in a huge blast that drove out everything else: the music, the road ahead, his (Green) own absent awareness of himself as a unique human creature. It was as if someone had put a psychic gun to his (Green) head and shot him (Green) with a .45 caliber scream. -LRB-!!! Later the workman told his (workman) wife that he (workman) knew it was just one of those niggery hairdos they were all wearing these days, but at the time it had looked just as if every hair on that coon's head was standing on end. He (workman) thought the black man was having a heart attack. The workman braked hard, dropping back into a luckily empty space behind him (workman). The workman cut to the left, still laying on his (workman) horn, and roared around the drunkenly weaving limousine. ``What is it with you, a fire?'' (she)

What did he (manager) mean, the Jets were playing the Bills? Didn't he (manager) know who the Jets were playing? Five hundred, seven-point spread. When Queems hung up, looking put-out, Hallorann understood how a man could make fifty grand a year running this little spa and still wear suits with shiny seats. letters. -LRB-Oh my God is it like that?-RRB- He (God) didn't know. But it could be. All week long the thought of his (God) own ending had been on his (God) mind like a ... well, like a -LRB-Go on, say it-RRB- like a premonition,. Death? For a moment his (God) whole life seemed to flash before him (God), not in a historical sense, no topography of the ups and downs that Mrs. Hallorann's third son, Dick, had lived through, but his (Dick) life as it was now. Martin Luther King had told them not long before the bullet took him (King) down to his (King) martyr's grave that he (King) had been to the mountain. Dick could not claim that. No mountain, but he (Dick) had reached a sunny plateau after years of struggle. He (Dick) had good friends. He (Dick) had all the references he (Dick) would ever need to get a job anywhere. When he (Dick) wanted fuck, why, he (Dick) could find a friendly one with no questions asked and no big shitty struggle about what it all meant. He (Dick) had come to terms with his (Dick) blackness -- happy terms. He (Dick) was up past sixty and thank God, he (God) was cruising. Was he (God) going to chance the end of that -- the end of him (God) -- for three white people he (God) didn't even know? But that was a lie, wasn't it? He (God) knew the boy. They had shared each other the way good friends can't even after forty years of it. He (God) knew the boy and the boy knew him (boy), because they each had a kind of searchlight in their heads, something they hadn't asked for, something that had just been given. -LRB-Naw, you got a flashlight, he (boy) the one with the searchlight.-RRB- And sometimes that light, that shine, seemed like a pretty nice thing. You could pick the horses, or like the boy had said, you could tell your daddy where his (daddy) trunk was when it turned up missing. But that was only dressing, the sauce on the salad, and down below there was as much bitter vetch in that salad as there was cool cucumber. You could taste pain and death and tears. And now the boy was stuck in that place, and he (boy) would go. For the boy. Because, speaking to the boy, they had only been different colors when they used their mouths. So he (boy) would go. He (boy) would do what he (boy) could, because if he (boy) didn't, the boy was going to die right inside his (boy) head. But because he (boy) was human he (boy) could not help a bitter wish that the cup had never been passed his (boy) way. *** -LRB-She (boy) had started to get out and come after him (boy).-RRB- He (boy) had been dumping a change of clothes into an overnight bag when the thought came to him (boy), freezing him (boy) with the power of the memory as it always did when he (boy) thought of it. He (boy) tried to think of it as seldom as possible. The maid, Delores Vickery her (Vickery) name was, had been hysterical. Had said some things to the other chambermaids, and worse still, to some of the guests. When the word got back to Ullman, as the silly quiff should have known it would do, he (Ullman) had fired her (Vickery) out of hand. She (Vickery) had come to Hallorann in tears, not about being fired, but about the thing she (Vickery) had seen in that second-floor room. She (Vickery) had gone into 217 to change the towels, she (Vickery) said, and there had been that Mrs.

Massey, lying dead in the tub. That, of course, was impossible. Mrs. Massey had been discreetly taken away the day before and was even then winging her (Massey) way back to New York -- in the shipping hold instead of the first class she (Massey)'d been accustomed to. Hallorann hadn't liked Delores much, but he (Vickery) had gone up to look that evening. The maid was an olive-complected girl of twenty-three who waited tables near the end of the season when things slowed down. She (maid) had a small shining, Hallorann judged, really not more than a twinkle; a mousy-looking man and his (man) escort, wearing a faded cloth coat, would come in for dinner and Delores would trade one of her (Delores) tables for theirs. The mousy little man would leave a picture of Alexander Hamilton under his (man) plate, bad enough for the girl who had made the trade, but worse, Delores would crow over it. She (Delores) was lazy, a goof-off in an operation run by a man who allowed no goof-offs. She (Delores) would sit in a linen closet, reading a confession magazine and smoking, but whenever Ullman went on one of his (Ullman) unscheduled prowls -LRB-and woe to the girl he (Ullman) caught resting her (girl) feet-RRB- he (Ullman) found her (girl) working industriously, her (girl) magazine hidden under the sheets on a high shelf, her (girl) ashtray tucked safely into her (girl) uniform pocket. Yeah, Hallorann thought, she (Hallorann)'d been a goof-off and a sloven and the other girls had resented her (Hallorann), but Delores had had that little twinkle. It had always greased the skids for her (Delores). But what she (Delores) had seen in 217 had scared her (Delores) badly enough so she (Delores) was more than glad to pick up the walking papers Ullman had issued her (Delores) and go. Why had she (Delores) come to him (Ullman)? A shine knows a shine, Hallorann thought, grinning at the pun. So he (Ullman) had gone up that night and had let himself into the room, which was to be reoccupied the next day. He (Ullman) had used the office passkey to get in, and if Ullman had caught him (Ullman) with that key, he (Ullman) would have joined Delores Vickery on the unemployment line. The shower curtain around the tub had been drawn. He (Ullman) had pushed it back, but even before he (Ullman) did he (Ullman)'d had a premonition of what he (Ullman) was going to see. Mrs. Massey, swollen and purple, lay soggily in the tub, which was half-full of water. He (Ullman) had stood looking down at her (Massey), a pulse beating thickly in his (Ullman) throat. There had been other things at the Overlook: a bad dream that recurred at irregular intervals -- some sort of costume party and he (Ullman) was catering it in the Overlook's ballroom and at the shout to unmask, everybody exposed faces that were those of rotting insects -- and there had been the hedge animals. Twice, maybe three times, he (Ullman) had -LRB-or thought he (Ullman) had-RRB- seen them move, ever so slightly. That dog would seem to change from his (Ullman) sitting-up posture to a slightly crouched one, and the lions seemed to move forward, as if menacing the little tykes on the playground. Last year in May Ullman had sent him (Ullman) up to the attic to look for the ornate set of firetools that now stood beside the lobby fireplace. While he (Ullman) had been up there the three lightbulbs strung overhead had gone out and he (Ullman) had lost his (Ullman) way back to the trapdoor. He (Ullman) had stumbled around for an unknown length of time, closer and closer to panic, barking his (Ullman) shins on boxes and bumping into things, with a stronger and stronger feeling that something was stalking him (Ullman) in the dark. Some great and frightening creature that had just oozed out of the woodwork when the lights went out. And when he (Ullman) had literally stumbled over the trapdoor's ringbolt he (Ullman) had hurried down as fast as he (Ullman) could, leaving the trap open, sooty and disheveled, with a feeling of disaster barely averted. Later

Ullman had come down to the kitchen personally, to inform him (Ullman) he (Ullman) had left the attic trapdoor open and the lights burning up there. Did Hallorann think the guests wanted to go up there and play treasure hunt? Did he (Ullman) think electricity was free? And he (Ullman) suspected -- no, was nearly positive -- that several of the guests had seen or heard things, too. In the three years he (Ullman) had been there, the Presidential Suite had been booked nineteen times. Six of the guests who had put up there had left the hotel early, some of them looking markedly ill. Other guests had left other rooms with the same abruptness. One night in August of 1974, near dusk, a man who had won the Bronze and Silver Stars in Korea -LRB-that man now sat on the boards of three major corporations and was said to have personally pink-slipped a famous TV news anchorman-RRB- unaccountably went into a fit of screaming hysterics on the putting green. And there had been dozens of children during Hallorann's association with the Overlook who simply refused to go into the playground. One child had had a convulsion while playing in the concrete rings, but Hallorann didn't know if that could be attributed to the Overlook's deadly siren song or not -- word had gone around among the help that the child, the only daughter of a handsome movie actor, was a medically controlled epileptic who had simply forgotten her (daughter) medicine that day. And so, staring down at the corpse of Mrs. Massey, he (actor) had been frightened but not completely terrified. It was not completely unexpected. Terror came when she (Massey) opened her (Massey) eyes to disclose blank silver pupils and began to grin at him (actor). Horror came when -LRB-she (Massey) had started to get out and come after him (actor).-RRB- He (actor) had fled, heart racing, and had not felt safe even with the door shut and locked behind him (actor). In fact, he (actor) admitted to himself now as he (actor) zipped the fiightbag shut, he (actor) had never felt safe anywhere in the Overlook again. And now the boy -- calling, screaming for help. He (boy) looked at his (boy) watch. It was 5:30 P.m.. He (boy) went to the apartment's door, remembered it would be heavy winter now in Colorado, especially up in the mountains, and went back to his (boy) closet. He (boy) pulled his (boy) long, sheepskin-lined overcoat out of its polyurethane dry-cleaning bag and put it over his (boy) arm. It was the only winter garment he (boy) owned. He (boy) turned off all the lights and looked around. Had he (boy) forgotten anything? Yes. One thing. He (boy) took the will out of his (boy) breast pocket and slipped it into the margin of the dressing table mirror. With luck he (boy) would be back to get it. Sure, with luck. He (boy) left the apartment, locked the door behind him (boy), put the key under the rush mat, and ran down the outside steps to his (boy) converted Cadillac. *** Halfway to Miami International, comfortably away from the switchboard where Queems or Queems's toadies were known to listen in, Hallorann stopped at a shopping center Laundromat and called United Air Lines. Flights to Denver? There was one due out at 6:36 p.m. Could the gentleman make that? Hallorann looked at his (gentleman) watch, which showed 6:02, and said he (gentleman) could. What about vacancies on the flight?

Just let me check. A clunking sound in his (gentleman) ear followed by saccharine Montavani, which was supposed to make being on hold more pleasant. It didn't. Hallorann danced from one foot to the other, alternating glances between his (gentleman) watch and a young girl with a sleeping baby, in a hammock on her (Hallorann) back unloading a coin-op Maytag. She (Hallorann) was afraid she (Hallorann) was going to get home later than she (Hallorann) planned and the roast would burn and her (Hallorann) husband -- Mark? Mike? Matt? -- would be mad. A minute passed. Two. He (Matt) had just about made up his (Matt) mind to drive ahead and take his (Matt) chances when the cannedsounding voice of the flight reservations clerk came back on. There was an empty seat, a cancellation. It was in first class. Did that make any difference? No. He (Matt) wanted it. Would that be cash or credit card? Cash, baby, cash. I've got to fly. And the name was -- ? Hallorann, two l's, two n's. Catch you later. He (Matt) hung up and hurried toward the door. The girl's simple thought, worry for the roast, broadcast at him (Matt) over and over until be thought he (Matt) would go mad. Sometimes it was like that, for no reason at all you would catch a thought, completely isolated, completely pure and clear ... and usually completely useless. *** He (Matt) almost made it. He (Matt) had the limo cranked up to eighty and the airport was actually in sight when one of Florida's Finest pulled him (Matt) over. Hallorann unrolled the electric window and opened his (Matt) mouth at the cop, who was flipping up pages in his (Matt) citation book.

the cop said comfortingly.

<< 39 >> ON THE STAIRS One of the things they had sold to swell their liquid assets a little before moving from Vermont to Colorado was Jack's collection of two hundred old rock 'n' roll and r & b albums; they had gone at the yard sale for a dollar apiece. One of these albums, Danny's personal favorite, had been an Eddie Cochran double-record set with four pages of bound-in liner notes by Lenny Kaye. Wendy had often been struck by Danny's fascination for this one particular album by a manboy who had lived fast and died young ... had died, in fact, when she (Wendy) herself had only been ten years old. Now, at quarter past seven -LRB-mountain time-RRB-, as Dick Hallorann was telling Queems about his (Hallorann) ex-wife's white boyfriend, she (ex-wife) came upon Danny sitting halfway up the stairs between the lobby and the first floor, tossing a red rubber ball from hand to band and singing one of the songs from that album. His (Danny) voice was low and tuneless.

``So I climb one-two flight three flight four,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny sang,
``five flight six flight seven flight more ... when I get to the top, I'm too tired to rock ...'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)

Her (ex-wife) heart took a frightened leap in her (ex-wife) chest, but she (ex-wife) managed to speak neutrally.

*** The kitchen was cold and deserted under the overhead fluorescent bars. She (mother) went to the rack where the carving knives hung from their magnetized strips. She (mother) took the longest and sharpest, wrapped it in a dish towel, and left the kitchen, turning off the lights as she (mother) went. *** Danny sat on the stairs, his (Danny) eyes following the course of his (Danny) red rubber ball from hand to hand. So I walk one-two flight three flight four. . :' -LRB- -- Lou, Lou, skip to m' Lou -- -RRB- His (Lou) singing broke off. He (Lou) listened. -LRB- -- Skip to m' Lou my darlin' -- -RRB- The voice was in his (Lou) head, so much a part of him (Lou), so frighteningly close that it might have been a part of his (Lou) own thoughts. It was soft and infinitely sly. Mocking him (Lou). Seeming to say: -LRB-Oh yes, you'll like it here. Try it, you'll like it. Try it, you'll liiiiike it -- -RRB- Now his (Lou) ears were open and he (Lou) could hear them again, the gathering, ghosts or spirits or maybe the hotel itself, a dreadful funhouse where all the sideshows ended in death, where all the specially painted boogies were really alive, where hedges walked, where a small silver key could start the obscenity. Soft and sighing, rustling like the endless winter wind that played under the eaves at night, the deadly lulling wind the summer tourists never heard. It was like the somnolent hum of summer wasps in a ground nest, sleepy, deadly, beginning to wake up. They were ten thousand feet high. -LRB-Why is a raven like a writing desk? The higher the fewer, of course! Have another cup of tea!-RRB- It was a living sound, but not voices, not breath. A man of a philosophical bent might have called it the sound of souls. Dick Hallorann's Nana, who had grown up on southern roads in the years before the turn of the century, would have called it ha'ants. A psychic investigator might have had a long name for it -- psychic echo, psychokinesis, a telesmic sport. But to Danny it was only the sound of the hotel, the old monster, creaking steadily and ever more closely around them: halls that now stretched back through time as well as distance, hungry shadows, unquiet guests who did not rest easy. In the darkened ballroom the clock under glass struck seven-thirty with a single musical note. A hoarse voice, made brutal with drink, shouted:
``Unmask and let's fuck!'' (unknown)
Wendy, halfway across the lobby, jerked to a standstill.

She (Wendy) looked at Danny on the stairs, still tossing the ball from hand to hand.

``Did you hear something?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny only looked at her (Wendy) and continued to toss the ball from hand to hand. There would be little sleep for them that night, although they slept together behind a locked door. And in the dark, his (Danny) eyes open, Danny thought: -LRB-He (Danny) wants to be one of them and live forever. That's what he (Danny) wants.-RRB- Wendy thought: -LRB-If I have to, I'll take him (Danny) further up. If we're going to die I'd rather do it in the mountains.-RRB- She (Wendy) had left the butcher knife, still wrapped in the towel, under the bed. She (Wendy) kept her (Wendy) hand close to it. They dozed off and on. The hotel creaked around them. Outside snow had begun to spit down from the sky like lead.

<< 40 >> IN THE BASEMENT -LRB-!!! The boiler the goddam boiler !!!-RRB- The thought came into Jack Torrance's mind full-blown, edged in bright, warning red. On its heels, the voice of Watson: -LRB-If you forget it'll just creep an creep and like as not you an your fambly wilt end up on the fuckin moon ... she (Wendy)'s rated for two-fifty but she (Wendy)'d blow long before that now ... I'd be scared to come down and stand next to her (Wendy) at a hundred and eighty.-RRB- He (creep)'d been down here all night, poring over the boxes of old records, possessed by a frantic feeling that time was getting short and he (creep) would have to hurry. Still the vital clues, the connections that would make everything clear, eluded him (creep). His (creep) fingers were yellow and grimy with crumbling old paper. And he (creep)'d become so absorbed he (creep) hadn't checked the boiler once. He (creep)'d dumped it the previous evening around six o'clock, when he (creep) first came down. It was now... He (creep) looked at his (creep) watch and jumped up, kicking over e stack of old invoices. Christ, it was quarter of five in the morning. Behind him (Christ), the furnace kicked on. The boiler was making a groaning, whistling sound. He (Christ) ran to it. His (Christ) face, which had become thinner in the last month or so, was now heavily shadowed with beardstubble and he (Christ) had a hollow concentration-camp look. The boiler pressure gauge stood at two hundred and ten pounds per square inch. He (Christ) fancied he (Christ) could almost see the sides of the old patched and welded boiler heaving out with the lethal strain. -LRB-She (Christ) creeps ... I'd be scared to come down and stand next to her (Christ) at a

hundred and eighty ...-RRB- Suddenly a cold and tempting inner voice spoke to him (Christ). -LRB-Let it go. Go get Wendy and Danny and get the fuck out of here. Let it blow sky-high.-RRB- He (Danny) could visualize the explosion. A double thunderclap that would first rip the heart from this place, then the soul. The boiler would go with an orangeviolet flash that would rain hot and burning shrapnel all over the cellar. In his (Danny) mind he (Danny) could see the redhot trinkets of metal careening from floor to walls to ceiling like strange billiard balls, whistling jagged death through the air. Some of them, surely, would whizz right through that stone arch, light on the old papers on the other side, and they would burn merry hell. Destroy the secrets, burn the clues, it's a mystery no living hand will ever solve. Then the gas explosion, a great rumbling crackle of flame, a giant pilot light that would turn the whole center of the hotel into a broiler. Stairs and hallways and ceilings and rooms aflame like the castle in the last reel of a Frankenstein movie. The flame spreading into the wings, hurrying up the black-and-blue-twined carpets like eager guests. The silk wallpaper charring and curling. There were no sprinklers, only those outmoded hoses and no one to use them. And there wasn't a fire engine in the world that could get here before late March. Burn, baby, burn. In twelve hours there would be nothing left but the bare bones. The needle on the gauge had moved up to two-twelve. The boiler was creaking and groaning like an old woman trying to get out of bed. Hissing jets of steam had begun to play around the edges of old patches; beads of solder had begun to sizzle. He (woman) didn't see, he (woman) didn't hear. Frozen with his (woman) hand on the valve that would dump off the pressure and damp the fire, Jack's eyes glittered from their sockets like sapphires. -LRB-It's my last chance.-RRB- The only thing not cashed in now was the life-insurance policy he (Jack) had taken out jointly with Wendy in the summer between his (Jack) first and second years at Stovington. Forty-thousand-dollar death benefit, double indemnity if he (Jack) or she (Wendy) died in a train crash, a plane crash, or a fire. Seven-come-eleven, die the secret death and win a hundred dollars. -LRB-A fire ... eighty thousand dollars.-RRB- They would have time to get out. Even if they were sleeping, they would have time to get out. He (Jack) believed that. And he (Jack) didn't think the hedges or anything else would try to hold them back if the Overlook was going up in flames. -LRB-Flames.-RRB- The needle inside the greasy, almost opaque dial had danced up to two hundred and fifteen pounds per square inch. Another memory occurred to him (Jack), a childhood memory. There had been a wasps' nest in the lower branches of their apple tree behind the house. One of his (Jack) older brothers -- he (Jack) couldn't remember which one now -- had been stung while swinging in the old tire Daddy had hung from one of the tree's lower branches. It had been late summer, when wasps tend to be at their ugliest. Their father, just home from work, dressed in his (father) whites, the smell of beer hanging around his (father) face in a fine mist, had gathered all three boys, Brett, Mike, and little Jacky, and told them he (Mike) was going to get rid of the wasps.

``Now watch,'' (he)
he (Mike) had said, smiling and staggering a little -LRB-he (Mike) hadn't been using the cane then, the collision with the milk truck was years in the future-RRB-.
``Maybe you'll learn something. My father showed me this.'' (He)
He (Mike) had raked a big pile of rain-dampened leaves under the branch where the wasps' nest rested, a deadlier fruit than the shrunken but tasty apples their tree usually produced in late September, which was then still half a month away. He (Mike) lit the leaves. The day was clear and windless. The leaves smoldered but didn't really burn, and they made a smell -- a fragrance that had echoed back to him (Mike) each fall when men in Saturday pants and light Windbreakers raked leaves together and burned them. A sweet smell with a bitter undertone, rich and evocative. The smoldering leaves produced great rafts of smoke that drifted up to obscure the nest. Their father had let the leaves smolder all that afternoon, drinking beer on the porch and dropping the empty Black Label cans into his (father) wife's plastic floorbucket while his (father) two older sons flanked him (father) and little Jacky sat on the steps at his (father) feet, playing with his (father) Bolo Bouncer and singing monotonously over and over:
``Your cheating heart ... will make you weep ... your cheating heart ... is gonna tell on you.'' (Bolo Bouncer singing)
At quarter of six, just before supper, Daddy had gone out to the apple tree with his (Daddy) sons grouped carefully behind him (Daddy). In one hand he (Daddy) had a garden hoe. He (Daddy) knocked the leaves apart, leaving little clots spread around to smolder and die. Then he (Daddy) reached the hoe handle up, weaving and blinking, and after two or three tries he (Daddy) knocked the nest to the ground. The boys fled for the safety of the porch, but Daddy only stood over the nest, swaying and blinking down at it. Jacky crept back to see. A few wasps were crawling sluggishly over the paper terrain of their property, but they were not trying to fly. From the inside of the nest, the black and alien place, came a never-to-be-forgotten sound: a low, somnolent buzz, like the sound of hightension wires.
``Why don't they try to sting you, Daddy?'' (he)
he (Daddy) had asked.
``The smoke makes em drunk, Jacky. Go get my gascan.'' (He)
He (Daddy) ran to fetch it. Daddy doused the nest with amber gasoline.
``Now step away, Jacky, unless you want to lose your eyebrows.'' (He)
He (Daddy) had stepped away. From somewhere in the voluminous folds of his (Daddy) white overblouse, Daddy had produced a wooden kitchen match. He (Daddy) lit it with his (Daddy) thumbnail and flung it onto the nest. There had been a white-orange explosion, almost soundless in its ferocity. Daddy had stepped away, cackling wildly. The wasps' nest had gone up in no time.
``Fire,'' (Jacky)
Daddy had said, turning to Jacky with a smile.
``Fire will kill anything.'' (the boys)
After supper the boys had come out in the day's waning light to stand solemnly around the charred and blackened nest. From the hot interior had come the sound of wasp bodies popping like corn. The pressure gauge stood at two-twenty. A low iron wailing sound was building up in the guts of the thing. Jets of steam stood out erect in a hundred places like porcupine quills. -LRB-Fire will kill anything.-RRB- Jack suddenly started. He (Jack) had been dozing off ... and he (Jack) had almost dozed

himself right into kingdom cone. What in God's name had he (God) been thinking of? Protecting the hotel was his (God) job. He (God) was the caretaker. A sweat of terror sprang to his (God) hands so quickly that at first he (God) missed his (God) grip on the large valve. Then he (God) curled his (God) fingers around its spokes. He (God) whirled it one turn, two, three. There was a giant hiss of steam, dragon's breath. A warm tropical mist rose from beneath the boiler and veiled him (God). For a moment he (God) could no longer see the dial but thought he (God) must have waited too long; the groaning, clanking sound inside the boiler increased, followed by a series of heavy rattling sounds and the wrenching screech of metal. When some of the steam blew away he (God) saw that the pressure gauge had dropped back to two hundred and was still sinking. The jets of steam escaping around the soldered patches began to lose their force. The wrenching, grinding sounds began to diminish. One-ninety... one-eighty ... one seventy-five ... -LRB-He (God) was going downhill, going ninety miles an hour, when the whistle broke into a scream -- -RRB- But he (God) didn't think it would blow now. The press was down to one-sixty. -LRB- -- they found him (God) in the wreck with his (God) hand on the throttle, he (God) was scalded to death by the steam.-RRB- He (God) stepped away from the boiler, breathing hard, trembling. He (God) looked at his (God) hands and saw that blisters were already rising on his (God) palms. Hell with the blisters, he (God) thought, and laughed shakily. He (God) had almost died with his (God) hand on the throttle, like Casey the engineer in

``The Wreck of the Old 97.'' (Casey the engineer)
Worse still, he (Casey) would have killed the Overlook. The final crashing failure. He (Casey) had failed as a teacher, a writer, a husband, and a father. He (father) had even failed as a drunk. But you couldn't do much better in the old failure category than to blow up the building you were supposed to be taking care of. And this was no ordinary building. By no means. Christ, but he (Christ) needed a drink. The press had dropped down to eighty psi. Cautiously, wincing a little at the pain in his (Christ) hands, he (Christ) closed the dump valve again. But from now on the boiler would have to be watched more closely than ever. It might have been seriously weakened. He (Christ) wouldn't trust it at more than one hundred psi for the rest of the winter. And if they were a little chilly, they would just have to grin and bear it. He (Christ) had broken two of the blisters. His (Christ) hands throbbed like rotten teeth. A drink. A drink would fix him (Christ) up, and there wasn't a thing in the goddamn house besides cooking sherry. At this point a drink would be medicinal. That was just it, by God. An anesthetic. He (God) had done his (God) duty and now he (God) could use a little anesthetic -- something stronger than Excedrin. But there was nothing. He (God) remembered bottles glittering in the shadows. He (God) had saved the hotel. The hotel would want to reward him (God). He (God) felt sure of it. He (God) took his (God) handkerchief out of his (God) back pocket and went to the stairs. He (God) rubbed at his (God) mouth. Just a little drink. Just one. To ease the pain. He (God) had served the Overlook, and now the Overlook would serve him (God). He (God) was sure of it. His (God) feet on the stair risers were quick and eager, the hurrying steps of a man who has come home from a long and bitter war. It was 5:20 A.M., MST.

<< 41 >> DAYLIGHT Danny awoke with a muffled gasp from a terrible dream. There had been an explosion. A fire. The Overlook was burning up. He (Danny) and his (Danny) mommy were watching it from the front lawn. Mommy had said:

``Look, Danny, look at the hedges.'' (He)
He (Danny) looked at them and they were all dead. Their leaves had turned a suffocant brown. The tightly packed branches showed through like the skeletons of halfdismembered corpses. And then his (Danny) daddy had burst out of the Overlook's big double doors, and he (Danny) was burning like a torch. His (Danny) clothes were in flames, his (Danny) skin had acquired a dark and sinister tan that was growing darker by the moment, his (Danny) hair was a burning bush. That was when he (Danny) woke up, his (Danny) throat tight with fear, his (Danny) hands clutching at the sheet and blankets. Had he (Danny) screamed? He (Danny) looked over at his (Danny) mother. Wendy lay on her (Wendy) side, the blankets up to her (Wendy) chin, a sheaf of straw-colored hair lying against her (Wendy) cheek. She (Wendy) looked like a child herself. No, he (Danny) hadn't screamed. Lying in bed, looking upward, the nightmare began to drain away. He (Danny) had a curious feeling that some great tragedy -LRB-fire? explosion?-RRB- had been averted by inches. He (Danny) let his (Danny) mind drift out, searching for his (Danny) daddy, and found him (Danny) standing somewhere below. In the lobby. Danny pushed a little harder, trying to get inside his (Danny) father. It was not good. Because Daddy was thinking about the Bad Thing. He (Danny) was thinking how -LRB-good just one or two would be i don't care sun's over the yardarm somewhere in the world remember how we used to say that al? gin and tonic bourbon with just a dash of bitters scotch and soda rum and coke tweedledum and tweedledee a drink for me and a drink for thee the martians have landed somewhere in the world princeton or houston or stokely on carmichael some fucking place after all tis the season and none of us are-RRB- -LRB-GET OUT OF HIS (Danny) MIND, YOU LITTLE SHIT!-RRB- He (Danny) recoiled in terror from that mental voice, his (Danny) eyes widening, his (Danny) hands tightening into claws on the counterpane. It hadn't been the voice of his (Danny) father but a clever mimic. A voice he (Danny) knew. Hoarse, brutal, yet underpointed with a vacuous sort of humor. Was it so near, then? He (Danny) threw the covers back and swung his (Danny) feet out onto the floor. He (Danny) kicked his (Danny) slippers out from under the bed and put them on. He (Danny) went to the door and pulled it open and hurried up to the main corridor, his (Danny) slippered feet whispering on the nap of the carpet runner. He (Danny) turned the corner.

There was a man on all fours halfway down the corridor, between him (man) and the stairs. Danny froze. The man looked up at him (Danny). His (Danny) eyes were tiny and red. He (Danny) was dressed in some sort of silvery, spangled costume. A dog costume, Danny realized. Protruding from the rump of this strange creation was a long and floppy tail with a puff on the end. A zipper ran up the back of the costume to the neck. To the left of him (Danny) was a dog's or wolf's head, blank eyesockets above the muzzle, the mouth open in a meaningless snarl that showed the rug's black and blue pattern between fangs that appeared to be papier-mache. The man's mouth and chin and cheeks were smeared with blood. He (man) began to growl at Danny. He (Danny) was grinning, but the growl was real. It was deep in his (Danny) throat, a chilling primitive sound. Then he (Danny) began to bark. His (Danny) teeth were also stained red. He (Danny) began to crawl toward Danny, dragging his (Danny) boneless tail behind him (Danny). The costume dog's head lay unheeded on the carpet, glaring vacantly over Danny's shoulder.

``Let me by,'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny said.
``I'm going to eat you, little boy,'' (unknown)
the dogman answered, and suddenly a fusillade of barks came from his (Danny) grinning mouth. They were human imitations, but the savagery in them was real. The man's hair was dark, greased with sweat from his (man) confining costume. There was a mixture of scotch and champagne on his (man) breath. Danny flinched back but didn't run.
``Let me by.'' (unknown)
``Not by the hair of my chinny-chin-chin,'' (unknown)
the dogman replied. His (Danny) small red eyes were fixed attentively on Danny's face. He (Danny) continued to grin.
``I'm going to eat you up, little boy. And I think I'll start with your plump little cock.'' (He)
He (Danny) began to prance skittishly forward, making little leaps and snarling. Danny's nerve broke. He (Danny) fled back into the short hallway that led to their quarters, looking back over his (Danny) shoulder. There was a series of mixed howls and barks and growls, broken by slurred mutterings and giggles. Danny stood in the hallway, trembling.
``Get it up!'' (unknown)
the drunken dogman cried out from around the corner. His (Danny) voice was both violent and despairing.
``Get it up, Harry you bitch-bastard! I don't care how many casinos and airlines and movie companies you own! I know what you like in the privacy of your own h-home! Get it up! I'll huff... and I'll puff ... until Harry Derwent's all bloowwwwn down!'' (He)
He (Danny) ended with a long, chilling howl that seemed to turn into a scream of rage and pain just before it dwindled off. His (Danny) mommy was sleeping in exactly the same position. No one was hearing this but him (Danny). He (Danny) peeked around the corner carefully. The man in the dog costume was still there. Maybe at first the things that had happened had only been accidents. Maybe at first the things he (Danny) had seen really were like scary pictures that couldn't hurt him (Danny). But now the hotel was controlling those things and they could hurt. The Overlook hadn't wanted him (Danny) to go to his (Danny) father. That might spoil all the fun. The Overlook was not going to let him (DICK) call Dick. That might spoil the fun, too. They were alone. Outside the snow came harder, curtaining them off from the world.

MID-AIR Dick Hallorann's flight was called at 6:45 A.M., EST, and the boarding clerk held him (Hallorann) by Gate 31, shifting his (Hallorann) flight bag nervously from hand to hand, until the last call at 6:55. They were both looking for a man named Carlton Vecker, the only passenger on TWA's flight 196 from Miami to Denver who hadn't checked in.

He (Vecker) kept his (Vecker) eye on his (Vecker) watch. It dragged off the minutes to the 7:00 takeoff time with maddening slowness. There were authorities. He (Hallorann) had gone down to the nearest bank of telephones, and after talking to three different operators, he (Hallorann) had gotten the emergency number of the Rocky Mountain National Park Authority. The man who answered the telephone sounded utterly worn out. Hallorann had given a false name and said there was trouble at the Overlook Hotel, west of Sidewinder. Bad trouble. << 43 >> DRINKS ON THE HOUSE

Jack stood in the dining room just outside the batwing doors leading into the Colorado Lounge, his (Jack) head cocked, listening. He (Jack) was smiling faintly. Around him (Jack), he (Jack) could hear the Overlook Hotel coming to life. It was hard to say just how he (Jack) knew, but he (Jack) guessed it wasn't greatly different from the perceptions Danny had from time to time ... like father, like son. Wasn't that how it was popularly expressed? It wasn't a perception of sight or sound, although it was very near to those things, separated from those senses by the filmiest of perceptual curtains. It was as if another Overlook now lay scant inches beyond this one, separated from the real world -LRB-if there is such a thing as a

``real world,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack thought-RRB- but gradually coming into balance with it. He (Jack) was reminded of the 3-D movies he (Jack)'d seen as a kid. If you looked at the screen without the special glasses, you saw a double image -- the sort of thing he (Jack) was feeling now. But when you put the glasses on, it made sense. All the hotel's eras were together now, all but this current one, the Torrance Era. And this would be together with the rest very soon now. That was good. That was very good. He (Torrance) could almost hear the self-important ding!ding! of the silver-plated bell on the registration desk, summoning bellboys to the front as men in the fashionable flannels of the 1920s checked in and men in fashionable 1940s double-breasted pinstripes checked out. There would be three nuns sitting in front of the fireplace as they waited for the check-out line to thin, and standing behind them, nattily dressed with diamond stickpins holding their blueand-white-figured ties, Charles Grondin and Vito Gienelli discussed profit and loss, life and death. There were a dozen trucks in the loading bays out back, some laid one over the other like bad time exposures. In the east-wing ballroom, a dozen different business conventions were going on at the same time within temporal centimeters of each other. There was a costume ball going on. There were soirees, wedding receptions, birthday and anniversary parties. Men talking about Neville Chamberlain and the Archduke of Austria. Music. Laughter. Drunkenness. Hysteria. Little love, not here, but a steady undercurrent of sensuousness. And he (Chamberlain) could almost hear all of them together, drifting through the hotel and making a graceful cacophony. In the dining room where he (Chamberlain) stood, breakfast, lunch, and dinner for seventy years were all being served simultaneously just behind him (Chamberlain). He (Chamberlain) could almost ... no, strike the almost. He (Chamberlain) could hear them, faintly as yet, but clearly -- the way one can hear thunder miles off on a hot summer's day. He (Chamberlain) could hear all of them, the beautiful strangers. He (Chamberlain) was becoming aware of them as they must have been aware of him (Chamberlain) from the very start. All the rooms of the Overlook were occupied this morning. A full house. And beyond the batwings, a low murmur of conversation drifted and swirled like lazy cigarette smoke. More sophisticated, more private. Low, throaty female laughter, the kind that seems to vibrate in a fairy ring around the viscera and the genitals. The sound of a cash register, its window softly lighted in the warm halfdark, ringing up the price of a gin rickey, a Manhattan, a depression bomber, a sloe gin fizz, a zombie. The jukebox, pouring out its drinkers' melodies, each one overlapping the other in time.

He (zombie) pushed the batwings open and stepped through

``Hello, boys,'' (He)
Jack Torrance said softly.
``I've been away but now I'm back.'' (unknown)
``Good evening, Mr. Torrance,'' (Lloyd)
Lloyd said, genuinely pleased.
``It's good to see you.'' (unknown)
``It's good to be back, Lloyd,'' (he)
he (Torrance) said gravely, and hooked his (Torrance) leg over a stool between a man in a sharp blue suit and a bleary-eyed woman in a black dress who was peering into the depths of a singapore sling.
``What will it be, Mr. Torrance?'' (unknown)
``Martini,'' (he)
he (Torrance) said with great pleasure. He (Torrance) looked at the backbar with its rows of dimly gleaming bottles, capped with their silver siphons. Jim Beam. Wild Turkey. Gilby's. Sharrod's Private Label. Toro. Seagram's. And home again.
``One large martian, if you please,'' (he)
he (Beam) said.
``They've landed somewhere in the world, Lloyd.'' (He)
He (Beam) took his (Beam) wallet out and laid a twenty carefully on the bar. As Lloyd made his (Lloyd) drink, Jack looked over his (Jack) shoulder. Every booth was occupied. Some of the occupants were dressed in costumes ... a woman in gauzy harem pants and a rhinestone-sparkled brassiere, a man with a foxhead rising slyly out of his (man) evening dress, a man in a silvery dog outfit who was tickling the nose of a woman in a sarong with the puff on the end of his (man) long tail, to the general amusement of all.
``No charge to you, Mr. Torrance,'' (Lloyd)
Lloyd said, putting the drink down on Jack's twenty.
``Your money is no good here. Orders from the manager.'' (unknown)
``Manager?'' (him)

``Of course. The manager.'' (Lloyd)
Lloyd's smile broadened, but his (Lloyd) eyes were socketed in shadow and his (Lloyd) skin was horribly white, like the skin of a corpse.
``Later he (manager) expects to see to your son's well-being himself. He (manager) is very interested in your son. Danny is a talented boy.'' (unknown)
The juniper fumes of the gin were pleasantly maddening, but they also seemed to be blurring his (Lloyd) reason. Danny? What was all of this about Danny? And what was he (Danny) doing in a bar with a drink in his (Danny) hand? He (Danny) had TAKEN THE PLEDGE. He (Danny) had GONE ON THE WAGON. He (Danny) had SWORN OFF. ``Where is the manager?'' (He)

``What do you want with my son? Danny's not in this ... is he (Danny)?'' (He)
He (Lloyd) heard the naked plea in his (Lloyd) own voice.

Lloyd's face seemed to be running, changing, becoming something pestilent. The white skin becoming a hepatitic yellow, cracking. Red sores erupting on the skin, bleeding foul smelling liquid. Droplets of blood sprang out on Lloyd's forehead like sweat and somewhere a silver chime was striking the quarter-hour. -LRB-Unmask, unmask!-RRB-

``Drink your drink, Mr. Torrance,'' (Lloyd)
