``It isn't a matter that concerns you. Not at this point.'' (He)
He (Lloyd) picked his (Lloyd) drink up again, raised it to his (Lloyd) lips, and hesitated. He (Lloyd) heard the hard, horrible snap as Danny's arm broke. He (Danny) saw the bicycle flying brokenly up over the hood of Al's car, starring the windshield. He (Al) saw a single wheel lying in the road, twisted spokes pointing into the sky like jags of piano wire. He (Al) became aware that all conversation had stopped. He (Al) looked back over his (Al) shoulder. They were all looking at him (Al) expectantly, silently. The man beside the woman in the sarong had removed his (man) foxhead and Jack saw that it was Horace Derwent, his (Jack) pallid blond hair spilling across his (Jack) forehead. Everyone at the bar was watching, too. The woman beside him (Jack) was looking at him (Jack) closely, as if trying to focus. Her (woman) dress had slipped off one shoulder and looking down he (Jack) could see a loosely puckered nipple capping one sagging breast. Looking back at her (woman) face he (Jack) began to think that this might be the woman from 217, the one who had tried to strangle Danny. On his (Danny) other hand, the man in the sharp blue suit had removed a small pearl-handled .32 from his (man) jacket pocket and was idly spinning it on the bar, like a man with Russian roulette on his (man) mind. -LRB-I want -- -RRB- He (man) realized the words were not passing through his (man) frozen vocal cords and tried again.
``I want to see the manager. I ... I don't think he (manager) understands. My son is not a part of this. He (manager) ... '' (Lloyd)
``Mr. Torrance,'' (Lloyd)
Lloyd said, his (Lloyd) voice coming with hideous gentleness from inside his (Lloyd) plague-raddled face,
``you will meet the manager in due time. He (Torrance) has, in fact, decided to make you his (Torrance) agent in this matter. Now drink your drink.'' (Lloyd)
``Drink your drink,'' (He)
they all echoed. He (Lloyd) picked it up with a badly trembling hand. It was raw gin. He (Lloyd) looked into it, and looking was like drowning. The woman beside him (Lloyd) began to sing in a flat, dead voice:
``Roll ... out... the barrel ... and we'll have... a barrel ... of fun...'' (him)
Lloyd picked it up. Then the man in the blue suit. The dog-man joined in, thumping one paw against the table
``Now's the time to roll the barrel -- '' (Derwent/Horace Derwent)
Derwent added his (Derwent) voice to the rest. A cigarette was cocked in one corner of his (Derwent) mouth at a jaunty angle. His (Derwent) right arm was around the shoulders of the woman in the sarong, and his (Derwent) right band was gently and absently stroking her (woman) right breast. He (Derwent) was looking at the dog-man with amused contempt as he (Derwent) sang.
'' -- because the gang's ... all ... here!'' (he)
Jack brought the drink to his (Jack) mouth and downed it in three long gulps, the gin highballing down his (Jack) throat like a moving van in a tunnel, exploding in his (Jack) stomach, rebounding up to his (Jack) brain in one leap where it seized hold of him (Jack) with a final convulsing fit of the shakes.

When that passed off, he (Jack) felt fine.

``Do it again, please,'' (he)
he (Jack) said, and pushed the empty glass toward Lloyd.
``Yes, sir,'' (Lloyd)
Lloyd said, taking the glass. Lloyd looked perfectly normal again. The olive-skinned man had put his (Lloyd) .32 away. The woman on his (Lloyd) right was staring into her (woman) singapore sling again. One breast was wholly exposed now, leaning on the bar's leather buffer. A vacuous crooning noise came from her (woman) slack mouth. The loom of conversation had begun again, weaving and weaving. His (Lloyd) new drink appeared in front of him (Lloyd).
'' Muchas gracias, Lloyd,'' (him)
he (Lloyd) said, picking it up.
``Always a pleasure to serve you, Mr. Torrance.'' (Lloyd)
Lloyd smiled.
``You were always the best of them, Lloyd.'' (unknown)
``Why, thank you, sir.'' (He)
He (Lloyd) drank slowly this time, letting it trickle down his (Lloyd) throat, tossing a few peanuts down the chute for good luck. The drink was gone in no time, and he (Lloyd) ordered another. Mr. President, I have met the martians and am pleased to report they are friendly. While Lloyd fixed another, he (Lloyd) began searching his (Lloyd) pockets for a quarter to put in the jukebox. He (Lloyd) thought of Danny again, but Danny's face was pleasantly fuzzed and nondescript now. He (Danny) had hurt Danny once, but that had been before he (Danny) had learned how to handle his (Danny) liquor. Those days were behind him (Danny) now. He (Danny) would never hurt Danny again. Not for the world.

<< 44 >> CONVERSATIONS AT THE PARTY He (Danny) was dancing with a beautiful woman. He (Danny) had no idea what time it was, how long he (Danny) had spent in the Colorado Lounge or how long he (Danny) had been here in the ballroom. Time had ceased to matter. He (Danny) had vague memories: listening to a man who had once been a successful radio comic and then a variety star in TV, infant days telling a very long and very hilarious joke about incest between Siamese twins; seeing the woman in the harem pants and the sequined bra do a slow and sinuous striptease to some bumping-andgrinding music from the jukebox -LRB-it seemed it had been David Rose's theme music from The Stripper-RRB-; crossing the lobby as one of three, the other two men in evening dress that predated the twenties, all of them singing about the stiff patch on Rosie O'Grady's knickers. He (O'Grady) seemed to remember looking out the big double doors and seeing Japanese lanterns strung in graceful, curving arcs that followed the sweep of the driveway -- they gleamed in soft pastel colors like dusky jewels. The big glass globe on the porch ceiling was on, and night-insects bumped and flittered against it, and a part of him (O'Grady), perhaps the last tiny spark

of sobriety, tried to tell him (O'Grady) that it was 6 A.M. on a morning in December. But time had been canceled. -LRB-The arguments against insanity fall through with a soft shurring sound/layer on layer ...-RRB- Who was that? Some poet he (poet) had read as an undergraduate? Some undergraduate poet who was now selling washers in Wausau or insurance in Indianapolis? Perhaps an original thought? Didn't matter. -LRB-The night is dark/ the stars are high/ a disembodied custard pie/ is floating in the sky ...-RRB- He (poet) giggled helplessly.

``What's funny, honey?'' (he)
And here he (poet) was again, in the ballroom. The chandelier was lit and couples were circling all around them, some in costume and some not, to the smooth sounds of some postwar band -- but which war? Can you be certain? No, of course not. He (poet) was certain of only one thing: he (poet) was dancing with a beautiful woman. She (woman) was tall and auburn-haired, dressed in clinging white satin, and she (woman) was dancing close to him (poet), her (woman) breasts pressed softly and sweetly against his (poet) chest. Her (woman) white hand was entwined in his (poet). She (woman) was wearing a small and sparkly cat`seye mask and her (woman) hair had been brushed over to one side in a soft and gleaming fall that seemed to pool in the valley between their touching shoulders. Her (woman) dress was full-skirted but be could feel her (woman) thighs against his (poet) legs from time to time and had become more and more sure that she (woman) was smooth-and-powdered naked under her (woman) dress, -LRB-the better to feet your erection with, my dear-RRB- and he (poet) was sporting a regular railspike. If it offended her (woman) she (woman) concealed it well; she (woman) snuggled even closer to him (poet).
``Nothing funny, honey,'' (he)
he (poet) said, and giggled again.
``I like you,'' (she)
she (woman) whispered, and he (poet) thought that her (woman) scent was like lilies, secret and hidden in cracks furred with green moss -- places where sunshine is short and shadows long.
``I like you, too.'' (unknown)
``We could go upstairs, if you want. I'm supposed to be with Harry, but he (Harry)'ll never notice. He (Harry)'s too busy teasing poor Roger.'' (unknown)
The number ended. There was a spatter of applause and then the band swung into
``Mood Indigo'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
with scarcely a pause. Jack looked over her (woman) bare shoulder and saw Derwent standing by the refreshment table. The girl in the sarong was with him (Derwent). There were bottles of champagne in ice buckets ranged along the white lawn covering the table, and Derwent held a foaming bottle in his (Derwent) hand. A knot of people had gathered, laughing. In front of Derwent and the girl in the sarong, Roger capered grotesquely on all fours, his (Roger) tail dragging limply behind him (Roger). He (Roger) was barking.
``Speak, boy, speak!'' (Harry/Harry Derwent)
Harry Derwent cried.
``Rowf! Rowf!'' (Roger)
Roger responded. Everyone clapped; a few of the men whistled.
``Now sit up. Sit up, doggy!'' (Roger)
Roger clambered up on his (Roger) haunches. The muzzle of his (Roger) mask was frozen in its eternal snarl. Inside the eyeholes, Roger's eyes rolled with frantic, sweaty hilarity. He (Roger) held his (Roger) arms out, dangling the paws.

``Rowf! Rowf!'' (unknown)
Derwent upended the bottle of champagne and it fell in a foamy Niagara onto the upturned mask. Roger made frantic slurping sounds, and everyone applauded again. Some of the women screamed with laughter.
``Isn't Harry a card?'' (partner)
his (Roger) partner asked him (Roger), pressing close again.
``Everyone says so. He (Harry)'s AC/DC, you know. Poor Roger's only DC. He (Roger) spent a weekend with Harry in Cuba once ... oh, months ago. Now he (Harry) follows Harry everywhere, wagging his (Harry) little tail behind him (Harry).'' (She)
She (Everyone) giggled. The shy scent of lilies drifted up.
``But of course Harry never goes back for seconds ... not on his (Harry) DC side, anyway ... and Roger is just wild. Harry told him (Harry) if he (Harry) came to the masked ball as a doggy, a cute little doggy, he (Harry) might reconsider, and Roger is such a silly that he (Roger) ...'' (unknown)
The number ended. There was more applause. The band members were filing down for a break.
``Excuse me, sweetness,'' (she)
she (Everyone) said.
``There's someone I just roust ... Darla! Darla, you dear girl, where have you been?'' (She)
She (Everyone) wove her (Everyone) way into the eating, drinking throng and he (Roger) gazed after her (Everyone) stupidly, wondering how they had happened to be dancing together in the first place. He (Roger) didn't remember. Incidents seemed to have occurred with no connections. First here, then there, then everywhere. His (Roger) head was spinning. He (Roger) smelled lilies and juniper berries. Up by the refreshment table Derwent was now holding a tiny triangular sandwich over Roger's head and urging him (Roger), to the general merriment of the onlookers, to do a somersault. The dogmask was turned upward. The silver sides of the dog costume bellowsed in and out. Roger suddenly leaped, tucking his (Roger) head under, and tried to roll in mid-air. His (Roger) leap was too low and too exhausted; he (Roger) landed awkwardly on his (Roger) back, rapping his (Roger) head smartly on the tiles. A hollow groan drifted out of the dogmask. Derwent led the applause.
``Try again, doggy! Try again!'' (The onlookers)
The onlookers took up the chant -- try again, try again -- and Jack staggered off the other way, feeling vaguely ill. He (Jack) almost fell over the drinks cart that was being wheeled along by a lowbrowed man in a white mess jacket. His (man) foot rapped the lower chromed shelf of the cart; the bottles and siphons on top chattered together musically.
``Sorry,'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack said thickly. He (Jack) suddenly felt closed in and claustrophobic; he (Jack) wanted to get out. He (Jack) wanted the Overlook back the way it had been ... free of these unwanted guests. His (Jack) place was not honored, as the true opener of the way; he (Jack) was only another of the ten thousand cheering extras, a doggy rolling over and sitting up on command.
``Quite all right,'' (the man)
the man in the white mess jacket said. The polite, clipped English coming from that thug's face was surreal.
``A drink?'' (unknown)
``Martini.'' (him)
From behind him (thug), another comber of laughter broke; Roger was howling to the tune of
``Home on the Range.'' (Roger)
Someone was picking out accompaniment on the Steinway baby grand.
``Here you are.'' (unknown)
The frosty cold glass was pressed into his (Roger) hand. Jack drank gratefully, feeling the gin hit and crumble away the first inroads of sobriety.

``Is it all right, sir?'' (unknown)
``Fine.'' (unknown)
``Thank you, sir.'' (unknown)
The cart began to roll again. Jack suddenly reached out and touched the man's shoulder.
``Yes, sir?'' (unknown)
``Pardon me, but... what's your name?'' (unknown)
The other showed no surprise.
``Grady, sir. Delbert Grady.'' (unknown)
``But you ... I mean that...'' (The bartender)
The bartender was looking at him (bartender) politely. Jack tried again, although his (Jack) mouth was mushed by gin and unreality; each word felt as large as an ice cube.
``Weren't you once the caretaker here? When you ... when...'' (he)
But he (Jack) couldn't finish. He (Jack) couldn't say it.
``Why no, sir. I don't believe so.'' (unknown)
``But your wife ... your daughters. . ``My wife is helping in the kitchen, sir. The girls are asleep, of course. It's much too late for them.'' ``You were the caretaker. You -- '' Oh say it! ``You killed them.'' Grady's face remained blankly polite. ``I don't have any recollection of that at all, sir.'' His (Grady) glass was empty. Grady plucked it from Jack's unresisting fingers and set about making another drink for him (Grady). There was a small white plastic bucket on his (Grady) cart that was filled with olives. For some reason they reminded Jack of tiny severed heads. Grady speared one deftly, dropped it into the glass, and handed it to him (Grady). ``But you -- '' ``You're the caretaker, sir,'' Grady said mildly. ``You've always been the caretaker. I should know, sir. I've always been here. The same manager hired us both, at the same time. Is it all right, sir?'' Jack gulped at his (Jack) drink. His (Jack) head was swirling. ``Mr. Ullman -- '' ``I know no one by that name, sir.'' ``But he (Ullman) -- '' ``The manager,'' Grady said. ``The hotel, sir. Surely you realize who hired you, sir.'' ``No,'' he (Grady) said thickly. ``No, I -- '' ``I believe you must take it up further with your son, Mr. Torrance, sir. He (Torrance) understands everything, although he (Torrance) hasn't enlightened you. Rather naughty of him (Torrance), if I may be so bold, sir. In fact, he (Torrance)'s crossed you at almost every turn, hasn't he (Torrance)? And him (Torrance) not yet six.'' ``Yes,'' Jack said. ``He (Torrance) has.'' There was another wave of laughter from behind them. ``He (Torrance) needs to be corrected, if you don't mind me saying so. He (Torrance) needs a good talking-to, and perhaps a bit more. My own girls, sir, didn't care for the Overlook at first. One of them actually stole a pack of my matches and tried to burn it down. I corrected them. I corrected them most harshly. And when my wife tried to stop me from doing my duty, I corrected her (wife).'' He (Jack) offered Jack a bland, meaningless smile. ``I find it a sad but true fact that women rarely understand a father's responsibility to his (father) children. Husbands and fathers do have certain responsibilities, don't they, sir?''
``Yes,'' (unknown)
Jack said.

``They didn't love the Overlook as I did,'' (Grady/Delbert Grady)
Grady said, beginning to make him (Grady) another drink. Silver bubbles rose in the upended gin bottle.
``Just as your son and wife don't love it. Not at present, anyway. But they will come to love it. You must show them the error of their ways, Mr. Torrance. Do you agree?'' (unknown)
``Yes. I do.'' (He)
He (Grady) did see. He (Grady) had been too easy with them. Husbands and fathers did have certain responsibilities. Father Knows Best. They did not understand. That in itself was no crime, but they were willfully not understanding. He (Father) was not ordinarily a harsh man. But he (Father) did believe in punishment. And if his (Father) son and his (Father) wife had willfully set themselves against his (Father) wishes, against the things he (Father) knew were best for them, then didn't he (Father) have a certain duty -- ?

Jack whispered. ``But that's really up to your son to decide, isn't it?'' Grady asked, raising his (Grady) eyebrows. He (man) -- '' ``I said I'll handle him (man)!'' Jack shouted suddenly, enraged. ``Tuxedo Junction'' had just concluded and a new tune hadn't begun. His (Jack) shout fell perfectly into the gap, and conversation suddenly ceased behind him (Jack). His (Jack) skin suddenly felt hot all over. He (Derwent) tried to turn again, to see what famous faces were hidden beneath the glitter and paint and masks, but he (Derwent) was frozen now, unable to look away from the clock -- its hands had come together and pointed straight up.
``Unmask! Unmask!'' (unknown)
the chant went up. The clock began to chime delicately. Along the steel runner below the clockface, from the left and right, two figures advanced. Jack watched, fascinated, the unmasking forgotten. Clockwork whirred. Cogs turned and meshed, brass warmly glowing. The balance wheel rocked back and forth precisely. One of the figures was a man standing on tiptoe, with what looked like a tiny club clasped in his (man) hands. The other was a small boy wearing a dunce cap. The clockwork figures glittered, fantastically precise. Across the front of the boy's dunce cap he (boy) could read the engraved word FOOLE. The two figures slipped onto the opposing ends of a steel axis bar. Somewhere, tinkling on and on, were the strains of a Strauss waltz. An insane commercial jingle began to run through his (Strauss) mind to the tune: Buy dog food, rowf-rowf, rowfrowf, buy dog food ... The steel mallet in the clockwork daddy's hands came down on the boy's head. The clockwork son crumpled forward. The mallet rose and fell, rose and fell. The boy's upstretched, protesting hands began to falter. The boy sagged from his (boy) crouch to a prone position. And still the hammer rose and fell to the light, tinkling air of the Strauss melody, and it seemed that he (Strauss) could see the man's face, working and knotting and constricting, could see the clockwork daddy's mouth opening and closing as he (daddy) berated the unconscious, bludgeoned figure of the son. A spot of red flew up against the inside of the glass dome. Another followed. Two more splattered beside it. Now the red liquid was spraying up like an obscene rain shower, striking the glass sides of the dome and running, obscuring what was going on inside, and flecked through the scarlet were tiny gray ribbons of tissue, fragments of bone and brain. And still he (daddy) could see the hammer rising and falling as the clockwork continued to turn and the cogs continued to mesh the gears and teeth of this cunningly made machine.
``Unmask! Unmask!'' (Derwent/Horace Derwent)
Derwent was shrieking behind him (Derwent), and somewhere a dog was howling in human tones. -LRB-But clockwork can't bleed clockwork can't bleed-RRB- The entire dome was splashed with blood, he (Derwent) could see clotted bits of hair but nothing else thank God he (God) could see nothing else, and still he (God) thought he (God) would be sick because he (God) could hear the hammerblows still falling, could hear them through the glass just as he (God) could hear the phrases of
``The Blue Danube.'' (he)
But the sounds were no longer the mechanical tink-tink-tink noises of a mechanical hammer striking a mechanical head, but the soft and squashy thudding sounds of a

real hammer slicing down and whacking into a spongy, muddy ruin. A ruin that once had been --

``UNMASK!'' (unknown)
-LRB- -- the Red Death held sway over all!-RRB- With a miserable, rising scream, he (God) turned away from the clock, his (God) hands outstretched, his (God) feet stumbling against one another like wooden blocks as he (God) begged them to stop, to take him (God), Danny, Wendy, to take the whole world if they wanted it, but only to stop and leave him (Danny) a little sanity, a little light. The ballroom was empty. The chairs with their spindly legs were upended on tables covered with plastic dust drops. The red rug with its golden tracings was back on the dance floor, protecting the polished hardwood surface. The bandstand was deserted except for a disassembled microphone stand and a dusty guitar leaning stringless against the wall. Cold morning light, winterlight, fell languidly through the high windows. His (Danny) head was still reeling, he (Danny) still felt drunk, but when he (Danny) turned back to the mantelpiece, his (Danny) drink was gone. There were only the ivory elephants ... and the clock. He (Danny) stumbled back across the cold, shadowy lobby and through the dining room. His (Danny) foot hooked around a table leg and he (Danny) fell full-length, upsetting the table with a clatter. He (Danny) struck his (Danny) nose hard on the floor and it began to bleed. He (Danny) got up, snufing back blood and wiping his (Danny) nose with the back of his (Danny) hand. He (Danny) crossed to the Colorado Lounge and shoved through the batwing doors, making them fly back and bang into the walls. The place was empty ... but the bar was fully stocked: God be praised! Glass and the silver edging on labels glowed warmly in the dark. Once, he (God) remembered, a very long time ago, he (God) had been angry that there was no backbar mirror. Now he (God) was glad. Looking into it he (God) would have seen just another drunk fresh off the wagon: bloody nose, untucked shirt, hair rumpled, cheeks stubbly. -LRB-This is what it's like to stick your whole hand into the nest.-RRB- Loneliness surged over him (God) suddenly and completely. He (God) cried out with sudden wretchedness and honestly wished he (God) were dead. His (God) wife and son were upstairs with the door locked against him (God). The others bad all left. The party was over. He (God) lurched forward again, reaching the bar.
``Lloyd, where the fuck are you?'' (he)
he (God) screamed. There was no answer. In this well-padded -LRB-cell-RRB- room, his (God) words did not even echo back to give the illusion of company.
``Grady!'' (unknown)
No answer. Only the bottles, standing stiffly at attention. -LRB-Roll over. Play dead. Fetch. Play dead. Sit up. Play dead.-RRB-
``Never mind, I'll do it myself, goddammit.'' (he)
Halfway over the bar he (God) lost his (God) balance and pitched forward, hitting his (God) head a muffled blow on the floor. He (God) got up on his (God) hands and knees, his (God) eyeballs moving disjointed from side to side, fuzzy muttering sounds coming from his (God) mouth. Then he (God) collapsed, his (God) face turned to one side, breathing in harsh snores.

Outside, the wind whooped louder, driving the thickening snow before it. It was 8:30 A.M.

<< 45 >> STAPLETON AIRPORT, DENVER At 8:31 A.M., MST, a woman on TWA's Flight 196 burst into tears and began to bugle her (woman) own opinion, which was perhaps not unshared among some of the other passengers -LRB-or even the crew, for that matter-RRB-, that the plane was going to crash. The sharp-faced woman next to Hallorann looked up from her (woman) book and offered a brief character analysis:

``Ninny,'' (character)
and went back to her (woman) book. She (woman) had downed two screwdrivers during the flight, but they seemed not to have thawed her (woman) at all.
``It's going to crash!'' (the woman)
the woman was crying out shrilly.
``Oh, I just know it is!'' (A stewardess)
A stewardess hurried to her (stewardess) seat and squatted beside her (stewardess). Hallorann thought to himself that only stewardesses and very young housewives seemed able to squat with any degree of grace; it was a rare and wonderful talent. He (character) thought about this while the stewardess talked softly and soothingly to the woman, quieting her (woman) bit by bit. Hallorann didn't know about anyone else on 196, but he (character) personally was almost scared enough to shit peachpits. Outside the window there was nothing to be seen but a buffeting curtain of white. The plane rocked sickeningly from side to side with gusts that seemed to come from everywhere. The engines were cranked up to provide partial compensation and as a result the floor was vibrating under their feet. There were several people moaning in Tourist behind them, one stew had gone back with a handful of fresh airsick bags, and a man three rows in front of Hallorann had whoopsed into his (man) National Observer and had grinned apologetically at the stewardess who came to help him (man) clean up.
``That's all right,'' (she)
she (stewardess) comforted him (man),
``that's how I feel about the Reader's Digest.'' (him)
Hallorann had flown enough to be able to surmise what had happened. They had been flying against bad headwinds most of the way, the weather over Denver had worsened suddenly and unexpectedly, and now it was just a little late to divert for someplace where the weather was better. Feets don't fail me now. -LRB-Buddy-boy, this is some fucked-up cavalry charge.-RRB- The stewardess seemed to have succeeded in curbing the worst of the woman's hysterics. She (woman) was snuffling and honking into a lace handkerchief, but had ceased broadcasting her (woman) opinions about the flight's possible conclusion to the cabin at large. The stew gave her (woman) a final pat on the shoulder and stood up just as the 747 gave its worst lurch yet. The stewardess stumbled backward and landed

in the lap of the man who had whoopsed into his (man) paper, exposing a lovely length of nyloned thigh. The man blinked and then patted her (stewardess) kindly on the shoulder. She (stewardess) smiled back, but Hallorann thought the strain was showing. It had been one hell of a hard flight this morning. There was a little ping as the No SMOKING light reappeared.

``This is the captain speaking,'' (unknown)
a soft, slightly southern voice informed them.
``We're ready to begin our descent to Stapleton International Airport. It's been a rough flight, for which I apologize. The landing may be a bit rough also, but we anticipate no real difficulty. Please observe the FASTEN SEAT BELTS and NO SMOKING signs, and we hope you enjoy your stay in the Denver metro area. And we also hope -- '' (her)
Another hard bump rocked the plane and then dropped her (Hallorann) with a sickening elevator plunge. Hallorann's stomach did a queasy hornpipe. Several people -- not all women by any means -- screamed.
'' -- that we'll see you again on another TWA flight real soon.'' (all women)
``Not bloody likely,'' (someone)
someone behind Hallorann said.
``So silly,'' (the woman)
the sharp-faced woman next to Hallorann remarked, putting a matchbook cover into her (woman) book and shutting it as the plane began to descend.
``When one has seen the horrors of a dirty little war ... as you have ... or sensed the degrading immorality of CIA dollar-diplomacy intervention ... as I have ... a rough landing pales into insignificance. Am I right, Mr. Hallorann? '' (unknown)
``As rain, ma'am,'' (he)
he (Hallorann) said, and looked bleakly out into the wildly blowing snow.
``How is your steel plate reacting to all of this, if I might inquire?'' (unknown)
``Oh, my head's fine,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said.
``It's just my stomach that's a mite queasy.'' (unknown)
``A shame.'' (She)
She (Hallorann) reopened her (Hallorann) book. As they descended through the impenetrable clouds of snow, Hallorann thought of a crash that had occurred at Boston's Logan Airport a few years ago. The conditions had been similar, only fog instead of snow had reduced visibility to zero. The plane had caught its undercarriage on a retaining wall near the end of the landing strip. What had been left of the eighty-nine people aboard hadn't looked much different from a Hamburger Helper casserole. He (Helper) wouldn't mind so much if it was just himself. He (Helper) was pretty much alone in the world now, and attendance at his (Helper) funeral would be mostly held down to the people he (Helper) had worked with and that old renegade Masterton, who would at least drink to him (Masterton). But the boy ... the boy was depending on him (boy). He (boy) was maybe all the help that child could expect, and he (boy) didn't like the way the boy's last call had been snapped off. He (boy) kept thinking of the way those hedge animals had seemed to move ... A thin white hand appeared over his (boy). The woman with the sharp face had taken off her (woman) glasses. Without them her (woman) features seemed much softer.
``It will be all right,'' (she)
she (woman) said. Hallorann made a smile and nodded. As advertised the plane came down hard, reuniting with the earth forcefully enough to knock most of the magazines out of the rack at the front and to send plastic trays cascading out of the galley like oversized playing cards. No one

screamed, but Hallorann heard several sets of teeth clicking violently together like gypsy castanets. Then the turbine engines rose to a howl, braking the plane, and as they dropped in volume the pilot's soft southern voice, perhaps not completely steady, came over the intercom system.

``Ladies and gentlemen, we have landed at Stapleton Airport. Please remain in your seats until the plane has come to a complete stop at the terminal. Thank you.'' (The woman)
The woman beside Hallorann closed her (woman) book and uttered a long sigh.
``We live to fight another day, Mr. Hallorann.'' (unknown)
``Ma'am, we aren't done with this one, yet.'' (unknown)
``True. Very true. Would you care to have a drink in the lounge with me?'' (unknown)
``I would, but I have an appointment to keep.'' (unknown)
``Pressing?'' (unknown)
``Very pressing,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said gravely.
``Something that will improve the general situation in some small way, I hope.'' (unknown)
``I hope so too,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said, and smiled. She (Hallorann) smiled back at him (pilot), ten years dropping silently from her (Hallorann) face as she (Hallorann) did so. *** Because he (pilot) had only the flight bag he (pilot)'d carried for luggage, Hallorann beat the crowd to the Hertz desk on the lower level. Outside the smoked glass windows he (Hertz) could see the snow still falling steadily. The gusting wind drove white clouds of it back and forth, and the people walking across to the parking area were struggling against it. One man lost his (man) hat and Hallorann could commiserate with him (man) as it whirled high, wide, and handsome. The man stared after it and Hallorann thought: -LRB-Aw, just forget it, man. That homburg ain't comin down until it gets to Arizona.-RRB- On the heels of that thought: -LRB-If it's this bad in Denver, what's it going to be like west of Boulder?-RRB- Best not to think about that, maybe.
``Can I help you, sir?'' (a girl)
a girl in Hertz yellow asked him (Hertz).
``If you got a car, you can help me,'' (he)
he (Hertz) said with a big grin. For a heavier-than-average charge he (Hertz) was able to get a heavier-than-average car, a silver and black Buick Electra. He (Hertz) was thinking of the winding mountain roads rather than style; he (Hertz) would still have to stop somewhere along the way and get chains put on. He (Hertz) wouldn't get far without them.
``How bad is it?'' (he)
he (Hertz) asked as she (Electra) handed him (Hertz) the rental agreement to sign.
``They say it's the worst storm since 1969,'' (she)
she (Electra) answered brightly.
``Do you have far to drive, sir?'' (unknown)
``Farther than I'd like.'' (unknown)
``If you'd like, sir, I can phone ahead to the Texaco station at the Route 270 junction. They'll put chains on for you.' ``That would be a great blessing, dear.'' She (Electra) picked up the phone and made the call. ``They'll be expecting you.''
``Thank you much.'' (unknown)
Leaving the desk, he (Hertz) saw the sharp-faced woman standing on one of the queues

that had formed in front of the luggage carousel. She (woman) was still reading her (woman) book. Hallorann winked at her (Hallorann) as he (Hertz) went by. She (Hallorann) looked up, smiled at him (Hertz), and gave him (Hertz) a peace sign. -LRB-shine-RRB- He (Hertz) turned up his (Hertz) overcoat collar, smiling, and shifted his (Hertz) flight bag to the other hand. Only a little one, but it made him (Hertz) feel better. He (Hertz) was sorry he (Hertz)'d told her (Hallorann) that fish story about having a steel plate in his (Hertz) head. He (Hertz) mentally wished her (Hallorann) well and as he (Hertz) went out into the howling wind and snow, he (Hertz) thought she (Hallorann) wished him (Hertz) the same in return *** The charge for putting on the chains at the service station was a modest one, but Hallorann slipped the man at work in the garage bay an extra ten to get moved up a little way on the waiting list. It was still quarter of ten before he (man) was actually on the road, the windshield wipers clicking and the chains clinking with tuneless monotony on the Buick's big wheels. The turnpike was a mess. Even with the chains he (Buick) could go no faster than thirty. Cars had gone off the road at crazy angles, and on several of the grades traffic was barely struggling along, summer tires spinning helplessly in the drifting powder. It was the first big storm of the winter down here in the lowlands -LRB-if you could call a mile above sealevel

``low'' (a mother)
-RRB-, and it was a mother. Many of them were unprepared, common enough, but Hallorann still found himself cursing them as he (Buick) inched around them, peering into his (Buick) snow-clogged outside mirror to be sure nothing was -LRB-Dashing through the snow ...-RRB- coming up in the left-hand lane to cream his (Buick) black ass. There was more bad luck waiting for him (Buick) at the Route 36 entrance ramp. Route 36, the Denver-Boulder turnpike, also goes west to Estes Park, where it connects with Route 7. That road, also known as the Upland Highway, goes through Sidewinder, passes the Overlook Hotel, and finally winds down the Western Slope and into Utah. The entrance ramp had been blocked by an overturned semi. Bright-burning flares had been scattered around it like birthday candles on some idiot child's cake. He (idiot) came to a stop and rolled his (idiot) window down. A cop with a fur Cossack hat jammed down over his (idiot) ears gestured with one gloved hand toward the flow of traffic moving north on I-25.
``You can't get up here!'' (he)
he (idiot) bawled to Hallorann over the wind.
``Go down two exits, get on 91, and connect with 36 at Broomfield!'' (unknown)
``I think I could get around him (You) on the left!'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann shouted back.
``That's twenty miles out of my way, what you're rappin!'' (unknown)
``I'll rap your friggin head!'' (the cop)
the cop shouted back.
``This ramp's closed!'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann backed up, waited for a break in traffic, and continued on his (cop) way up Route 25. The signs informed him (cop) it was only a hundred miles to Cheyenne, Wyoming. If he (cop) didn't look out for his (cop) ramp, he (cop)'d wind up there. He (cop) inched his (cop) speed up to thirty-five but dared no more; already snow was threatening to clog his (cop) wiper blades and the traffic patterns were decidedly

crazy. Twenty-mile detour. He (cop) cursed, and the feeling that time was growing shorter for the boy welled up in him (boy) again, nearly suffocating with its urgency. And at the same time he (boy) felt a fatalistic certainty that he (boy) would not be coming back from this trip. He (boy) turned on the radio, dialed past Christmas ads, and found a weather forecast.

'' -- six inches already, and another foot is expected in the Denver metro area by nightfall. So stay home and wax up your boards and keep tuned to -- '' (He)
``Thanks, mother,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said, and turned the radio off savagely.

<< 46 >> WENDY Around noon, after Danny had gone into the bathroom to use the toilet, Wendy took the towel-wrapped knife from under her (Wendy) pillow, put it in the pocket of her (Wendy) bathrobe, and went over to the bathroom door.

``Danny?'' (unknown)
``What?'' (unknown)
``I'm going down to make us some lunch. `Kay?'' (unknown)
``Okay. Do you want me to come down?'' (unknown)
``No, I'll bring it up. How about a cheese omelet and some soup?'' (unknown)
``Sure.'' (She)
She (Wendy) hesitated outside the closed door a moment longer,
``Danny, are you sure it's okay?'' (She)
``Yeah,'' (he)
he (Danny) said.
``Just be careful.'' (unknown)
``Where's your father? Do you know?'' (unknown)
His (Danny) voice came back, curiously flat:
``No. But it's okay.'' (She)
She (Wendy) stifled an urge to keep asking, to keep picking around the edges of the thing. The thing was there, they knew what it was, picking at it was only going to frighten Danny more ... and herself. Jack had lost his (Jack) mind. They had sat together on Danny's cot as the storm began to pick up clout and meanness around eight o'clock this morning and had listened to him (Danny) downstairs, bellowing and stumbling from one place to another. Most of it had seemed to come from the ballroom. Jack singing tuneless bits of song, Jack holding up one side of an argument, Jack screaming loudly at one point, freezing both of their faces as they stared into one another's eyes. Finally they had heard him (Jack) stumbling back across the lobby, and Wendy thought she (Wendy) had heard a loud banging noise, as if he (Jack) had fallen down or pushed a door violently open. Since eightthirty or so -- three and a half hours now -- there had been only silence.

She (Wendy) went down the short hall, turned into the main first floor corridor, and went to the stairs. She (Wendy) stood on the firstfloor landing looking down into the lobby. It appeared deserted, but the gray and snowy day had left much of the long room in shadow. Danny could be wrong. Jack could be behind a chair or couch ... maybe behind the registration desk ... waiting for her (Wendy) to come down... She (Wendy) wet her (Wendy) lips.

``Jack?'' (unknown)
No answer. Her (Wendy) hand found the handle of the knife and she (Wendy) began to go down. She (Wendy) had seen the end of her (Wendy) marriage many times, in divorce, in Jack's death at the scene of a drunken car accident -LRB-a regular vision in the dark two o'clock of Stovington mornings-RRB-, and occasionally in daydreams of being discovered by another man, a soap opera Galahad who would sweep Danny and her (Wendy) onto the saddle of his (Danny) snowwhite charger and take them away. But she (Wendy) had never envisioned herself prowling halls and staircases like a nervous felon, with a knife clasped in one hand to use against Jack. A wave of despair struck through her (Wendy) at the thought and she (Wendy) had to stop halfway down the stairs and hold the railing, afraid her (Wendy) knees would buckle. -LRB-Admit it. It isn't just Jack, he (Jack)'s just the one solid thing in all of this you can hang the other things on, the things you can't believe and yet are being forced to believe, that thing about the hedges, the party favor in the elevator, the mask-RRB- She (Wendy) tried to stop the thought but it was too late. -LRB-and the voices.-RRB- Because from time to time it had not seemed that there was a solitary crazy man below them, shouting at and holding conversations with the phantoms in his (man) own crumbling mind. From time to time, like a radio signal fading in and out, she (Wendy) had heard -- or thought she (Wendy) had -- other voices, and music, and laughter. At one moment she (Wendy) would hear Jack holding a conversation with someone named Grady -LRB-the name was vaguely familiar to her (Wendy) but she (Wendy) made no actual connection-RRB-, making statements and asking questions into silence, yet speaking loudly, as if to make himself heard over a steady background racket. And then, eerily, other sounds would be there, seeming to slip into places -- a dance band, people clapping, a man with an amused yet authoritative voice who seemed to be trying to persuade somebody to make a speech. For a period of thirty seconds to a minute she (Wendy) would hear this, long enough to grow faint with terror, and then it would be gone again and she (Wendy) would only hear Jack, talking in that commanding yet slightly slurred way she (Wendy) remembered as his (Jack) drunk-speak voice. But there was nothing in the hotel to drink except cooking sherry. Wasn't that right? Yes, but if she (Wendy) could imagine that the hotel was full of voices and music, couldn't Jack imagine that he (Jack) was drunk? She (Wendy) didn't like that thought. Not at all. Wendy reached the lobby and looked around. The velvet rope that had cordoned off the ballroom had been taken down; the steel post it had been clipped to had been knocked over, as if someone had carelessly bumped it going by. Mellow white light fell through the open door onto the lobby rug from the ballroom's high, narrow windows. Heart thumping, she (Wendy) went to the open ballroom doors and looked in. It was empty and silent, the only sound that curious subaural echo that seems to linger in all large rooms, from the largest cathedral to the smallest

hometown bingo parlor. She (Wendy) went back to the registration desk and stood undecided for a moment, listening to the wind howl outside. It was the worst storm so far, and it was still building up force. Somewhere on the west side a shutter latch had broken and the shutter banged back and forth with a steady flat cracking sound, like a shooting gallery with only one customer. -LRB-Jack, you really should take care of that. Before something gets in.-RRB- What would she (Wendy) do if he (Jack) came at her (Wendy) right now, she (Wendy) wondered. If he (Jack) should pop up from behind the dark, varnished registration desk with its pile of triplicate forms and its little silver-plated bell, like some murderous jack-in-the-box, pun intended, a grinning jack-in-the-box with a cleaver in one hand and no sense at all left behind his (Jack) eyes. Would she (Wendy) stand frozen with terror, or was there enough of the primal mother in her (Wendy) to fight him (Jack) for her (Wendy) son until one of them was dead? She (Wendy) didn't know. The very thought made her (Wendy) sick -- made her (Wendy) feel that her (Wendy) whole life had been a long and easy dream to lull her (Wendy) helplessly into this waking nightmare. She (Wendy) was soft. When trouble came, she (Wendy) slept. Her (Wendy) past was unremarkable. She (Wendy) had never been tried in fire. Now the trial was upon her (Wendy), not fire but ice, and she (Wendy) would not be allowed to sleep through this. Her (Wendy) son was waiting for her (Wendy) upstairs. Clutching the haft of the knife tighter, she (Wendy) peered over the desk. Nothing there. Her (Wendy) relieved breath escaped her (Wendy) in a long, hitching sigh. She (Wendy) put the gate up and went through, pausing to glance into the inner office before going in herself. She (Wendy) fumbled through the next door for the bank of kitchen light switches, coldly expecting a hand to close over hers at any second. Then the fluorescents were coming on with minuscule ticking and humming sounds and she (Wendy) could see Mr. Hallorann's kitchen -- her (Wendy) kitchen now, for better or worse -- pale green tiles, gleaming Formica, spotless porcelain, glowing chrome edgings. She (Wendy) had promised him (Hallorann) she (Wendy) would keep his (Hallorann) kitchen clean, and she (Wendy) had. She (Wendy) felt as if it was one of Danny's safe places. Dick Hallorann's presence seemed to enfold and comfort her (Wendy). Danny had called for Mr. Hallorann, and upstairs, sitting next to Danny in fear as her (Wendy) husband ranted and raved below, that had seemed like the faintest of all hopes. But standing here, in Mr. Hallorann's place, it seemed almost possible. Perhaps he (Hallorann) was on his (Hallorann) way now, intent on getting to them regardless of the storm. Perhaps it was so. She (Wendy) went across to the pantry, shot the bolt back, and stepped inside. She (Wendy) got a can of tomato soup and closed the pantry door again, and bolted it. The door was tight against the floor. If you kept it bolted, you didn't have to worry about rat or mouse droppings in the rice or flour or sugar. She (Wendy) opened the can and dropped the slightly jellied contents into a saucepan -- plop. She (Wendy) went to the refrigerator and got milk and eggs for the omelet. Then to the walk-in freezer for cheese. All of these actions, so common and so much a part of her (Wendy) life before the Overlook had been a part of her (Wendy) life, helped to calm her (Wendy). She (Wendy) melted butter in the frying pan, diluted the soup with milk, and then poured the beaten eggs into the pan. A sudden feeling that someone was standing behind her (Wendy), reaching for her (Wendy) throat.

She (Wendy) wheeled around, clutching the knife. No one there. -LRB-! Get ahold of yourself, girl!-RRB- She (girl) grated a bowl of cheese from the block, added it to the omelet, flipped it, and turned the gas ring down to a bare blue flame. The soup was hot. She (girl) put the pot on a large tray with silverware, two bowls, two plates, the salt and pepper shakers. When the omelet had puffed slightly, Wendy slid it off onto one of the plates and covered it. -LRB-Now back the way you came. Turn off the kitchen lights. Go through the inner office. Through the desk gate, collect two hundred dollars.-RRB- She (Wendy) stopped on the lobby side of the registration desk and set the tray down beside the silver bell. Unreality would stretch only so far; this was like some surreal game of hide-and-seek. She (Wendy) stood in the shadowy lobby, frowning in thought. -LRB-Don't push the facts away this time, girl. There are certain realities, as lunatic as this situation may seem. One of them is that you may be the only responsible person left in this grotesque pile. You have a five-going-on-six son to look out for. And your husband, whatever has happened to him (husband) and no matter how dangerous he (husband) may be ... maybe he (husband)'s part of your responsibility, too. And even if he (husband) isn't consider this: Today is December second. You could be stuck up here another four months if a ranger doesn't happen by. Even if they do start to wonder why they haven't heard from us on the CB, no one is going to come today ... or tomorrow ... maybe not for weeks. Are you going to spend a month sneaking down to get meals with a knife in your pocket and jumping at every shadow? Do you really think you can avoid Jack for a month? Do you think you can keep Jack out of the upstairs quarters if he (Jack) wants to get in? He (Jack) has the passkey and one hard kick would snap the bolt.-RRB- Leaving the tray on the desk, she (Jack) walked slowly down to the dining room and looked in. It was deserted. There was one table with the chairs set up around it, the table they had tried eating at until the dining room's emptiness began to freak them out.

``Jack?'' (she)
she (Jack) called hesitantly. At that moment the wind rose in a gust, driving snow against the shutters, but it seemed to her (Jack) that there had been something. A muffled sort of groan.
``Jack?'' (Colorado Lounge)
No returning sound this time, but her (Jack) eyes fell on something beneath the batwing doors of the Colorado Lounge, something that gleamed faintly in the subdued light. Jack's cigarette lighter. Plucking up her (Jack) courage, she (Jack) crossed to the batwings and pushed them open. The smell of gin was so strong that her (Jack) breath snagged in her (Jack) throat. It wasn't even right to call it a smell; it was a positive reek. But the shelves were empty. Where in God's name had he (God) found it? A bottle hidden at the back of one of the cupboards? Where? There was another groan, low and fuzzy, but perfectly audible this time. Wendy walked slowly to the bar.
``Jack?'' (unknown)
No answer. She (Wendy) looked over the bar and there he (God) was, sprawled out on the floor in a stupor. Drunk as a lord, by the smell. He (Drunk) must have tried to go right over the

top and lost his (Drunk) balance. A wonder he (Drunk) hadn't broken his (Drunk) neck. An old proverb recurred to her (Wendy): God looks after drunks and little children. Amen. Yet she (Wendy) was not angry with him (God); looking down at him (God) she (Wendy) thought be looked like a horribly overtired little boy who had tried to do too much and had fallen asleep in the middle of the living room floor. He (boy) had stopped drinking and it was not Jack who had made the decision to start again; there had been no liquor for him (Jack) to start with ... so where had it come from? Resting at every five or six feet along the horseshoe-shaped bar there were wine bottles wrapped in straw, their mouths plugged with candles. Supposed to look bohemian, she (Wendy) supposed. She (Wendy) picked one up and shook it, half-expecting to hear the slosh of gin inside it -LRB-new wine in old bottles-RRB- but there was nothing. She (Wendy) set it back down. Jack was stirring. She (Wendy) went around the bar, found the gate, and walked back on the inside to where Jack lay, pausing only to look at the gleaming chromium taps. They were dry, but when she (Wendy) passed close to them she (Wendy) could smell beer, wet and new, like a fine mist. he (Jack) said, and began to grin. he (Jack) screamed. ``Oh, I know how you do it! I guess I know that! When I say, `We're going to stay here and I'm going to do my job,' you say, `Yes,

Just like -LRB-Grady.-RRB- With almost swooning horror, she (Wendy) realized at last who it was that Jack had been conversing with in the ballroom. ``You turned my son against me. You've always been jealous, haven't you? Just like your mother. You couldn't be satisfied unless you had all the cake, could you? Could you?'' She (Wendy) couldn't talk. ``Well, I'll fix you,'' he (Jack) said, and tried to put his (Jack) hands around her (Wendy) throat. She (Wendy) took a step backward, then another, and he (Jack) stumbled against her (Wendy). She (Wendy) remembered the knife in the pocket of her (Wendy) robe and groped for it, but now his (Jack) left arm had swept around her (Wendy), pinning her (Wendy) arm against her (Wendy) side. She (Wendy) could smell sharp gin and the sour odor of his (Jack) sweat. ``Have to be punished,'' he (Jack) was grunting. ``Chastised. Chastised ... harshly.'' His (Jack) right hand found her (Wendy) throat. As her (Wendy) breath stopped, pure panic took over. His (Jack) left hand joined his (Jack) right and now the knife was free to her (Wendy) own hand, but she (Wendy) forgot about it. Both of her (Wendy) hands came up and began to yank helplessly at his (Jack) larger, stronger ones. ``Mommy!'' Danny shrieked from somewhere. ``Daddy, stop! You're hurting Mommyl'' He (Danny) screamed piercingly, a high and crystal sound that she (Wendy) heard from far off. Red flashes of light leaped in front of her (Wendy) eyes like ballet dancers. The room grew darker. She (Wendy) saw her (Wendy) son clamber up on the bar and throw himself at Jack's shoulders. Suddenly one of the hands that had been crushing her (Wendy) throat was gone as Jack cuffed Danny away with a snarl. The boy fell back against the empty shelves and dropped to the floor, dazed. The hand was on her (Wendy) throat again. The red flashes began to turn black. Danny was crying weakly. Her (Wendy) chest was burning. Jack was shouting into her (Wendy) face:

``I'll fix you! Goddam you, I'll show you who is boss around here! I'll show you -- '' (unknown)
But all sounds were fading down a long dark corridor. Her (Wendy) struggles began to weaken. One of her (Wendy) hands fell away from his (Jack) and dropped slowly until the arm was stretched out at right angles to her (Wendy) body, the hand dangling limply from the wrist like the hand of a drowning woman. It touched a bottle -- one of the straw-wrapped wine bottles that served as decorative candleholders. Sightlessly, with the last of her (woman) strength, she (woman) groped for the bottle's neck and found it, feeling the greasy beads of wax against her (woman) hand. -LRB-and U God if it slips-RRB- She (woman) brought it up and then down, praying for aim, knowing that if it only struck his (God) shoulder or upper arm she (woman) was dead. But the bottle came down squarely on Jack Torrance's head, the glass

shattering violently inside the straw. The base of it was thick and heavy, and it made a sound against his (Torrance) skull like a medicine ball dropped on a hardwood floor. He (Torrance) rocked back on his (Torrance) heels, his (Torrance) eyes rolling up in their sockets. The pressure on her (woman) throat loosened, then gave way entirely. He (Torrance) put his (Torrance) hands out, as if to steady himself, and then crashed over on his (Torrance) back. Wendy drew a long, sobbing breath. She (Wendy) almost fell herself, clutched the edge of the bar, and managed to hold herself up. Consciousness wavered in and out. She (Wendy) could hear Danny crying, but she (Wendy) had no idea where he (Danny) was. It sounded like crying in an echo chamber. Dimly she (Wendy) saw dime-sized drops of blood falling to the dark surface of the bar-from her (Wendy) nose, she (Wendy) thought. She (Wendy) cleared her (Wendy) throat and spat on the floor. It sent a wave of agony up the column of her (Wendy) throat, but the agony subsided to a steady dull press of pain... just bearable. Little by little, she (Wendy) managed to get control of herself. << 47 >> DANNY It was three in the afternoon of a long, long day. They were sitting on the big bed in their quarters. Danny was turning the purple VW model with the monster sticking out of the sun roof over and over in his (Danny) hands, compulsively. They had heard Daddy's batterings at the door all the way across the lobby, the batterings and his (Danny) voice, hoarse and petulantly angry in a weak-king sort of a way, vomiting promises of punishment, vomiting profanity, promising both of them that they would live to regret betraying him (Danny) after he (Danny) had slaved his (Danny) guts out for them over the years. Danny thought they would no longer be able to hear it upstairs, but the sounds of his (Danny) rage carried perfectly up the dumb-waiter shaft: Mommy's face was pale, and there were horrible brownish bruises on her (Danny) neck where Daddy had tried to... He (Danny) turned the model over and over in his (Danny) hands, Daddy's prize for having learned his (Danny) reading lessons. -LRB-... where Daddy had tried to hug her (Danny) too tight.-RRB- Mommy put some of her (Danny) music on the little record player, scratchy and full of horns and flutes. She (Danny) smiled at him (player) tiredly. He (player) tried to smile back and failed. Even with the volume turned up loud he (player) thought he (player) could still hear Daddy screaming at them and battering the pantry door like an animal in a zoo cage: What if Daddy had to go to the bathroom? What would he (Daddy) do then? Danny began to cry. Wendy turned the volume down on the record player at once, held him (Danny), rocked him (Danny) on her (Wendy) lap.

``Danny, love, it will be all right. It will. If Mr. Hallorann didn't get your message, someone else will. As soon as the storm is over. No one could get up here until then anyway. Mr. Hallorann or anyone else. But when the storm is over, everything will be fine again. We'll leave here. And do you know what we'll do next spring? The three of us?'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny shook his (Danny) head against her (Wendy) breasts. He (Danny) didn't know. It seemed there could never be spring again.
``We'll go fishing. We'll rent a boat and go fishing, just like we did last year on Chatterton Lake. You and me and your daddy. And maybe you'll catch a bass for our supper. And maybe we won't catch anything, but we're sure to have a good time.'' (unknown)
``I love you, Mommy,'' (he)
he (Danny) said, and hugged her (Wendy).
``Oh, Danny, I love you, too.'' (unknown)
Outside, the wind whooped and screamed,

*** Around four-thirty, just as the daylight began to fail, the screams ceased. They had both been dozing uneasily, Wendy still holding Danny in her (Wendy) arms, and she (Wendy) didn't wake. But Danny did. Somehow the silence was worse, more ominous than the screams and the blows against the strong pantry door. Was Daddy asleep again? Or dead? Or what? -LRB-Did he (Danny) get out?-RRB- Fifteen minutes later the silence was broken by a hard, grating, metallic rattle. There was a heavy grinding, then a mechanical humming. Wendy came awake with a cry. The elevator was running again. They listened to it, wide-eyed, hugging each other. It went from floor to floor, the grate rattling back, the brass door slamming open. There was laughter, drunken shouts, occasional screams, and the sounds of breakage. The Overlook was coming to life around them.

<< 48 >> JACK He (JACK) sat on the floor of the pantry with his (JACK) legs out in front of him (JACK), a box of Triscuit crackers between them, looking at the door. He (JACK) was eating the crackers one by one, not tasting them, only eating them because he (JACK) had to eat something. When he (JACK) got out of here, he (JACK) was going to need his (JACK) strength. All of it. At this precise instant, he (JACK) thought he (JACK) had never felt quite so miserable in his (JACK) entire life. His (JACK) mind and body together made up a large-writ scripture of pain. His (JACK) head ached terribly, the sick throb of a hangover. The attendant symptoms were there, too: his (JACK) mouth tasted like a manure rake had taken a swing through it, his (JACK) ears rung, his (JACK) heart had an extra-heavy, thudding beat, like a tom-tom. In addition, both shoulders ached fiercely from throwing himself against the door and his (JACK) throat felt raw and peeled from useless shouting. He (JACK) had cut his (JACK) right hand on the doorlatch. And when he (JACK) got out of here, he (JACK) was going to kick some ass. He (JACK) munched the Triscuits one by one, refusing to give in to his (JACK) wretched stomach, which wanted to vomit up everything. He (JACK) thought of the Excedrins in his (JACK) pocket and decided to wait until his (JACK) stomach had quieted a bit. No sense swallowing a painkiller if you were going to throw it right back up. Have to use your brain. The celebrated Jack Torrance brain. Aren't you the fellow who once was going to live by his (Torrance) wits? Jack Torrance, best-selling author. Jack Torrance, acclaimed playwright and winner of the New York Critics Circle Award.

John Torrance, man of letters, esteemed thinker, winner of the Pulitzer Prize at seventy for his (Torrance) trenchant book of memoirs, My Life in the Twentieth Century. All any of that shit boiled down to was living by your wits. Living by your wits is always knowing where the wasps are. He (Torrance) put another Triscuit into his (Torrance) mouth and crunched it up. What it really came down to, he (Torrance) supposed, was their lack of trust in him (Torrance). Their failure to believe that he (Torrance) knew what was best for them and how to get it. His (Torrance) wife had tried to usurp him (Torrance), first by fair -LRB-sort of-RRB- means, then by foul. When her (wife) little hints and whining objections had been overturned by his (Torrance) own well-reasoned arguments, she (wife) had turned his (Torrance) boy against him (Torrance), tried to kill him (Torrance) with a bottle, and then had locked him (Torrance), of all places, in the goddamned fucking pantry. Still, a small interior voice nagged him (Torrance). -LRB-Yes but where did the liquor come from? Isn't that really the central point? You know what happens when you drink, you know it from bitter experience. When you drink, you lose your wits.-RRB- He (Torrance) hurled the box of Triscuits across the small room. They struck a shelf of canned goods and fell to the floor. He (Torrance) looked at the box, wiped his (Torrance) lips with his (Torrance) hand, and then looked at his (Torrance) watch. It was almost six-thirty. He (Torrance) had been in here for hours. His (Torrance) wife had locked him (Torrance) in here and he (Torrance)'d been here for fucking hours. He (Torrance) could begin to sympathize with his (Torrance) father The thing he (Torrance)'d never asked himself, Jack realized now, was exactly what had driven his (Jack) daddy to drink in the first place. And really ... when you came right down to what his (Jack) old students had been pleased to call the nifty-gritty ... hadn't it been the woman he (Jack) was married to? A milksop sponge of a woman, always dragging silently around the house with an expression of doomed martyrdom on her (woman) face? A ball and chain around Daddy's ankle? No, not ball and chain. She (woman) had never actively tried to make Daddy a prisoner, the way Wendy had done to him (prisoner). For Jack's father it must have been more like the fate of McTeague the dentist at the end of Frank Norris's great novel: handcuffed to a dead man in the wasteland. Yes, that was better. Mentally and spiritually dead, his (man) mother had been handcuffed to his (man) father by matrimony. Still, Daddy had tried to do right as he (Daddy) dragged her (mother) rotting corpse through life. He (Daddy) had tried to bring the four children up to know right from wrong, to understand discipline, and above all, to respect their father. Well, they had been ingrates, all of them, himself included. And now he (father) was paying the price; his (father) own son had turned out to be an ingrate, too. But there was hope. He (father) would get out of here somehow. He (father) would chastise them both, and harshly. He (father) would set Danny an example, so that the day might come when Danny was grown, a day when Danny would know what to do better than he (Danny) himself had known. He (Danny) remembered the Sunday dinner when his (Danny) father had caned his (Danny) mother at the table ... how horrified he (Danny) and the others had been. Now he (Danny) could see how necessary that bad been, how his (Danny) father had only been feigning drunkenness, how his (Danny) wits had been sharp and alive underneath all along, watching for the slightest sign of disrespect.

Jack crawled after the Triscuits and began to eat them again, sitting by the door she (mother) had so treacherously bolted. He (Jack) wondered exactly what his (Jack) father had seen, and how he (father) had caught her (mother) out by his (father) playacting. Had she (mother) been sneering at him (father) behind her (mother) hand? Sticking her (mother) tongue out? Making obscene finger gestures? Or only looking at him (father) insolently and arrogantly, convinced that he (father) was too stupidly drunk to see? Whatever it had been, he (father) had caught her (mother) at it, and he (father) had chastised her (mother) sharply. And now, twenty years later, he (father) could finally appreciate Daddy's wisdom. Of course you could say Daddy had been foolish to marry such a woman, to have handcuffed himself to that corpse in the first place ... and a disrespectful corpse at that. But when the young marry in haste they must repent in leisure, and perhaps Daddy's daddy had married the same type of woman, so that unconsciously Jack's daddy had also married one, as Jack himself had. Except that his (Jack) wife, instead of being satisfied with the passive role of having wrecked one career and crippled another, had opted for the poisonously active task of trying to destroy his (Jack) last and best chance: to become a member of the Overlook's staff, and possibly to rise ... all the way to the position of manager, in time. She (wife) was trying to deny him (manager) Danny, and Danny was his (Danny) ticket of admission. That was foolish, of course -- why would they want the son when they could have the father? -- but employers often had foolish ideas and that was the condition that had been made. He (father) wasn't going to be able to reason with her (wife), he (father) could see that now. He (father) had tried to reason with her (wife) in the Colorado Lounge, and she (wife) had refused to listen, had hit him (father) over the head with a bottle for his (father) pains. But there would be another time, and soon. He (father) would get out of here. He (father) suddenly held his (father) breath and cocked his (father) head. ``There'll Be a Hot Time in the Old Town Tonight.'' (unknown)

Jack's words and breath halted. For a moment he (Jack) felt that death itself was outside that door. The feeling passed. He (Jack) whispered: ``Thank you, Grady. I swear you won't regret it. I swear you won't.'' There was no answer. He (Jack) became aware that all sounds had stopped except for the cold swooping of the wind outside. He (Jack) pushed the pantry door open; the hinges squealed faintly. The kitchen was empty. Grady was gone. Everything was still and frozen beneath the cold white glare of the fluorescent bars. His (Grady) eyes caught on the large chopping block where the three of them had eaten their meals. Standing on top of it was a martini glass, a fifth of gin, and a plastic dish filled with olives. Leaning against it was one of the roque mallets from the equipment shed. He (Grady) looked at it for a long time. Then a voice much deeper and much more powerful than Grady's, spoke from somewhere, everywhere ... from inside him (Grady). -LRB-Keep your promise, Mr. Torrance.-RRB- ``I will,'' he (Torrance) said. He (Torrance) heard the fawning servility in his (Torrance) own voice but was unable to control it.

``I will.'' (unknown)
He (Torrance) walked to the chopping block and put his (Torrance) hand on the handle of the mallet. He (Torrance) hefted it. Swung it. It hissed viciously through the air. Jack Torrance began to smile.

<< 49 >> HALLORANN, GOING UP THE COUNTRY It was quarter of two in the afternoon and according to the snow-clotted signs and the Hertz Buick's odometer, he (Buick) was less than three miles from Estes Park when he (Estes) finally went off the road. In the hills, the snow was falling faster and more furiously than Hallorann had ever seen -LRB-which was, perhaps, not to say a great deal, since Hallorann had seen as little snow as he (Estes) could manage in his (Estes) lifetime-RRB-, and the wind was blowing a capricious gale -- now from the west, now backing around to the north, sending clouds of powdery snow across his (Estes) field of vision, making him (Estes) coldly aware again and again that if he (Estes) missed a turn he (Estes) might well plunge two hundred feet off the road, the Electra cartwheeling ass over teapot as it went down. Making it worse was his (Estes) own amateur status as a winter driver. It scared him (Estes) to have the yellow center line buried under swirling, drifting snow, and it scared him (Estes) when the heavy gusts of wind came unimpeded through the notches in the hills and actually made the heavy Buick slew around. It scared him (Buick) that the road information signs were mostly masked with snow and you could flip a coin as to whether the road was going to break right or left up ahead in the white drive-in movie screen he (Buick) seemed to be driving through. He (Buick) was scared, all right. He (Buick) had driven in a cold sweat since climbing into the hills west of Boulder and Lyons, handling the accelerator and brake as if they were Ming vases. Between rock 'n' roll tunes on the radio, the disc jockey constantly adjured motorists to stay off the main highways and under no conditions to go into the mountains, because many roads were impassable and all of them were dangerous. Scores of minor accidents had been reported, and two serious ones: a party of skiers in a VW microbus and a family that had been bound for Albuquerque through the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. The combined score on both was four dead and five wounded.

``So stay off those roads and get into the good music here at KTLK,'' (the jock)
the jock concluded cheerily, and then compounded Hallorann's misery by playing
``Seasons in the Sun.'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
``We had joy, we had fun, we had -- '' (Terry)
Terry Jacks gibbered happily, and Hallorann snapped the radio off viciously, knowing he (Terry) would have it back on in five minutes. No matter how bad it was, it was better than riding alone through this white madness. -LRB-Admit it. Dis heah black boy has got at least one long stripe of yaller ... and it runs rant up his (boy) ebberlubbin back!-RRB- It wasn't even funny. He (boy) would have backed off before he (boy) even cleared Boulder if it hadn't been for his (boy) compulsion that the boy was in terrible trouble. Even now a small voice in the back of his (boy) skull -- more the voice of reason than of cowardice, he (boy) thought -- was telling him (boy) to hole up in an Estes Park motel for the night and wait for the plows to at least expose the center stripe again. That voice kept reminding him (Estes) of the jet's shaky landing at Stapleton, of that

sinking feeling that it was going to come in nose-first, delivering its passengers to the gates of hell rather than at Gate 39, Concourse B. But reason would not stand against the compulsion. It had to be today. The snowstorm was his (Stapleton) own bad luck. He (Stapleton) would have to cope with it. He (Stapleton) was afraid that if he (Stapleton) didn't, he (Stapleton) might have something much worse to cope with in his (Stapleton) dreams. The wind gusted again, this time from the northeast, a little English on the ball if you please, and he (Stapleton) was again cut off from the vague shapes of the hills and even from the embankments on either side of the road. He (Stapleton) was driving through white null. And then the high sodium lights of the snowplow loomed out of the soup, bearing down, and to his (Stapleton) horror he (Stapleton) saw that instead of being to one side, the Buick's nose was pointed directly between those headlamps. The plow was being none too choosy about keeping its own side of the road, and Hallorann had allowed the Buick to drift. The grinding roar of the plow's diesel engine intruded over the bellow of the wind, and then the sound of its airhorn, hard, long, almost deafening. Hallorann's testicles turned into two small wrinkled sacs filled with shaved ice. His (Buick) guts seemed to have been transformed into a large mass of Silly Putty. Color was materializing out of the white now, snow-clotted orange. He (Buick) could see the high cab, even the gesticulating figure of the driver behind the single long wiper blade. He (driver) could see the V shape of the plow's wing blades, spewing more snow up onto the road's left-hand embankment like pallid, smoking exhaust. WHAAAAAAAAA! the airhorn bellowed indignantly. He (driver) squeezed the accelerator like the breast of a muchloved woman and the Buick scooted forward and toward the right. There was no embankment over here; the plows headed up instead of down had only to push the snow directly over the drop. -LRB-The drop, ah yes, the drop -- -RRB- The wingblades on Hallorann's left, fully four feet higher than the Electra's roof, flirted by with no more than an inch or two to spare. Until the plow had actually cleared him (driver), Hallorann had thought a crash inevitable. A prayer which was half an inarticulate apology to the boy flitted through his (boy) mind like a torn rag. Then the plow was past, its revolving blue lights glinting and flashing in Hallorann's rearview mirror. He (boy) jockeyed the Buick's steering wheel back to the left, but nothing doing. The scoot had turned into a skid, and the Buick was floating dreamily toward the lip of the drop, spurning snow from under its mudguards. He (lip) flicked the wheel back the other way, in the skid's direction, and the car's front and rear began to swap places. Panicked now, he (lip) pumped the brake hard, and then felt a hard bump. In front of him (lip) the road was gone ... he (lip) was looking into a bottomless chasm of swirling snow and vague greenish-gray pines far away and far below. -LRB-I'm going holy mother of Jesus I'm going off-RRB- And that was where the car stopped, canting forward at a thirty-degree angle, the left fender jammed against a guardrail, the rear wheels nearly off the ground. When Hallorann tried reverse, the wheels only spun helplessly. His (Jesus) heart was doing a Gene Krupa drumroll.

He (Jesus) got out -- very carefully he (Jesus) got out -- and went around to the Buick's back deck. He (Jesus) was standing there, looking at the back wheels helplessly, when a cheerful voice behind him (Jesus) said:

``Hello there, fella. You must be shit right out of your mind.'' (him)
He (Jesus) turned around and saw the plow forty yards further down the road, obscured in the blowing snow except for the raftered dark brown streak of its exhaust and the revolving blue lights on top. The driver was standing just behind him (driver), dressed in a long sheepskin coat and a slicker over it. A blue-and-white pinstriped engineer's cap was perched on his (engineer) head, and Hallorann could hardly believe it was staying on in the teeth of the wind. -LRB-Glue. It sure-God must be glue.-RRB-
``Hi,'' (he)
he (engineer) said.
``Can you pull me back onto the road?'' (unknown)
``Oh, I guess I could,'' (driver)
the plow driver said.
``What the hell you doing way up here, mister? Good way to kill your ass.'' (unknown)
``Urgent business.'' (unknown)
``Nothin is that urgent,'' (driver)
the plow driver said slowly and kindly, as if speaking to a mental defective.
``If you'd 'a hit that post a leetle mite harder, nobody woulda got you out till All Fools' Day. Don't come from these parts, do you?'' (unknown)
``No. And I wouldn't be here unless my business was as urgent as I say.'' (unknown)
``That so?'' (The driver)
The driver shifted his (driver) stance companionably as if they were having a desultory chat on the back steps instead of standing in a blizzard halfway between hoot and holler, with Hallorann's car balanced three hundred feet above the tops of the trees below.
``Where you headed? Estes?'' (unknown)
``No, a place called the Overlook Hotel,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said.
``It's a little way above Sidewinder -- '' (the driver)

``I guess I know well enough where that is,'' (he)
he (driver) said.
``Mister, you'll never get up to the old Overlook. Roads between Estes Park and Sidewinder is bloody damn hell. It's driftin in right behind us no matter how hard we push. I come through drifts a few miles back that was damn near six feet through the middle. And even if you could make Sidewinder, why, the road's closed from there all the way across to Buckland, Utah. Nope.'' (He)
He (driver) shook his (driver) head.
``Never make it, mister. Never make it at all.'' (unknown)

Hallorann said, calling on his (driver) last reserves of patience to keep his (driver) voice normal.
``There's a boy up there -- '' (unknown)

``He (Boy)'s the son of the caretaker. He (Boy)'s in trouble.'' (unknown)
``How would you know that?'' (unknown)
His (driver) patience snapped.
``For Christ's sake are you going to stand there and flap y'jaw at me the rest of the day? I know, I know! Now are you going to pull me back on the road or not?'' (unknown)
``Kind of testy, aren't you?'' (the driver)
the driver observed, not particularly perturbed.
``Sure, get back in there. I got a chain behind the seat.'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)

Hallorann got back behind the wheel, beginning to shake with delayed reaction now. His (driver) hands were numbed almost clear through. He (driver) had forgotten to bring gloves. The plow backed up to the rear of the Buick, and he (Buick) saw the driver get out with a long coil of chain. Hallorann opened the door and shouted:

``What can I do to help?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
``Stay out of the way, is all,'' (the driver)
the driver shouted back.
``This ain't gonna take a blink,'' (unknown)
Which was true. A shudder ran through the Buick's frame as the chain pulled tight, and a second later it was back on the road, pointed more or less toward Estes Park. The plow driver walked up beside the window and knocked on the safety glass. Hallorann rolled down the window.
``Thanks,'' (he)
he (driver) said.

the driver said with a grin.
``I guess you're sorta strung up. You take these.'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
A pair of bulky blue mittens dropped into Hallorann's lap.
``You'll need em when you go off the road again, I guess. Cold out. You wear em unless you want to spend the rest of your life pickin your nose with a crochetin hook. And you send em back. My wife knitted em and I'm partial to em. Name and address is sewed right into the linin. I'm Howard Cottrell, by the way. You just send em back when you don't need em anymore. ``Thanks. One hell of a lot.'' (unknown)
