Hallorann got going again, the chains flailing at the snowcover on the road, finally digging in enough to start the Buick moving. Behind him (Buick), Howard Cottrell gave a final good-luck blast on his (Cottrell) plow's airhorn, although it was really unnecessary; Hallorann could feel him (Cottrell) wishing him (Cottrell) good luck. That's two shines in one day, he (Cottrell) thought, and that ought to be some kind of good omen. But he (Cottrell) distrusted omens, good or bad. And meeting two people with the shine in one day -LRB-when he (Cottrell) usually didn't run across more than four or five in the course of a year-RRB- might not mean anything. That feeling of finality, a feeling

-LRB-like things are all wrapped up-RRB- he (Cottrell) could not completely define was still very much with him (Cottrell). It was The Buick wanted to skid sideways around a tight curve and Hallorann jockeyed it carefully, hardly daring to breathe. He (Buick) turned on the radio again and it was Aretha, and Aretha was just fine. He (Buick)'d share his (Buick) Hertz Buick with her (Buick) any day. Another gust of wind struck the car, making it rock and slip around. Hallorann cursed it and hunched more closely over the wheel. Aretha finished her (Hallorann) song and then the jock was on again, telling him (jock) that driving today was a good way to get killed. Hallorann snapped the radio off. *** He (jock) did make it to Sidewinder, although he (jock) was four and a half hours on the road between Estes Park and there. By the time he (Estes) got to the Upland Highway it was full dark, but the snowstorm showed no sign of abating. Twice he (Estes)'d had to stop in front of drifts that were as high as his (Estes) car's hood and wait for the plows to come along and knock holes in them. At one of the drifts the plow had come up on his (Estes) side of the road and there had been another close call. The driver had merely swung around his (driver) car, not getting out to chew the fat, but he (driver) did deliver one of the two finger gestures that all Americans above the age of ten recognize, and it was not the peace sign. It seemed that as he (driver) drew closer to the Overlook, his (driver) need to hurry became more and more compulsive. He (driver) found himself glancing at his (driver) wristwatch almost constantly. The hands seemed to be flying along. Ten minutes after he (driver) had turned onto the Upland, he (driver) passed two signs. The whooping wind had cleared both of their snow pack so he (driver) was able to read them. SIDEWINDER 10, the first said. The second: ROAD CLOSED 12 MILES AHEAD DURING WINTER MONTHS.

``Larry Durkin,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann muttered to himself. His (driver) dark face was strained and tense in the muted green glow of the dashboard instruments. It was ten after six.
``The Conoco by the library. Larry -- '' (him)
And that was when it struck him (driver) full-force, the smell of oranges and the thought-force, heavy and hateful, murderous: -LRB-GET OUT OF HERE YOU DIRTY NIGGER THIS IS NONE OF YOUR BUSINESS YOU NIGGER TURN AROUND TURN AROUND OR WE'LL KILL YOU HANG YOU UP FROM A TREE LIMB YOU FUCKING JUNGLE-BUNNY COON AND THEN BURN THE BODY THAT'S WHAT WE DO WITH NIGGERS SO TURN AROUND NOW-RRB- Hallorann screamed in the close confines of the car. The message did not come to him (driver) in words but in a series of rebuslike images that were slammed into his (driver) head with terrific force. He (driver) took his (driver) hands from the steering wheel to blot the pictures out. Then the car smashed broadside into one of the embankments, rebounded, slewed halfway around, and came to a stop. The rear wheels spun uselessly. Hallorann snapped the gearshift into park, and then covered his (driver) face with his (driver) hands. He (driver) did not precisely cry; what escaped him (driver) was an uneven huh-huh-huh sound. His (driver) chest heaved. He (driver) knew that if that blast had taken him (driver) on a stretch of road with a dropoff on one side or the other, he (driver) might well be dead now.

Maybe that had been the idea. And it might hit him (driver) again, at any time. He (driver) would have to protect against it. He (driver) was surrounded by a red force of immense power that might have been memory. He (driver) was drowning in instinct. He (driver) took his (driver) hands away from his (driver) face and opened his (driver) eyes cautiously. Nothing. If there was something trying to scare him (driver) again, it wasn't getting through. He (driver) was closed off. Had that happened to the boy? Dear God, had that happened to the little boy? And of all the images, the one that bothered him (God) the roost was that dull whacking sound, like a hammer splatting into thick cheese. What did that mean? . -LRB-Jesus, not that little boy. Jesus, please.-RRB- He (Jesus) dropped the gearshift lever into low range and fed the engine gas a little at a time. The wheels spun, caught, spun, and caught again. The Buick began to move, its headlights cutting weakly through the swirling snow. He (Jesus) looked at his (Jesus) watch. Almost six-thirty now. And he (Jesus) was beginning to feel that was very late indeed.

<< 50 >> REDRUM Wendy Torrance stood indecisive in the middle of the bedroom, looking at her (Torrance) son, who had fallen fast asleep. Half an hour ago the sounds had ceased. All of them, all at once. The elevator, the party, the sound of room doors opening and closing. Instead of easing her (Torrance) mind it made the tension that had been building in her (Torrance) even worse; it was like a malefic hush before the storm's final brutal push. But Danny had dozed off almost at once; first into a light, twitching doze, and in the last ten minutes or so a heavier sleep. Even looking directly at him (Danny) she (Torrance) could barely see the slow rise and fall of his (Danny) narrow chest. She (Torrance) wondered when he (Danny) had last gotten a full night's sleep, one without tormenting dreams or long periods of dark wakefulness, listening to revels that had only become audible -- and visible -- to her (Torrance) in the last couple of days, as the Overlook's grip on the three of them tightened. -LRB-Real psychic phenomena or group hypnosis?-RRB- She (Torrance) didn't know, and didn't think it mattered. What had been happening was just as deadly either way. She (Torrance) looked at Danny and thought -LRB-God grant he (God) lie still-RRB- that if he (God) was undisturbed, he (God) might sleep the rest of the night through. Whatever talent he (God) had, he (God) was still a small boy and he (God) needed his (God) rest. It was Jack she (Torrance) had begun to worry about. She (Torrance) grimaced with sudden pain, took her (Torrance) hand away from her (Torrance) mouth, and saw she (Torrance) had torn off one of her (Torrance) fingernails. And her (Torrance) nails were one thing she (Torrance)'d always

tried to keep nice. They weren't long enough to be called hooks, but still nicely shaped and -LRB-and what are you worrying about your fingernails for?-RRB- She (Torrance) laughed a little, but it was a shaky sound, without amusement. First Jack had stopped howling and battering at the door. Then the party had begun again -LRB-or did it ever stop? did it sometimes just drift into a slightly different angle of time where they weren't meant to hear it?-RRB- counterpointed by the crashing, banging elevator. Then that had stopped. In that new silence, as Danny had been falling asleep, she (Torrance) had fancied she (Torrance) heard low, conspiratorial voices coming from the kitchen almost directly below them. At first she (Torrance) had dismissed it as the wind, which could mimic many different human vocal ranges, from a papery deathbed whisper around the doors and window frames to a full-out scream around the eaves ... the sound of a woman fleeing a murderer in a cheap melodrama. Yet, sitting stiffly beside Danny, the idea that it was indeed voices became more and more convincing. Jack and someone else, discussing his (Jack) escape from the pan try. Discussing the murder of his (Jack) wife and son. It would be nothing new inside these walls; murder had been done here before. She (wife) had gone to the heating vent and had placed her (wife) ear against it, but at that exact moment the furnace had come on, and any sound was lost in the rush of warm air coming up from the basement. When the furnace had kicked off again, five minutes ago, the place was completely silent except for the wind, the gritty spatter of snow against the building, and the occasional groan of a board. She (wife) looked down at her (wife) ripped fingernail. Small beads of blood were oozing up from beneath it. -LRB-Jack's gotten out.-RRB- -LRB-Don't talk nonsense.-RRB- -LRB-Yes, he (Jack)'s out. He (Jack)'s gotten a knife from the kitchen or maybe the meat cleaver. He (Jack)'s on his (Jack) way up here right now, walking along the sides of the risers so the stairs won't creak.-RRB- -LRB-! You're insane !-RRB- Her (wife) lips were trembling, and for a moment it seemed that she (wife) must have cried the words out loud. But the silence held. She (wife) felt watched. She (wife) whirled around and stared at the night-blackened window, and a hideous white face with circles of darkness for eyes was gibbering in at her (wife), the face of a monstrous lunatic that had been hiding in these groaning walls all alongIt was only a pattern of frost on the outside of the glass. She (wife) let her (wife) breath out in a long, susurrating whisper of fear, and it seemed to her (wife) that she (wife) heard, quite clearly this time, amused titters from somewhere. -LRB-You're jumping at shadows. It's bad enough without that. By tomorrow morning, you'll be ready for the rubber room.-RRB- There was only one way to allay those fears and she (wife) knew what it was. She (wife) would have to go down and make sure Jack was still in the pantry. Very simple. Go downstairs. Have a peek. Come back up. Oh, by the way, stop and grab the tray on the registration counter. The omelet would be a washout,

but the soup could be reheated on the hotplate by Jack's typewriter. -LRB-Oh yes and don't get killed if he (Jack)'s down there with a knife.-RRB- She (wife) walked to the dresser, trying to shake off the mantle of fear that lay on her (wife). Scattered across the dresser's top was a pile of change, a stack of gasoline chits for the hotel truck, the two pipes Jack brought with him (Jack) everywhere but rarely smoked ... and his (Jack) key ring. She (wife) picked it up, held it in her (wife) hand for a moment, and then put it back down. The idea of locking the bedroom door behind her (wife) had occurred, but it just didn't appeal. Danny was asleep. Vague thoughts of fire passed through her (wife) mind, and something else nibbled more strongly, but she (wife) let it go. Wendy crossed the room, stood indecisively by the door for a moment, then took the knife from the pocket of her (wife) robe and curled her (wife) right hand around the wooden haft. She (wife) pulled the door open. The short corridor leading to their quarters was bare. The electric wall flambeaux all shone brightly at their regular intervals, showing off the rug's blue background and sinuous, weaving pattern. -LRB-See? No boogies here.-RRB- -LRB-No, of course not. They want you out. They want you to do something silly and womanish, and that is exactly what you are doing.-RRB- She (wife) hesitated again, miserably caught, not wanting to leave Danny and the safety of the apartment and at the same time needing badly to reassure herself that Jack was still . safely packed away. -LRB-Of course he (Jack) is.-RRB- -LRB-But the voices-RRB- -LRB-There were no voices. It was your imagination. It was the wind.-RRB-

``It wasn't the wind.'' (unknown)
The sound of her (wife) own voice made her (wife) jump. But the deadly certainty in it made her (wife) go forward. The knife swung by her (wife) side, catching angles of light and throwing them on the silk wallpaper. Her (wife) slippers whispered against the carpet's nap. Her (wife) nerves were singing like wires. She (wife) reached the corner of the main corridor and peered around, her (wife) mind stiffened for whatever she (wife) might see there. There was nothing to see. After a moment's hesitation she (wife) rounded the corner and began down the main corridor. Each step toward the shadowy stairwell increased her (wife) dread and made her (wife) aware that she (wife) was leaving her (wife) sleeping son behind, alone and unprotected. The sound of her (wife) slippers against the carpet seemed louder and louder in her (wife) ears; twice she (wife) looked back over her (wife) shoulder to convince herself that someone wasn't creeping up behind her (wife). She (wife) reached the stairwell and put her (wife) hand on the cold newel post at the top of the railing. There were nineteen wide steps down to the lobby. She (wife) had counted them enough times to know. Nineteen carpeted stair risers, and nary a Jack crouching on any one of them. Of course not. Jack was locked in the pantry behind a hefty steel bolt and a thick wooden door. But the lobby was dark and oh so full of shadows. Her (wife) pulse thudded steadily and deeply in her (wife) throat.

Ahead and slightly to the left, the brass yaw of the elevator stood mockingly open, inviting her (wife) to step in and take the ride of her (wife) life. -LRB-No thank you-RRB- The inside of the car had been draped with pink and white crepe streamers. Confetti had burst from two tubular party favors. Lying in the rear left corner was an empty bottle of champagne. She (wife) sensed movement above her (wife) and wheeled to look up the nineteen steps leading to the dark second-floor landing and saw nothing; yet there was a disturbing corner-of-the-eye sensation that things -LRB-things-RRB- had leaped back into the deeper darkness of the hallway up there just before her (wife) eyes could register them. She (wife) looked down the stairs again. Her (wife) right hand was sweating against the wooden handle of the knife; she (wife) switched it to her (wife) left, wiped her (wife) right palm against the pink terrycloth of her (wife) robe, and switched the knife back. Almost unaware that her (wife) mind had given her (wife) body the command to go forward, she (wife) began down the stairs, left foot then right, left foot then right, her (wife) free hand trailing lightly on the banister. -LRB-Where's the party? Don't let me scare you away, you bunch of moldy sheets! Not one scared woman with a knife! Let's have a little music around here! Let's have a little life!-RRB- Ten steps down, a dozen, a baker's dozen. The light from the first-floor hall filtered a dull yellow down here, and she (woman) remembered that she (woman) would have to turn on the lobby lights either beside the entrance to the dining room or inside the manager's office. Yet there was light coming from somewhere else, white and muted. The fluorescents, of course. In the kitchen. She (woman) paused on the thirteenth step, trying to remember if she (woman) had turned them off or left them on when she (woman) and Danny left. She (woman) simply couldn't remember. Below her (woman), in the lobby, highbacked chairs hulked in pools of shadow. The glass in the lobby doors was pressed white with a uniform blanket of drifted snow. Brass studs in the sofa cushions gleamed faintly like cat's eyes. There were a hundred places to hide. Her (woman) legs stilted with fear, she (woman) continued down. Now seventeen, now eighteen, now nineteen. -LRB-Lobby level, madam. Step out carefully.-RRB- The ballroom doors were thrown wide, only blackness spilling out. From within came a steady ticking, like a bomb. She (madam) stiffened, then remembered the clock on the mantel, the clock under glass. Jack or Danny must have wound it ... or maybe it had wound itself up, like everything else in the Overlook. She (madam) turned toward the reception desk meaning to go through the gate and the manager's office and into the kitchen. Gleaming dull silver, she (madam) could see the intended lunch tray. Then the clock began to strike, little tinkling notes. Wendy stiffened, her (Wendy) tongue rising to the roof of her (Wendy) mouth. Then she (Wendy) relaxed. It was striking eight, that was all. Eight o'clock ... five, six, seven ... She (Wendy) counted the strokes. It suddenly seemed wrong to move again until the

clock had stilled ... ... eight ... nine ... -LRB-?? Nine ??-RRB- ... ten ... eleven ... Suddenly, belatedly, it came to her (Wendy). She (Wendy) turned back clumsily for the stairs, knowing already she (Wendy) was too late. But how could she (Wendy) have known? Twelve. All the lights in the ballroom went on. There was a huge, shrieking flourish of brass. Wendy screamed aloud, the sound of her (Wendy) cry insignificant against the blare issuing from those brazen lungs.

``Unmask!'' (unknown)
the cry echoed.
``Unmask! Unmask!'' (unknown)
Then they faded, as if down a long corridor of time, leaving her (Wendy) alone again. No, not alone. She (Wendy) turned and he (Wendy) was coming for her (Wendy). It was Jack and yet not Jack. His (Jack) eyes were lit with a vacant, murderous glow; his (Jack) familiar mouth now wore a quivering, joyless grin. He (Jack) had the roque mallet in one hand.
``Thought you'd lock me in? Is that what you thought you'd do?'' (unknown)
The mallet whistled through the air. She (Wendy) stepped backward, tripped over a hassock, fell to the lobby rug.
``Jack -- '' (he)
``You bitch,'' (he)
he (Jack) whispered.
``I know what you are.'' (unknown)
The mallet came down again with whistling, deadly velocity and buried itself in her (Wendy) soft stomach. She (Wendy) screamed, suddenly submerged in an ocean of pain. Dimly she (Wendy) saw the mallet rebound. It came to her (Wendy) with sudden numbing reality that he (Jack) meant to beat her (Wendy) to death with the mallet he (Jack) held in his (Jack) hands. She (Wendy) tried to cry out to him (Jack) again, to beg him (Jack) to stop for Danny's sake, but her (Wendy) breath had been knocked loose. She (Wendy) could only force out a weak whimper, hardly a sound at all.
``Now. Now, by Christ,'' (he)
he (Jack) said, grinning. He (Jack) kicked the hassock out of his (Jack) way.
``I guess you'll take your medicine now.'' (unknown)
The mallet whickered down. Wendy rolled to her (Wendy) left, her (Wendy) robe tangling above her (Wendy) knees. Jack's hold on the mallet was jarred loose when it hit the floor. He (Jack) had to stoop and pick it up, and while he (Jack) did she (Wendy) ran for the stairs, the breath at last sobbing back into her (Wendy). Her (Wendy) stomach was a bruise of throbbing pain.
``Bitch,'' (he)
he (Jack) said through his (Jack) grin, and began to come after her (Wendy).
``You stinking bitch, I guess you'll get what's coming to you. I guess you will.'' (She)
She (Wendy) heard the mallet whistle through the air and then agony exploded on her (Wendy) right side as the mallet-head took her (Wendy) just below the line of her (Wendy) breasts, breaking two ribs. She (Wendy) fell forward on the steps and new agony ripped her (Wendy) as she (Wendy) struck on the wounded side. Yet instinct made her (Wendy) roll over, roll away, and the mallet whizzed past the side of her (Wendy) face, missing by a naked inch. It struck the deep pile of the stair carpeting with a muffled thud. That was when she (Wendy) saw the knife, which had been jarred out of her (Wendy) hand by her (Wendy) fall. It lay glittering on the fourth stair riser.
``Bitch,'' (he)
he (Wendy) repeated. The mallet came down. She (Wendy) shoved herself upward and it landed just below her (Wendy) kneecap. Her (Wendy) lower leg was suddenly on fire. Blood began to trickle down her (Wendy) calf. And then the mallet was coming down again. She (Wendy) jerked

her (Wendy) head away from it and it smashed into the stair riser in the hollow between her (Wendy) neck and shoulder, scraping away the flesh from her (Wendy) ear. He (Wendy) brought the mallet down again and this time she (Wendy) rolled toward him (Wendy), down the stairs, inside the arc of his (Wendy) swing. A shriek escaped her (Wendy) as her (Wendy) broken ribs thumped and grated. She (Wendy) struck his (Wendy) shins with her (Wendy) body while he (Wendy) was offbalance and he (Wendy) fell backward with a yell of anger and surprise, his (Wendy) feet jigging to keep their purchase on the stair riser. Then he (Wendy) thumped to the floor, the mallet flying from his (Wendy) hand. He (Wendy) sat up, staring at her (Wendy) for a moment with shocked eyes.

``I'll kill you for that,'' (he)
he (Wendy) said. He (Wendy) rolled over and stretched out for the handle of the mallet. Wendy forced herself to her (Wendy) feet. Her (Wendy) left leg sent bolt after bolt of pain all the way up to her (Wendy) hip. Her (Wendy) face was ashy pale but set. She (Wendy) leaped onto his (Wendy) back as his (Wendy) hand closed over the shaft of the roque mallet.
``Oh dear God!'' (she)
she (Wendy) screamed to the Overlook's shadowy lobby, and buried the kitchen knife in his (Wendy) lower back up to the handle. He (Wendy) stiffened beneath her (Wendy) and then shrieked. She (Wendy) thought she (Wendy) had never heard such an awful sound in her (Wendy) whole life; it was as if the very boards and windows and doors of the hotel had screamed. It seemed to go on and on while he (Wendy) remained board-stiff beneath her (Wendy) weight. They were like a parlor charade of horse and rider. Except that the back of his (rider) red-and-black-checked flannel shirt was growing darker, sodden, with spreading blood. Then he (rider) collapsed forward on his (rider) face, bucking her (Wendy) off on her (Wendy) hurt side, making her (Wendy) groan. She (Wendy) lay breathing harshly for a time, unable to move. She (Wendy) was an excruciating throb of pain from one end to the other. Every time she (Wendy) inhaled, something stabbed viciously at her (Wendy), and her (Wendy) neck was wet with blood from her (Wendy) grazed ear. There was only the sound of her (Wendy) struggle to breathe, the wind, and the ticking clock in the ballroom. At last she (Wendy) forced herself to her (Wendy) feet and hobbled across to the stairway. When she (Wendy) got there she (Wendy) clung to the newel post, head down, waves of faintness washing over her (Wendy). When it had passed a little, she (Wendy) began to climb, using her (Wendy) unhurt leg and pulling with her (Wendy) arms on the banister. Once she (Wendy) looked up, expecting to see Danny there, but the stairway was empty. -LRB-Thank God he (God) slept through it thank God thank God-RRB- Six steps up she (Wendy) had to rest, her (Wendy) head down, her (Wendy) blond hair coiled on and over the banister. Air whistled painfully through her (Wendy) throat, as if it had grown barbs. Her (Wendy) right side was a swollen, hot mass. -LRB-Come on Wendy come on old girl get a locked door behind you and then look at the damage thirteen more to go not so bad. And when you get to the upstairs corridor you can crawl. I give my permission.-RRB- She (girl) drew in as much breath as her (girl) broken ribs would allow and half-pulled, half-fell up another riser. And another. She (girl) was on the ninth, almost halfway up, when Jack's voice came from behind and below her (girl). He (Jack) said thickly:
``You bitch. You killed me.'' (He)
Terror as black as midnight swept through her (girl). She (girl) looked over her (girl) shoulder and saw Jack getting slowly to his (Jack) feet. His (Jack) back was bowed over, and she (girl) could see the handle of the kitchen knife sticking out of it. His (Jack) eyes seemed to have contracted, almost to have lost

themselves in the pale, sagging folds of the skin around them. He (Jack) was grasping the roque mallet loosely in his (Jack) left hand. The end of it was bloody. A scrap of her (girl) pink terrycloth robe stuck almost in the center.

``I'll give you your medicine,'' (he)
he (Jack) whispered, and began to stagger toward the stairs. Whimpering with fear, she (girl) began to pull herself upward again. Ten steps, a dozen, a baker's dozen. But still the first-floor hallway looked as far above her (girl) as an unattainable mountain peak. She (girl) was panting now, her (girl) side shrieking in protest. Her (girl) hair swung wildly back and forth in front of her (girl) face. Sweat stung her (girl) eyes. The ticking of the domed clock in the ballroom seemed to fill her (girl) cars, and counterpointing it, Jack's panting, agonized gasps as he (Jack) began to mount the stairs.

<< 51 >> HALLORANN ARRIVES Larry Durkin was a tall and skinny man with a morose face overtopped with a luxuriant mane of red hair. Hallorann had caught him (Durkin) just as he (Durkin) was leaving the Conoco station, the morose face buried deeply inside an army-issue parka. He (Durkin) was reluctant to do any more business that stormy day no matter how far Hallorann had come, and even more reluctant to rent one of his (Durkin) two snowmobiles out to this wild-eyed black man who insisted on going up to the old Overlook. Among people who had spent most of their lives in the little town of Sidewinder, the hotel had a smelly reputation. Murder had been done up there. A bunch of hoods had run the place for a while, and cutthroat businessmen had run it for a while, too. And things had been done up at the old Overlook that never made the papers, because money has a way of talking. But the people in Sidewinder had a pretty good idea. Most of the hotel's chambermaids came from here, and chambermaids see a lot. But when Hallorann mentioned Howard Cottrell's name and showed Durkin the tag inside one of the blue mittens, the gas station owner thawed.

``Sent you here, did he (God)?'' (Durkin/Larry Durkin/Larry)
Durkin asked, unlocking one of the garage bays and leading Hallorann inside.
``Good to know the old rip's got some sense left. I thought he (God) was plumb out of it.'' (He)
He (Durkin) flicked a switch and a bank of very old and very dirty fluorescents buzzed wearily into life.
``Now what in the tarnal creation would you want up at that place, fella?'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann's nerve had begun to crack. The last few miles into Sidewinder had been very bad. Once a gust of wind that must have been tooling along at better than sixty miles an hour had floated the Buick all the way around in a 360° turn. And there were still miles to travel with God alone knew what at the other end of them. He (God) was terrified for the boy. Now it was almost ten minutes to

seven and he (God) had this whole song and dance to go through again.

``Somebody is in trouble up there,'' (he)
he (God) said very carefully.
``The son of the caretaker.'' (unknown)
``Who? Torrance's boy? Now what kind of trouble could he (boy) be in?'' (unknown)
``I don't know,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann muttered. He (God) felt sick with the time this was taking. He (God) was speaking with a country man, and he (God) knew that all country men feel a similar need to approach their business obliquely, to smell around its corners and sides before plunging into the middle of dealing. But there was no time, because now he (God) was one scared nigger and if this went on much longer he (God) just might decide to cut and run.
``Look,'' (he)
he (God) said.
``Please. I need to go up there and I have to have a snowmobile to get there. I'll pay your price, but for God's sake let me get on with my business!'' (unknown)
``All right,'' (Durkin/Larry Durkin/Larry)
Durkin said, unperturbed.
``If Howard sent you, that's good enough. You take this ArcticCat. I'll put five gallons of gas in the can. Tank's full. She (I)'ll get you up and back down, I guess.'' (unknown)
``Thank you,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said, not quite steadily.
``I'll take twenty dollars. That includes the ethyl.'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann fumbled a twenty out of his (Durkin) wallet and handed it over. Durkin tucked it into one of his (Durkin) shirt pockets with hardly a look.
``Guess maybe we better trade jackets, too,'' (Durkin/Larry Durkin/Larry)
Durkin said, pulling off his (Durkin) parka.
``That overcoat of yours ain't gonna be worth nothin tonight. You trade me back when you return the snowsled.'' (unknown)
``Oh, hey, I couldn't --'' (Durkin/Larry Durkin/Larry)
``Don't fuss with me,'' (Durkin/Larry Durkin/Larry)
Durkin interrupted, still mildly.
``I ain't sending you out to freeze. I only got to walk down two blocks and I'm at my own supper table. Give it over.'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Slightly dazed, Hallorann traded his (Durkin) overcoat for Durkin's fur-lined parka. Overhead the fluorescents buzzed faintly, reminding him (Durkin) of the lights in the Overlook's kitchen.
``Torrance's boy,'' (Durkin/Larry Durkin/Larry)
Durkin said, and shook his (Durkin) head.
``Good-lookin little tyke, ain't he (tyke)? He (tyke)'n his (tyke) dad was in here a lot before the snow really flew. Drivin the hotel truck, mostly. Looked to me like the two of em was just about as tight as they could get. That's one little boy that loves his (boy) daddy. Hope he (boy)'s all right.'' (unknown)
``So do I.'' (unknown)
Hallorann zipped the parka and tied the hood.
``Lemme help you push that out,'' (Durkin/Larry Durkin/Larry)
Durkin said. They rolled the snowmobile across the oil-stained concrete and toward the garage bay.
``You ever drove one of these before?'' (unknown)
``No. '' (unknown)
``Well, there's nothing to it. The instructions are pasted there on the dashboard, but all there really is, is stop and go. Your throttle's here, just like a motorcycle throttle. Brake on the other side. Lean with it on the turns. This baby will do seventy on hardpack, but on this powder you'll get no more than fifty and that's pushing it.'' (Durkin/Larry Durkin/Larry)
Now they were in the service station's snow-filled front lot, and Durkin had raised his (Durkin) voice to make himself heard over the battering of the wind.
``Stay on the road!'' (he)
he (Durkin) shouted at Hallorann's ear. ``Keep your eye on the guardrail posts

and the signs and you'll be all right, I guess. If you get off the road, you're going to be dead. Understand?'' Hallorann nodded. ``Wait a minute!'' Durkin told him (Durkin), and ran back into the garage bay. While he (Durkin) was gone, Hallorann turned the key in the ignition and pumped the throttle a little. The snowmobile coughed into brash, choppy life. Durkin came back with a red and black ski mask. ``Put this on under your hood!'' he (Durkin) shouted. Hallorann dragged it on. It was a tight fit, but it cut the last of the numbing wind off from his (Durkin) cheeks and forehead and chin. Durkin leaned close to make himself heard. ``I guess you must know about things the same way Howie does sometimes,'' he (Durkin) said. ``It don't matter, except that place has got a bad reputation around here. I'll give you a rifle if you want it.'' ``I don't think it would do any good,'' Hallorann shouted back. ``You're the boss. But if you get that boy, you bring him (boy) to Sixteen Peach Lane. The wife'll have some soup on.'' ``Okay. Thanks for everything.'' ``You watch out!'' Durkin yelled.

``Stay on the road!'' (unknown)
Hallorann nodded and twisted the throttle slowly. The snowmobile purred forward, the headlamp cutting a clean cone of light through the thickly falling snow. He (Durkin) saw Durkin's upraised hand in the rearview mirror, and raised his (Durkin) own in return. Then he (Durkin) nudged the handlebars to the left and was traveling up Main Street, the snowmobile coursing smoothly through the white light thrown by the streetlamps. The speedometer stood at thirty miles an hour. It was ten past seven. At the Overlook, Wendy and Danny were sleeping and Jack Torrance was discussing matters of life and death with the previous caretaker. Five blocks up Main, the streetlamps ended. For half a mile there were small houses, all buttoned tightly up against the storm, and then only wind-howling darkness. In the black again with no light but the thin spear of the snowmobile's headlamp, terror closed in on him (caretaker) again, a childlike fear, dismal and disheartening. He (caretaker) had never felt so alone. For several minutes, as the few lights of Sidewinder dwindled away and disappeared in the rearview, the urge to turn around and go back was almost insurmountable. He (caretaker) reflected that for all of Durkin's concern for Jack Torrance's boy, he (Durkin) had not offered to take the other snowmobile and come with him (Durkin). -LRB-That place has got a bad reputation around here.-RRB- Clenching his (Durkin) teeth, he (Durkin) turned the throttle higher and watched the needle on the speedometer climb past forty and settle at forty-five. He (Durkin) seemed to be going horribly fast and yet he (Durkin) was afraid it wasn't fast enough. At this speed it would take him (Durkin) almost an hour to get to the Overlook. But at a higher speed he (Durkin) might not get there at all. He (Durkin) kept his (Durkin) eyes glued to the passing guardrails and the dime-sized reflectors mounted on top of each one. Many of them were buried under drifts. Twice he (Durkin) saw curve signs dangerously late and felt the snowmobile riding up the drifts that masked the dropoff before turning back onto where the road was in the summertime. The odometer counted off the miles at a maddeningly slow clip -- five, ten, finally fifteen. Even behind the knitted ski mask his (Durkin) face was beginning to

stiffen up and his (Durkin) legs were growing numb. -LRB-Guess I'd give a hundred bucks for a pair of ski pants.-RRB- As each mile turned over, his (Durkin) terror grew -- as if the place had a poison atmosphere that thickened as you neared it. Had it ever been like this before? He (Durkin) had never really liked the Overlook, and there had been others who shared his (Durkin) feeling, but it had never been like this. He (Durkin) could feel the voice that had almost wrecked him (Durkin) outside of Sidewinder still trying to get in, to get past his (Durkin) defenses to the soft meat inside. If it had been strong twenty-five miles back, how much stronger would it be now? He (Durkin) couldn't keep it out entirely. Some of it was slipping through, flooding his (Durkin) brain with sinister subliminal images. More and more he (Durkin) got the image of a badly hurt woman in a bathroom, holding her (woman) hands up uselessly to ward off a blow, and he (Durkin) felt more and more that the woman must be -- -LRB-Jesus, watch out!-RRB- The embankment was looming up ahead of him (Jesus) like a freight train. Woolgathering, he (Jesus) had missed a turn sign. He (Jesus) jerked the snowmobile's steering gear hard right and it swung around, tilting as it did so. From underneath came the harsh grating sound of the snowtread on rock. He (Jesus) thought the snowmobile was going to dump him (Jesus), and it did totter on the knife-edge of balance before halfdriving, half-skidding back down to the more or less level surface of the snowburied road. Then the dropoff was ahead of him (Jesus), the headlamp showing an abrupt end to the snowcover and darkness beyond that. He (Jesus) turned the snowmobile the other way, a pulse beating sickly in his (Jesus) throat. -LRB-Keep it on the road Dicky old chum.-RRB- He (Jesus) forced himself to turn the throttle up another notch. Now the speedometer needle was pegged just below fifty. The wind howled and roared. The headlamp probed the dark. An unknown length of time later, he (Jesus) came around a driftbanked curve and saw a glimmering flash of light ahead. Just a glimpse, and then it was blotted out by a rising fold of land. The glimpse was so brief he (Jesus) was persuading himself it had been wishful thinking when another turn brought it in view again, slightly closer, for another few seconds. There was no question of its reality this time; he (Jesus) had seen it from just this angle too many times before. It was the Overlook. There were lights on the first floor and lobby levels, it looked like. Some of his (Jesus) terror -- the part that had to do with driving off the road or wrecking the snowmobile on an unseen curve -- melted entirely away. The snowmobile swept surely into the first half of an S curve that he (Jesus) now remembered confidently foot for foot, and that was when the headlamp picked out the -LRB-oh dear Jesus god what is it-RRB- in the road ahead of him (Jesus). Limned in stark blacks and whites, Hallorann first thought it was some hideously huge timberwolf that had been driven down from the high country by the storm. Then, as he (Jesus) closed on it, he (Jesus) recognized it and horror closed his (Jesus) throat. Not a wolf but a lion. A hedge lion. Its features were a mask of black shadow and powdered snow, its haunches wound tight to spring. And it did spring, snow billowing around its pistoning rear legs in a silent burst of crystal glitter. Hallorann screamed and twisted the handlebars hard right, ducking low at the

same time. Scratching, ripping pain scrawled itself across his (Jesus) face, his (Jesus) neck, his (Jesus) shoulders. The ski mask was torn open down the back. He (Jesus) was hurled from the snowmobile. He (Jesus) hit the snow, plowed through it, rolled over. He (Jesus) could feel it coming for him (Jesus). In his (Jesus) nostrils there was a bitter smell of green leaves and holly. A huge hedge paw batted him (Jesus) in the small of the back and he (Jesus) flew ten feet through the air, splayed out like a rag doll. He (Jesus) saw the snowmobile, riderless, strike the embankment and rear up, its headlamp searching the sky. It fell over with a thump and stalled. Then the hedge lion was on him (Jesus). There was a crackling, rustling sound. Something raked across the front of the parka, shredding it. It might have been stiff twigs, but Hallorann knew it was claws.

``You're not there!'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann screamed at the circling, snarling hedge lion.
``You're not there at all!'' (He)
He (Jesus) struggled to his (Jesus) feet and made it halfway to the snowmobile before the lion lunged, batting him (Jesus) across the head with a needletipped paw. Hallorann saw silent, exploding lights.
``Not there,'' (he)
he (Jesus) said again, but it was a fading mutter. His (Jesus) knees unhinged and dropped him (Jesus) into the snow. He (Jesus) crawled for the snowmobile, the right side of his (Jesus) face a scarf of blood. The lion struck him (Jesus) again, rolling him (Jesus) onto his (Jesus) back like a turtle. It roared playfully. Hallorann struggled to reach the snowmobile. What he (Jesus) needed was there. And then the lion was on him (Jesus) again, ripping and clawing.

<< 52 >> WENDY AND JACK Wendy risked another glance over her (Wendy) shoulder. Jack was on the sixth riser, clinging to the banister much as she (Wendy) was doing herself. He (Jack) was still grinning, and dark blood oozed slowly through the grin and slipped down the line of his (Jack) jaw. He (Jack) bared his (Jack) teeth at her (Wendy).

``I'm going to bash your brains in. Bash them right to fuck in.'' (He)
He (Jack) struggled up another riser. Panic spurred her (Wendy), and the ache in her (Wendy) side diminished a little. She (Wendy) pulled herself up as fast as she (Wendy) could regardless of the pain, yanking convulsively at the banister. She (Wendy) reached the top and threw a glance behind her (Wendy). He (Jack) seemed to be gaining strength rather than losing it. He (Jack) was only four risers from the top, measuring the distance with the rogue mallet in his (Jack) left hand as he (Jack) pulled himself up with his (Jack) right.
``Right behind you,'' (he)
he (Jack) panted through his (Jack) bloody grin, as if reading her (Wendy) mind.
``Right behind you now, bitch. With your medicine.'' (She)
She (Wendy) fled stumblingly down the main corridor, hands pressed to her (Wendy) side. The door to one of the rooms jerked open and a man with a green ghoulmask on

popped out.

``Great party, isn't it?'' (He)
He (man) screamed into her (Wendy) face, and pulled the waxed string of a party-favor. There was an echoing bang and suddenly crepe streamers were drifting all around her (Wendy). The man in the ghoulmask cackled and slammed back into his (man) room. She (Wendy) fell forward onto the carpet, full-length. Her (Wendy) right side seemed to explode with pain, and she (Wendy) fought off the blackness of unconsciousness desperately. Dimly she (Wendy) could hear the elevator running again, and beneath her (Wendy) splayed fingers she (Wendy) could see that the carpet pattern appeared to move, swaying and twining sinuously. The mallet slammed down behind her (Wendy) and she (Wendy) threw herself forward, sobbing. Over her (Wendy) shoulder she (Wendy) saw Jack stumble forward, overbalance, and bring the mallet down just before he (Jack) crashed to the carpet, expelling a bright splash of blood onto the nap. The mallet head struck her (Wendy) squarely between the shoulder blades and for a moment the agony was so great that she (Wendy) could only writhe, hands opening and clenching. Something inside her (Wendy) had snapped -- she (Wendy) had heard it clearly, and for a few moments she (Wendy) was aware only in a muted, muffled way, as if she (Wendy) were merely observing these things through a cloudy wrapping of gauze. Then full consciousness came back, terror and pain with it. Jack was trying to get up so he (Jack) could finish the job. Wendy tried to stand and found it was impossible. Electric bolts seemed to course up and down her (Wendy) back at the effort. She (Wendy) began to crawl along in a sidestroke motion. Jack was crawling after her (Wendy), using the roque mallet as a crutch or a cane. She (Wendy) reached the comer and pulled herself around it, using her (Wendy) hands to yank at the angle of the wall. Her (Wendy) terror deepened -- she (Wendy) would not have believed that possible, but it was. It was a hundred times worse not to be able to see him (Jack) or know how close he (Jack) was getting. She (Wendy) tore out fistfuls of the carpet napping pulling herself along, and she (Wendy) was halfway down this short hall before she (Wendy) noticed the bedroom door was standing wide open. -LRB-Danny! O Jesus-RRB- She (Wendy) forced herself to her (Wendy) knees and then clawed her (Wendy) way to her (Wendy) feet, fingers slipping over the silk wallpaper. Her (Wendy) nails pulled little strips of it loose. She (Wendy) ignored the pain and halfwalked, half-shambled through the doorway as Jack came around the far corner and began to lunge his (Jack) way down toward the open door, leaning on the roque mallet. She (Wendy) caught the edge of the dresser, held herself up against it, and grabbed the doorframe. Jack shouted at her (Wendy):
``Don't you shut that door! Goddam you, don't you dare shut it!'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
She (Wendy) slammed it closed and shot the bolt. Her (Wendy) left hand pawed wildly at the junk on the dresser, knocking loose coins onto the floor where they rolled in every direction. Her (Wendy) hand seized the key ring just as the mallet whistled down against the door, making it tremble in its frame. She (Wendy) got the key into the lock on the second stab and twisted it to the right. At the sound of the tumblers falling, Jack screamed. The mallet came down against the door in a volley of booming blows that made her (Wendy) flinch and step back. How could he (Jack) be doing that with a knife in his (Jack) back? Where was he (Jack) finding the strength? She (Wendy) wanted to shriek Why aren't you dead? at the locked door.

Instead she (Wendy) turned around. She (Wendy) and Danny would have to go into the attached bathroom and lock that door, too, in case Jack actually could break through the bedroom door. The thought of escaping down the dumb-waiter shaft crossed her (Wendy) mind in a wild burst, and then she (Wendy) rejected it. Danny was small enough to fit into it, but she (Wendy) would be unable to control the rope pull. He (Danny) might go crashing all the way to the bottom. The bathroom it would have to be. And if Jack broke through into there -- But she (Wendy) wouldn't allow herself to think of it.

``Danny, honey, you'll have to wake up n -- '' (unknown)
But the bed was empty. When he (Jack) had begun to sleep more soundly, she (Wendy) had thrown the blankets and one of the quilts over him (Jack). Now they were thrown back.
``I'll get you!'' (Jack/Jack Torrance/Torrance)
Jack howled.
``I'll get .both of you!'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Every other word was punctuated with a blow from the roque hammer, yet Wendy ignored both. All of her (Wendy) attention was focused on that empty bed.
``Come out here! Unlock this goddam door!'' (unknown)
``Danny?'' (she)
she (Wendy) whispered. Of course ... when Jack had attacked her (Wendy). It had come through to him (Jack), as violent emotions always seemed to. Perhaps he (Jack)'d even seen the whole thing in a nightmare. He (Jack) was hiding. She (Wendy) fell clumsily to her (Wendy) knees, enduring another bolt of pain from her (Wendy) swollen and bleeding leg, and looked under the bed. Nothing there but dustballs and Jack's bedroom slippers. Jack screamed her (Wendy) name, and this time when he (Jack) swung the mallet, a long splinter of wood jumped from the door and clattered off the hardwood planking. The next blow brought a sickening, splintering crack, the sound of dry kindling under a hatchet. The bloody mallet head, now splintered and gouged in its own right, bashed through the new hole in the door, was withdrawn, and came down again, sending wooden shrapnel flying across the room. Wendy pulled herself to her (Wendy) feet again using the foot of the bed, and hobbled across the room to the closet. Her (Wendy) broken ribs stabbed at her (Wendy), making her (Wendy) groan.
``Danny?'' (She)
She (Wendy) brushed the hung garments aside frantically; some of them slipped their hangers and ballooned gracelessly to the floor. He (Wendy) was not in the closet. She (Wendy) hobbled toward the bathroom and as she (Wendy) reached the door she (Wendy) glanced back over her (Wendy) shoulder. The mallet crashed through again, widening the hole, and then a hand appeared, groping for the bolt. She (Wendy) saw with horror that she (Wendy) had left Jack's key ring dangling from the lock. The hand yanked the bolt back, and as it did so it struck the bunched keys. They jingled merrily. The hand clutched them victoriously. With a sob, she (Wendy) pushed her (Wendy) way into the bathroom and slammed the door just as the bedroom door burst open and Jack charged through, bellowing. Wendy ran the bolt and twisted the spring lock, looking around desperately. The bathroom was empty. Danny wasn't here, either. And as she (Wendy) caught sight of her (Wendy) own bloodsmeared, horrified face in the medicine cabinet mirror, she (Wendy) was glad. She (Wendy) had never believed that children should be witness to the little quarrels of their parents. And perhaps the thing that was now raving through the bedroom, overturning things and smashing them, would finally collapse before it

could go after her (Wendy) son. Perhaps, she (Wendy) thought, it might be possible for her (Wendy) to inflict even more damage on it ... kill it, perhaps. Her (Wendy) eyes skated quickly over the bathroom's machine-produced porcelain surfaces, looking for anything that might serve as a weapon. There was a bar of soap, but even wrapped in a towel she (Wendy) didn't think it would be lethal enough. Everything else was bolted down. God, was there nothing she (Wendy) could do? Beyond the door, the animal sounds of destruction went on and on, accompanied by thick shouts that they would

``take their medicine'' (He)
and
``pay for what they'd done to him (Danny).'' (He)
He (God) would
``show them who's boss,'' (He)
They were
``worthless puppies,'' (He)
the both of them. There was a thump as her (Wendy) record player was overturned, a hollow crash as the secondhand TV's picture tube was smashed, the tinkle of windowglass followed by a cold draft under the bathroom door. A dull thud as the mattresses were ripped from the twin beds where they had slept together, hip to hip. Boomings as Jack struck the walls indiscriminately with the mallet. There was nothing of the real Jack in that howling, maundering, petulant voice, though. It alternately whined in tones of selfpity and rose in lurid screams; it reminded her (Wendy) chillingly of the screams that sometimes rose in the geriatrics ward of the hospital where she (Wendy) had worked summers as a high school kid. Senile dementia. Jack wasn't out there anymore. She (Wendy) was hearing the lunatic, raving voice of the Overlook itself. The mallet smashed into the bathroom door, knocking out a huge chunk of the thin paneling. Half of a crazed and working face stared in at her (Wendy). The mouth and cheeks and throat were lathered in blood, the single eye she (Wendy) could see was tiny and piggish and glittering.
``Nowhere left to run, you cunt,'' (unknown)
it panted at her (Wendy) through its grin. The mallet descended again, knocking wood splinters into the tub and against the reflecting surface of the medicine cabinet -LRB-!! She (Wendy) began to paw through its contents. Behind her (Wendy) that hoarse voice bellowed:
``Here I come now! Here I come now, you pig!'' (unknown)
It was demolishing the door in a machinelike frenzy. Bottles and jars fell before her (Wendy) madly searching fingers -- cough syrup, Vaseline, Clairol Herbal Essence shampoo, hydrogen peroxide, benzocaine -- they fell into the sink and shattered. Her (Wendy) hand closed over the dispenser of double-edged razor blades just as she (Wendy) heard the hand again, fumbling for the bolt and the spring lock. She (Wendy) slipped one of the razor blades out, fumbling at it, her (Wendy) breath coming in harsh little gasps. She (Wendy) had cut the ball of her (Wendy) thumb. She (Wendy) whirled around and slashed at the hand, which had turned the lock and was now fumbling for the bolt. Jack screamed. The hand was jerked back. Panting, holding the razor blade between her (Wendy) thumb and index finger, she (Wendy) waited for him (Jack) to try again. He (Jack) did, and she (Wendy) slashed. He (Jack) screamed again, trying to grab her (Wendy) hand, and she (Wendy) slashed at him (Jack) again. The razor blade turned in her (Wendy) hand, cutting her (Wendy) again, and dropped to the tile floor by the toilet. Wendy slipped another blade out of the dispenser and waited.

``Oh God,'' (she)
she (Wendy) muttered brokenly through a mouth that seemed filled with broken sticks and old sawdust.

She (Wendy) had to leave now, had to go find her (Wendy) son so they could face the rest of this nightmare side by side. She (Wendy) reached out and fumbled at the bolt. Her (Wendy) arm seemed to stretch for miles. At last she (Wendy) got it to come free. She (Wendy) pushed the door open, staggered out, and was suddenly overcome by the horrible certainty that Jack had only pretended to leave, that he (Jack) was lying in wait for her (Wendy): Wendy looked around. The room was empty, the living room too. Jumbled, broken stuff everywhere. The closet? Empty. Then the soft shades of gray began to wash over her (Wendy) and she (Wendy) fell down on the mattress Jack had ripped from the bed, semiconscious.

<< 53 >> HALLORANN LAID LOW Hallorann reached the overturned snowmobile just as, a mile and a half away, Wendy was pulling herself around the corner and into the short hallway leading to the caretaker's apartment. It wasn't the snowmobile he (caretaker) wanted but the gascan held onto the back by a pair of elastic straps. His (caretaker) hands, still clad in Howard Cottrell's blue mittens, seized the top strap and pulled it free as the hedge lion roared behind him (caretaker) -- a sound that seemed to be more in his (caretaker) head than outside of it. A hard, brambly slap to his (caretaker) left leg, making the knee sing with pain as it was driven in a way the joint had never been expected to bend. A groan escaped Hallorann's clenched teeth. It would come for the kill any time now, tired of playing with him (caretaker). He (caretaker) fumbled for the second strap. Sticky blood ran in his (caretaker) eyes. -LRB-Roar! Slap!-RRB- That one raked across his (caretaker) buttocks, almost tumbling him (caretaker) over and away from the snowmobile again. He (caretaker) held on -- no exaggeration -- for dear life. Then he (caretaker) had freed the second strap. He (caretaker) clutched the gascan to him (caretaker) as the lion struck again, rolling him (caretaker) over on his (caretaker) back. He (caretaker) saw it again, only a shadow in the darkness and falling snow, as nightmarish as a moving gargoyle. Hallorann twisted at the can's cap as the moving shadow stalked him (caretaker), kicking up snowpuffs.

As it moved in again the cap spun free, releasing the pungent smell of the gasoline. Hallorann gained his (caretaker) knees and as it came at him (caretaker), lowslung and incredibly quick, he (caretaker) splashed it with the gas. There was a hissing, spitting sound and it drew back.

``Gas!'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann cried, his (caretaker) voice shrill and breaking.
``Gonna burn you, baby! Dig on it awhile!'' (him)
The lion came at him (caretaker) again, still spitting angrily. Hallorann splashed it again but this time the lion didn't give. It charged ahead. Hallorann sensed rather than saw its head angling at his (caretaker) face and he (caretaker) threw himself backward, partially avoiding it. Yet the lion still hit his (caretaker) upper rib cage a glancing blow, and a flare of pain struck there. Gas gurgled out of the can, which he (caretaker) still held, and doused his (caretaker) right hand and arm, cold as death. Now he (caretaker) lay on his (caretaker) back in a snow angel, to the right of the snowmobile by about ten paces. The hissing lion was a bulking presence to his (caretaker) left, closing in again. Hallorann thought he (caretaker) could see its tail twitching. He (caretaker) yanked Cottrell's mitten off his (caretaker) right hand, tasting sodden wool and gasoline. He (caretaker) ripped up the hem of the parka and jammed his (caretaker) hand into his (caretaker) pants pocket. Down in there, along with his (caretaker) keys and his (caretaker) change, was a very battered old Zippo lighter. He (caretaker) had bought it in Germany in 1954. Once the hinge had broken and he (caretaker) had returned it to the Zippo factory and they had repaired it without charge, just as advertised. A nightmare flood of thoughts flooding through his (caretaker) mind in a split second. -LRB-Dear Zippo my lighter was swallowed by a crocodile dropped from an airplane lost in the Pacific trench saved me from a Kraut bullet in the Battle of the Bulge dear Zippo if this fucker doesn't go that lion is going to rip my head off-RRB- The lighter was out. He (caretaker) clicked the hood back. The lion, rushing at him (caretaker), a growl like ripping cloth, his (caretaker) finger flicking the striker wheel, spark, flame, -LRB-my hand-RRB- his (caretaker) gasoline-soaked hand suddenly ablaze, the flames running up the sleeve of the parka, no pain, no pain yet, the lion shying from the torch suddenly blazing in front of it, a hideous flickering hedge sculpture with eyes and a mouth, shying away, too late. Wincing at the pain, Hallorann drove his (caretaker) blazing arm into its stiff and scratchy side. In an instant the whole creature was in flames, a prancing, writhing pyre on the snow. It bellowed in rage and pain, seeming to chase its flaming tail as it zigzagged away from Hallorann. He (caretaker) thrust his (caretaker) own arm deep into the snow, killing the flames, unable to take his (caretaker) eyes from the hedge lion's death agonies for a moment. Then, gasping, he (caretaker) got to his (caretaker) feet. The arm of Durkin's parka was sooty but unburned, and that also described his (caretaker) hand. Thirty yards downhill from where he (caretaker) stood, the hedge lion had turned into a fireball. Sparks flew at the sky and were viciously snatched away by the wind. For a moment its ribs and skull were etched in orange flame and then it seemed to collapse, disintegrate, and fall into separate burning piles. -LRB-Never mind it. Get moving.-RRB-

He (caretaker) picked up the gascan and struggled over to the snowmobile. His (caretaker) consciousness seemed to be flickering in and out, offering him (caretaker) cuttings and snippets of home movies but never the whole picture. In one of these he (caretaker) was aware of yanking the snowmobile back onto its tread and then sitting on it, out of breath and incapable of moving for a few moments. In another, he (caretaker) was reattaching the gascan, which was still half-full. His (caretaker) head was thumping horribly from the gasfumes -LRB-and in reaction to his (caretaker) battle with the hedge lion, he (caretaker) supposed-RRB-, and he (caretaker) saw by the steaming hole in the snow beside him (caretaker) that he (caretaker) had vomited, but he (caretaker) was unable to remember when. The snowmobile, the engine still warm, fired immediately. He (caretaker) twisted the throttle unevenly and started forward with a series of neck-snapping jerks that made his (caretaker) head ache even more fiercely. At first the snowmobile wove drunkenly from side to side, but by half-standing to get his (caretaker) face above the windscreen and into the sharp, needling blast of the wind, he (caretaker) drove some of the stupor out of himself. He (caretaker) opened the throttle wider. -LRB-Where are the rest of the hedge animals?-RRB- He (caretaker) didn't know, but at least he (caretaker) wouldn't be caught unaware again. The Overlook loomed in front of him (caretaker), the lighted first-floor windows throwing long yellow rectangles onto the snow. The gate at the foot of the drive was locked and he (caretaker) dismounted after a wary look around, praying he (caretaker) hadn't lost his (caretaker) keys when he (caretaker) pulled his (caretaker) lighter out of his (caretaker) pocket ... no, they were there. He (caretaker) picked through them in the bright light thrown by the snowmobile headlamp. He (caretaker) found the right one and unsnapped the padlock, letting it drop into the snow. At first he (caretaker) didn't think he (caretaker) was going to be able to move the gate anyway; he (caretaker) pawed frantically at the snow surrounding it, disregarding the throbbing agony in his (caretaker) head and the fear that one of the other lions might be creeping up behind him (caretaker). He (caretaker) managed to pull it a foot and a half away from the gatepost, squeezed into the gap, and pushed. He (caretaker) got it to move another two feet, enough room for the snowmobile, and threaded it through. He (caretaker) became aware of movement ahead of him (caretaker) in the dark. The hedge animals, all of them, were clustered at the base of the Overlook's steps, guarding the way in, the way out. The lions prowled. The dog stood with its front paws on the first step. Hallorann opened the throttle wide and the snowmobile leaped forward, puffing snow up behind it. In the caretaker's apartment, Jack Torrance's head jerked around at the high, wasplike buzz of the approaching engine, and suddenly began to move laboriously toward the hallway again. The bitch wasn't important now. The bitch could wait. Now it was this dirty nigger's turn. This dirty, interfering nigger with his (nigger) nose in where it didn't belong. First him (nigger) and then his (nigger) son. He (nigger) would show them. He (nigger) would show them that ... that he (nigger) ... that he (nigger) was of managerial timber! Outside, the snowmobile rocketed along faster and faster. The hotel seemed to surge toward it. Snow flew in Hallorann's face. The headlamp's oncoming glare spotlighted the hedge shepherd's face, its blank and socketless eyes. Then it shrank away, leaving an opening. Hallorann yanked at the snowmobile's steering gear with all his (Snow) remaining strength, and it kicked around in a sharp semicircle, throwing up clouds of snow, threatening to tip over. and running up the steps. He (Snow) stumbled, fell, picked himself up. The dog was growling -- again in his (Snow) head -- close behind him (Snow). << 54 >> TONY -LRB-Danny ...-RRB- -LRB-Dannneee ...-RRB- Darkness and hallways. He (Danny) was wandering through darkness and hallways that were like those which lay within the body of the hotel but were somehow different. The silkpapered walls stretched up and up, and even when he (Danny) craned his (Danny) neck, Danny could not see the ceiling. It was lost in dimness. All the doors were locked, and they also rose up to dimness. Below the peepholes -LRB-in these giant doors they were the size of gunsights-RRB-, tiny skulls and crossbones had been bolted to each door instead of room numbers. And somewhere, Tony was calling him (Tony). -LRB-Dannneee ...-RRB- There was a pounding noise, one he (Tony) knew well, and hoarse shouts, faint with distance. He (Tony) could not make out word for word, but he (Tony) knew the text well enough by now. He (Tony) had heard it before, in dreams and awake. He (Tony) paused, a little boy not yet three years out of diapers, and tried to decide where he (Tony) was, where he (Tony) might be. There was fear, but it was a fear he (Tony) could live with. He (Tony) had been afraid every day for two months now, to a degree that ranged from dull disquiet to outright, mind-bending terror. This he (Tony) could live with. But he (Tony) wanted to know why Tony had come, why he (Tony) was making the sound of his (Tony) name in this hall that was neither a part of real things nor of the dreamland where Tony sometimes showed him (Tony) things. Why, where --

``Danny.'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Far down the giant hallway, almost as tiny as Danny himself, was a dark figure. Tony.

he (Tony) called softly to Tony.

There was sadness in Tony's voice.
``Danny,'' (Tony)
Tony said. ``Your mother is going to be badly hurt. Perhaps killed.

Mr. Hallorann, too.'' ``No!'' He (Tony) cried it out in a distant grief, a terror that seemed damped by these dreamy, dreary surroundings. Nonetheless, death images came to him (Tony): dead frog plastered to the turnpike like a grisly stamp; Daddy's broken watch lying on top of a box of junk to be thrown out; gravestones with a dead person under every one; dead jay by the telephone pole; the cold junk Mommy scraped off the plates and down the dark maw of the garbage disposal. Yet he (Tony) could not equate these simple symbols with the shifting complex reality of his (Tony) mother; she (mother) satisfied his (Tony) childish definition of eternity. She (mother) had been when he (Tony) was not. She (mother) would continue to be when he (Tony) was not again. He (Tony) could accept the possibility of his (Tony) own death, he (Tony) had dealt with that since the encounter in Room 217. But not hers. Not Daddy's. Not ever. He (Tony) began to struggle, and the darkness and the hallway began to waver. Tony's form became chimerical, indistinct. ``Don't!'' Tony called. ``Don't, Danny, don't do that!'' ``She (mother)'s not going to be dead! She (mother)'s not!'' ``Then you have to help her (mother). For the first time, Tony began to walk closer. ``You're deep down in yourself in a place where nothing comes through. We're alone here for a little while, Danny. This is an Overlook where no one can ever come. No clocks work here. None of the keys fit them and they can never be wound up. The doors have never been opened and no one has ever stayed in the rooms. But you can't stay long. Because it's coming.'' ``It ...'' Danny whispered fearfully, and as he (Tony) did so the irregular pounding noise seemed to grow closer, louder. His (Tony) terror, cool and distant a moment ago, became a more immediate thing. Now the words could be made out. Hoarse, huckstering; they were uttered in a coarse imitation of his (Tony) father's voice, but it wasn't Daddy. He (Tony) knew that now. He (Tony) knew -LRB-You brought yourself. Because you knew.-RRB- ``Oh Tony, is it my daddy?'' Danny screamed.

``Is it my daddy that's coming to get me?'' (unknown)
Tony didn't answer. But Danny didn't need an answer. He (Danny) knew. A long and nightmarish masquerade party went on here, and had gone on for years. Little by little a force had accrued, as secret and silent as interest in a bank account. Force, presence, shape, they were all only words and none of them mattered. It wore many masks, but it was all one. Now, somewhere, it was coming for him (Danny). It was hiding behind Daddy's face, it was imitating Daddy's voice, it was wearing Daddy's clothes. But it was not his (Daddy) daddy. It was not his (Daddy) daddy.

The air seemed to be shimmering around him (Danny), the blows of the mallet against the walls echoing and re-echoing. He (Danny) seemed to be bursting through some thin placental womb from sleep to *** the rug outside the Presidential Suite on the third floor; lying near him (Danny) in a bloody heap were the bodies of two men dressed in suits and narrow ties. They had been taken out by shotgun blasts and now they began to stir in front of him (Danny) and get up. He (Danny) drew in breath to scream but didn't. -LRB-!! FALSE FACES !! NOT REAL !!-RRB- They faded before his (Danny) gaze like old photographs and were gone. But below him (Danny), the faint sound of the mallet against the walls went on and on, drifting up through the elevator shaft and the stairwell. The controlling force of the Overlook, in the shape of his (Danny) father, blundering around on the first floor.

A door opened with a thin screeing sound behind him (Danny). A decayed woman in a rotten silk gown pranced out, her (woman) yellowed and splitting fingers dressed with verdigris-caked rings. Heavy-bodied wasps crawled sluggishly over her (woman) face.

it screamed, but the voice was still only in his (Danny) head. He (Danny) could still hear the thing that was wearing Jack's face down on the first floor ... and something else. The high, whining sound of an approaching motor. Danny's breath stopped in his (Danny) throat with a little gasp. Was it just another face of the hotel, another illusion? Or was it Dick? He (Dick) wanted -- wanted desperately -- to believe it was Dick, but he (Dick) didn't dare take the chance. He (Dick) retreated down the main corridor, and then took one of the offshoots, his (Dick) feet whispering on the nap of the carpet. Locked doors frowned down at him (Dick) as they had done in the dreams, the visions, only now he (Dick) was in the world of real things, where the game was played for keeps. He (Dick) turned to the right and came to a halt, his (Dick) heart thudding heavily in his (Dick) chest. Heat was blowing around his (Dick) ankles. From the registers, of course. This must have been Daddy's day to heat the west wing and -LRB-You will remember what your father forgot.-RRB- What was it? He (father) almost knew. Something that might save him (father) and Mommy? But Tony had said he (Tony) would have to do it himself. What was it? He (Tony) sank down against the wall, trying desperately to think. It was so hard ... the hotel kept trying to get into his (Tony) head ... the image of that dark and slumped form swinging the mallet from side to side, gouging the wallpaper ... sending out puffs of plaster dust.
``Help me,'' (he)
he (Tony) muttered.
``Tony, help me.'' (he)
And suddenly he (Tony) became aware that the hotel had grown deathly silent. The whining sound of the motor had stopped -LRB-must not have been real-RRB- and the sounds of the party had stopped and there was only the wind, howling and whooping endlessly. The elevator whirred into sudden life. It was coming up. And Danny knew who -- what -- was in it. He (Danny) bolted to his (Danny) feet, eyes staring wildly. Panic clutched around his (Danny) heart. Why had Tony sent him (Tony) to the third floor? He (Tony) was trapped up here. All the doors were locked. The attic! There was an attic, he (Tony) knew. He (Tony) had come up here with daddy the day he (Tony) had salted the rattraps around up there. He (Tony) hadn't allowed Danny to come up with him (Danny) because of the rats. He (Danny) was afraid Danny might be bitten. But the trapdoor which led to the attic was set into the ceiling of the last short corridor in this wing. There was a pole leaning against the wall. Daddy had pushed the trapdoor open with the pole, there had been a ratcheting whir of counterweights as the

door went up and a ladder had swung down. If he (Danny) could get up there and pull the ladder after him (Danny) ... Somewhere in the maze of corridors behind him (Danny), the elevator came to a stop. There was a metallic, rattling crash as the gate was thrown back. And then a voice -- not in his (Danny) head now but terribly real -- called out:

``Danny? Danny, come here a minute, will you? You've done something wrong and I want you to come and take your medicine like a man. Danny? Danny!'' (him)
Obedience was so strongly ingrained in him (Danny) that he (Danny) actually took two automatic steps toward the sound of that voice before stopping. His (Danny) hands curled into fists at his (Danny) sides. -LRB-Not real! False face! I know what you are! Take off your mask!-RRB-
``Danny!'' (unknown)
it roared.
``Come here, you pup! Come here and take it like a man!'' (unknown)
A loud, hollow boom as the mallet struck the wall. When the voice roared out his (Danny) name again it had changed location. It had come closer. In the world of real things, the hunt was beginning. Danny ran. Feet silent on the heavy carpet, he (Danny) ran past the closed doors, past the silk figured wallpaper, past the fire extinguisher bolted to the corner of the wall. He (Danny) hesitated, and then plunged down the final corridor. Nothing at the end but a bolted door, and nowhere left to run. But the pole was still there, still leaning against the wall where Daddy had left it. Danny snatched it up. He (Danny) craned his (Danny) neck to stare up at the trapdoor. There was a hook on the end of the pole and you had to catch it on a ring set into the trapdoor. You bad to -- There was a brand-new Yale padlock dangling from the trapdoor. The lock Jack Torrance had clipped around the hasp after laying his (Torrance) traps, just in case his (Torrance) son should take the notion into his (Torrance) head to go exploring up there someday. Locked. Terror swept him (Torrance). Behind him (Torrance) it was coming, blundering and staggering past the Presidential Suite, the mallet whistling viciously through the air. Danny backed up against the last closed door and waited for it.

<< 55 >> THAT WHICH WAS FORGOTTEN Wendy came to a little at a time, the grayness draining away, pain replacing it: her (Wendy) back, her (Wendy) leg, her (Wendy) side ... she (Wendy) didn't think she (Wendy) would be able to move. Even her (Wendy) fingers hurt, and at first she (Wendy) didn't know why. -LRB-The razor blade, that's why.-RRB- Her (Wendy) blond hair, now dank and matted, hung in her (Wendy) eyes. her (Wendy) ribs stabbed inside, making her (Wendy) groan. Now she (Wendy) saw a field of blue and white mattress, spotted with blood. Her (Wendy) blood, or maybe Jack's. << 57 >> THE EXPLOSION Hallorann could never be sure of the progression of things after that. He (Danny) remembered that the elevator had gone down and past them without stopping, and something had been inside. But he (Danny) made no attempt to try to see in through the small diamond-shaped window, because what was in there did not sound human. A

moment later there were running footsteps on the stairs. Wendy Torrance at first shrank back against him (Danny) and then began to stumble down the main corridor to the stairs as fast as she (Torrance) could.

``Danny! Danny! Oh, thank God! Thank God!'' (She)
She (Torrance) swept him (Danny) into a hug, groaning with joy as well as her (Torrance) pain. -LRB-Danny.-RRB- Danny looked at him (Danny) from his (Danny) mother's arms, and Hallorann saw how the boy had changed. His (boy) face was pale and pinched, his (boy) eyes dark and fathomless. He (boy) looked as if he (boy) had lost weight. Looking at the two of them together, Hallorann thought it was the mother who looked younger, in spite of the terrible beating she (mother) had taken. -LRB-Dick -- we have to go -- run -- the place -- it's going to-RRB- Picture of the Overlook, flames leaping out of its roof. Bricks raining down on the snow. Clang of firebells ... not that any fire truck would be able to get up here much before the end of March. Most of all what came through in Danny's thought was a sense of urgent immediacy, a feeling that it was going to happen at any time.
``All right,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said. He (Danny) began to move toward the two of them and at first it was like swimming through deep water. His (Danny) sense of balance was screwed, and the eye on the right side of his (Danny) face didn't want to focus. His (Danny) jaw was sending giant throbbing bursts of pain up to his (Danny) temple and down his (Danny) neck, and his (Danny) cheek felt as large as a cabbage. But the boy's urgency had gotten him (Danny) going, and it got a little easier.
``All right?'' (Wendy/Wendy Torrance)
Wendy asked. She (Wendy) looked from Hallorann to her (Wendy) son and back to Hallorann.
``What do you mean, all right?'' (unknown)
``We have to go,'' (Hallorann/Mrs. Hallorann)
Hallorann said.
``I'm not dressed ... my clothes...'' (Danny/Torrance/Danny Torrance)
Danny darted out of her (Hallorann) arms then and raced down the corridor. She (Hallorann) looked after him (Danny), and as he (Danny) vanished around the corner, back at Hallorann.
``What if he (God) comes back?'' (unknown)
``Your husband?'' (unknown)
``He (God)'s not Jack,'' (she)
she (Hallorann) muttered.
``Jack's dead. This place killed him (Jack). This damned place.'' (She)
